reviews.review: A bit too crowdy on weekends. This temple is impressive but it gets too crowdy on weekends. You can find a big market place just in front of him that attracts many people.
Everything from tourist shops to food. A must see temple, you can spend hours looking at the tourist shops, plenty to see and do, make sure you leave yourself enough time to see everything.

One of the more impressive temples. Grand Shinto temple covering a very large site and is said to be Tokyo's oldest temple. Magnificent architecture, very well maintained and a significant site for local worshippers. Excellent photo opportunities abound here using the smoke from the central fire area. Very crowded, but a must see attraction

Good, but hot! (あつい). It's been summer to autumn, and the weather was so hot! The temple was great, but frankly I didn't like the smell of ash. There are a pond inside the temple, many people wash their body with that water. But I saw it was not a clean water :( or, maybe I was there on the high season so mny people flooded those place.
Beautiful temple. Nice beautiful temple. A great combination to do next to nakamise shopping street. This is one of the more beautiful temples around
Nice. The complex is very nice, with a big temple and a few small shrines. It is a must see when visiting Asakusa.

Good temple and surrounding area but crowded. The temple is free to see, and is quite impressive and in very good condition. However, the adjoining pagoda was totally covered when I visited (Oct 2016) which was disappointing. The place has a calming influence, though be prepared for thousands of others pushing and shoving to get a better vantage point.
Indispensable . Even if staying just one day in Tokyo, this place has to be visited.Senso-ji is the soul history of Tokyo.Good feelings and a great ambiance!
Nice. Probably the most famous temple in Tokyo, you should find some time during your trip in Tokyo to visit it.
a victim of its own success. Unfortunately a victim of its own success! Definitely worth a visit but it's so busy we didn't stay long.
Great vibe . More than I expected ! Really enjoyed the vibe there, temple is beautiful , it's really crowded but it ads it to the vibe as I saw many geishas there!

Beautiful!. Very beautiful temple. it is big, colorful with statues and smaller buildings around. During day time you can look inside the building and see all the decorations. Closest metro stations are G19 or A18. Take some time to walk around. Pagoda was covered with building wrap in mid October 2016.

The Key Attraction In Asakusa. The Asakusa Kannon Temple of ads it is known , the Sensoji Temple is the key attraction on Asakusa which takes you back to old Tokyo and the Edo era. Once through the Hozomon Gate you will find the five story Pagoda that was reconstructed in 1973. Close by is the Nakamise shopping Street that has just about anything you might need from crackers to clothing in a myriad of small shops. If you have an interest in Japanese Yukata or kimono this is a place to look. Otherewise this is probably the best place around to see what old style Tokyo was like. Grom Ginza Station take the Asakusa line and get off at Asakusa and go to Exit 4.

Senso-Ji Temple. The Senso-Ji Temple is an impressive structure. There are, however, too many tourists, and too many vendors. It is interesting to see quite a few Japanese ladies wearing their traditional dresses coming to worship at the temple.

Magnificent temple. One of the popular temples in Japan. Lined with souvenir shops at the entrance leading up to the temple for those who need to do souvenir shopping and those who love snacks. You can even see Tokyo skytree from the grounds of the temple.
Great temple in Tokyo . Is was a beautiful place, it looked particularly striking at sunset. It looks like it was painted yesterday. There are pleasant garden surroundings too.
Cultural Heritage. Step into the old Japan, solemn shrines and temples, towering pagodas, lush gardens, quiet and peaceful time.

Every year I visit here. The most well-known temple in Tokyo, A must to visit here both day amd night timeDay time : full of people and all souvenir shops will open, you can find many japanese dessert this timeNight time: non of the shop will open but the temple at night was so beautiful and peacefull which you will never see at day time, many painting along the way, The restaurent around here will close very late night (I was there at 11pm)

Beautiful at night!. I happened to wander towards the Senso-ji temple at night during my stay in Kyoto and I'm so glad I had such great luck! I'd originally planned to go during the day but couldn't find the time so during a search for dinner one night, I happened to walk by and it was absolutely gorgeous and breathtaking (not to mention tourist free)! In a nutshell, go at night if you can :-)

Tons of shops and people. This must be the most crowded temple we've visited during our two and half weeks visit to Japan. We went there an hour before it closed hoping there would less people. The shopping street was still full of people and you really do not want to do much shopping when it's that crowded. We just went through the side street to the temple which was perfect. Less people when we came out of so we managed to browse a few shops.The temple itself was nothing special. The ground was well maintained in beautiful Japanese style.

Touristy, but still felt Sacred. Went there on a rainy weekeday afternoon. Tourists were still flocking. Could not get a decent picture with the Kaminarimon without being photo bombed. Should have went there early in the morning. Nakamise-dori had great selection of souvenirs, though I had limited time and just glanced at the merchandise. They say you have to start at Kaminarimon and walk the long road to Senso-ji Temple for good luck. Well, won't lose something if we follow. So many people made the fountain on the side a photo op, while washing hands someone will take a photo of them. Well, it is a tourist spot afterall.

Ok.... Large crowds and tons of never ending souvenir shops. Temple and shrines were beautiful, grounds were really well maintained as is the custom. The rows of never ending dollar store wares quickly becomes disenchanting and takes away from the zen.

quite crowded. Traditional Japanese shrine with a huge lantern at the entrance and old Buddhist accoutrement. Lots of buildings to see inside and more tourist stores all around outside. Bus load of tourists arriving every minute.

Good experience. A great experience. Alot of people but a visit here is totally worth it. The area before one gets to the temple is also very unique with lots of small japanese restaurants with really good food and floor sitting.

Must see in Tokyo. Great shopping in the area, as well!. Visited the temple on a Sunny Sunday afternoon. Packed with locals and tourists. Many people go here to worship at the oldest Buddhist Temple in Tokyo. Others go to experience Japanese tradition, and take in the sights and energy of the thousands of people in the area.
Beautiful Temple. Set in the old Asakusa ward, the Temple is surrounded by shops and food carts. Popular with tourists and locals.

Temple in town . Enjoyed our visit to Senso-Ji. It was packed full of people but that does provide an atmosphere which is quite unique. There are opportunities to immerse yourself in the local culture like receiving a fortune and wafting in the breath of the Gods (incense). It's a very spiritual place and beautiful architecture. Wasn't a massive fan of the huge number of stalls and shops straight after but think that is also part of the experience

One of the Oldest Temples in Tokyo. We visited Senso-ji Temple at night and we are so glad that we did. The crowds were gone and we could get close up shots of the temple structure and signs. Unfortunately, all of the shops were closed because it was after 7pm, but we still found several small restaurants and bars open. This is a must-see and should be on your list if visiting Tokyo.

A Glimpse of Japanese Culture. Senso-ji Temple is a historic landmark for both locals and tourists alike. Nice to see something so different from ones own culture. def recommend for first timers to come. better to come on weekdays and earlier to avoid crowds!
Very Nice . It is really beautiful with the natural beauty surrounding it.We also attended a tea ceremony here which was quite interesting.

Beautiful Temple. Senso-ji Temple is really a neat experience. The beautiful temple offers unique moments of reflection. Despite all the crowds, incense smells, and noises, walking up the temple steps seemed to offer a reprieve from the commotion.There is a lot of activity, and many smaller temples dotting the area. This was one of my favorite locations in Tokyo. Yes, it's crowded. But I think seeing the people interact with all the various aspects of the grounds made it more enjoyable.Take your time, look around. There are shops and street food vendors throughout. The shops sold traditional Japanese gifts.

Reflection of old Tokyo.... When we think of Tokyo, we think of tradition and city filled with temples and shrines.Senso-ji Temple is a must see and highly recommend going in the morning ; the markets open around 9am thus go around that time as it does get extremely crowded as the day goes along.There are many shops to frequent in between the beginning and the main temple ; lots of interesting and tasty treats but the main reason to visit is for the Temple and that is a very peaceful and tranquil experience.Rub the smoke on body part that aches, use the cleansing water to wash your hands and of course, pray or make a wish....its one of the highlights of Tokyo...
crawded. A big lantern in the gate is impressive.Shopping street was exciting.But full of tourists.we saw skytree from there.
cool visit. It was cool to see this piece of Japanese history after seeing it in so many movies and photo's. Great shopping here too.
Beautiful Temple in Tokyo. One of sn important landmark in Tokyo. Really great to visit here. Beautiful temple. great for shopping.

Taste of old Japan. When you visit this old Buddhist temple, you will realise how it was in japan several centuries ago. Of course you will have much more if you have time to travel away from Tokyo. But if you are a short term visitor to Tokyo, this is a must.

Big, impressive but swamped by visitors. Visit this temple and you know you really are in Japan....people everywhere (including us!). Great looking temple buildings and very large. Despite the crowds, worth visiting just to see the many Bhuddist visitors doing whatever Bhuddisty thing they were doing!
Must see Temple in Tokyo. Theres lots of temples and shrines to visit in Japan. But if in Tokyo then Senso-ji is one of the most impressive. It can get quite busy but that just adds to it.

Beuatiful Temple. This is a beautiful Temple, a must see. Allow time to explore the area around the Temple as well as it is a lovely old neighbourhood with lots of eateries and you can pick some Japanese gifts.
Nice temple!. One of the best temple in Tokyo and the mist visited in Japan. Many ladies with kimono and a nice stroll between shops.

crowded temple. A classic and crowded temple but somehow you can feel the peace when you see the local prays. Walk around the surrounding, there are some smaller altars and the environment is very peaceful. Can get souvenirs at the Nakamise shopping street.
Oh ya, you can take some pictures with Tokyo Skytree as background.

beautiful temple. This is a must see temple in Asakusa, very beautiful and big. I stumbled upon it in the evening one night and decided to check it out. The shops were closed but it was certainly enjoyable without the mass of tourists there, while in the evening. Its much more relaxing and you can enjoy exploring the temple. I also visited during the day and it was a completely different experience, VERY busy, no place to take pictures and MANY people, even on a weekday! Do yourself a favor and visit during the evening hours for a more relaxing exploration. If not, then visit on the weekday. The weekends are even more insane! On the gates of many of the shops on Nakamise Dori (Street lined shops within the temple) are beautiful artworks worth grabbing a few pictures. Many places to eat when done visiting! Check it out

Real Busy. This seems to be the temple that everyone, especially locals want to pray, go to and it gets quite packed. Seems very commercial with the temple and street stalls. Zojoji was better, I thought.

A vibrant working temple surrounded by interesting shops & eateries. We stayed at a hotel very near the temple complex in Asakusa and so we walked through the temple grounds to get to and from the subway every day. At night it is tranquil and quite safe, in the daytime it is a bustling area surrounded by commerce. As you might expect, the most touristy things are right in the market stalls leading directly to the temple, but the side streets all around are filled with interesting shops featuring everything from handmade brushes and combs to modern kimono and jinbei for men to toys, musical instruments, curtains/noren, etc. And snacks galore: mochi, waffles & ice cream, shaved ice, even when it isn't a festival day. When it is a festival day, a whole additional set of snack and eating stands opens up like at a state fair: fish and squid on sticks, frozen fruit, chocolate covered bananas, fried octopus balls, etc. The temple buildings and statues are beautiful and there are numerous nooks and crannies to explore with statues of historic figures and such. Get someone to explain the symbiotic relationship of shinto and buddhism in Japan to understand the symbols and shrines.

Mix of capitalism and tradition. After passing through the main door with it's iconic giant red lantern, you'll reach the busy street leading to the shrine lined with stalls hawking their wares. It's a good place to browse for souvenirs. The side roads leading away from the main street are dotted with restaurants and specialty shops. Try the local soba if you have the time. After braving through the crowded "business area" and reaching the main temple, you'll reach the temple itself. The architecture is impressive but unless you're a devout Buddhist, there's nothing really distinguishing it from the others. Note: try visiting either early in the morning or in the evening - the mid-day sun can get quite pretty bad at times.
Have a good feel on how the locals pray. The Senso-ji Temple is a place where many Japanese stop by to pray, and this place, to my dismay, was quite crowded.

Crowded but a must visit!. This is said to be the oldest temple in Tokyo. Tourist flocks in here for a visit so expect a crowded place. There are many souvenir shops, foods to try and just enjoy the experience being with everybody else.
It's all right but don't plan a big stay. We went there mid day and it was super hot a lot of people and not much to see. You cannot really entered the temple, so don't plan a long stay

More than a temple - this is a neighborhood. A buzzing place, colorful and noisy. Strolling around this temple with all the narrow rows of shop and eateries is a lot of fun. Don't mind the crowding - people watching is a big part of the fun.

Tokyo's Oldest Temple. This is a major tourist attraction for Japanese visitors and consequently very crowded. Unless you are trying to bag as many Buddhist temples in Japan as you can, I would skip it.
Beautiful temple. This beautiful temple is a haven from the surrounding alleys filled with stalls supplying tourists with souvenirs. It manages to swallow up the crowd and remain calm.
Beautiful. An area which is busy with tourists but very beautiful. A popular Buddhist temple where you will see ladies dressed in traditional Kimono.

Regular Good Luck received. Not a stop but rather extensive 2 or more hours venture into history and religion of Japan and Tokyo. Wonderful customs and fun people-watching. Construction doesn't truly limit access. Must see!

Beautiful. We came here pretty late so it was already dark outside and Nakaminse dori was closed. But it was so beatiful im actually glad we didnt come during daytime! The taller building to the left (the pagoda) was under construction so we didnt get to see that which was quite disappointing but we're going back next year so im guessing its fixed by then :)

Incense!. We were told that the large pots of incense are used for prayers and wishes. If you pray for intelligence, you waft the incense over your head; if you want to ease the pain in a joint, wave some in that direction; if you hope to be more beautiful, it's your face... All manner of uses, and it smells divine!Beautiful temple. Best time to visit is late evening, as quieter (cooler, in summer months!) and you can see the lit up Tokyo Sky Tree from the gates!

Beautiful shrine, cool market on the way to it. After visiting so many shrines in the last two weeks this one was just another shrine for me. However I should admit it is beautiful and there is a nice and interesting procedure of making a wish - you have to pick a stick out of the metal container and then match the writing on the stick with the one on the small woden drawers. Open the drawer, take the piece of paper out and read it. It's like the fortune cookie, but a different type.The most interesting part for me was the market on the way to the shrine. You can get some gifts for friends or taste some yummy japanese sweets. They also have those famous owl cafes around there. Pretty sad to be honest. If you're an animal lover don't go there, you'll get upset.

Senso Ji remains the top spot for a reason. I went twice to Senso Ji, first on a rainy day which stil had thousands the going around the stalls that lead to the temple and soaking up the rain and the atmosphere. Then again later on a mid week and less busy time, both times great fun for people watching and the stalls that are nearby are good. The temples are great to see and functioning, in contrast to the European cathedrals and churches which wake up on Sunday's only these are living vibrant places of worship. So one has to be respectful.It was great seeing all the kimono girls open to have their pictures taken when they weren't doing selfies. Good fun. And the rickshaw rangers in the roads nearby.I'd happily share pictures if I hadn't lost them all in a camera phone disaster. Oh the joys of travelSenso Ji - Well worth a visit

Beautiful experience. This is a really lovely place to spend an hour or so.It is very atmospheric and spiritual and an amazing site of tranquillity amidst the dynamic street life of Tokyo.There is an arcade of tourist shops which are interesting and fun as well.Definitely worth a visit.It is free, and we had breakfast at the nearby Starbucks before entering.

Nice Temple. This Buddhist temple is enormous! It has very cool paintings in the sealing, and monks walking around keeping the place clean. You can also see them praying if you are lucky enough! Outside you have loads of small street tents selling food. There is also an avenue of small amenities were you can buy all kinds of souvenir. There are people dressed in Kimonos in this part of the town. You can also rent kimonos here if you like.

Great cultural experience. Visiting the temple was an eye opening experience, but also a great learning curve. Some signs dotted around the temple have English translations, so it's a perfect opportunity to learn about Buddhist culture. We visited in the week and also on our last day (Sunday) and it was markedly busier on the latter. Therefore if you want to avoid the crowds I'd recommend perhaps going in the week. Also try the street food within the temple, freshly cooked seafood and fresh fruit juices!
beautiful. This is a must see! Very beautiful at night as well and there will be less people around so your pictures will be better.
Best temple. This is definitely my favorite temple in Tokyo. Crowded, but that is Tokyo for you. A lot of shops and eateries around the area so make sure to explore them too.
Local culture. On weekends the temple and the shops surrounding it gets incredibly busy with people, toursit and locals. And it's a very nice experience to just get lost into it.
Lots to do in the area. Shopping, the temple and a large variety of restaurants are all options for you when visiting the temple and its surrounding areas

The main temple in the city. If this is your first time in Tokyo, or in Japan, this is a must visit place. Get off at Asakusa metro station. You will find a long walking street which lead to the temple. The temple itself is not as grand as one in Kansai region though. The place is in the itinerary of almost every tour group visiting Tokyo so be prepared for large crowd.

Looks like the top tourist hot spot in Tokyo. The area is very nice with the garden and the temple, but to be honest very much crowded and completely full. I was there around 09:00 morning and it felt as half Tokyo was already there. I would recommend to go there early morning to enjoy the nice temple garden without the crowd. But still a very nice place. One more thing; a part of the area is currently under renovation as some other tourist places around Japan (Olympic games 2020!!)

Touristy but nice!. Upon arriving at the main gate you will find rickshaws tour guides. They are pricy 7000yen for 2 (half hr ride) to head towards one location within the complex. As it was large and daunting we took it up because the rickshaw left us in senso-ji and we spent 2 hrs wondering around which was a blessing as it can be confusing. Along with sovernier stores, mini restaurants, and shops, nearby there is the viewing tower and the star walk

Beautiful temple, vibrant market. I wish I could appreciate the significance of the temple a bit more, but even without knowing anything about it it is a beautiful piece of architecture surrounded by interesting shops and gardens.

Pleasant enough. Trinkets, souvenirs and snacks aplenty on the walk to this shrine. 110 yen got me an icy cold green tea, while many others indulged in other items such as those red bean things . Shrine is a biggie ! But it's the people watching that is fun here - the rent-a-kimono girls quickly find themselves hilariously laughing as tourist after tourist mistakes them for authentic Japanese (they were Filipinos!) and lines form to have photos taken with them. The L-O-N-G selfie stick lives on around these parts, and is put to good use ! Admire the small well kept gardens off to the right (as you approach the shrine gateway) juxtaposed with the tower in the background. Go here for the shrine, but see the circus around you too ...
very japanese feeling. you can really feel that you are in japan because of this very beautiful attraction, but there are lots of souvenir shops and restaurants that further imbibe Tokyo
Tranquil experience . Visited while on a university study tour on the first day of our trip. Peaceful gardens and amazing structures. A unique insight to Japanese culture

Nice temple in a very busy shopping/tourist area. This temple has many shops and restaurants around it, really good for tourists. The temple is nice looking but the area is really the attraction for me. There were many locals praying at the temple, this is really a good view of Japanese culture.

Great cultural experience!. This area is easily accessed by the Tokyo Metro.
There are lots of shops for gifts and food in all directions from the temple.
There are lots of people but everyone is friendly and polite.
There is a lot to see and lots of Japanese history dating back hundreds of years!

Night Visit better than Day for Sightseeing . great temple, more beautiful lit up at night with many less tourists. the pagoda is beautiful day or night, and during the day time you will be able to experience rituals taking place.

Amazing site but a bit of a tourist trap. One of the best things I've seen whilst in Japan. Honestly breath taking. We were disappointed that the pagoda is currently under resoration but this did not soil our visit. It's one of the few parts of Japan where there was an obvious 'market' for tourists but just take that and the crowds in your stride. There are rules not to take photos inside the temple and it was disappointing to see this being blatentally flaunted.
Best at night. . At night they light everything up and it feels really fun. Worth seeing any time though. Lots of omiyage (souvenir) choices too.

Nostalgic. If you come to Tokyo this would be one of the place to visit if you want to learn their culture. Despite the tourist packed street you can spot some who visited for religious purpose. There are three temple (1 main, 2 small by the side) that you can see & visit. And the street is packed with kiosk selling traditional & non traditional Japanese Sweets and goods. Price can vary but i'd say it's worth to try. If you don't like red bean as much as I do, i'd still say you should try. You can draw your fortune for ¥100 by the temple, or hanged your wish, burn the incense (for a price), was your hand & face in the holy fountain, and more. Just hold on to your kid during the visit. This place is packed with people and quite big.

The temple revisited. This is an old temple within the busy cityLots of tourists in the morning especially from the cruise shipsThe main attraction is to see how the local people practise their prayer rituals by washing the hands,say the prayer,and deliberately move the hands to let the smoke from the burning incense encircling the brain to enhance the thinking powerSurprising just like other Japanese shrines and temples you do not see the real stature that one worships which is hiding somewhere behind the curtainsLots of small shops along sides of the streets selling the hand made cookies made into man shaped figures,now one or two shops are fully computerized and machine made which is fun to watchThere are some isolated gardens with memorials and Buddhist figures,one of them is particularly outstanding which is gold colour with the right leg drawn up in sitting positionIt is obvious the bald head has lot of marks indicating people like to put their hands on it for good luck and blessingthis tiny stature claims it can offer relief of health problem etc.There are lots of school children in uniforms around and also Chinese handling newspaper about the local mainland news at the main entranceThere are two huge lantern at the far side of the street which is a landmark of the temple and is a major photo attractionThere is no way to take a photo with nobody at the backgroundYou can spend about a good two hours here watching the scene and the people

Old Japan contrasting with tourist shops. The best of old Japan - a magnificent temple, very traditional. Interesting to see so many young women in traditional dress. I never saw that anywhere else in the area so nice to see that tradition here. To get to the temple, you must pass through a multitude of small shops. The selection varied from touristy trinkets to more traditional Japanese items. Nice that on a hot and humid early September day, most of the little shops had fans or air conditioning which allowed us to cool off as we browsed. If you can only visit one temple while in the area, this would probably be the one.

Good to start with. I was in a hotel near the Asakusabashi metro station and the SensoJi temple area was the first to start with. It starts with a nice walk among shops selling Souvenirs til you reach the temple. You will feel the Japanese history

Impressive. It was raining on the day we visited, which meant lots of sheltering under the eaves or dodging umbrellas. Nevertheless the temple was impressive to visit - to see its ornate interior and to witness visitors participate in prayer or contemplation. A beautifully restored/maintained building; several smaller structures within the grounds too.
Many tacky tourist souvenir stall abound nearby.

Very traditional Japanese architecture. Beautiful buddhist temple, fantastic atmoshere, it is a must to visit, typical ancient Japanese architecture, nice surroundings, with garden and other buildings

The very definition of "touristy" - but still worth visiting!. The best time to walk around here would be very early in the morning or late at night. The alleys are dark and quiet (but safe; this is Japan we're talking about) and a great place to have photo-walks.During "peak hours" of between 10am to 7pm, expect a deluge of tourists and locals. It's crowded, but a good time to do souvenir shopping.

Loved the atmosphere! . Great place to visit! If you stay in central Tokyo, this is a complete different atmosphere. Very cultural. Great also for shopping. Dont eat at Dennys, very crowed and over priced.

A heaven of souvenirs. Why I gave that title to my review? Because unfortunately for me this place is better as a souvenir centre then a temple. Actually it's an old beautiful temple. And I am a huge fan of heritages. But why I don't really like this place as a temple? Because I can't find a peace ambience as a temple. People come from around the world to take pictures & buy souvenirs! Yes many visitors tried to do a simple ritual but they do it not in a silence situation. The worse situation is anyone can enter the temple to take pictures. And many of them using inappropriate costumes like hot pants. How can it happens in a temple!I usually find in other temple (South East Asia) that visitor must use appropriate costume to enter the temple. Sometimes the management borrow a sarong for visitors (like in Thai & Indonesia). I understood that this temple is in a public & open space so may be it's too hard to apply the same situations. But again, this is the temple! I am wondering do people (who really want yo pray here) bother or not by this crowd situation?Actually inside the temple there are some warning signs not to take picture. But.....the visitors never care about it (as long as I saw at that time). So sad :(.But talking about the souvenirs outside the temple.... He he he it's a heaven because we can find any kind of it and also Japanese snacks. And I love it very much :).

Exciting experience. Being one of the fan of manga comics since I was a child, seeing this typical Japanese temple is a really exciting experience.It is located in middle of of city and it can be reached through Asakusa metro station.From the metro station, you need to walk few blocks and you can see the entrance of the temple while passing by many interesting gift and food shop.The temple itself is very different.You can really feel the ambiance people praying in this place.Take some time to walk around this temple to feel it (and to take picture of course !!!).It is free of charge, so it made it more interesting.Overall it is a beautiful place to see to admire the architecture and the culture of local in doing their faith.

Temple in Asakusa . Getting there through the many markets and shops, took as a walk around to find the official entrance. But it was worth it and it's was beautifully breathtaking. Essence burning and locals and foreigners making offerings up at the main temple. There's gardens and temples surrounding it with people showing their respects and getting pictures everywhere. There's stalls around the main temple that sell talismans for everything to protection, safety, study, wish come true and more. The talismans are just as beautiful and in variety of design and use. (I got wish come true...)Highly recommended for a beautiful temple experience in Tokyo.

Back in Time. We came here during New Year when it was crowded with locals coming to pay respect to Kannon, the God/Goddess of Mercy at Sensoji, the 7th century Buddhist Temple there. The religious atmosphere was strong. Along the old, bustling Nakamise Street leading to the temple and lined with small stands, we could buy variety of Japanese souvenirs, clothing, snacks, food, etc., many of the stalls were run by families over generations. It would be nice to come very early in the morning when it's not crowded for different atmosphere and photos (Jan. a few years back).

Now and Zen. Tourists with cameras jostle as Japanese in traditional garb make their pilgrimage. Tokyo's oldest temple is a must see. Just don't expect quiet reverence. There is a lively shopping and restaurant scene surrounding it. The temple is a haven before you plunge headlong back into the action. Tip: do your souvenir shopping after the temple. Will make the visit more comfortable without juggling bags.

Lovely to walk especially early morning or at night - shame the pagoda was under maintenance!. We walked the temple grounds several times, once during the day and a couple of times at night. Walking at these two timings exude a different atmosphere. Go early morning or late evening when the crowds lessen, and avoid weekends if you can. It has a beautiful golden main pavilion showcasing its interesting blend of Buddhism, a place to draw fortunes and write hopes/prayers, a small garden grounds with a stream.

Oldest temple in Tokyo. A must see and the surrounding area is also a lot of fun. This temple is very busy but that is part of the experience. Be sure to walk around the grounds. During our visit, the pagoda is under repair but this does not impact your experience too much.

Great experience.. This is a fabulous place with beautiful eye-traffic everywhere! Not just the place but all the interesting people there to see it too. It does require a good bit of walking and I wouldn't try to go in a large group...too crowded for group-ogling. As you enter, be sure to stop at the fountain and ladle some water onto your hands...sweet and refreshing, then visit the incense fire and smoke yourself...not sure what it does but I felt better. There are many cheap souvenir huts ...kinda hilarious...other side of the world and the Cracker Barrel business model prevails! Fridge mag and shot glass, check.

A must see on your visit. This is a wonderful piece of history that you should see. Like all historic places it has a lot of tourists, but this doesn't detract from its beauty. It is still a working temple, with services being held, and you can see it holds an important place in the hearts of Japanese people as that was the majority of the tourists on the day we went.

Small Temple but worth a visit. The architecture was beautiful and throws you back to those Japanese movies set in the 17th Century. As can be expected with a place like this, it busy non stop through the day even in the middle of the night, although less crowded. Even if you don't get to enter the temple itself, the visit to the area around the temple grounds is a definite most! with very cute small shops and shopping streets where you get yourself anything from a kimono to some truly unique Japanese art.

My favorite Temple in Tokyo. This temple is full of people, incense, bright colors. We were there on a weekday afternoon. There is a fair amount of tourist trap items, but the Temple itself is beautiful.

Beautiful Temple. I visited this temple in the evening time and it was beautiful. It is always very busy with people. The big lanterns are amazing to see. There are many shops running up to the temple selling all sorts of souvenirs.

An ancient Buddhist temple. It is the oldest temple in Tokyo dedicated to Kannon (Goddess of Mercy). When you enter through Kaminarimon, you are on Nakamise-dori, a shopping street lined with Edo-styled shops selling souvenirs and snacks. If your destination is the Senso-ji, go straight to the Ji (temple). There is a huge incense burner in the open space in front of the Main Hall. On the right, you could draw a bamboo divination stick with a small donation of 100 yen. The Oracle is in Kanji and has English translation. On the left is a shop where you could purchase an Omamori (amulet). More to see and visit are the Five-storied Pagoda, 7 other halls, 2 other gates and Demboin.

Great shrine to combine shopping with shrine hopping. An easily accessible shrine. It has some great shopping streets leading up to the shrine. Great for souvenir shopping and slurping on some ice cold matcha ice tea. The shrine itself can get a bit crowded albeit it's a beautiful shrine. Worth going here if you want to combine hopping with shrine hopping.

The temple was nice, too much people. I went to asakusa in Tokyo after already being in Kyoto. The temples in Kyoto are nicer so I guess I am kind of comparing them. This was a nice place to visit. It is extremely crowded and if you are not Budhist they wont let you in the praying place. Worth the visit if you are in Tokyo

Mypiglife review . Tourist trap ,Before getting to the temple you have a long line of various type stores on both sides with what seems to be highly priced items.The desserts from stalls were mediocre.I would still recommend coming here for the experience as it is something to do !
Culture. Nice temple and nice area. Much to see and do here. It is inspiring to study Japanese culture. Hope u all take time to visit this Temple

Tokyo's "most famous" temple :). Be sure to check out the left-side grounds of the Temple (the left side as you're facing the main temple building) and see the beautiful stream with colorful fish and a little stone bridge above and where you'll also see smaller shrines adding "charm" to the temple grounds. Apart from the main temple building, the other two prominent structures there are the five-storied pagoda (seemed to be off-limits to public or maybe it was just due to renovation when I was there) on the front-left side of the temple grounds and the Asakusa Shrine (that you get to by going through a torii gate) directly to the right of the main temple building. Might also want to drink water from the dragons' mouths right in front of the main building :). Also, something that should not be overlooked is the set of displays right outside the temple gate on the left side of the way leading to the Temple: those displays portray the history of the Temple as the two brother fishermen found a statue of Buddha in the Sumida River, they put it back but the statue kept turning up and they finally decided to build a shrine for the statue, as the story goes.The Temple's adjacent to Nakamise Market which is partly under long arch-shaped roofs & partly outdoors (but no outdoor hawkers or kiosks, just like house shops fronting the streets in the market area), and it's just about a five-minute walk north from Asakusa Station (Toei Asakusa Line & Metro Ginza Line). I even walked to Ueno Park from the gateway on the west side of the Temple, taking about 45 minutes (can take the Ginza Line too to Ueno Park from the nearby Asakusa Station as mentioned above).And my suggestion if you stay not too far from the Temple (like me who stayed at Khaosan Tokyo Original just about a ten-minute walk from the Temple) is to go there again in the evening after dark, and you'll see all the main structures (the entrance gate, the main temple building & the five-storied pagoda) brightly lit up.

A must see. A must see on any visit to Tokyo. Gets very crowded from 10am on. Very scenic. Striking photos. A long pedestrian street lined with Japanese booths selling traditional foods and souvenirs connects the Sanso-ji to a second smaller shrine.

Must do in Tokyo. The senso Ji is the oldest temple in Tokyo and is a must do when visiting the city. Lots of shops line the road to the temple and it gets very busy. Visit during the day and come back at night for a different feel.
Must see. The temples here are a must see. Plenty of them, bright vibrant colours and very interesting. It can get crowded but is worth seeing.

Lovely even with lots of tourists. A don't-miss temple - enjoyable even when mobbed with tourists. Very well-maintained and a national treasure. Easy access on the train. Very walkable so don't pay for the rickshaw guys, over-priced! Walk to the river at the end and hop on the riverboat for a beautiful trip on to Roppongi or the Emporer's Palace.
Beautiful at night! . Lovely and not so crowded at night. We appreciated the cool walk after a hot day and loved our pictures. Very impressive sight.

Awesome temple in the middle of the very interesting Asakusa Neighbourhood. It is free to go in, and quite a nice temple with a lot in the surrounding area to see. It is a bit crowded given it is in the middle of Asakusa. But still, if you are in Tokyo, you need to go to Asakusa, and if you are in Asakusa, you must see this temple.
Very cool. This was a really cool place to visit with many things to see. The atmosphere is great and the people are friendly. Definitely recommend checking out.

Small but perfectly formed temple.. A very popular site for both locals and tourists. It isn't the biggest temple but it is quite pretty and there are a number of sites surrounding it that will bulk out the visit. At the time of my visit the pagoda was covered up for maintenance/cleaning, try and catch sight of the giant woven sandals near the entrance of the temple, certainly not something I expected to see at a temple!

Crowded. Nice Temple but crowded as expected
OK if visit other spots in the area but not worth if going for it alone

Amazing temple, but very, very touristy.... Senso-ji is an amazing, bustling temple, with lots to see and the possibility of taking part in burning incense, getting a fortune told, making a prayer offering etc. The building is really quite something, and there's a buzzing atmosphere in the area. My only word of caution would be that the market beforehand is geared for tourists (obviously) and so unlike many other places in Tokyo it feels very touristy. Every stall is souvenirs, things to catch the eye of those from abroad, and it was the first place in Tokyo where I felt I needed to watch my bag.My tip would be to head for the gardens just behind the temple - there's a winding path through some lovely smaller temples, over a little stone bridge with koi carp in the water below. It's an entirely different atmosphere back there, very beautiful and calm.

Sensational Sensoji. A must even if you visit for one day. Architecture and the spiritual weight of this place are inspiring. There is a lot to learn. I'd recommend a guide. Make sure you go on an empty stomach, there are lots of food stands that offer, sweets, savory pancakes, iced green tea and ice cream. It also offers a whole range of gifts. I bought sushi and pearing knives and they spent 15 minutes sharpening each. It runs in the family. Also bought some chop sticks as gifts.

Very nice touristic place. It is a very nice shrine to visit. You can try your luck at fortune as well as smell the ensence and see the lanterns and the large statues. Many gift shops around for souvenirs

Really beautiful!. This temple located in Asakusa is very beautiful and it is surrounded of some buddha statues and the street with hundred souvenir shops. We went ther during the day and the night also, and it was so quiet and nice int he night!

oldest temple in tokyo. if you wanna feel the traditional tokyo, then you have to visit asakusa. Senso-ji temple is the main attraction in the area and the oldest temple in tokyo, so you'll find it always crowded. There are a lot of souvenir shop near the temple, the price is quite high.
Nice place. Very beautiful temple that strikes one with its granduer. Also a very good shopping place for souvenirs.
Beautiful architecture. Many many overpriced food and souvenir stalls; which is to be expected. The Temple buildings are well maintained, quite impressive.

Best temple in Tokyo. Pros:- Massive temple- Huge decorations that eminate an aura of grandeur- Amazing pagoda- My personal favourite 'traditional' location- Hugely popular and brimming with life- An interesting insight into how seriously the Japanese take their religion- Area between the gate and temple is full of good souvenir shopsCons:- Check website to see if any of it is under maintenance. The pagoda is really worth seeing when it is not obstructed by building works.Advice:- When finished, wander the streets to the West of the temple - these are full of smaller streets and have that traditional 'feel' about them.
Beautiful temple. A beautiful temple near asakusa which is well worth a visit when in Tokyo and a welcome break from the bright lights and sensory overload of many other parts of Tokyo

Beautiful old temple. Great spirit of traditional Japan. Beautiful temple, surrounded by local market with traditional street food and local gifts. Be sure to visit this place both during the day as well as at night, when lights build special atmosphere.
Best photographed at night. This temple is very crowded during the daytime. I preferred taking photos at night as it was deserted apart from a few tourists.

Hidden gem. We arrived at the Senso-Ji temple towards the end of an exhausting day exploring Tokyo. We were very tired but thought we should see it as it came highly recommended in tourist guides. So glad we did!!! The narrow lane of shoos leading to the temple sold lots of touristy gifts but also some good quality goods. The you hit the temple. A really great example of a Buddhist temple hidden away in the streets of Tokyo. Great sights and people. We found a small bar close by for a beer before returning to hotel and were "adopted" by 6 locals who were desperate to try their English and try and understand my limited Japanese. Great end to a great day.
Good for a rainy day. Lots of different buildings make up this temple. There are some signs in English which is also helpful.

Tokyo's iconic temple. This temple and its surrounding area really deserves to to seen and despite it being 'touristy' its a fascinating insight in to a bygone era. The iconic lantern at the Thunder Gate entrance and the main hall shrouded in smoke from incense burning made this one of the highlights of out visit to Tokyo.Make sure you have a spare 100Y to get your fortune told - look out for the wooden boxes either side of the main hall, shake one of the canisters until a stick falls out, note the number on the stick and go to a draw with that matching number and read your fortune (they are in English too) and then tie the paper on the nearby racks.TIP : If you visit the nearby tourist information centre (Asakusa Culture Centre) head up to the top floor to the Miharashi cafe for a drink and see great views down onto the Nakamise-dori street and Thunder Gate (Kaminari-mon).

Big temple and surrounding area is great for souvenirs. Really enjoyed this temple with the family and we got a lot of souvenirs and snacks in the surrounding area. very cultural place and you can get little nick nacks that the kids can bring home for friends as gifts. Really cool place.
Beautiful Temple.. This has to be one of the top things I really wanted to see in tokyo! Just so beautiful and lively. Amazing!
A Must see. the symbol of the neighborhood. Perhaps the most striking point of the ancient Tokyo. Beautiful walk along with people dressed in yukata.
Beautiful Temple. This is a great way to start your Japan adventure! The temple is beautiful and has many shops around it.
beatyful palace. unfortunately was closed when i arrived there . but eventhough that its was closed i enjoyed the small park behind the temple and the market where you can buy a lot of souvenirs

A must see!. With Meiji-Jingu, Senso-ji is one of the two temple you should visit. The whole area surrounding it very lively; a great place to find any sort of souvenirs, or varying quality. Entering the temple is actually not the most interesting; seeing it from far is quite a sight! I suggest coming after dark, when most tourists have left. The temple and adjacent pagodas are beautifully lighten up, great pictures to be taken!

Great Temples in the Centre of Asakusa. Great Temple and Pagoda ensemble in the historical centre of Asakusa. In direct Proximity to the next Park and vivid tourist quarter, this is a great place to stroll around and have some lunch on a bench or to take your time and wander through the temples and gardens...
Magnificent Temple. Went here today to see the temple and the structure and the building is splendid. It was surrounded by a gate and a few other structures but the main building is the beauty of it.
Beautiful temple . I enjoyed walking around by the temple every day while I was staying in Asakusa. Very lively with people during the day and peaceful at night.
Street Fun galore . If you like old temples little shops and fun food, then this is the place when you have just a day in Tokyo! You can even take a ride on a rickshaw! Great time!

Beautiful sight, but area is extremely overcrowded. The temple is beautiful, but the area is way too overcrowded! The pagoda was under construction during my visit so I didn't the opportunity to see it. Near the Asakusa line.

Religion and money making all rolled in one. It was a fun enough experience despite the title. But seriously as with all religion, the opportunity to make money is never far away. It is a lovely looking temple and the grounds were pretty. But the highlight is the souvenirs and food. You just have to look at the crowd and know what most are there for. The temple is a side issue here. Looks to shop for and tasty little mosels of food waiting to be snapped up for consumption.I must admit that is what I loved as well.Do take the time walk the grounds and admire the lovely gardens and buildings. It does get a little difficult to better appreciate the insides of the temple because the fenced off. But still it's beautiful on the insides.follow the crowds when you arrive at the train station and you will eventually find your way there.

A Tokyo Experience. The Senso-ji Temple combines both the religious and commercial sides of Tokyo that one should experience. The temple is a great place to come and see worshippers at the shrine. There is a large incense cauldron that people believe the smoke from it improves your health and well being. You might want to let some smoke get on you. Then right near the temple is an arcade street full of shoppers and everything is here for your shopping pleasure. It is a sight to see in Tokyo.

Most interesting place we have visited so far near Tokyo. We visited the Sensoji (Asakusa Kannon Temple) and surrounding area. This is a popular tourist spot with easy access via Tsukuba Express train. Besides the temple buildings and temple grounds, which are very picturesque, there a tons of merchant stands to buy just about anything you can think of, and tons of small food stands with lots of options for food and drink. It was very hot, so we stopped for drinks (and shade) often. We felt this was a safe place to wander around, and the vendors were very polite and helpful.

Too touristic, lost the sense of religious place. Granted, the temple is a beautiful piece of art and statues, colours and carvings are amazing, but all the mess around the temple turned an holy place in a flat, commercial and low level bazar. Only few shops offers real quality items and most of them are not on the main path to the temple.

If you don't go to Kyoto don't miss this. Senso Ji Temple is an experience and combines the tacky Tokyo tourist shops with an amazing Buddhist temple. It's easy to get to from the train station via the Ginza line to Asakusa exit 1. The temple itself is beautiful and the surrounding gardens offer great photo opps and a little escape from the heat with one covered area with cool water spraying. We went when it was very crowded and would of loved to see it early morning or at night lit up (my opinion that night is the most amazing experience at any temple or shrine). If you are going to Kyoto, then this isn't a must see at all as Kyoto has the most beautiful shrines and temples in my opinion.

Incredible experience at this Buddhist SensoJi Temple in Tokyo near Asakusa station. From the train station, there is a nice walk along Nakamise Street. As we approached the main entrance at the Kaminarimon Gate, there is an large imposing red Lantern with statues of the Shinto gods Fūjin and Raijin. Fūjin is the the god of wind and Raijin, is the god of thunder. These statues look to be about 10 ft. tall and protected by screens to keep tourists and birds away from the statues.Inside there are many small buildings but the most impressive is the huge pagoda and the main temple with another red lantern at the entrance.

It's a beautiful temple but overcrowded. If you only have time to visit one temple in Tokyo....please make sure you visit this temple. It's crowded but worth visiting it. It's beautiful and you will find this temple unique. Come hungry and taste some snacks before or after visiting the temple.

A beautiful sight. I went to Senso-ji twice when I was in Japan. Once at night and once in the daytime. I definitely recommend going for a walk to see it at night - it's absolutely gorgeous! Just don't get your fortune until its daytime else it's bad luck.
Senso-Ji Temple. it's an active temple at the area, locals still come to pray here. On your way to the temple you'll find shops for tourist souvenir
First and best temple in Tokyo. Even my kids were impressed - they liked the fortune telling, rubbing smoke in their hair, chanting monks, impressive gates.

Fascinating, crowded, beautiful!. You first pass the red Kaminarimon Gate which is the entrance to the Senso-Ji Buddhist temple and take tons of pictures. Then through the gate to a long crowded pedestrian avenue lined by small stores that sell everything from tourist stuff to very traditional Japanese stuff like peels of radish that the seller is peeling in front of you. We were lucky to be there when a movie was been shot so we saw a traditional Buddhist wedding procession going through the crowd with a carriage filled with musicians in traditional garb. You then proceed through another tall red gate, and get to the spot where you can shake tablets in a container, get a blessing, go to a small drawer to get the printed blessing that you keep or tie to strings in the temple. Then you move incense smoke from a large cauldron towards places in your body that are sick or painful.... then wash your hands with a bamboo laddle and climb the few stairs to view the central hall of the temple. Very dark with gold highlights, lots of people looking and some praying. Very interesting!

A must-see!. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. It is extremely beautiful and worth seeing. It is also near the Japan's oldest historic shopping district which is also a must-see. Try the tradition Japanese sweet bean buns. They make them right in front of you!

famous temple in asakusa. Located close by the Tokyo Skytree. There are shops lining up along the alley that leads to the temple. A famous temple in Asakusa area frequented by tourists and locals alike.
Japan experience. An amazing temple as well as a touristic area. For me it was a great experience to go to this temple. I really felt I was in Japan!

Crowded but beautiful . It's pretty crowded due to the fact it's really beautiful..
Apart the spirituality you could experience also a tour in the market.. Nice place..

Very crowded temple. The day we visited Senso-Ji Temple was one of the hottest of the summer and the temple was so crowded. It honestly made for a not so pleasant experience. Coming out of the subway and walking down the tourist shop lane that leads to the temple was a bad sign. A temple to me should be peaceful and should not be so inundated with commercial shops selling cheap tourist souvenirs. Anyway, we braved our way through the crowds to the temple itself. The temple is nice, nothing spectacular though and its cramped. There is so little space around it. There are many ways to make wishes which is interesting to see and experience. However those can be experienced in other temples and shrines.I would recommend any traveler to go to the Meiji Shrine instead of this temple. The Meiji Shrine is Shinto while Senso-Ji is Buddhist so they represent different parts of the culture. But the Meiji Shrine is beautiful and peaceful, with stunning tall trees providing ample shade for a hot summer stroll. We did not really walk around in the streets outside of the temple. I did read there are some interesting artisanal shops in the area. I don't know if we missed anything worthwhile.

Busy but beautifoul. Busy by day, wonderfully illuminated and quiet in the evening. Go twice, as daytime will let you marvel at the intricate designs and details of the interior while the night will give you a glimps of the mystic old times.
Touristical magnet. Even if the place is over-touristic, it's worth a visit because the place is very nice and you experience locals praying.

Asakusa Kannon. This is Tokyo's most sacred and spectacular temple. The first shrine was built in 645 and expanded over time and the temple survived the big 1923 earthquake, but not the bombing of WWII so much structures were built in the late 50's but to former designs.

Roaming around. A lot of tourists during summer season. Many stores of different merchandise including food. If you like visiting temples, Sensoji Temple should be in your list for Tokyo trip. Must try the ready-made ningyo yaki of red bean pastes. Best served hot.

Touristy and crowded, but still a must see in Tokyo.. We happend to visit on a festival day, on a Sunday. So it was jam packed with people. But it was the first full day of our trip so we were ready for it and took in some awesome people watching. Lot's of cool little junk shops on the way in. I imagine it's less busy early in the morning. We arrived around 10am. We saw many more temples on our trip and this one definitely had things that made it unique, particularly the giant lanterns. I would have loved to see it at night too, but we didn't go back.One thing that was disappointing is that the 5 story pagoda is hidden behind a scaffold for renovations right now, so we didn't get to see it at all. It would probably enrich the experience greatly to visit with an English speaking guide who can explain the customs and history behind some of the customs, charms, buildings, etc. We ended up educating ourselves about it pretty well once back at our hotel using the internet.

Morning serenity in one of largest metropolitan . This temple is island of serenity I visited on Saturday early morning around 6:30 AM to experience the peace. Later in day this place is bustling with visitors and tourist alike.The voices of cicada shrilling sound made the atmosphere even more reverberations from nature voices.I think early morning is best time to visit shrine.Peace......

great place. Well, if you like a huge number of people, lots of junk souvenir stalls, fast food stalls, and marooned in the middle of it all a Buddhist temple...then this is for you. On a hot summer day, it felt super exposed to the sun and the garden offered little relief from the oppressive humidity. The temple itself readily accessible to visitors apart from a few ceremonial rooms, but neither the architecture nor decor struck me as especially noteworthy.

Lovely sight. I passed through this temple 2 times a day and I will miss it . Very impressive and nice. Take some time to walk around and find out all the other small Jinja's. Go see it early morning and at night. Lovely

Beautiful. Really nice temple - good for souvenir shopping too as there is a large market at the front.
Very crowded however but we did visit in summer.

Not great....touristy, tacky. Well, if you like a huge number of people, lots of junky souvenir stalls, fast food stalls, and marooned in the middle of it all a Buddhist temple...then this is for you. On a hot summer day, it felt super exposed to the sun and the garden offered little relief from the oppressive humidity. The temple itself readily accessible to visitors apart from a few ceremonial rooms, but neither the architecture nor decor struck me as especially noteworthy. This is one place that frankly I would skip...and the "old Tokyo style" surrounding neighborhood of Asakusa was not especially interesting to me either. It all just felt tacky and crowded.

Must See But Avoid Crowds. Due to my jet leg, I visited Senso-ji Temple before 6:00 am. It was so early that when I arrived, the monks were still in their morning chants. The temple had a peacefulness about it unlike the many pictures and videos taken and published that are packed with people. It was quite an unique feeling to have the grounds pretty much to yourself. I understand many like to visit it during dusk and at night as well.Of course, the many shops and stalls of Nakamise Dori were not opened that early. So one must return with the crowds to experience and taste that part of Asakusa.People were hurrying pass the Temple on their morning commute. To them, it was just another work day. But I was thrilled to walk through the Karinarimon Gate and see the giant sandals of the god. I came half way around the world to visit. Whether you go early, late or peak crowded hours, don't skip Sensoji and the Asakusa neighborhood. In the distance you can see the Tokyo Skytree. With the old and the new - side by side.
Great temple. The first temple I visited and Japan. Very nice and with lots of restaurants around to take a break from walking around Tokyo.

Great show of people. We went there in the afternoon of the Saturday with the biggest annual fireworks show in Tokyo, and this explains the huge loads of people around.The temple itself is very beautiful and well-preserved. There are many shops around, for food, clothes or souvenirs, as Asakusa is well known for this lively atmosphere. So those who dislike being flooded around, don't go!Anyway, being such a festive day, there were thousands and thousands of people dressed in yukata (not kimono!), mostly Japanese but also foreigners. Amazing view, i can't remember anything similar outside Japan. I would say I enjoyed more the people show than the temple and the fireworks.

Beautiful!. Situated in the busy junction near a city and metro station, its not hard to find this beautiful land mark as the crimson tower stood out majestically.Lots of street vendors, stores located conventionally outside of the temple. Selling all kinds of stuff from food to souvenirs. We went there both during the day and night, at night it was peaceful, quiet.But during the day, the place is packed with energy, tourist everywhere and it is difficult to navigate around without getting lost.

Magnificent Temple. Post war constructed but still a marvel to see. Very impressive to walk towards the temple along Nakamise Dori, Take lots of pictures because this is the best example of an ancient temple you will see in Tokyo. Lots to see in the temple area as well such a buddahs, ponds, and several places to buy lucky charms.

busy. This is a beautiful place!but its a tourest destination so there is going to be alot of people.erm the store some of them felt kinda hmm i donno , i felt like a tourest trap.you know when you find the real japanese goods.check the stores more than the market street as they tend to hmm not have offical items.i dident get anything as i had a panic attack due to the croud.but yes i recomend this place to travalers to japan.its a place you cant ignore when visiting.

Very cool, just like the photos. It looks just like the photos you see, there's a lot of people, and the Asakusa neighborhood is fun to walk through with food stalls (the maple pastries are yummy!) and shops (visit the umbrella shop, they only sell umbrellas).

Very beautiful but too crowded. I would say the temple is more crowded during the weekends, specially Sundays, but it is also crowded during the week anyway. You can see the temple, walk around the market and eat traditional japanese food.

On of the MUST-VISIT place. The place is quite close to station. During the walk to sensoji, you'll pass the famous Kaminarimon gate. And while you walk towards Sensoji, you'll find yourself surround by a lot of people shopping for souvenirs on the left and right. You could also pick your fortune telling paper here, at sensoji Temple
Some Restoration. Don't want to reiterate anything below, but tall tower is is completely canvassed for some construction work. Not sure when completion date is.

Beautiful temple!. Visited Senso-ji Temple on my own and found it was a very beautiful place to go and see. Was very busy and the market next to it was very good with lots of shops which sell everything you could want. Would definitely recommend a visit here, was one of the highlights of my trip to Tokyo!

Nice temple near a busy shopping street. Along the walk to the temple, you will find many many interesting small shops... the prices are reasonable but some may charge more.. Look out for signs... Most of the shops are selling similar items but they are all very nice.

Fantastic Edo period architecture . *FREE* entry into one of the best places of worships I have visited. The interior and exterior of the temple is marvellous to look at. Don't forget to have your fortune told by shaking the stick out of the bucket and matching into to the symbol on one of the draws. Typically a donation of ¥100 is advised when having this done.

Very very busy, and some under restoration.. It's a must see place, but this time of year was crazy busy. You couldn't move or really feel any atmosphere of the temple. The shopping stalls were great, but again far too busy to enjoy (think peak hour Tokyo subway type of busy). I would avoid unless the temple has religious significance for you.

An explosion of colour, bling and crowds. The most famous Buddhist temple here; elaborately and richly decorated with paintings, and housing an ornate sanctum-sanctorum. Nakamise Street leads to the temple and is a great place to buy souvenirs.

Major temple. This is a special temple not to be missed. It is on the Hop on bus route but also easily reached by taxi or subway. The temple has some adjacent smaller temples. Through the arch out front the walk is lined by shops selling religious items. Plus the nearby streets are worth a stroll with restaurants and shops. On Sunday there were families coming to the temple in kimonos which was nice to see.

Discover the Amazing Japanese Tradition. There're a lot of temples in Japan, and they all have its own unique designs and structures. Senso-ji Temple is one of the famous tourist spot in Tokyo and it's also a must visit one! It's very convenient from the subway station of Asakusa about 3 mins walk. Before you reach the Temple you'll pass by some souvenir and snack shops and you'll can find some good thing. It will take you around 1-2 hours to discover the place, and it definitely worth the time!

Temple you must see, but do not forget to walk around Asakusa. Senso-ji is a must visit, but make sure to be there before 5pm or you might miss best of it since shops on Nakamise (road to temple) close from around 5. That is best place to buy souvenirs in Tokyo! but try some finger foods there as well, these are odango, ricecrackers-osembei, castera, ningyoyaki, shaved ice and mush more. Temple itself offers experience any tourist will enjoy. There are few spots you can take fantastic pictures of temple with Sky Tree.....past & future. Enjoy!
Touristy area but worth it. Very crowded but you know why when yu are there. I doubt there's anything like it in other parts of the world.

Big and busy. The temple is a much fun outside of opening hours of the adjacent market. If you do not NEED to go inside, you might want to just walk around its impressive main temple. While incredibly tourisitic, the market is very worth it, there's all sorts of fake and authentic products to find, ranging from a few dollars to serious cash.(buy some tenugui) and the temple grounds are worth a stop for a quick pic and some good luck wishing.

Temple in the labyrinth of shoping alleys. Although the giant red lantern hinging from the temple gateway is visible from a distance, one has to negotiate the maze of small kiosks selling souvenirs and other stuff on the way to the temple proper. The two giants of stone on the main gate guarding the temple look fierce. The five-story pagoda, resplendent in the dark, is bound to please the visitor. The main goddess is locked inside a room, and is out of bounds for visitors. But one can pay obeisance and pay a donation outside. The buildings are beautiful and well maintained. I was slightly disheartened to learn that they were built in 1958 only after the original Senso-ji was raised to the ground by WW-II bombing. The main gate is where the action is. It is swarming with foreigners and also locals. Rickshaw pullers will take you for a ride across Asakusa area from here. Food stalls (McDonald, KFC, Japanese Sushi) are all to be found in the alleys in the temple area.

Very impressive. Very nice, big and beautiful temple where still are able to coexist all the tourists with the locals.The most fun, get your destiny told by the holy wooden sticks..go find out yours! ;9

Big nice temple, lots of tourists. We visited a few temples during our visit in Tokyo and this one was the one with the most tourists and the most souvenir shops, but it was a very nice temple, even on a rainy day.

Most significant. It is Tokyo's oldestv temple located in a central part of old town Tokyo. Ancient Buddhist architecture. Very popular therefore very crowded. Truly colorful, distinguished by the outer gate that is a popular photo spot.

Amazing temple for beautiful photos!. Visiting Sensoji Temple which is the oldest one in Tokyo is a must! It's a unique experience being in this Buddhist temple with the beautiful architecture, peaceful yet fervent chanting of the monks inside, and the flurry of people - mostly tourists who want to join in as observers of the rituals. It's a bit smoky with the incense in one area (warning for those with asthma), then another section for purification with water (wash your hands then some for your mouth to spit after), so you definitely won't run out of interesting things to do and/or photograph. I went during early afternoon in the summer and all the photos were just picture perfect ! Just stay hydrated and it's definitely a destination to mark on your trip to Japan!

Beautiful temple . Was staying in Yokohama for a conference so a perfect chance to take a break and explore nearby cities. It took an hour to go to Asakusa by train but was totally worth it since the Senso temple was simply gorgeous. As expected there were loads of people. But if you have a morning free this place is not to be missed.

Great Japanese atmosphere!. I always visit here whenever I travel to Tokyo. Such a great Japanese atmosphere with the temple and Japanese ladies clad in kimono/yukata. If you go on weekend mornings, you can really feel the vibrancy. Don't forget to buy some Japanese snacks here to bring back as souvenirs!

Gorgeous Temple. The temple is very easy to find from the train station. There are some great souvenir shops all around. The whole site is very impressive and beautiful. During the day there's a greater chance that the main temple is open, so visit before sun down. Expect large crowds, during vacation times and holidays expect very very large crowds.

One of Oldest Landmarks is Tokyo. Dragged my jet lagged self there before any of the shops leading up to it opened so I could see the Temple before the crowds converged on it. Beautiful. If you like the shops, stay to see them... there are lots of them on the walk up to the primary temple... there are additional structures nearby... the one I wanted to see (the 5 story pagoda) was getting a face lift.

Beautiful! A must visit temple in Tokyo!. The temple was beautiful, particularly during the Sakura season, but be prepared for the huge crowd. The shopping street leading to the temple was fun and interesting. The temple was definitely worth visiting.

Photographers delight in Sundays. We went to the temple area twice: devoid of crowds in the evening, wandering through the quaint market streets, and being amazed how many bikes are used in Tokyo. And again on a Sunday morning, when the place was crawling with people and food stalls. The many flower shops proved a perfect photo scene for a bit of street photography!
A big temple. I don't really get the tourist obsession with visiting temples. This large temple is surrounded by stalls (handy), has public toilets and fortune sticks/boxes. It is busy.

Beautiful Temple. Came here with the family for a look around as we styed in an AirBnB nearby.The temple is amazing, not too big, and not to small. And it being a temple completely free. Make sure you try the cleansing ritual as you enter into the temple grounds. When in Japan you may as well follow the local customs. You can get into the inner shrine, but you will have to take your shoes off. It was a little crowded when we were there, but if you go in the evenings them the crowds lessen quite considerably. Loads of shops and stall attached to the temple to have a look around as well.
Beautiful temple. We really enjoyed our visit here, gorgeous old temple, great souvenir shopping nearby and easy walk from station.
Gorgeous temple!. One of the temples that you should go to. Very beautiful and you can make wishes. Lots of tourists and shops but worth the visit.

Absolutely Magical During Services. It's an interesting place to visit. There are all sorts of fortune telling and good luck things to do... light incense, drink and anoint oneself with holy water, light candles, etc. The whole grounds is worth a look. The Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate), the gardens... But the best thing is to visit during a service. They do chanting along with taiko drumming and use a PA system to amplify the sound. It was really exciting, tremendous energy. I'd go so far as to say magical. Definitely worth a visit. (Also, just down the walkway next to the main temple is a place to get Melon Bread and fabulous soft serve ice cream in all kinds of unusual flavors.)

Point zero for the spiritual side of Tokyo. This is the nexus for all things Tokyo shinto-esque. Full of tourists (minus 1star) and already crammed with photographers. Yes, it's iconic as every tourist brochure and every 1st time visitor must go here to pay homage to his/her intstagram altar. It's nice, photogenic, ticks all the right boxes. However, the sheer amount of tourists jostling for space detracts the solemnity and serenity of Sensoji.
Beautiful temple.. Colorful temple. Great shopping street. Really clean.Go early. Everything close in the evening. Enjoy the place take your time in the temple.

One of the must see temples in Tokyo. It was raining and foggy early in the morning and we scrapped our plans to visit the Tokyo Metropolitan Building because of poor visibility. Instead we took the subway to Asakusa. Arriving at Asakusa we walked towards Senso-ji Temple which is very close to the subway station. After leaving Exit 1 of Asakusa subway station you can see the Kaminarimon gate which leads to the very busy Nakamise dori which has small shops on both sides of the streets selling from souvenirs to food. We slowly made our way to the main temple entrance.The temple area was very crowded. It was cool to see a lot of locals visiting wearing traditional japanese dresses.

Good way to spend an hour . A very nice temple in the heart of asakusa. The surrounding area has plenty of market stalls and shops to visit. The temple is a major tourist attraction and with that, expect very large crowds and tour groups getting in the way of your photos! Interesting to see locals still using this as a place of worship!

Full of tourists but good visit. This Buddhist temple was quite huge and very visually stunning. My only gripe was that there were far too many tourists for you to really enjoy but I guess that has become the norm for Asakusa. You would expect a temple to be a quiet, serene place but with the crowds, the vibe is actually quite lively and energetic. There was much activity going on in the place.
Beautiful and Landmark Japan. I love this Here temple very nice place to visit Beautiful and Classic japan, But people so much around can Shopping and Food very good.

Nice Temple. The most crowded place that I have ever been. Packed with a lot of tourists & tips:not suitable to drag luggages around as I did. Like the temple because of its bright red wooden structures. :)
Sensoji temple. This is one of the best temples I have ever seen and looks very colourful during the day and night. This is must for all the travellers to Tokyo

Full day . Spent the entire day around the temple. The area is packed with tourists but if you take some side streets 1 or 2 blocks you'll find it a lot less crowded and well worth it. Bought 2 beautiful jackets for $10 each at a small kimono shop that was selling samples. The only con is when you first arrive from the subway you're barraged with tour guides asking you if you want a tour. Be sure to go on an empty stomach plenty of food to sample along the way

crowded but worth the stop.... One of the more popular temples in Tokyo. Located in Asakusa district which in itself is worth a half day visit. Temple is nice however it is too crowded and might ruin the experience. Avoid the tourist trap street before it and just enjoy your time within the temple grounds which is huge. Peaceful at times even with the crowd.

Very busy! Great shops along the route.. Visited on a rainy day and was very busy which added to the atmosphere as lots going on. Didn't stay long with the rain but loved the shops on the route from the train station, very touristy but fun.

Beautiful, but crowded!. The experience of this ancient temple was a little dampened by the number of people present on the grounds! Still, a good example of traditional architecture. Avoid weekends and holidays!

Nice Place to Visit !!!. Very nice place to visit and explore...You can learn the history of Japan and their culture...You can browse the surrounding area and full with market and the most important sushi...If you want to buy cheap Japan's souvenir, this is the correct place compare to others...but you shall visit the market during daytime (prefer morning)...

Pretty fun!. A busy place with alot of tourists. I have some tips on visiting this place, make sure you dont rush wondering around because this place is huge. Alot of things to buy with the little stores around the temple. The green tea ice cream is recommended.

Decent. nice temple. Nice temple to visit, but I can't say it's one of my favs. There are better ones in Kansai region and China. But still worth a visit as it's just down Nakamise, and you can get loads of amulets here.

Walking distance from hotel. The Temple is well worth a visit if you are in the vicinity. The last time I was here, I did not get to see inside as it was evening, but this time I was able to see how beautiful it was; ;the massive doors have gold metal plates on them and are unique. Also, within the grounds is a waterfall and, for a place like Tokyo, there is plenty of space to move and walk around.
Nothing has changed in 15 years. Good place to visit and buy some junk at the little "Tourist Traps" lining the walkway to the Temple

The shops on the way to the Temple is more fun !. We don't know much about history of this Temple. We still had a lot of fun being there. We enjoyed more the shops on the way to the Temple than the Temple itself. There are so many shops and every one has it's own speciality although a lot of them have sticky rice balls.
