We later found the prices here is pretty much same as other places(tourist and non-tourist). Don't miss this place if you are in Tokyo.

Visit while at Asakusa. It's my mum first visit to a Japanese Temple, it's really fun for her while explaining the way the pray.It's usually quite crowded even during rainy day. The shrine is quite quiet although it's crowded.
Exciting!. Visited there with my family at the end of the year. the weather was so good. Took so many photo there, and tried green tea ice cream which sold near the temple, it was so delicious

Beautifull complex. Very big and beautifull complex of temples and shrines in northern Tokyo. With our luck the 5 tiered pagode was covered in scaffolding. But the other sides made it more than worth while.

Worth a visit . This temple is definitely worth a trip (even if it is under construction...) however it is quite average in comparison to other temples around Japan. Its still a great spot to see so if you have time still go and make your own opinions.

Great old temple and vibrant independent shopping. A stone's throw from the akasuka subway station one enters through a large gate which frames enormous globes for candles at night. After one enters the gate dodging the picture takers theater is as long line of shops leading up to three shrine offering Japanese food, delicacies, candies, desserts, and a very wide range of souvenirs and local goods at much better prices than the big department stores. Note: there after many other stores on the streets in all directions from there central roadway to the shrine. In addition there are many restaurants at multiple price levels. Once one gets to three shrine there is another enormous lantern and a will preserved shrine supposedly the oldest in the area. It is well built and impressive. Prayers can be said for you and souvenirs purchased. Around the main shrine there is a secondary shrines which is not add impressive as well as tent shops. This is well worth the visit both for the shrine and the shopping.
Must see. Senso-ji is a very popular temple. A must see when in Tokyo. There are many shops along side the road as you walk towards the temple. Very beautiful.

Buddhist Temple and Market Experience.. Another cultural Japanese site that has large tourist appeal. Also seems to incorporate a market. Apparently, the original structure was burned down during WWII and was recreated in the 60s. The area was a little busy and hectic, otherwise, a good experience.

Beautiful . The temple was close to our hotel so we wondered through the grounds daily and at different times. You are able to have your fortune told by putting ¥100 in the boxes and then shaking the canisters to find your number to them match with the drawers where your fortune is on a sheet of paper.There are many shops leading to the temple where you can get all sorts of souvenirs. The incense around the temple were strong so be warned if you are sensitive to smoke.

Beautiful Temple and surrounding area!. Senso-ji is beautiful - make time to take part in rituals such as lighting incense and you will have a connection with the temple. The shopping leading up to the temple and restaurants and shops on side street are all great to stroll along and browse but the ground surrounding the temple are where you want to spend your time.

Nice temple, but not essential viewing if you're travelling for a long time.. Beware of shrine and temple overdose if you're travelling for a long period in Japan; each individual shrine may be nice but they do blend into one another if you seen too many in short succession. If you're just visiting Tokyo though, or want an introduction to traditional Japanese culture, check out Sennoji with a free tour guide from the tourist centre. It's a nice temple with an attractive surrounding area with lots to do. It will be crowded though.

A must-go when you are in Tokyo. A very beautiful temple and lots local street food are here when we visited here. It is also allowed you to pay for Japan traditional costume rental. We went here in the evening and those shops are almost ready to close. Shall come here earlier so you can spend a long day at here.

Go at night, it's not crowded. I got to Tokyo late at night, and my teacher brought us here to give us a quick tour. This place is impressive, and at night he traffic is lite enough that you can walk around without feeling crammed. There are lots of places to eat and drink at night as well, so sightseeing and sake is a easy combination.

Beautiful temple (but crowded). Tokyo's oldest temple and one of the most significant! Worth seeing, it's beautiful, though very crowded with tourists (as to be expected). It's free of charge, and close to Asakusa subway station. Don't forget to check out the Asakusa Shrine (when facing the temple, it's to the right). Lots of souvenir shops lining the streets and you will spot women in kimono attending the temple.The feel of "worship" is not there because of the abundance of tourists.Tip: if you're up for walking, walk to Ueno and walk along the kitchenware street (there you will see plastic food stores that only sells plastic food). Go to Tourist Information Centre right across Asakusa Subway Station for walking directions.Enjoy!
Beautiful temple. A very spiritual place for Japanese people. It is nice to see all the young people coming in traditional clothing to worship and pay respects.

Crowded always, but great place!. If you are in Tokyo, a must to at least stop by for a few hours for photo taking. But beware as it is always crowded! Was there during weekday morning and almost all Nakamise Shopping Street food queues were already very long!

It's to worth your time if you've visited other temples in Kyoto.. If this is your first and only trip to Japan, then by all means, go to Senso-ji. It is fairly close to the subway station and along the way there are a lot of souvenir shops to browse. The temple itself is not impressive to say the least, and it is hard to get a good picture since you will be rubbing shoulders with 5,000 of your best friends (all foreign tourists). I really don't think local Japanese go to Sensoji to pray anymore.

Very nice architectural temple. It was the main purpose for us to visit Asakusa to take a look of the temple. It is huge in size and very well maintained. The architecture of the temple is very nice that you feel very comfortable to be there. We went on the weekday and there were a few hundreds of visitor but not crowd and noisy. Recommend you to visit if you are in Tokyo. The metro station is very nearby the temple for about 10 minutes walk.

Too touristy. Go if you wanna cross one of the main sightseeing places off your list but be aware there will be way too many tourists bumping into you. Not really a tranquil and relaxing place like one would expect form a temple. Still interesting to see and compare to temples from other Asian countries.
A must visit for those in the vicinity . A good place to visit when your in town. There are many small shop buzzing around the temple which offers reasonable priced food, snacks and gifts.
Number One Spot To see in Tokyo . I saw the Sensoji Temple on my first day in Tokyo. This is a great place to get souvenirs as the Nakamise Shopping Street is located at the main entrance.

Good place for tourist to hang around. Was there one week and managed to experience the Chinese Lantern Plant Fair at the temple. Apparently the lantern plants are not for eating, but just for decoration, as lucky charms. A local lady told me that she brought home 2 pieces of it, put them at home, then will have to bring back and return them to the temple, then buy new ones again.  Also, should walk in to the temple for a pray, and try out for the fortune-telling paper strips to see for your luck!

Best place to buy souvenir and lots of restaurants in the area.. We went at Senso Ji Temple last June. It was crowded but manageable. Best place to buy souvenir. Got mine at 300¥. Tried Green Tea Macha and Black Sesame ice cream. Lots of restaurant in the area. Very near in Asakusa Station.

Favourite place in Tokyo. Came here during the new year. The temple was bustling - a great place to come and visit, with little market stalls and food stalls abound. Cannot miss this place when visiting Tokyo!

Удачное дополнение к Асакусе / A good addition to Asakusa [RUS&ENG]. Заглянув на Асакусу, проходить мимо Сенсо-джи не стоит. Красивый, впечатляющий храм, принимающий множество посетителей, не оставит вас равнодушными. Можно понюхать благовония, зажечь там ароматические палочки, загадать желание (далеко не одним способом). Также это прекрасная возможность полюбоваться на японцев в национальных одеждах, а с некоторыми даже сфотографироваться. С некоторых мест виднеется центр Токио, создавая весьма интересный контраст традиционной и современной Японии. Оживленное место с ярко выраженным духом страны восходящего Солнца оставит приятные впечатления. __________Visiting Asakusa, you shouldn't miss the Senso-ji temple. It's a beautiful, impressive temple, welcoming many tourists daily, and it won't leave you disappointed. You can smell incense and light up some aroma sticks, make a wish (with more than one way). It is also a good opportunity to adore the Japanese in their national clothes, perhaps even take pictures with some. From certain spots you can see the Tokyo city center, and it creates an interesting contrast with traditional and modern Japan. A lively place with a bright spirit of the land of the rising sun will only leave good impressions.

Highly recommend visiting during day AND night!. We fortunately stayed in Asakusa so getting to the temple was an easy walk. I highly recommend visiting both during the day and at night. One significant advantage to visiting at night is there was hardly anyone there.

Very beautiful but over crowded. This temple is a must see in Tokyo. No more conments about it. It has several budhist statues in the Shrine and the landscaping is amazing. The Tori is just impressive.
The down side is that they have kind a market on the way in and it gets over crowded.
Youmust visit it.

Shouldn't be missed!. This was our first temple of our trip. Loved it! Has a bunch of cute shops on the way to the temple. Small garden off the left. And an Inari shrine to the right. We went the first day of the Sanja Matsuri to see the parade and opening ceremonies. The parade had geisha and other official looking people in it. Lots of food stalls as well. We had shaved ice and takoyaki!

Truly magnificent. An amazing place to visit - but beware of the thousands of tourists! All of the buildings were just glorious. The hundreds of little stalls surrounding the temples were actually a little off putting, but I must admit that some had some pretty cool little souvenirs and trinkets.
Very crowded, but definitely worth it . Came here in the afternoon and it was still extremely busy. Great opportunity for fortune telling. It's right next to Asakusa station and a must see of Tokyo.
Touristy. The shrine was big and pretty cool to look at but there wasn't much to see. To many tourists in the way. But if you're visiting Asakusa you should see it anyway while you're there.

packed with tourists!. The mass number of tourists on a hot and humid day lessened the enjoyment of visiting this ancient temple. Best to go early in the morning. For 100 yen, enjoy a nice cold green tea (matcha)..slightly sweeten.
worth the trip. Awesome place to take pictures, a real tourist trap with cosplay girls walking around in traditional Japanese clothes to enhance the temple experience!

Stunning Temple at the Heart of Asakusa. An absolute must visit. The oldest Buddhist temple in Tokyo, easily accessible by Asakusa toei subway line.Main entrance gate, long shopping street and then the temple itself. There is also a garden area off to the left.Very impressive buildings with huge lanterns the feel of old Japan. You can have your fortune told outside the temple and light some incense.

The Oldest Temple in Tokyo. There were many souvenir shops on both sides of the main passage to the temple. When I went to buy a particular Japanese fan (a kind of folding out one), my friend explained to me that Sensoji was the oldest temple in Tokyo. It’s a very big temple, but I was very surprised to hear that ‘kan’non-sama’ (the goddess of mercy) in the temple was only 5.5cm tall!
Magnificent. If you are only going to Tokyo , this is the temple to see.Can be very crowded on holidays. Has an interesting street of tourist tat leading up to it (aimed at Japanese visitors mostly)

Temple and garden, No English. Once you are able to cross the tourist shopping streets you get to a lovley temple area and garden. Not english friendly at all.
When I got there It was super crowded (week-end)

Better than many other temples in Tokyo. What's wonderful about this temple is that you can get up close and personal. Plus it's in the middle of a bustling traditional market area, meaning many still use the temple for daily prayers.
Loved the temple architecture. Running the gauntlet to the temple was interesting. Fun to try some foods and explore the shops. Temple and grounds were pretty and clean.

Really crowded. We went to several temples in Tokyo but this was the most crowded with tourists. Plus side is that there were Lots of shops if you want shopping. And the river cruises started from there. But if you are looking for a peaceful spiritual place...this is not it.

Senso-ji Temple. Beautiful at night. Can see light from Tokyo Sky Tree Tower.
Day time a bit crowded as many went there for prayers and many tourist around
Oldest Temple. We went twice to this temple and both days it was busy, be prepared for crowds. Lovely grounds to wander in, lots of touristy souvenirs and food stalls close by.
Nice Temple . ...Nice temple close to our hotel. Our kids loved the possibility to make a wish at the temple. Worth a visit if you are in Asakusa.

Temples..... I am a bit bias as I am not a big fan of visiting places of worship as to me it means nothing. I go more for the architecture and the area. So for me it was just another temple. The area is nice and has a beautiful park near by. It does also have a nice souvenir street leading to the temple which is great for gifts and to have a look. I would say go for that. I would say visit it on your way to the sky tree of something else near by as it isn't a whole day activity

Rickshaw ride EBISUYA Asakusa. Rickshaw ride was the best bit of the visit. EBISUYA Asakusa - is the name of the firm of rides catch them in the main road in front of the temple gate (with the big red lantern). Ask for Take or Shun. Their English is very good. They are funny and charming. Ride for at least 30 mins to get the benefit of the tour.

Amazing Temple. I only had 2 days in Tokyo and I am so glad I made this a priority to visit. This was the first traditional temple I visited. What a great and truly inspiring experience. Make sure to read your fortune and place incense. Tours are available. There are also very unique gift shops inside the temple overing a range of traditional items such as charms etc.
Popular. Very popular tourist spot as it is so easy to get to. Structures and the surrounding gardens were impressive. The amount of touristy souvenirs was overwhelming though, seemed commercialized.
A must see. Like being in a Studio Ghibli film! Great temple and grounds, shops in the run up are a rip off however Best visited at night with no crowds and very atmospheric when lit up.

too busy. no way would I recommend this location to any one else if you value your calmness and sanity. Too many tourists pushing and cutting in lines in the shops in front of the shrine here. Spend your time somewhere else of your gonna go crazy. We didnt even walk back up the row of shops to exit. found a back way instead. Too crazy here.
Still worth visiting again:). I just like coming here...seeing the temple, the swirl of incense smoke, the hordes of tourists, the many stores...

Giant Lanterns are the Rule. I am not Buddhist and did not partake in the rituals of the temple but it did not keep me from appreciating the beautiful architecture and scenery. It is a very photogenic structure and worth a visit! There is a nice garden area directly next to it with some coy fish.

Wonderful complex but look out for the touists. First time I've been in the company of so many Anglo Saxons for days. Temple complex is beautiful and plenty of locals here too, many in traditional dress.

Worth visiting if you are in the area. I visited recently on a trip to Tokyo and found the temple to be very pretty. The pagoda was being restored so it was not possible to see this building, but other buildings were open. The venue was a bit crowded (we visited in the afternoon) but not to the point where it was difficult to navigate.

Beautiful temple, very crowded. This temple is large and beautiful. There is a long row of vendors leading up to the temple that is also fun to browse - be sure to grab some Imagawayaki (little cakes with sweet red bean paste inside) there for a snack, and watch them make it first. The temple is crowded, but beautifully preserved, and plenty of people are there to pray and make wishes by tossing their coins. We also enjoyed the Omikuji (fortune telling) that you could enjoy just outside the temple. After paying, you shake a little box, and a stick comes out, telling you a number, and then you find the drawer with the corresponding number, which tells you your fortune. We loved our experience here.

Very nice temple and so busy.. Sensoji Temple is also known as Asakusa Kannon Temple. It is a Buddhist temple located in the Asakusa area of Tokyo. It is one of Tokyo's most colorful and popular temples. It was very busy when we were there and the walk down to the temple was very interesting with many stalls lining both sides of the roads selling a wide range of souvenirs, food and nick nacks. The temple itself is very impressive and its easy to wander round for an hour or so looking at all the various parts of the temple, with many photo opportunities. Well worth spending a morning taking in this site and its surrounding area which also has many Japanese restaurants, ideal for a quick lunch.

Great walk around the temple. Since it's one the most famous places to visit in Tokyo, there are almost nothing left to say. Except that I feel walking around the temple's area is quite fun and full (yummy). Lots of famous dessert are here along with some nice souvenir shops. Since the temple is located in the old area, in front of the temple, there's even a century old tempura shop.

A Lot Going On. I visited on a Saturday and it was super crowded, but had a great time going to all the vendors that line the street leading to the temple. The temple itself is huge and beautiful, well-maintained and well-loved. People from all over can be seen praying and tossing coins and making wishes. It helps to do a little reading for background before you get there so you know what you are looking at.

Absolutely beautiful!. It's interesting to see this large, strikingly beautiful temple sandwiched in between modern buildings. It's a great example of how Japan is progressive, yet honors its history.

One of my favourite temples despite the crowds. It was very very busy when we visited but it added to the experience. The walk down past all the stalls was fun even though is was so congested. I loved all the statues, the huge bell, and all the side buildings as well as the main temple of course. We spent ages taking lots and lots of photos including plenty of all the women dressed in their beautiful kimonos.
a must see. Definitely a national treasure, glad that they preserved the place. Lots of visitors all day. It houses the huge lanterns at Kaminari (Thunder) Gate which is very famous throughout Japan.

Crowed visit. Excellent temple from 7 century, the oldest in Tokyo, renovated in 1952. A must see in Tokyo. You shall need 2h. including transport as it is in Asakusa, a bid out of central Tokyo. We were at the entrance at around 9am. on Sunday at it was already pretty crowed. When we came out around 1h. later, it was impossible to walk across the souvenirs street prior the main entrance of the temple. Have a look to those shops, you will certainly find something to bring back home at a very competitive prices.. No need to follow main street, go to the paralel street, less crowed and interesting things to find as well. It is a pity we could not see the pagoda, under renovation.

Beautiful. Please remember go visit the temple in the evening. It was a beautiful, quiet park around it.I have experienced the "praying ceremony" in the early morning and it was a peaceful moment for me. I enjoyed this surprise and loved it.

Beautiful, even in the rain.. It was raining the day we went, but that meant that there wasn't a big crowed. Unfortunately, the main gate (the Thunder gate) was under repair, so we didn't get to see it. Other than that, a great place to visit.

Start your day early!. Situated in asakusa. Just next to train station. Packed on weekends as early as 8am! You will see locals in kimonos and its a lovely sight! You will walk down the namikase street full of souvenior shops and alot of eateries in between the alleys. Everything about this area is lovely!

A visit to the temple plus everything else around it. The temple itself is very nice - lots of history and beautiful ceremony.What I enjoyed was more than just the temple though - there is HEAPS off shopping nearby as you approach the temple. LOTS of photo opportunities and interesting shops and restaurants nearby. You can spend an entire day here very easily.

Nice temple. I'm not really a big fan of temple, but this place was nice to visit. This was my first visit to any temple in Japan. Different culture, traditions.. it's good to know. Overall must visit if you are in Tokyo.

Attractive temple. Very nice temple with lots of architectural features. On the day we visited we saw lots of young girls in kimonos. We were told that that's a common practice at this temple. Pretty grounds surrounding the temple. Much nicer (imho) than the Meiji Shrine, although they are both quite different. Lots of small shops along Nakamise street leading up to the temple.

Pure history, pure culture.. Although this is a popular tourist destination, this does not detract from the fact that this Buddhist temple is the oldest in Tokyo, and a wonderful sight to see. The grounds include lovely gardens, koi ponds, a five storied pagoda and the adjacent Asakusa Shrine. The 200 meter Nakamise shopping street leading from the outer gate to the second gate has a history of several centuries.

A Must-Visit in Asakusa!. Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa is known as Japan's oldest temple and is an amazing place to visit. There are large crowds during the days and weekends, and an even more massive crowd during Sanja Matsuri in May of each year. The beautiful grounds include other temples and shrines. The Nakamise shopping street and Dempoin Street are must-visits too! Food, clothes, souvenirs, jewelry, gifts can all be found here!

Same same. After Kyoto and many other shrines and temples around Japan, this was just another impressive building. Pagoda under preservation. The place was good to see, but not stand out, and just too busy with tourists.

Nice temple and lots of interesting shops just outside the temple gates. My wife and I visited this temple as one stop on a Hop on Hop off bus tour we took during our stay in Toyko. The temple was crowded because we were there on a weekend day and they had a special procession. The Asakusa Sagimai Parade has girls dressed like large egrets or storks and other people in costumes and a small "float" with musicians pulled by several men. Guess we just got lucky because it was quite interesting.
Whatever the season, Senso-ji is Majestic!. I have been to Senso-ji in every season and the view is unique each time. A must see if you are visiting Tokyo area.

Tokyo Must See. This was one of my top destination must see's for Tokyo. Sadly, it was absolutely pouring with rain when we were there. That produced a mass of umbrella clad tourists jockeying for that photo with the V / peace sign!!! This is a truly magnificent ancient temple. At the entrance, just off the street, is the very grand Thunder Gate (Kaminarimon). This houses one of the main tour book Tokyo sights, the huge red and black paper lantern. This apparently signifies thunderclouds and lightning. Once through the gate and beyond the sea of umbrella's was Nakamise-dori, a corridor of covered stalls selling crafts and food. At the other end is the Treasure House Gate (Hozomon) and the entrance to main temple. To the left is a stunning five level pagoda. The rain diluted our experience but it was still a sight to behold.
Shinto Shrines co-exist with Buddhist temples.. This shrine is next door to the Asakusa Buddhist temple. It draws fewer tourists but many Japanese were visiting and prayring every time I went there.
One of the most beautiful in Tokyo. This is One of the most beautiful temples in Tokyo. It is well preserved and it is good place to visit.

Nice place to go. Too many tourists were there , the must go temple to visit. Everyone who was in Tokyo have to go as the symbol of Tokyo. Great for taking photo.Got lots of shops for shopping and eating around.You can walk around and take many pictures at the temple. I think the price of goods at the shops around was a bit too expensive coz it's in the tourists area.
Great temple. Very easy to get to by metro. Lots of stores leading up to the temple itself. Great cultural site. Very busy when we went. Not sure if it would be better earlier.

Tokyo Highlight!. We are on a day long tour and stopped at the Senso-ji Temple. The temple is the oldest in Tokyo and presents a very good example of the architecture of its day. There is shopping with numerous stalls lined up the roads leading to the temple. Very nice.
Very Crowds-but must visit place. the place very crowd with tourist and local japanese devotees. by the way is worth to visit since u came to tokyo

Pretty at night, bustling during the day. I first visited this temple at night and it was so pretty to see all the buildings lit up. I went back again during the day and it was full of people and there was a wonderful street leading up to the main temple that had many souvenir shops and street food shops. It was great to have a look at and walk around. Bought some nice dolls there and enjoyed the ice cream burger.

Tokyo's most sacred and spectacular temple!. It is easy to get here. You can just take the metro to Asakusa. The first structure you will see is the big Kaminarimon gate or thunder gate with the guardian statues. Then you walk through Nakamise -dori which is a pedestrian alley where you can get dolls, kimonos, hair combs, fans, etc. (most are not of the best quality and are mainly made to satisfy the tourist desire to get a Japanese souvenir). Then you go through the impressive Hozomon gate and you will find the incense burner where you should smoke the fumes to have good health. In front of it, you will see the main hall where you can see the kannon and many unique paintings of "angels" with lotto flowers. You have to see the hexagonal temple which is the oldest structure and only survivor of the original complex, the pagoda with the garden, and the awashima hall dedicated to a deity that protects women. Do not forget to touch the Nada Botokhesan Buddha as you will have good luck!The temple is relatively new when compared with many other temples in Japan as the original complex was destroyed during the second world war. The new complex resembles the original architecture and style. It is very big and nice.The entrance is free.The temple is impressive. The daily rituals make the visit to the temple special.

Too Crowded!. Sensoji Temple is really, really big. The main temple itself is quite large, with lots of space for worshippers. There are various areas where one can participate in temple rituals – be sure to bring some coins as an offering as well as to buy incense and candles. The temple stamp stand is to the left of the temple. It costs 500¥ for the nicer stamp design, which I did opt for. There are also a lot of smaller worship areas dedicated to different smaller gods all around the temple as well as a pagoda. Definitely go either very early in the morning or the evening!

A must see in Tokyo!. You will walk past Nakamise Dori during your time here. Senso-ji is listed on almost all the prominent tourist websites & guides (for good reason). It's beautiful & a heck of a location for your travel selfies. I didn't step inside the temple due to the daunting crowds but I did walk around the area a fair bit. There are hidden gems in every lane near this temple & you could easily spend 2-3 hours here. Make sure to try the melon bread while you're here & the yummy mochi. This area can get rather crowded (at certain times) but while just loitering around - a part of you will simply love just how quaint & laid-back this whole area feels. I found a fantastic Sento called Jakotsuyu near the Senso-ji temple & was glad I chose to stay in Asakusa... !

One of the best temples. How to get here:Therr are several lines connecting to asakusa but the nearest is the ginza line which is just a 5 min walk from the temple.What to see; Especial novelty shops.. best to buy souvenirs. There are a lof of food establishment that offers authentic japanese food. Sushi restaurants to be exact. The dood ranges for the sushi and maki is around 125 yen to 500. Ramen is aroind 7t0 to 900 yen.Over all this place is nice for tourist. You can experience japan and buy a lot of souvenirs blwhen you go to this place. If you also look at the infrastructure it has this old japan feel and look.

See it by day AND by night!. we stayed in a hotel next to the temple so we had chances to see it in the early morning when the people just start to come in, during the day when there are LOTS of people, and at night when it was empty but lit and BEAUTIFUL.
Mornings and evenings are magical. We were staying nearby and walked through here every morning and every evening. Lovely and relaxed. Locals walking with dogs and on their way to work. So peaceful.

Good vibes . This is a good place where you do get positive vibes
Neighbour hood gives feeling of old Tokyo
History is interesting and dates back to 6th century
Crazy Busy. This traditional temple was brilliant to see and was crazy busy.. It felt like an authentic experience.

Impressive but too busy to truly enjoy. From Shinjuku we caught the Yanamote line to Ueno and transferred to the metro rail on the Ginza line to get to Asakusa. It was a Sunday afternoon and extremely busy. You could not see in front of you for people. It was interesting to see the incense burning and people waving it around themselves. It felt like I shouldn't have been at this shrine as it was not peaceful. Very busy and very noisy. I would have liked to have visited when there were less people so I could truly experience it.But its worth visiting. As a bonus you get to go through Nakamise shopping street before you get to the Temple.
Free and lots of culture . Go midweek and not Sat, as its busy. Great place to visit, the temples and burial sites are amazing and the water garden is lovely. Make a wish and maybe it will come true!

Don't miss it. A spectacular complex of temple buildings and associated smaller shrines. Enter by way of Kaminarimon (thunder gate) and stroll down the shopping street; it's full of souvenir and Japanese snack shops, as well as visitors and school groups. There are some good shopping and restaurant choices in the surrounding streets, too.

Our first visit to a Temple in Japan. We were to see many Temples during our visit to Japan and this was our first. It was very busy with people but everyone is polite with no pushing! Because all the culture was new to us we were fascinated by what we saw people doing. There was incense burning and visitors were wafting the smoke towards them and their children - for good health apparently. All the buildings are beautiful - such a contrast to the high rise buildings in Tokyo.

Great temple. The temple was massive and had lots of tourists, and there is so much to enjoy about it. The temple had many fun rituals to do ( lighting candles, buying shrines, pulling fortunes,etc. ). I loved the fact how it could be so crowded and busy, yet serene and quiet. The visit toke me about 1 and a half hours.

Busy!. We've seen a lot of temples and it was crowded here but hey we're in Tokyo, you just learn to share the space. It was good to take part in the rituals, lighting smoking incense sticks, and waving the smoke over your head, taking part in stick fortunes...and reading your fortune.

Scenic temple for first day visit. We went to Tokyo and used trains to get from Shinjuku to the Sensoji temple. Very picturesque and walkable. You walk through an aisle of food vendors to get there. The delicious smell as you start walking are these waffle like delicacies filled with red bean paste - sweet, warm, and delicious! The photo shows the mini waffles that are in many creative shapes including chickens and beehives. Be careful not to eat while you walk though- it's uncouth. There's an eating area to the right of the temple where you can sit and eat, with bathrooms behind.
beautiful. I'd recommend going at night to avoid the crowds, the temple is lit up and very peaceful and stunning

Must See in Tokyo. If you are visiting Tokyo, Sensoji Temple is a must see. It is one of the largest if not the largest of its kind. The road leading up to the temple is also made up of merchant stalls selling everything from food/snacks to all types of gifts.

Cultural Attraction in Tokyo. The most famous attraction in Tokyo for both Japanese and foreign tourists. In front of the temple, there is a walking street which sells Japanese souvenir, food and desserts. You can see people wear tradition costume, called Kimono and Yukata, and come to this temple.

Beautiful at Night. This temple complex was a 2 minute walk from our hotel. The best part was being able to walk there of an evening after dinner when it is lit up and all the tourists gone. Early mornings we would see a few older locals walking up for their morning prayers. Tourists need to remember this is not just a tourist attraction to some it is still their local temple...

THE temple. Arguably the most famous temple in all of Japan, Senso-Ji is a wonderfully kept and fantastic temple in the heart of Asakusa.The street leading up to the Temple is full of souvenir stalls and street food, and are worth the time to stop and explore. The Temple grounds are huge, with a large shrine, giant gate, and lovely gardens. The temple grounds remain fairly busy throughout the day, so I would recommend coming early in the morning to make the most of photo opportunities (I particularly liked the 5-storey pagoda). If you walk through the garden, you will find yourself in the older area of Asakusa, with a lot of authentic restaurants and experiences to be had! If you only see one temple in Japan, make it this one!

A Must-see for foreigners. An ancient Japanese Temple with a reasonable size that is a big attraction for foreigners and not only.The area where the Temple is located is a famous area for tourists due to several attractions, so this is definitely a spot that cannot be missed
Obligatory point to visit on 'trip to Tokyo' list. Nice place to rest with beautifull area that you can wonder around, shop and eat well. Highly recommended!

Wonderful cultural experience. The oldest temple in Tokyo, although much of it has been reconstructed following a fire. It is still a must-see. You can visit the market outside which are packed with souvenirs and tourists. Great photo opportunities. Buy a fortune paper inside, they have english on the back if required.

Don't Just Take Pictures :). It is worth visiting and meditating there in the mist of all chaos.I don't like the minimum 100 words TripAdvisor's policy, which forces me to say unnessary things. In fact I have said it all in the title!

The oldest Budhist temple in Japan. In the middle of the city, there is this beautiful Sensoji Temple with so many history. People come to pray and admiring the temple at the same time. The beautiful garden surrounding the temple is another part of the temple to be admired as well.If you are I Tokyo, you must visit this temple. While walking thru this temple I could only imagine what it had seen thru out the centuries.

Must see. Sensoji temple in Asakusa, Tokyo is one of the main temples, so should be visited. A long street lined with stall holders offering souvenirs, food takes you up to the temple. Great spot for photos.
satisfied. Nice temple. Can buy several good japanese things. we had lunch at that time near the temple. good place.

1st time in Tokyo . Great area to visit if you just want to get a feel for Tokyo. Lots of knick knack shopping and food. Tried sticky rice balls on a stick which wasn't my cup of tea. Temple was free and worth seeing.
Window to some culture. . A window to the Japanese culture. Paid my respect and also did the Omikuji! A must visit if you're in the area.

Beautiful but no English explanations. The temple is very impressive and beautiful but, as is often the case In Tokyo, it is hard to find more than the occasional plaque explaining what you're looking at. Don't forget to draw your fortune, and try to visit the place with Japanese friends or a guide!
Stunning tranquil peaceful. One of d oldest temples.. Beautiful.. Peaceful.. But only problem is lots of crowd.. Esp d Chinese crowd. Otherwise architecture is nice. Worth a visit

Interesting. Thankfully, I had a guide with me to explain what I was seeing. (Michiko Muranaka, Triple Lights Tours) Temples themselves aren't as interesting to me as the people at the temple and what they were doing. Again, would be meaningless without a guide, or at least an English guidebook, as there is not much explaination in other languages around.Such AWESOME shopping around the temple.

The oldest Buddhist Temple in the region. A wonderful example of a traditional temple complete with giant lantern in the Asakusa cultural area of the city. Always busy and especially popular with well dressed and behaved school groups as well as visitors and tourists
Great experience . Great place to visit definitely recommend to anybody visiting the Tokyo area. Was located in a very cool, tourist friendly area
Serenity!. Beautiful. We came here 4 times as very close to our hotel. Very pretty at night. Loved this whole area as very quaint.

Beautiful, historical, spiritual. . We made it a point to come here many times during our stay. The first day of our stay we were still clueless and a little jet lagged but even then you are still able to appreciate how gorgeous this temple is. The timelessness of the building contrasted with the hustle and bustle of the people is incredible to see. We came back our second day with a lovely tour guide named Rena from Kanji House (which I highly recommend you make a reservation for if you will be in this area). She took time to explain the history and story behind the temple and the surrounding area and it really have is a deeper appreciation for what we had see. I strongly encourage everyone who visits Tokyo to visit and experience this wonderful place.

Interesting Sensoji Shrine. Put in your bucket list! Interesting temple with unique design. There is place to fortune your future, wash your hand or face to bring you fortune. Also you can throw coins to give respects. After that visit Nakamise street which full of souvenir, antiques, foods and of course ice creams!

One of Tokyo Great Temple. You could find many great temple in Kyoto, but not in Tokyo. This is one of a must visit temple in Tokyo if you are a culture or history lover. You would love to see the interaction of many different people in market nearby the temple.

Go early or late to avoid the Tourist Crush..Be amazed by the size and beauty of Temple complex.... You have to visit Sensoji sooner or later on your Tokyo trip. This is the oldest and one of the busiest temples in Tokyo. But the crowds are brutal. To avoid the Chinese/Japanese tourists, go early (opens 6a) or late (7p). And you'll be rewarded with the tranquility you hope for. However, lots of touristy stalls selling Gee-gaws, but you can shop to you drop. Enjoy!

Busy, busy, busy. This is definately a tourist area and is very saturated with people. its a very beautiful temple with a lot to see and appreciate. its a must see attraction, but just be prepared for the crowds.

Tourist trap peddling junk. Tourist trap peddling junk, don't even bother, a waste of the 15 minutes I spent there. I walked through only because I was nearby. The temple is shabby and decaying, the grounds are some of the least beautiful I have seen in Japan, and the place is overrun by selfie-taking tourists.

Many Shop and Culinary. So many shop from the gate until the shrine. But they all closed at 7 PM. So must come earlier if want to shopping. The price is cheap enough to buy. They also can receive payment with card if you didn't bring enough cash money. So mang shop sell traditional food like okonomiyaki and takoyaki. Must try the real okonomiyaki and the taco for takoyaki is really big.

Amazing Temple. Visit during evenings. This place is bustling with tourists from all over. very serene environment. Felt like temples of India. One of the cheapest places to pick up souvenirs for Japan visit.
beautiful temple . i recommend visiting this temple at night. less people and beautiful lighting for taking pictures but beware many of the shops close early

Amazing temple which is a must if visiting Tokyo. This temple is probably one of the best we saw when doing some travelling in the Far East. As other reviews say, it is very very busy but because of how amazing the temple is it didn't necessarily detract from our enjoyment. The architecture is amazing and the grounds the temple occupies are fairly large so the crowd disperses slightly. Lots of excellent photo opportunities and also the market leading to the temple from the subway stop is worth passing through. Definitely a worthwhile journey on the subway.

Go at night!. While we went to Asakusa over a holiday weekend, it's best to see the Senso-ji Temple at night, when it is less crowded, and you can see the Temple area all lit up, and experience more of a tranquil environment.During the day, it was more of a tourist area, with street vendors, geisha women, and everyone taking pictures.A definite must see if you're visiting Asakusa!

Our Second Tour Stop in Tokyo - Impressive!. The Senso-Ji Temple was a great place to immerse ourselves in Japanese custom and history. With our tour guide's direction we cleansed our hands at the water fount and hopefully obtained divine assistance at the incense fire. I followed directions and coaxed the fragrant smoke all over, as I need any kind of help I can get. We toured the main temple, the protecting thunder gate and the very crowded Nakamise shopping street. Many people in traditional kimonos along with the international tourists. As crowded as it was, the people were aware and respectful of others and we moved about without much trouble. At the end of Nakamise St. We found a 7-Eleven with an ATM that allowed us to use our debit cards with favorable exchange rates and fees. Rumi-san our guide explained that the people wearing masks were sick or suffering allergies and didn't want anything to spread - I always thought that they didn't want to catch something. If you're on a tour, you won't have sufficient time to explore and site see so study up in advance to figure out what you'll not want to miss.

Must see. As you approach the temple area you find a couple of roads of touristy shops along with a few food shops, there very touristy but hey we're tourists and my wife had instructions from all 4 grand daughters that they wanted Hello Kitty keyrings and typical Japanese ones for their school bags, these we easily found here. It was pretty crowded here but manageable and it didn't detract from visiting the Temple, we did note if you go around the back of the main temple its a lot quieter with a few empty seats along with a rather impressive statue, which I note when you search for images in Google it never comes up. I've included a picture of the statue along with a group of dating couples that I asked to take their picture along with to very beautiful girls all in traditional dress. I hope they will not be embarrassed being included on Tripadvisor.

An absolute must see in Tokyo. I would highly recommend a visit to Senso-Ji when visiting Japan/Tokyo. It does tend to get quite busy given it being a popular attraction, but this doesn't take away the fact that this place has the most unique "vibe" about it. Even in the hustle and bustle there is something really tranquil about the temple and surrounding areas. On the strip leading up to the temple, there are various stalls selling souvenirs and Japanese street food. Once you get up to the temple, on the left is a stunning Japanese garden with Koi Carp in the river and Buddha shrines. I would definitely visit again if I get the chance!

Crowded. Maybe it was a special occasion, maybe it was because it was weekend, but it was extremely crowded. I guess there were ceremonies going on, with people in short kimonos and there underwear showing were participating but also drinking a lot.

Worth a stop by if you're in the neighbourhood. More than any temple, I really felt like I was misappropriating Buddhist culture by being here, being part of the tourist horde. It just feels like they've taken something beautiful and meaningful, and turned it into just another Eiffel Tower or Statue of Liberty.My complaint isn't of the temple itself. It's not the monks' fault it became a must-see attraction. Well, I assume it's not... I guess they need funding for the work they do, so who knows!! This is especially driven home by the huge shopping street next door, which doesn't get any more commercial.....

Fantastic atmosphere. Yes it's another temple and yes it's crowded; but it's a great experience. What makes this temple really unique is the long Nakamise shopping street leading up to the temple. There's the usual souvenir shops but hidden among them are little gems - like the shop small rice flour cakes in many shapes with bean paste filling & a long waiting line at another shop to buy Fuwafuwa (frozen fruit shaved into slivers and served in a cup). Take your time to discover these treasures and you're sure to have a great outing!

Our favorite part of our visit to Tokyo.. Senso-ji and the surrounding area were the best part of our spring break trip to Tokyo. It has culture, shopping, and food all wrapped into one. The shopping street is a little touristy- but we were tourists and it was nice to be able to have some reasonably priced souvenir options where we could pay with a credit card. And, don't neglect all the little side streets off the main Nakamise shopping street, either- we bought some of our favorite items in these little shops. The temple is lovely at night- we timed our visit so we could visit the temple in daylight, do some shopping and eating, then visit the temple again after nightfall- it really was wonderful- like right out of a movie. We ended up with amazing photos. The Asakusa area is very much 'old Japan' feeling. It definitely has it's own unique charm. Not to be missed.
Needs visiting. One of the most beautiful temples in Tokyo. Impressive building. Attractive surroundings. Lots of tourist shops around. Also a view on the recently build Tokyo sky Tree.

VERY Crowded and Touristy, but still worthwhile. Sensoji (浅草寺, Sensōji, also known as Asakusa Kannon Temple) is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa. Sensoji Temple is a few steps from Asakusa Station, served by the Ginza Subway Line, Asakusa Subway Line and Tobu Railways. it is ALWAYS crowded and very touristy. Usually lots of school kids here so expect it to be noisy and somewhat frantic.When approaching the temple, you usually enter through the Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate), the outer gate of Sensoji Temple and the symbol of Asakusa and the entire city of Tokyo. However, the gate is currently (as of May 2016) completely enclosed in a box for what appears to be a renovation. A long shopping street consisting of tightly packed stalls and small stores, called Nakamise, leads from the outer gate to the temple's second gate, the Hozomon. Typical Japanese souvenirs such as yukata, t-shirts, mugs and folding fans are sold here, along with various traditional local snacks from the Asakusa area. I usually visit the Kane So knife shop on Willow Street behind the Nakamise and pick up some knives for myself and for gifts.My favourite part of the temple is getting my fortune. Deposit your hundred yen, shake the metal box until a stick falls out - and match the symbols on the stick to the symbols on the wood drawer containing your paper fortune. Fortunes are now available in both Japanese and English. ;o) For extra luck tie your fortune to the nearby stands.As a photographer I always find this place always has a lot of good subject matter for me. If you can tolerate the touristy nature and crowds, it is worth a look.

Touristy - but definitely worth visiting. I happened to see this temple at the perfect time. Got there around 5pm for some afternoon photos, just as a lot of the souvenir shops were closing. I then went over tot he Asahi building and had a beer on the rooftop to watch the sunset! It's indoors, so don't worry about the weather. I came back to Senso-ji temple at night time and the whole thing was lit up and looked stunning! I'd highly recommend the Asakusa area, and particularly the temple.

The oldest Tokyo temple.... Yeah...so that's a historical fact. It is the oldest temple of Tokyo. And if the boards outside are to be believed, the gate of the temple has been destroyed many times, most recently during the second world war.But the place is beautiful. It has a real calming influence on you and your hands automatically go up in prayer. The main shrine is awe inspiring. And like I said earlier, divine. Great place. Not to be missed. Yes, it is a favourite among the tourists and will be crowded. But that does not diminish your experience.

The heart of Asakusa. This temple lies after the Thunder Gate and between the gate and the temple lie the many many souvenir and sweets shops Asakusa is known for (many of them, especially the treats, are really very good). Walk the side streets as there is much more to see, taste and buy. The temple itself is very busy with tourists, and resplendent in antique Buddhist architecture. There is a beautiful pagoda is on the left as you approach. This is definitely worth the trip. Even just for the food.
Nothing special . No tour guide and very limited English explanation, so, it was hard to understand what locals were doing. Market around was nice

So-so. Probably because I'm not a temple kind of a guy, my views could be biased. This is good for a few photos here and there. Though we did see a wedding take place which I believe is a common occurrence there.

Stunning grandeur. This temple is a must-see landmark of Tokyo with the iconic giant red chōchin hanging under Kaminarimon. Lots of shops selling snacks and souvenirs line the Nakamise-Dōri, the main street leading to the temple. Before entering the main temple, you can cleanse your hands and mouth with holy water and light incense sticks. Lots of people come here to make a wish and pray respect to the Buddha. To avoid crowds, just come here before 8 am.

Touristy. Seeing Tokyo should include seeing this temple simply to say you have. It's very busy with many many people. The temples are only visible from the outside. The little road leading up the temple is filled with shops which could be appealing to some but I found it all feeling like a big tourist trap.Many fit guys outside that area will offer you rickshaw rides. You don't have to take the ride because they're pricey, but you can ask them for information about the area.

Beautiful temple in Tokyo!. This was one of our favorite temples in Tokyo, and it's located in one of our favorite areas of the city! Cleanse your body with the incense burner before going in, and go through the purification ritual too. It's definitely worth your trip!

The iconic Temple at Asakusa and a must see in Tokyo!!. Unlike many temples in Kyoto and Nara, there is no historic heritage in Senso-ji Temple in Tokyo. But, they say it was build in 645, as Tokyo's oldest temple. Anyway, it is the iconic Temple at Asakusa and one of most a must see in Tokyo.
Beautiful Temple grounds. This is a beautiful temple but the vendors inside the temple grounds may make the experience a little less solemn.

Great Temple and garden. Great Temple and gardens just in the center of Asakusa.
Lots of souvenir shops and restaurants that will enchant you with that traditional feel that we were looking for.
The temple it self is well preserved and kept clean, lots of tourists but not overcrowded.

Big temple but nothing much to see. It's a really touristy spot, and it is really crowded during holiday seasons. If you're not looking to visit a "tourist-must-go" place then I'd say you may skip it. You will get to watch some of the temple rituals (from a distance) if you're there at the right time. The shopping street in front of the temple is a great place to visit though.

Heart Stunning. You can feel very free & frolic when you reached here, its resembles like our Newari temples in Nepal. the architect is great one to view.everybody wants lovely picture with the other to captured.

Too crowded. Senso-ji Temple is one of the attractions that draws visitors to Tokyo. One cannot help but be awed by the grandeur and majesty of the temple and gates. But there were too many people when we were there on a Monday afternoon.

A must to see. No visit to Tokyo would be complete without going to the Senso-Ji temple. It is majestic and although you cannot go in to it, you can walk around the outside it gives a real sense of what it was like. But be ware, it is beyond crowded. We went midweek in the middle of the day and it was heaving! However, the market stalls are brilliant for picking up the souvenirs on your list too but again be prepared for elbows and crowds!

Stunning. A wonderful place to saunter around during the day or at night when it is floodlit though it does get a bit crowded. The stalls lining the road to the temple are great for souvenirs and snacks.
Exotic temple but overcrowded. The temple premises has a quaint market specialising in interesting local handicrafts and souvenirs . The place was overcrowded though the main shrine was opulent.

Can skip if short on time ! . My review is purely from the perspective of a tourist. I wouldn't know the religious significance of the shrine. If you are also visiting Kyoto then you can skip this shrine in Tokyo. There are more beautiful and serene shrines in Kyoto which will more than make up for missing this. It's also very crowded and touristy. If you have limited time in Tokyo and are also visiting Kyoto skip this.

Very crowded, pretty commercial (too many vendors). I actually enjoyed the temple in Narita more than I did the temple in Asakusa. There seemed to be more shops and more crowd at this temple than the Narita one. There also seemed to be less to see here as it comes to statues/ artwork. If you come very early or very late maybe the crowd won't be as much of an issue. One tip for you though, go to the visitor center across the street from the entrance to the shopping street that leads to the temple. Go to the top floor and you have a great view of the temple, and the rest of the city.

Great Temple. We came here first thing in the morning and the temple was very empty. The shops leading up to the temple was still closed. It was very peaceful and we drew our fortunes here. The large lanterns are impressive. We do want to come back for our next visit to check out the shops.

Beautiful temple and shrine in Tokyo. This is the beautiful and the oldest temple in Tokyo, usually crowded with local Japanese and foreign tourists. From the entrace and walk-way to the shrine and the main temple area inside, you will find souvenir shops along the way on both sides. A good place to visit and see local women wearing a traditional kimono dress.

Enjoyable temple visit . We visited the temple on our first day in Tokyo.
It's usually quite crowned but a must see temple. The surrounding gardens are also stunning.
This attraction is free.
Beautiful. The first temple we saw in Tokyo.It was special for that reason. The day was crisp and clear which made our pics special too. A sight to enjoy!
Great buzzing atmosphere. Had a great time experiencing the temple culture. Lots of tourists so didn't feel out of place. Very cool having my fortune read and making a wish!

Kimono experience in Sensoji Temple. Our group availed of kimono rentals near the temple, so we got to take pictures and stroll along Sensoji Temple wearing the kimono.
The temple is actually very crowded, due to a number of local and foreign tourist. But it is still a must-see area, and you will able to view Tokyo Sky Tree from the area.

Nice placw. Super crowded, but it's so worth the visit.
Pleasant to walk around all the souvenirs shops along the way, and then appreciate this huge, beautiful temple right in the middle is metropolitan Tokyo.

Going there at midnight, perfect for taking pictures. It was really crowded in the morning at noon. So I decided to visit other place then went back here at midnight, it was totally worth it. Lots if local people ran surrounds the shrine and it was worth to visit.
Only 10 minutes walk from Kuramae Station and really close to Asakusa Station Ginza Line

Popular shrine. This was a 1st visit to a shrine in Japan and it was an enlightening experience. We had to walk through the very busy Nakamise Shopping Street to reach the shrine. The only piece of advice - don't get distracted by the opportunity to shop! Do that on your way back I guess. We spent a lot of time browsing the shops and became a little tired by the time we got to the shrine. There's a little fountain where you can wash your hands, then buy some incense sticks to burn (as offering I guess) before you go into the shrine. That was very interesting for us.

Great place, I come to this each visit.. There is so much to see here. Nakamisidori street has tons of souvenir shops leading up to the temple. Have plenty of yen. The incense in the air fills the temple and streets and there are plenty of eateries around. You can leave your prayers at the temple and leave a monetary gift and get your fortune told too if you wish.

One of Tokyo's best temples. This beautiful temple is located in the middle of the city and is a must see when visiting Tokyo. The temple and the streets surrounding it are packed with people, but that's the price you pay. The vendors in the street sell some great food and souvenirs.
Very interesting. . Only drawback is tourist herd. Probably best to go on weekday. We were there April 1 and cherry blossoms were in full bloom.

Touristy but worth the visit. It is a great Temple worth the visit. The story is that it's customary for the Japanese parents to take their child to the temple to have them "bathe" in the smoke that is generated from the incense which will - by osmosis - make the child smarter and do better on their exams. Also, there are several "sticks" that is shaken and depending on the particular "stick" that falls out, you go to a corresponding box to read your "fortune." In order to make the fortune come true, you then must tie the paper that the fortune is written on to a post/wire there at the temple. All in all, I probably mixed up the details but you get the point. There is a main thoroughfare that leads directly up to the Temple and it's lined with various shops selling souvenirs, drinks and ice cream. While there isn't much, it is worth the trip if you are in the neighborhood.

Go once. The Senso-ji Temple itself is well worth seeing but the Nakamise or shopping street leading to it is a crowded tourist trap that has little to offer. An early morning walk before the crowds arrive and the souvenir shops open is the best way to see Senso-ji. If you are lucky enough to visit when the nearby Dempoin Temple and garden are open to the public (a very rare occurrence) you will be rewarded with a very special experience that will be a highlight of your visit to Tokyo.

Crowded yet lively. Revisited each time when visit Tokyo area. The street lead to the temple particularly crowded and very lively. Love the atmosphere and the little shops selling souvenir and snacks. Please 'DO NOT eat while WALKING' to respect the local custom.
Go at night. The shops shut down before the temple, and there aren't many tourists around, so it feels a bit more serene. And it looks cool all lit up.

An amazing experience. Our group went to see the Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa in May 2016, and we were overwhelmed by the beauty, traditions and the amounts of Japanese and other tourists that were there that day. True - we did visit during Japan's Golden Week, but this was the first huge crowd that we had come across in 4 days in Tokyo. The experience started as we disembarked from our subway train - the crowd was basically shuffling from the train to the entrance gate of Senso-ji - around 500m! But as soon as we neared the temple itself, the numbers began to dissipate and we were able to see the temple and its beautiful surrounds more clearly. I spent 100 yen and bought a paper fortune (omikuji). My first one was 'Bad Luck - Normal', but my second one was 'Best Ever Luck', so I tied my bad luck to the waiting racks and kept the good luck. We walked through the cleansing smoke in the cauldron near the temple, and then waited our turn to throw a coin in the temple shrine. The surrounding gardens, statues and flags were a delight to see!
soulful and authentic experience. Go early in the morning if possible, to enjoy the quiteness and take the omikuji to ask the divine about your future!
Must see in Tokyo. Overcrowded to visit during Golden Week. Renowned oldest temple in Tokyo with unique architecture, surrounded by food and souvenir streets.
Loved it. Probably the best place for tourist shopping. Visit at night aswell for a whole different experience. Also the view from Asakusa information centre was amazing, as it is free.

Children festival. Great time to visit sensoji temple when there is a festival or in festival season. i was there during golden week and children day, it was pretty crowded but you can experience the festive atmosphere.

Japanese culture. We took subway here. It is said the one of the most representative sight spot in Tokyo. Outside the Senso-ji Temple are many stalls selling snacks and souvenirs, and the prices are cheaper than any other shops in Tokyo. And we paryed and drew divination sticks at this temple, but I don't understand Japanese. It was s very interesting experience I've never had.

Beautiful temple and great shopping street. This temple is a must see in Tokyo. For two things, one the temple itself and second the old shopping street which leads to the temple.There are so many things you can buy here and huge variety of local food is available to enjoy.The temple itself is nice with beautiful landscape. We went during the sakura season which added to the charm.It is approachable by subway and easy to find. I would recommend it.
Another beautiful shrine. Another beautiful shrine in the midst of all the highly organized chaos. Worth the walk just to wonder at the building skills.

Famous tourist spot. As always very crowded! The temples are great. Souvenir shops are affordable and some items handy too. I like the magnets of Japan's famous places and food, very cute. Worth a visit when you come to Tokyo.

Beautiful . Visited during golden week so very busy...this brought its own charm also.Its a very popular shrine and lots of rickshaw riders available to get you there from any point in the area. Not as big as done of the others but historically important.
Crowds and Noisy. This was outrageous. I checked Lonely Planet and Trip Advisor and they rated it very well but it was too noisy. Never go in. The weekend

Beautiful Temple!. Getting to the temple is very easy with Tokyo subway.I wasn't aware there's a Sanja Festival (Sanja Matsuri) at Senso-Ji Temple, it was packed with locals and tourists. It was a great experience watching the locals performing this religious celebration. Sanja Matsuri only held in May once a year, and I was lucky enough to witness such a great festival.The Temple itself is very beautiful, well maintained, and located at the center of Asakusa. There's a lot of vendors, shops and ramen shops around the area, take your time and explore the area, grab some street food while visiting the shrine. It's also walking distance to Tokyo Sky Tree & Super Dry Hall.

Lovely Temple. As we stayed right next to this temple we often strolled through its grounds on our way elsewhere within Tokyo and were able to enjoy the temple and its view in both the day time (when it is quite busy) and also of an evening when it is illuminated. It is a beautiful temple and one that you should not miss.

Beautiful, bustling shrine in the centre of Tokyo. This is a place of calm and peace in the centre of hectic Tokyo. There are many good street food stalls that are set up around the shrine that means you can have a great lunch at the same time as visiting the shrine.
A tourist attractions. Senso-Ji is the famous tourist place and it must visit here once. Full of tourist surrounding. This place is nearby to Tokyo skytree, just walking distance

Teeming with life, tourists, temple-members - oh my!. Probably one of the best trips I made. Take your time too! There are a number of other attractions right in the same area and the sheer amount of food and souvenir vendors was wild. Really one of the nicest trips I made.

Ancient temple at the city. The temple starts with Kaminarimon Gate. As you walk thru, you'll pass Nakamise Street and then you'll reach Sensoji Temple.This place is quite overcrowded from morning till night, unless you come super early.

Best at 7 or 8 am. We stayed at the Richmond hotel, so we were able to view the Senso-ji temple grounds at 8 am before the activity of pilgrims and tourists. At that hour, it is easier to appreciate the architecture and the imposing mass of the temple that originally was built in about 645 AD. The current temple building is a reinforced concrete structure that preserves the original lines. The complex also includes the Asakusa Shinto shrine and a five-story pagoda. We enjoyed the activity of people seeking their fortune for 100 Yen at O-mikuji booths. Despite their reputation for offering many interesting things, we were unable to find souvenirs that suited our taste in the shops of Nakamise Street. Nevertheless they were very popular with visitors and they provided a bottleneck in the flow of tourists. We feel that this temple complex was the high point of our visit to Asakusa.

Don’t forget to check the schedule!. I came here directly without checking the schedule…and guess what happen?? It is closed. But the view from outside was awesome. Will plan next time visit in order to go inside

Popular locality. Being the oldest temple in Tokyo, set amidst shops and eateries, large crowds come to this area however it felt quite safe. Take time to wander around the main and little streets plus the arcades.

Great by day and spectacular at night. Always extremely popular so really crowded all the time. Loads of interesting shops leading up to the temple, but make sure you wander around the surrounding streets, lots of wonderful little shops to surprise you. Great food stalls right at the entrance up til about 5 in the afternoon. And once it's lit up at night it's beautiful. It tends to get quieter as the evening settles in. There are fantastic temple buildings all around, and small gardens with interesting sculptures. Easy to spend a full day at the temple and surrounding areas. Not to be missed!

Marvellous experience . If there then I recommend starting from the main gate with 3 large hanging lanterns. Make your way through a busy Street selling souvenirs till you come to the temple itself. You may catch people wafting scented smoke and also a fountain of holy water. Must take a walk around the adjoining area.

Amazing experience . My daughter loved seeing the monks walk around! We also picked our fortunes and went into the temple. It was a very humbling experience. I do not recommend going on Sunday's because that is the day most Japanese travel. There is a market outside of the temple where you can buy different souvenirs and food.

Typical tourist spot. We have visited Senso-ji temple of Asakusa prefecture during our stay in Toyko this April. As usual, the temple area was full of crowds/worshippers because it was located very near to the metro station and many eating houses and souvenir shops were available nearby. Recommend tourists to come here to experience the way of life in Asakusa

If you can handle the crowds...... If you can handle the crowds this is an exciting temple to visit. It seems to be a very popular temple for locals /Japanese to attend and it is a nice place to visit. Its very welcoming and people like "tourists" to get involved....One of the best parts is the shopping strip leading up to the temple, its fun and exciting place to visit, just be warned about the crowds.....

Very crowded. An interesting and beautiful place close to Asakusa subway station. We visited during the golden week in May, so it was very crowded. There are plenty of shops and eateries near the temple.

Just beautiful. Amazing and beautiful an ancient Buddhist temple. Very old with many buildings around. In front of the temple there is a great local market. In the main street you can find lots of Japan gifts and in other streets all you need.

Tokyo away from the modern world. One of the major temples in Tokyo, it is no surprise that the place is heaving with people. So be prepared for the crowd. An imposing, impressive looking temple complex, which looks amazing both day and night, and has a different character at the different time of day. Equally filled with people are the streets and stalls around the temple, which are filled with shops of every kind. There is a feel of old world Japan that is a million miles away from a modern metropolis. Try the street food and shop for souvenirs to your heart's content. Back at the temple, do jump in with the local and participate in the washing rituals before entering the temple and pay to have your fortune read if you fancy.

Busy, lovely. Beautiful place, worth a visit of course! If you love Japanese art, in amongst the riot of shops selling cheap tourist stuff, there is a very old, venerable art shop called Ukiyo-e Gallery. Easy to miss on the long "street" of stalls.Original pieces (expensive but beautiful to dream about!), new originals (reasonable and couldn't resist one!).. and much cheaper but still gorgeous prints. A great souvenir.

Spiritual and Vibrant.. Senso-ji temple is the oldest Buddhist temple located in Asakusa prefecture and located at a short walk from the Asakusa metro station.The main entrance gate leads to a shopping street lined with small shops/kiosks selling all kind of souvenirs and local delicacies. This place, as we came to know is always crowded and you walk rubbing your shoulders with fellow visitors.We were lucky as on the day of our visit there was a religious procession with some dance performances and children dressed in various costumes. It was nice to have a feel of the local culture.At the side of the second gate there is a small well where you can wash your hands before entering the temple. It feels very spiritual inside the main temple where you can pay your obeisance to the presiding deities. On the way out suggest to take the side street to avoid incoming crowds and if you desire, to have a taste of the local delicacies. Would highly recommend visiting this place for it's energy and vibrancy.

Very neat. Senso-ji Temple and the immediate alleys/neighborhoods around it were very eventful for us. Yes it is crowded because of its popularity but that's part of the experience. Taking a #followmeto type of picture is also fun and neat in this area. Lots of trinket shops, an area to buy fortunes, and temples to to view. The neighborhood to the left at the end of the temple was very alive and colorful during our visit. We highly recommend visiting the area towards the afternoon to feel the energy of the people.

A sight to see day and night. Beautiful buildings, but it can get crowded. Best to arrive before 11am or later in the day. Many tourist shops, but it is up to the visitor whether one likes to buy the merchandise.Spectacular at night and quiet enough to put up a tripod.

favourite area in Tokyo !. Amazing plaice in heart of Asakusa, very convenient to visit from airport or main areas in Tokyo via transports. not to be missed while visiting Tokyo ! Also surroundings, river side, market, Asahi building, downtown Asakusa, opposite to maim road next to temple id full of izakayas and restaurants where you can easily find some pearls of authenticity as for drinks, shops, and foods :)

God bless us. Almighty is the only person who helps us good days to stay ground d and in bad days to lift us.....a spiritual environment between the traditional shopping and eatables in heart of Tokyo

Because of lots of people, didn't catch the spirit. This is the first attraction after two whole days in Tokyo that I saw it was packed with tourists. That killed the enjoyment a little because it is not a big area. Lots of photo opportunities though. A best part: walking towards Ueno station/park from here was through a non-tourist street, packed with small shops, no roman characters, small café like in Murakami books... Don't know the name of the street unfortunately...

Fascinating place!. This is a popular location for school groups but there were tourists as well. Many little stores nearby. The temple itself has a lot going on; lots for tourists and students to look at and experience. We had a great time here!

Great to experience another culture. Tokyo's most famous temple, and always really really crowded. We went at Cherry Blossom time so there were many stalls round the temple selling things on sticks (chicken, octopus, fish, bananas and a great many other things unfamiliar to Western palates). And of course cherry blssom much in evidence. Because of the number of people, it's hard to feel anything spiritual, but the buildings are beautiful and everyone is very respectful.The street leading up to the temple, Nakamise-dori, is teeming with souvenirs galore, I'm sure some overpriced, but equally some beautiful and just what you're looking for!The whole thing is a great experience and will easily take up a morning.

Chaotic calm. Being a very popular destination in Tokyo for travellers and locals, Senso-ji can be surprisingly overwhelming for the first-time visitor. A street market lines the main thoroughfare to the main temple gates, where more food carts lie beyond.Once you climb up the temple steps though, you will encounter an almost puzzling serenity in the inner section of the temple, where serious devotees and robed monks pray and meditate.Your visit to Senso-ji shouldn't end at the main temple. Wander around the connecting roads towards the west and you will find a pleasant shopping street that leads to other smaller temples and shrines.

Impressive day or night. This was the first temple we saw when visiting Japan. Very impressive. It was very busy during the day, but very quiet after dark when the temple and the pagoda are both lit up. Maybe combine with a dinner in one of the many restaurants or Izakaya that are in this area.Nakamise street that leads to the temple is good fun. Lots of souvenir shops with kitschy and cute geegaws. Plus places to sample Japanese snacks like bean paste filled cakes.

I prefer night temple!. There are lots of place to drink around Asakusa. And if you enjoy,If you enjoy drinking, just enjoy and don't get drunk. While you the nice drinking set you enough, go out and visit the temple. They are amazingly beautiful and amazingly calm. If the weather sort it out, it is just so amazing. Dark sky, temple light, chilly breeze and you are some what drunk and you are in Japan. Even if you are not a drinker, it worth to have a night walk.If you are here day time, it is packed and packed with people and tourist all around the world. Just visit here night time, it is expensive experience.

Astonishing temple complex. The crowd in front of this place is just amazing. Hundreds of people at least walk to the temple and stopping for souvenir and snacks along the way to the temple. When you see the temple it is just a nice feeling.
A must see. Completely rebuilt after WW2, is a beautiful place to visit. Surrounding streets and arcades well worth exploring too.

biggest buddhist temple in tokyo. Senso-ji temple is the main temple of Asakusa temple area. It is very near the MRT station, I don't remember the name of the station sadly. Anyway, it is very famous spot so people would easy to guide you how to get there. If you seek the beauty and tranquility of the place, should visit early morning, because it gets crowded by the day and night also. Lots of food stalls, souvenirs, fortune teller and many visitors wearing kimono is a sight to see.

Visit before the crowds hit. This place gets really crowded, so I would recommend coming before 9 o clock before it gets really busy. It is a beautiful, beautiful temple with an amazing ambience. You can try the fortune telling from the fortune sticks for 100 yen and leave bad fortune behind :) and there is an English translation on the papers s well, which is very nice. Lots of souvenir shops around (not too expensive) and lovely places to buy snacks or eat if you end up there at lunchtime or dinner time, some very reasonably priced. Plus it is only a short walk from the Asakusa metro station.

Biggest Buddhist temple in Tokyo. Biggest is not the best. After seeing temples in Nikko, Kyoto, Nara or Kamakura, this spot is just big. It is not very old but it is overcrowded. It is nice to walk through narrow street with souvenir shops but it will take you a lot of time. You can try some predicting of your fortune from sticks with numbers but you will not feel any divine presence, just a mass of thousands of visitors.

Awesome - maybe my favourite place in Tokyo. Such a cool place. Great atmosphere. Really nice temple, and huge paper lanterns. Loads to see as there is a market here for tourists and locals alike. A strip with loads of street food also. Just a really nice spot to spend an hour or two. Definitely recommend this place.

Crowded but Worth Visiting. This temple is distinguish by its red pillars and the writing of Kaminarimon on the lantern. After entering the gate, there are rows of shopping area catered for tourists, of course you can also buy the local snacks too.
