The price for souvenirs is surprisingly a little bit more expensive than inside Tokyo Tower.I tried the fortune telling in the temple, You just have to pay 100 yen and shakes the tube that contained the fortune sticks. Once the stick dropped from tube you just have to match the numbers on the stick and the drawers. Good thing there is a English version of the fortune so you don't have to crack your brain reading the Japanese!!!Treat for the ladies: the rickshaw pullers in front of the temple are eye candy :)

Interesting Temple and interesting shops. The imposing temple gate with its huge lantern makes a good photo. This is a Buddhist temple and is a nice change from the numerous shrines in the city. Directly approaching the entrance to the temple is a small pedestrian street flanked on both sides with interesting shops selling souvenirs and traditional Japanese snacks and crafts. The temple is really near the subway station. This is my third visit and it is still interesting.
Tranquil experience. This temple is located at Asakusa and can be very easily accessed by Asakusa train station. It is worth a visit and a serene experience.

If you want to experience something truly Japanese and do not have a lot of time, talk a stroll through the temple. The whole of the Senso-Ji Temple grounds (as well as the surrounding areas in Asakusa) are absolutely beautiful. History and spirituality meet here, with a flair of the modern through the many gift shops that line the street up to the temple.

very impressive, a must-visit in Tokyo. one of very few landmarks in Tokyo in my opinion. I don't consider Tokyo skytree or things like that "must-visit" as they just don't have any Japanese elements at all. However, you don't see Senso-ji or anything like that in any other countries. To me that is the most convincing reason to add this into my "must-visit" list.

Packed out - but then it was cherry blossom season!. Senso-ji temple is the perfect example of how the Japanese combine spiritual reverence with a jolly good day out. On the way up to the temple there are many souvenir stalls selling lower and very high quality Japanese momentoes. Meanwhile you can snack to your hearts content.As you draw near the temple there are many picture taking opportunities. Don't forget to bathe in the sacred smoke and to wash your hands. Finally enjoy the serenity of the temple itself. Get to know the friendly Japanese people here.

Good Fortune and Good Food / Senso-ji Temple. Very crowded that day, but we really enjoyed it. Senso-ji is a little far from Tokyo Central District but worth to see. You can play many fortune games, buy mochi sweets and pastries, cheap geisha clothing and ninja outfits (this is true... all sizes, kids & adults!). Recommended to visit during the Cherry blossom season, there are many good food shops and restaurants around (we suggest to avoid fast food, it's not worth) that serve tonkatsu, takoyaki, yakitori and udon. Recommended for all family.

One of the most beautiful attractions in tokyo by far. Just walking into this area and getting to the gates of the temple is a fun experience...once you get there...it gives you an idea on what to expect from japanese temples...the design is very beautiful and the Colours are simply wonderful...the problem is that its always crowded in the season
Very beautiful temple. Beautiful place and clean and organised like everything i Japan.Very popular, so arrive early morning for less people or in the evening, where there's light on the temple

One of the biggest temples in Tokyo. This temple is beautiful and has a lot of architectural details, worth looking in detail.It's open only on special dates, like holidays, so if you want to check the insides, it's better to check their schedule. Even if it's closed, it's beautiful, with lots of traditional statues and ornaments.Many people go there to pray, so don't be angry if they stay in front of your pictures.You can also buy food and souvenirs nearby.

CLOSE TO ASAKUSA STATION. We were fortunate the morning we arrived that we were able to watch pre-school aged children celebrating O-cha-tou-bi (Days for Acts of Merits) as part of Spring Festival which involved them strolling up to the temple bearing a material dragon drape above their heads. The gardens are beautiful to look at and of course photograph. There were still a few cherry trees in blossom. There are many souvenir stalls lining the walk up to the temple and their prices vary. Seno-ji is worth the visit.
A good cultural spot . Pretty busy but worth visiting. A good place to go souvenir shopping too. Bring cash as most shops do not have credit facilities.
Fantastic. Really blew me away. Lovely temple, beautifully kept. Not crazy busy but busy. Great photo opportunities and a chance to take in some brilliant sights in a lovely area of Tokyo.
Famous Buddhist temple in Asakusa. Walk along the 820 feet long Nakamise shopping street full of souvenir shops.crowded place with locals and tourists.
Worth a visit!. Great tourist place to visit although it was extremely crowded on a weekend. But otherwise, fun! also lots of delicious street food along the way to Senso-ji!

Beautiful temple. This is my second time visiting the temple and I enjoyed it just as much as the first time. However, this time I visited the temple early in the morning before all the tour groups get there and it was perfect! I highly recommend visiting the temple once when all of the shops are open and once early when you can peacefully walk through the grounds.  I really enjoyed strolling through the temple grounds enjoying the beautiful architecture and cherry blossoms. This temple is a must visit while in Tokyo.

Asakusa / Kappabashi area. A lovely temple at the end of a market street. It's very scenic and you will get some lovely photos of the area. Yes- it is touristy, probably even more directed at the Japanese tourist, but it is still a nice place to visit. This would be a great place to buy touristy trinkets. The boat ride on the river to to here is a lovely way to get here, and Asakusa is a specialist Tempura area so this makes it even more worthwhile. A 10 minute walk from here and you will also find yourself in Kappabashi which is my favourite shopping area in Tokyo- Kitchen town.

Beauty in Asakusa. Asakusa district is very popular fpr locals as well as tourists. just along the asakusa market, where do not hesitate to shop yourself sick with souvenirs for a bargain, you will find this beautiful temple. Great walk in the gardens and area nearby. Alltogether a lovely afternoon program. Recommend!

Beautiful structure, but far from peaceful. The temple was great to look at. Architecture uniquely Japanese. But the place was extremely crowded with tourist like me! There were so many small shops around which was fun to explore.

Very beautiful . When you are visiting Tokyo try not to skip asakusa area it's very nice .the temple the markets and the restaurants and don't forget to take the rickshaw you may feel guilty about the guy but it should be done in Japan !!! The guy took us for 30 min and took so many pictures for us and told us a lot of history
Majestic temple overshadowed by commercial shops. To avoid the crowds thronging the shops leading to temples, suggest visiting it early morning before shops open for business or at night.
Very pleasant spot. Essentially stumbled across this temple while visiting another attraction in Taito.Very picturesque place although quite crowded. Lots of good souvenir shopping nearby too.

So much fun . The half day spent at the temple and the surrounding area was one of the highlights of my trip. The temple itself is beautiful and filled with statues of deities. Every so often you'll get to catch a monk at prayer on speaker. Lots of locals visit this place, too, to provide a small donation in exchange for a fortune out of the fortune boxes. Note that if you pull a bad fortune, you're supposed to tie it on one of the many ropes adjacent to the fortune boxes. The area surrounding the temple is a souvenir heaven. There are hundreds of stalls selling souvenirs for competitive prices. You can and should do all your souvenir shopping here in less than an hour, but you'll want to walk around more and have dessert from one of the stalls selling fried steamed sweet buns and these rice ball things covered in sauce. Delicious.
Go see this place. Worth the trip. Spend the time to go see this. You will not be disappointed. I recommend this Temple.
Too crowded. Too busy and crowded, and the buildings are just recent reconstructions from 50's and 60's. Go to Kyoto for nice temples.

An enjoyable visit. I think what made this temple so special was everything leading up to it. There are many small little stores and a bustling little street. Can't forget the huge lanterns or large shoes! The temple was very ornate and large.

An ancient Buddhist temple. We were quick visited Sensō-ji. A short walking distance from Asakusa station. the front door is very crowded by tourists. there are lots of stores selling souvenirs and food. We tried to have pineapple custard bun (so huge) and deep fried potatoes with minced beef ball (very large too). both of them are really tasty.

Beautiful and breath taking. Love the temple surroundings. You would too if shopping is on top of your list.The temple itself is serene and this is my second time to visit. I feel blessed & lucky just by visiting.By the way, take time to worship when visiting.

Beautiful but crowded temple. This temple is located in a small park next to other shrines that are worth visiting. It was quite crowded, but we still enjoyed the visit. You can make a wish and get to know your fortune there.

Great place to visit even with crowds. This was an amazing experience. Absolutely overpacked and crowded but that contributes to experience. There's so much happening here and especially interesting to walk down some of the side streets that are less crowded. Full of unique food and things to buy.

Nice but very crowded. The biggest buddha tempel in Tokyo. It has very nice elements that makes this place worth a visit. But be aware you won't be alone at this place. Never. It is a very crowded place visited by thousands of people a day. No entrance fee.

One of the most popular temple in Tokyo. I have been here 6 years ago but for this trip in 2016 seems a lot of people visit here more than before. Quite crowded and everyone would like to take a photo with big red lantern which is landmark so you will get your photo with many stranger LoL.

First Shrine Visited. The Sensoji Temple is easily accessible. You can take the train up to the Asakusa station and it's just a few meters from there. But before you get to the shrine, you will first pass various shops along the Asakusa shopping alley. This is a very touristy area so you will have to wait for turns to have your picture taken without photobombers. But it's worth the visit. Make sure you read tips on how to pay respect to their Torii gates and how to purify your hands before praying. No picture-taking is allowed of the temple.
Asakusa Nakamise street and Sensoji. This area is beautiful and a must. Koi fish ponds, beautiful architecture and opportunity to pray and revel a fortune in the traditional way of the Japanese.

Very popular temple in Tokyo. Constantly buzzing with people, there is also a food market nearby which has lots of delicious street food treats. Good place to pick up some souvenirs from the market traders. Beautiful temple too.

Well preserved Buddhist temple. A five minute walk from Asakusa subway station, and you will find this stunning Buddhist temple. Well preserved and worth a visit. It was busy when we got there, but spaced enough to enjoy the experience. The gardens are pleasant. One just needs to get through the souvenir shopping "alley". Great red bean paste buns though, that one could buy on the way on Nakamise street.

Good culture in Japan. There are most foreign tourists and a row of shops street. It was really very lively. 100 yen for a cup of warm wine, drink a whole body warm up.It is with a little sweet. The female staff also look cute.We started to go in the Senso-ji Temple’s main hall, according to research,it had been through a century of baptism as a temple. Every year about 30 million people, in Tokyo, visited there. It is really a very amazing figure. The grand hall is dedicated place to the Avalokitesvara. Of course, we should follow the rules from there. We went to wash hands before visiting. Here are some skills to worship , donate the money first. Temples are cast five yuan. Because the meaning of five yuan in Japanese means become attached to God. After that, then shake the big bell, tell God I came. Then say twice thanks and two beats worship, pray with very simple techniques. In fact, you just follow everyone’s movement to do is ok.You can choose a sign to foresee you futrue about love, money, jobs, health. Wish you to have a good draw and futrue as mine.

Another must do in Tokyo. We went on a day when there was a huge food festival with food vendors galore displaying and selling wonderful interesting products. There are also shops for souvenirs along the route of the temple.

Tokyo's most famous temple is chaotic.. While we ticked this off our to see list the centre temple was overrun with tourists and chaotic. When you got off to the side gardens and shrines it was much more pleasant. The main street leading to the temple is just a souvenir boulevard which I felt took away from the spiritual nature of the temple. The side streets surrounding the temple are lovely to walk down and hardly have anybody on them.

Twilight at the Temple. I visited the temple, located in Asakusa, Tokyo, at dusk. As I got there, it was still crowded, but people were living it, mostly. The temple and the pagoda look beautiful in the evening.

Worth a visit if you are in Tokyo. We visited the Senso-ji temple as the first stop of our visit to Japan on a beautiful day as the cheery blossom (Sakura) season started. The temple premises were extremely crowded but it was a worthwhile visit that gave us a good glimpse of Japanese culture.The temple buildings are ancient and very interesting and depict ancient Japanese architecture. Part of the temple was not open to non members and there was some function happening. Not all areas could be photographed but there are signs where photos are not allowed. The temple is a very touristy place and there are various ways they collect money. There are market stalls and food stalls all around the temple which make good salesThere was a very festive atmosphere with a lot of young girls in traditional kimono trotting along and photographing themselves. There were also a few wedding parties.

A taste of Japanese Culture. It is one thing to read about the temple or look at pictures but to actually stand in the temple and walk it's grounds was truly a step into Japanese culture. A definite must do!

Typifies a Japanese temple. We came just after the major cherry blossom season, it was just packed. There was an actual funeral happening so the inner area inside the temple was closed off for memorial attenders but the rest of the temple was open to the public.Places to pray, 100 yen fortune drawers, strong scent of incense burning, amazing architectural design and craftsmanship of the various figures.The markets all around the temple is very touristy but the temple itself is worth visiting.
Good but touristy. We really liked all the shopping and sites here. If you don't like a lot of people, this temple might not be the place for you. But it is beautiful.

Important Temple for locals and tourists. Devotees throng here and to get to the temple you have to weave your way through throngs of people particularly as it was Sakura time. However, it is a worthwhile must-visit place.

A must see place. If you really want to feel atmosphere of Tokyo, please go to Senso-ji Temple - beautiful temple and the whole place is a mixture of cultures, food and tastes. Fully recommended during sakura when it is in full blossom.

Stunning Temple and grounds, but very busy. I visited Senso-ji twice and would go back again, it's so large and imposing. The gardens at the side and other temples and shrines on the same site are lovely too. We went into the Demboin Temple Garden just next to the temple and it was really lovely, cheery blossom just fading but acers and azaleas starting to bloom, very peaceful and lovely.

Too touristy but liked the markets. Markets were bustling and a fun place to get sourveniers and street food. Temple wasnt as interesting as i thought it would be, very very packed. Go see the temple quickly then stroll the markets with meat on a stick.

Beautiful temple. This is a wonderful temple. We have Ben back three times over the past decade as it has such a great feel about it. The whole area surrounding the Te,pale including gardens and markets are great.
Must visit temple in Tokyo. If you visit Tokyo. This temple is a must to visit. Come to Asakusa station from Ginza or Asakusa subway line then walk pass many interesting shop and people.

Worth the visit and crowd. We went here in August. It was very, very crowded, but still beautiful. Definitely worth the visit. There are alters to burn incents and pray. It is a unique experience and great for people watching.
Nice temple complex. Visit it Friday night and it was amazing, nice lights, beautiful pictures, great garden, many tourists. A place worth to visit.

expect crowds!. Came with my girlfriend one early afternoon while we were staying in Tokyo, beautiful atmosphere and amazing to go look at! It was incredibly busy, but I think it actually added to the feeling around the temple.Loads of small stalls selling varying Japanese treats! It was cold, but we couldn't resist the black sesame ice cream which was delicious! We sat down just out of the way of the temple and people watched for a while, which was great fun!

Nice historical site. The temple is the end point of a cluster of attractions, starting with the main gate followed by Nakamise street. At the temple, do try the fortune telling which you do by yourself. You just need to shake a container for a stick to randomly drop out. Based on the number indicated on the stick, pick out a piece of paper from the drawer to know your fortune. Interesting and fun. The temple also sell amulets of various kinds, though the choices are not as wide compared to other temples. While we were there, there were also stores selling local food. Do go early to avoid the crowd.

Beautiful but crowded. Got here around 11am on a Friday morning, the place was v busy already, however this didn't detract too much from the experience, the temple main building is gorgeous.This temple is quite "interactive" and you have a chance to get a good luck prayer, burn some incense in the main burner and also purify yourself before heading to the main temple. However a small offering is required for this and I would suggest taking plenty of 100 yen coins.Also don't miss the chance to visit the Denbo gardens which are part of the complex, not only are the gardens beautiful and much more peaceful than the rest of the temple, the entrance fee also includes a small museum fill with artefacts and paintings related to the temple.

Beautiful temple complex. A beautiful place to wander round and absorb the atmosphere of a Japanese temple. Tends to be very crowded, especially in cherry blossom season. It is fun trying the prayer sticks and finding out how much good/bad luck you're going to have that year! it is also surrounded by lovely pedestrianised streets full of tourist shops and good restaurants.

Must visit. We went there early morning with our kids. We reached this place at 7.30 AM and it was so quite, extremely less crowded and very serene. We took all our time to see the temple and the garden beside. We had all the time in world to also take our family pics. As I had read in forums that the place gets crowded during later part of the day.After the temple visit we checked out the the temple approach which is a colourful pedestrian lane, Nakamise Dori, lined with shops and souvenir stalls. We also bought few stuff from here. The shops perhaps aopen post 0830 hrs.There is a Mc Donalds in the inner lanes near the temple where we had our breakfast. If you are in Tokyo do visit this place. It is at a stone's throw distance from the Asakusa station
Peaceful beautiful. This was beautiful and peaceful there where beautiful art work on the ceilings and the temple was very colourful

Lovely old temple and great atmosphere despite the crowds. Very easy to get to from Asakusa station, only around 10min walk from there.Visited around 4pm in April (Sakura season) and it was super busy! However, this is a beautiful temple to walk around, and despite the crowds the atmosphere is brilliant and there many opportunities for photos. It is also worth venturing into the smaller streets around there, which are much less busy than Denbouin Street.

Great temple area to take a stroll and pictures. We were there during sakura season and was able to take a few shots of the temple with sakura. The area is very busy and has a lot to see, including souvenir shops, toy shops, food (bread and hot buns,etc). At the temple, you can purchase some objects to bless either your health, schoolwork or success at test. You can easily spend around 2-3 hours here.
Quite pretty but also very busy. It was very busy due to cherry blossom / sakura season. It was nice but not grand...but it is still a nice spot to visit
Senso-ji temple. Wonderful temple to visit, tokyo's oldest temple based in Asakusa, beautiful, well worth a visit, lots of food and drink can be bought through the gates of the temple.
Beautiful but crowded...... Stunning place with great photo opportunities and shopping. It is very crowded but it didn't detract from the experience.

Pretty, but very touristy.. Lots of cool architecture and plenty of history for those that want to read before going, so you know what you are looking at. A lot of tourists that take some of the fun out of the experience.

Very busy. Very busy during cherry blossom time but lovely to see in the sunshine. Lots of temples and shrines near the city do do a bit of research before you go and choose the ones you think will be interesting for you

Beautiful area but very touristy. There is a lot to see in this area of Tokyo. We stumbled onto some market stalls that are just outside of the temple by accident and they had some pretty cool souvenirs in them. The grounds are quite big with lots of shrines to see. It seemed very commercialised but nonetheless, still nice to see legitamit Japanese people visiting the temple amongst the tourists to see what they do.

Asakusa Kannon Temple Tokyo. I loved this place but it was so crowded. This temple is simply stunning. It was builty for the goddess of Kannon. Story says that two brothers fished a statue of Kannon (goddess of mercy) out of Sumida river. No matter how hard they tried to to put the statue back into the river it always returned to them. Got my fortune read too. There are a lot of cherry blossom trees around here.

Take Note~ No eating on the way to the temple!. Been here many times and it's still as busy as ever. Love the bustling street that leads to Sensoji temple but do note that any food you buy along the street, needs to be consumed within the shop! This means you cannot eat while strolling through the street. A bit of a damper but still a great visit to make.
Interesting Place. This was the first temple we visited on our arrival into Japan. Like most temples elsewhere, it has it's own history and is worth a visit.

What Crowds?. Went early on a weekday with cool temperatures and occasional rain showers. There was none of the crowds mentioned in the other reviews. Beautiful temple and temple grounds that is about a block away from a metro stop. Well worth the short walk and Metro ride.

Beautiful temple grounds right next to Nakamise. The temple is a great place to visit, especially during cherry blossom season as the cherry blossoms blow so beautifully in the wind and accent the already lovely, elegant atmosphere. I like the convenience of the temple, as it's just a bit northwest of the cluster of Akihabara stations on the JR Yamanote, Ginza, and Toei subway lines. There are plenty of photo opportunities here both during the day and at night, and I'd say both times are worth dropping by during: come by during the day to see the lively and bustling atmosphere with ample visibility, and come at night to get photos of the temple grounds without many tourists in them!

Morning breeze at Senso-ji Temple. Came in early morning, temple was not crowded. Local people were came to pray and some place on the emple was on cleaning process. Temple was beautiful and even more when it was decorated with sakura blooming.
Crowded. One of the "big" sites to see, in all the guidebooks. Consequently, it is very crowded. A huge sea of humanity. Great for people watching, though.

Another Temple. After being to alot of temples around other areas of Japan before heading to Tokyo I was a little let down. It was quite similar to the rest of them and the crowds were just wow. Barely any room to move. If it is out of your way when in Tokyo and you have see other temples, I wouldn't bother.
Beautiful. I stumbled across this by accident and WOW!The best part of seeing this is all the souvenirs stalls, hundreds of them :)

Worth a visit!. Great to visit, can be busy as there is a street full of shops closeby to the temple too which has lots of street food to try. Make sure to pass the smoke over your head which is supposed to bring added wisdom and if goes near your pocket it is supposed to mean prosperity (apparently!)

Beautiful temple in the middle of Asakusa. On the day we visited Senso-Ji Temple it was raining, but that didn't keep the crowds away. It was still a fabulous site even in the wet. We went back that same evening when the skies had cleared and the temple was lit up by lights. Really beautiful and not so crowded. We then went back the next day when the sun was out and experienced it again. I highly recommend paying a visit to the garden next to the 5 storey pagoda. Such a beautiful serene place in the middle of the bustle of Asakusa. It can get quite crowded, especially in the market street that leads up to the main gate of the temple. There are lots of shops and stalls hawking there wares. Lots of fun and a must see site in Tokyo.

Small but Beautiful gardens, especially during the sakura. My business trip to Tokyo just happened to fall right on the week of the Sakura blossom, there for it added some much needed flavor to this tourist attraction. The Temples are very impressive, including the small Japanese designed gardens with koi fish. The Sakura trees in full blossom make this visit and even better experience. The long market leading up to the Temple make for a good souvenir grab. All in all, a great place to visit.

Small and crowded Temple. Sensoji was the first place that I have seen in Tokyo. In my experience gates are in the front of something interesting so I went down the rows and rows of shops and ended up in the front of beautiful old temple. Sensoji is an complex of shrines, pagoda, temples and other smaller and larger eye candies. During the day market in the front of the temple is full of interesting stalls that sell everything from tourist goodies, finger food, to art items. I recommend one stall close to the temple that makes patisseries filled with chocolate. It is made in the front of you and has heavenly taste.

An iconic place in Tokyo.... In the many ads promoting Tokyo, you might probably come across a huge red lantern leading to a temple. This is the place where you will find that big lantern. There is a street full of vendors - souvenirs and street food leading to this great temple. Unfortunately, this place is really popular and busy the street is always packed with people. I recommend that you take one of the side lanes (parallel to the street full of vendors) and you may be surprised that there are stall and restaurants there too - much less crowded!

Busy but beautiful. We ventured up on the Asakusa red line at around 5pm as we heard it was spectacular on sunset. This was a fabulous time to visit As the temple starts to light up for the night. The touristy stalls that line the temple entrance are just that, but the lanterns are pretty and the market is easy to bypass. We only spent about 40 mins here, as it is all outside and free.

Unique Temple. I love this temple neighborhood and best time to visit it is at the night when the lights are on and less people to shop (unless you want to shop in their famous nakamise street). If you want to get more story, you can join Asakusa walking tour and get the story of this famous temple
Great to visit on a weekend. The temple is near many other sites (such as the 5-story pagoda); crowded on weekends but had a lot of open-air food booths nearby.
Beautiful temple!. Great temple and recommend you go early as it gets very busy! Recommend the food markets outside along the walk way as well, which are a bit of a rip off but hey when in Tokyo!

Beautiful! At the heart of Asakusa city!. This is a large and beautiful temple at the heart of the hustling and bustling of Asakusa city! Japan definitely has the best of both worlds! You can also catch the Skytree near the bridge nearby.

Must see!. I traveled here at night and this is a spectacular temple to see in person. You enter through a gate with a hanging lantern which is a cool photo spot. As you walk toward the temple their are countless shops and street vendor selling touristy things as well as local crafts and snacks. The temple itself is beautiful at night and is well lit up. You can pray, walk around, get a fortune card, or just simply enjoy being there. Great place to take pictures and buy some local knickknacks.

Visit in the evening. Very busy place to visit day time, it seems to be less crowded in the evening... what I would recommend for great photo opportunity, but shops around are closed at this time as is the main temple.

Crowded but well worth a visit. You can find this beautiful site in Asakusa- take the Ginza line to Asakusa, exit 1.Entry is free but be careful you don't try and enter the gardens by mistake as they are chargeable.The Pagoda so close to the temple allows from some lovely pictures and with the Tokyo Skytree in the background it's a lovely mix of old vs new.
An experience. Visiting the Senso-ji temple is an experience that starts at the outer gate, with a walk down the long Nakamise Street to see the oldest temple in Tokyo.

Expect the crowds. Let's face it - the crowds are everywhere. Go as early as you can if you want to take the time to explore the temple complex and take pictures without too many people crowding around. Nonetheless, the temple itself is an exemplary specimen of Japanese architecture, and full of history. The hanging lantern at the Kaminarimon Gate is impressive and awe-inspiring. The stalls lining the walkway leading up to the temple itself offer a delightful array of snacks and souvenirs... Just be sure that if you're stopping to eat something you've just purchased, eat it in front of the stall itself and not stand around blocking another stall / shop or you'll get shooed.

a lot of ppl. the mostvfamous place to go in Japan. if u dont get in, you never get to Japan. when u go there u have to wash your hands and mouth before go in and beckon the smoke of incense to yourself for goodluck

A Must see in Tokyo. Senso-Ji is a beautiful temple in Tokyo and the prettiest and busiest one. From the moment to reach the area you will be flooded with people and traditional shops. However as you approach the temple you will see how pretty and peaceful it is. Really remarkable

Asakusa. There were many things to see. Great little shops and places to eat. Best to go when there isn't a festival going on just so you can see everything. Otherwise it's pretty packed. But so worth the trip. I will be going back.

A beautiful introduction to Japanese temples and shrines. As the largest temple complex in Tokyo Senso-ji gets VERY crowded. There are lots of shops in the area. I recommend exploring all the side streets for the less touristy places. Great second hand kimono shops nearby!

Tourist spot. It was too crowded even on weekdays. The main street towards the temple was filled with tourists and locals that you can hardly walk. It took me quite some time to reach the temple even it is just a short distance. On the way to the temple, there are many souveniers stalls on both sides of the street but they are too small to fit in the crowd at one time. The temple itself is beautiful and definitely worth a visit. However, if you are going to other temples, please think twice before buy the amulet there as they are quite expensive compared to other places. If and only if there is less people, Senso-ji temple would be a wonderful place for praying and enjoy the tranquility around the temple.

See the diversity of Japan's culture!. Great place for discovering a piece of Japans history and culture. Went during Sakura blossoming so very crowded. Close to Asakusa station this place is full of food stalls, shops, and temple related areas. We also visited the garden with the Shinji-ike pond which is way better than the ones around Sydney.

Interesting visit. A very popular spot for Sanja Matsuri, the annual festival for the Senso-ji temple which are very famous that it was packed with people all year round. You can find alot souvenirs include Yukata, tradtional delicacies, and etc.
Glad we saw it. However lacked a lot of the tranquility that we have found in other temples. Very bustling and busy and noisy. More tourists than perhaps other places but worth a look

Very impressive. Well worth a visit. It was recommended to me as I only had a short time in Tokyo. I got there just before it closed. It is stunning and situated in a lively market and street food area.

Religious temple in the middle of crowded Tokyo. It is a must place to visit. Long way from the front gate but worth to go because we had to pass nakamise shopping st which was very crowded with local n people from all over the world. The temple itself was a religious place to pray. Beautiful architecture and everything around it.

Breath taking, you need to take the time to appreciate this!!. It was utterly awe inspiring! I loved this part of our visit, donating a coin, reading my fortune, exploring the gardens around it! Even when the markets leading up to it were shut, you couldn't help but gasp at the sheer size of the temple! LOVE LOVE LOVE, WANT TO VISIT AGAIN!

Most attractive temple in Tokyo.. Yes, it is the most attractive temple here, especially with those big paper lanterns under the two entrance gates. Having been here in the day and again at night, I prefer the lit up view of this temple better.

Never disappoints. This is just one of those places you must visit if you're in Tokyo. This was the first time i'd been at night and it was so very lovely and there was a lot less people...win-win.The temple is just down the road from Asakusa station and has a smashing load of shops as you approach it. You can buy street food, samurai swords, kimonos, lovely woodblock prints, temple bells, lanterns, masks...most things to be honest.I love this place :)

The One to See in Tokyo. If you are limited on time in Tokyo this is the one temple that you should visit. That said it is very popular / crowded but has beautiful temple buildings and a shopping street. We enjoyed the sakura trees here as well.

Beautiful Temple. Senso-Ji temple is a beautiful temple to visit. It is very crowded in the day time. We visited the temple both day and night.....Senso-Ji temple is most beautiful at night and less crowded. In front of main gate of the temple...there is a row of small stores selling souvenirs and local Japanese foods during day time.
Get your fortune!. Really cool area with shops leading up to the temple. A great stop if you are headed to Northern Tokyo
Beautiful. It's nice but it's so crowded. I just stayed outside and took pics. Yes most def a tourist trap. I find the shrines are less crowded.
Super. It lights up at night and cherry blossoms everywhere Must go as you can see everything light up with sky tree in background The lantern go so well with the cherry blossoms
japanese cultural temple. I visit Sensoji temple yesterday. It was crowded by locals & tourists. There is a small park at the back of the temple with sakura trees there.

Pretty but crowdy. The Temple itself is quite extraordinary and beautiful. But the sheer amount of tourists makes me label it as a tourist trap. Plenty of other, more serene temples you can visit. Go here if you need your mandatory souvenir.
Worth the visit. My friends and I visited this shrine during the sakura festivals and the views were beautiful. It was definitely worth a visit.
too crowded. I really don't if it's the wrong time to visit, but it was so crowded during my visit there. It's close to the Tokyo skytree.

Worth a visit. The place is bustling. We came in side entrance and made our way to the temple. It was a rainy day so everyone was under umbrellas or scrambling for cover. Made interesting walking under a sea of umbrellas. Nice grounds to stroll around and people watch. We went back out the main entrance, wow, what a zoo of souvenir stalls. Worth a visit, it's free.
beautiful temple in the heart of the city. in the midst of a beautiful part in the heart of the city right next to the market where you can spend the entire day.

A MUST WHEN IN TOKYO. At the end of the Ginza line, you exit the station and turn right and then you see it. The long trail leading to the main building is surrounded by every type of souvenir and eatery shop. The amount to people visting this temple is unbelievable, but once you make your way to it, all is well. BTW, as you leave the Ginza station, you also be bombarded by the rickshaw rides salesmen.

Lovely Temple in Tokyo. We enjoyed our visit to this temple. It is easy to reach by public transportation or walking. It is near the Sumida River. It does seem to get very crowded with tourists however.

wow. quite close to Tokyo Skytree is this important temple Sensoji. post offering prayers one has to option of checking ones fate by taking out a stick from a box and then read the fate details from the drawer (provided one understands Japnese).
Great temple. An impressive temple, but crowded. Well worth a visit if you are in the area. Free entrance, and a large area to walk around.

Open at all hours and always full of tourists & locals. This is an active place of worship and there are locals every day who visit this temple so respecting the customs and culture here is a must. Having said that, this is also 'old Tokyo' and it is quite beautiful. It really takes you away from the city hustle and bustle and you can easily spend a couple of hours exploring the shopping street leading up to the temple, sample some delicious street food (soft serve, takoyaki, crab legs, okonomiyaki, corn, etc) from the vendors and pick up a few trinkets of your travels. Lots of great little spots for photos as well and you can see views of the Skytree.

A busy tourist destination. This is a late review as I was there in July 2015.My wife booked a bus tour that took us to the temple. It was a short tour and we were a little rushed and could barely see much of anything. However we decided to return the following day and spend some time checking out some of the places to shop and eat around the temple. You will be hounded by rickshaw drivers so just be prepared. I did buy some souvenirs to bring home but you must be selective and look around for the best items at the best price.

Interesting Temple. A bit touristy but the temple is interesting. Lots of small tourist shops around with local food and other items for local and foreign tourists. Avoid the peak seasons or come in the evenings to enjoy this place without the crowds.

So much history!. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. There are MANY people that visit this temple and it is totally worth it. While walking towards the temple, you will encounter many vendors selling food, candies, and souvenirs.
My first Buddhist temple. Asakusa is one of the top places in Tokyo, and this temple is the main attraction of it so don't miss!

Temple that surrounded by food and souvenirs shop. This is a must spot to visit while you are in Tokyo..I was visiting it on peak season, so it's very crowded.So my tips, avoid public holiday and other peak season

Old and big temple without much spirituality. I enjoyed looking around the temple and its various buildings and shrines, but the 100 Yen fortune cookies (without the cookies), that are very popular here, left me a bit cold. I am not religious, but can see the point of an imposing mosque or cathedral, but struggled with this temple. Perhaps this brand of Buddhism was a bit too far from my cultural roots. Having moaned, this is certainly worth seeing if you have been up the river to Asakusa. There is plenty to photograph, and the streets of shops leading to it are also somewhere to stroll up.

Awesome. Awesome temple with a rich cultural past. A must see as this is the root of Buddhist culture in Japan. Do take the time to admire and immerse in the majestic scale of the entire establishment. Also do draw a lot and worship to the Gods, it is a very different experience.

Crowded but interesting . Good but very limited plantations and lots of history. However in our opinion the sight doesn't contain enough items (or enough where there was a translation to make it get a better rating. Maybe if we brought along a guide book....
Visit in the evening. Too much tourists in the day, but better in the evening. Nice when it is illuminated, also nice architecture.

Small temple great tourist tack market outside. Quite a small temple, the attraction was the iconic thunder gate with giant red lantern outside, also the tourist tack market. The place was full of Chinese tourists dressed in rented kimono and pretend to be Japanese to let other tourists take photos. The place was polluted by tourist. Not exactly the authentic experience. Go to Hie Shrine for a Japanese experience, if you go in a Saturday you may be lucky enough to see a traditional Japanese wedding ceremony.

Beautiful and tranquil. Must see. I went to Sensoji temple while staying on Tokyo an even with the tourists everywhere it was beautiful. In fact the crowds added something too it, there were men and women (mostly women) in kimonos either rented or bought and the smell of incense was thick in the temple grounds. However even then there were quiet places, the Hikan Inari shrine was quiet and peaceful for the most part. Of a night though the place has an entirely different character. It was still beautiful but it was dead quiet and, without the people, had an almost mystical air to it. the Nakamise market was lit up, cherry blossom branches overhanging the path with paintings on the shutters of the closed shops. If you go to Tokyo you should definitely visit and if you do, make sure you do it twice, once during the day and once during the night.
Must visit!. Must visit in Tokyo.. beautiful traditional temple. It was a little crowded during the time I visited but definitely worthed!

Popular Temple in Tokyo. A large and popular temple in Tokyo, it covers quite an area. There are gardens to walk around too, and it has a view of the Tokyo Skytree. In fact, it's easy to go to the Skytree from Sensoji Temple - as you can't miss it!The gardens are compact but pleasant. The Temple is very busy, with locals worshipping, school groups visiting, and tourists snapping away with their Nikons.

Overrated tourist attraction . Way to many tourists and touristic shops around this temple. I will urge my friends not to go to this temple since there are many other better places to visit for a nice temple experience.

Interesting. This temple is a major tourist attraction. Along the way from the front gate to the actually temple, there are a gazillion shops selling souvenirs along with interesting tasty snacks. After a really long walk you finally get to the temple. On the right side you can donate 100 yens to test your fortune. Find the drawer number that coincides with your wooden stick to get your fortune paper. Make sure to put back the wooden stick in the metal box. If you don't like the fortune, you can tie it to the rack and wish for something better.There is a fountain to "purify" yourself before entering the temple along with burning incense. Mainly this is a religious temple that's become a tourist attraction. It's fairly common to see these during my travels throughout Asia.

Super busy but free. I enjoyed this temple because of all the souvenir and snack shops leading up. It was quite fun looking around and people watching although depending on the time you go, it's very busy. This temple is free so expect the crowds to be massive. The temple ground itself is very pretty and seemed to be well taken care of. It was hard to really take it in with the amount of people that were standing around but I'm still glad we went. If you're in the area, I'd recommend going but be prepared for the rush.

Crowded But A Nice Experience Still!. First went around the area in the evening and the entrance looks nice with the lighting. Went again the next morning and it was crowded. There are rows or stalls where you can get snacks and souvenirs.Overall, a nice experience.
A must in asakusa. A traditional japanese religious construction. The visit worths not just because of the architecture, but also because of the environment and peace you find here.

Beauty trapped in the city. This is a beautiful yet typically crowded temple fixed in the middle of Asakusa. It has great detail and wonderful shops all around it, a must if you are in the area. It is very crowded and there is no walking and eating. Please refrain from buying snack and eating them while walking. Respect the area and stand still while eating, and throw away your trash properly.
Full of culture, but very packed. May sights to see and customs to partake in but it's quite the tourist attraction with plenty of people around. depending on when you go it might be packed.

Very touristy and crowded. Extremely busy and touristy place. You can see as many selfie sticks as tourists. If this is your first few temple experience in Japan it is still worth to go to experience the buzz and custom. It closes at late afternoon/ early evening (4:30pm-5:00pm) so make sure you are there before if you want to go inside the temple - you can always check out the shops and stalls afterwards.

VERY crowded, but free!. Lots of souvenir shops nearby, very touristy and crowded. The architecture is lovely, and especially the interior of the main hall. Make sure to look at the ceiling which is thoroughly painted and decorated.
Big temple . Went here on weekend was so crowded. Beautiful inside the temple and they not allow to take picture. Red light outstanding in front. Must visit in Asakusa.

Beautiful!. I stayed at a Ryokan not far from Senso-Ji Temple so I actually ended up visiting this spot more than once. It is very cool to visit both during the day and at night. The architecture, idols, and statues.. everything was very beautiful and there was a lot to see. There are also a lot of shops nearby. I highly recommend seeing this! It's free and easy to find.
Fantastic temple. You should go there very early in the morning otherwise too many tourists were there. Great for taking photo and pray respect. Very nice.
Beautiful temple in the Kaminarimon Gate area. Great place to explore by day and by night for different views - the pagoda is beautiful and the garden and pond behind the temple is pretty
Excelent Japanese Temple.. Big and great temple in the middle of the city. Good to knw more of the culture and history of the country.
Beautiful Temple. The beautiful temple is located at city area. Quite crowded but worth a visit.Before you enter the temple there is a lot of shop selling souvenir and food.

Edo culture. This is Tokyo's oldest Buddhist temple. This is one of the places you must visit. You can take part in the rituals or just observe others. In the initiate area you'll find food stands as well a long road of shops on Nakamise street where you can pick up some souvenirs andtry some local flavors. Try coming early if you despise crowds because it will be packed by noon. I found most shops open by 10am. One can definitely see the interesting mix of Edo architecture, modern architecture and postmodern architecture in Asakusa. Absolutely worth visiting.

Great but busy. As with everything in Tokyo, it's very busy so get there early. We passed through a market selling food and souvenirs but it was so busy it was hard to appreciate anything properly. Look out for the con artists trying to get money off you for "good luck charms". They will approach with a donation form and try and make you give as much as possible with some pre-written donations of anywhere between 10,000 to 50,000 Yen.

Night visit. We visited this temple at 2100 hours. Although the temple itself and the shops were closed at that hour, it was still a beautiful sight. Shutters for the shops are beautifully adorned with Japanese cultural paintings.
There were no promoters bugging you to take their tours and less tourists at this hour.

wowz. was here in winter after an overnight snow on a layover where as the day went on more melt occurred. Beautiful day with lots of fun shops and good eats surrounding. I hope to return soon. If you're lucky monks will be singing at the main temple.

One of the main temples to visit in Tokyo. The temple and the entire area around it is one of the main tourist areas in Tokyo. Both locals and tourists visit this temple and it was very busy when we were there. The temple area and buildings are very beautiful and the shopping area around it is worthwhile to visit too. You can spend a few hours here in the Asakusa area.

Beatuful. We visited the Senso-ji Temple one evening after admiring it at a distance, several blocks away. The beauty of this temple really stood out well at night, and becausei twas well lit, at it was wonderful to study at close quarters, even in the eening.

Together with the park and the shopping area, a great place ot spend few hours.. The temple, nearby park, and shopping area makes this area a really good option. Very popular with local people who visit it, and if there are religious festivities, a must-see.

Great visit. There's some volunteers who help the tourist at the entrance of the temple. Great place to get some souvenirs here. Love the atmosphere there, if u love the Japanese culture, go pray and have fun.

Kaminarimon Gate with Giant Lantern. You can reach here from Asakusa station either on Tobu line, Subway or Tsukuba Express. It is open 365 days. Sensoji Temple is the oldest temple in Tokyo...full with tourists & locals. I just walk from Hotel New Tochigiya to walk the entire temple. From the Kaminarimon Gate to the Hozomon Gate are lined with stores that also known as Nakamise Shopping Street. I love the location because it let you feel the mood of the Edo era. You should come here!

Lovely place to see old and new. Located in Asakusa, tis is a great temple complex to visit for an hour or so, and a lovely place for people-watching. With a lot of Japanese people coming to visit the temple, this is a great location for watching the old and the new.

Best place for Japanese culture. Would recommend this for anybody with the area surrounding it,The temple still in use with people still praying and lighting intense, Buddhas all around, Japanese gardens, koi carps, the work from the tube station is a Great Walk to.A must if you visit Tokyo

the streets are more interesting. the walking journey to and from the temple were more interesting and insightful to japan culture than the temple. the temple seemed light on in genuine worshippers and heavy on tourists who took it all fairly lightly. the temple seemed a bit perfect and lacked a rustic, lived in and significant feel. it felt a bit hollow.

Definitely one of the best temples to visit in the Kanto region. In Asakusa is where Senso-ji Temple (or Asakusa Kannon Temple) is located.The legend of the temple is that in the year 628, two brothers who were fishing, retrieved the statue of Kannon (the Goddess of Mercy) out of the Sumida River. Each time they put the statue back in the river, it would keep coming back to them. So, Sensoji was built nearby for the Goddess of Kannon.When you arrive, the first temple you will most likely see is the Komagatado Hall. A location where the statue of Bodhisattva Kannon was found and marks the origins of the temple. This hall is only available for public viewing on the 19th of every month. A major festival is held on April 19th.Also, right at the front is the Kaminarimon Gate and you will see the Fuji (wind god) and Raijin (thunder god) at the left and right side of the gate.As you continue to walk up, you will be greeted by the huge Hozomon Gate ~Niomon Gate~. Built in 942 by military commander Taira no Kinmasa, he offered prayers at Senso-ji in hopes of becoming the lord of Musashi province (Tokyo) and built the gate for his wishes to come true.But like many of the structures in this area, they were destroyed by fires and rebuilt again and again. This current version was rebuilt after it was burned down during the World War II Tokyo air raids of March 1945 (the previous structure was built in 1649).Once you get to the rear,you will reach the Main Hall ~Kannondo Hall~ which is a national treasure built by third Edo shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu but unfortunately was obliterated in the Air Raids of World War II in 1945. The hall was reconstructed in 1958 and mirrors the original stall but with solid reinforced concrete structures and titanium roof tiles.To the left is the five-story pagoda build in 942 and another building lost to fire and reconstructed. It was declared a national treasure in 1911, destroyed during the World War II Air Raids and reconstructed and rebuilt in 1973. This version now features facilities for mortuary tablets and relics.And as you proceed further right, you will then reach Asakusa Jinja Shrine.Asakuksa Shrine was commissioned by Tokugawa Iemitsu and constructed in 1649 during Japan’s Edo period and uses the gongen-zukuri style of architecture.The small Shinto shrine honores the three individuals (two brothers, fishermen Hinokuma Hamanari and Hinokuma Takenari and the wealthy warlord named Haji no Nakatomo) who were involved in the founding of Senso-ji.It was run as part of the Senso-ji Shrine but is now ran independently.Also, unlike other temples that were bombed and rebuilt, the architecture constructed in 1649, during feudal times did survive the World War II air raids.Overall, the trip to Senso-ji Shrine is breathtaking and no doubt one of the best temples to visit in the Kanto region.Made in the year 645, the temple is Tokyo’s oldest temple.
Awesome. This is my 2nd time visit the temple. The experience still give a great feeling and the temple and the place just coexist so well together. Nice!!!

Cry Babies. This is not only one of Tokyo's most popular tourist attractions but you will also see a lot of local people who go there to worship.so, please be considerate when taking fotos.The complex has managed to preserve some of the old shopping street flavor that used to be part of a temple as popular as this one. Feel invited to stroll the long rows of concession stands that flank the approach to the main temple building over a distance of ca. 300 meters (1000 ft).Bonus tip: if you happen to be in Tokyo at the end of April do not miss the baby sumo! Officially it is called Nakizumo (from naku - to cry) and it involves babies held by real sumo wrestlers in one-on-one bouts. Winner is the first one to cry. It's a big event and happens every year on the 4th Sunday in April.

Lovely Buddhist temple. The temple the most famous in Tokyo and the largest. It is indeed a lovely building seen from all angles and is open to the public but no photos. Having been to many in Thailand, I did not find this particularly peaceful or holy. Worth a visit all the same.
Woah, people.. sooooooooo many people here (not even cherry blossom season), very touristy and a lot of touristy stalls all the way up. Kinda defeats the purpose of the temple to me..

It doesn't get old. I ten visits to Japan we must have visited Sensoji on at least half of those occasions. It never gets old. We like to avoid holidays and weekends as the crowds can be crazy. Even on a Wednesday afternoon, it was very buys, but not uncomfortably so. We picked up some souvenir nick-nacks on the walk down to the temple, offered up smoking incense for our ills and took the opportunity to find out what the future holds at one of the few locations that has English fortune stick translations. I guess we keep visiting as we usually have people with us on their first trip to Tokyo. We also visit because Sensoji is a very impressive and, despite the crowds, a very peaceful and special place.

Crowded but worth it!. There are so many temples to see in Japan. This is by far one of the most popular. I knew as soon as I arrived just because I've seen so many photos of the big lantern before. I do recommend visiting though, especially if your trip is primarily in Tokyo and you won't have time to make it to Kyoto. The temple grounds are gorgeous. You'll forget you are in the middle of Toyko, until you catch a glimpse of the Tokyo Skytree. Speaking of, the photo I took of the Skytree from the Senso-ji Temple was one of my favorite trip photos!
Serene in the city. This is a busy temple visited by many Japanese from around the country, yet the atmosphere is calm. It is lovely to experience.

Wheelchair accessible temple grounds. The entire temple ground is accessible. There is even an elevator up to the Senso-ji Temple main hall. There are several accessible toilets too. Easily reached by train.

lovely but crowded temple in Tokyo. Beautiful architectural building. Nice colour, dominated by red. Visited during new year holiday season. There were a lot of people. Along the road to the temple is filled with souvenir and culinary shops. It was not easily reach the main temple. In the main temple, we can saw how the Japanese do their ritual prayer during the new year. Nice to know their new year tradition. We can also see some of them wearing their kimonos.Overall is nice, but crowded.

Fantastic. This is definitely worth a visit and sits in an interesting neighbourhood. A must visit in Toyko. The temple is beautiful, as are the surrounds, which incorporates a kindergarten, several small shrines and gardens and a bustling shopping area for visitors. Please note the shopping opens up at about 11am, like the rest of Japan.

A wonderful morning. We spent a morning at the Sensoji Temple in Asakusa, Tokyo in November 2015. There is a road leading up to the temple that has a large amount of stores on either side. Most were souvenir stores but there were some other stores. this road is pretty crowded.The temple itself is very beautiful. There are several buildings in the temple complex but most people are concentrated around the main temple building. We were lucky enough to arrive there at a time when a Shinto ceremony was taking place. They don't allow any photos to be taken in the main temple building because it's a working temple and there are worshipers there all the time.You don't need more than an hour or two to see all there is to see here.

loved the history, culture and the atmopshere. definately a must visit in Tokyo! it is not hard to find, only 5 minutes walk from the Asakusa station. The little street market has alot of food and omeyage (Souvenirs) you can buy and lucky charms too! you can send half a day in Asakusa.

Beautiful!. I visited the Senso-ji Temple with some friends in September 2015. Tied in with the Asakusa Temple it is a great place to come to check out Japanese architecture at its best! Plus there are some lovely gardens, it's great to come and just check out these great temples and gardens! Recommended.
good. na pai mak makkkkkkkkk ka if have money I'm want to go to japannnnnnnnn!!!!! i like japanfood very good i going to✈️
stunningly beautiful. I love the architectural design of these buildings.absolutely breath-taking. wish I took more picture than I did.

Boring, took around 10 minutes don't waste your time here. Lots of tourists, really boring, although there is a market that you walk through to get to the temple which has lots of different food samples.

Serene and surreal. It can be easy to forget in the modern parts of Tokyo that the city is built on over a millennium of history. This temple puts the history back in the present where people cut through its grounds on the way to school or work while monks walk by on the way to prayer. On the whole a truly beautiful site and it should be at the top of anyone's list in Tokyo.
Not a breakaway winner when it comes to temples. I enjoyed the intense "well" which was billowing smoke which everyone grabs and pulls towards themselves. Make sure you do this too!!

One of The Oldest Areas of Tokyo. I went to Senso-ji Temple during the middle of the day and it was incredibly busy.The Temple was a classic Shinto Shrine. However, most of my excitement was gone once i was through Namikaze Street which is, in my opinion, the real attraction of Asakusa.
Come early. Most people see this temple teaming with visitors. It's worth coming very early and enjoying the serenity that this temple has to offer.
Lovely temple. A good place to get an idea of a typical Japanese Buddhist temple. Try to go early in the morning to avoid the large crowds.

Beautiful old temple. Beautiful ancient temple within walking distance of our accommodation. Fairly busy and touristy area but well worth a visit. Read up on the history of the Senso-ji Temple and Edo before arriving here. It will give you a greater appreciation of the area and its history.

Accessible Old School Authentic Tokyo. I stayed in Taito, Tokyo during my very first visit to Japan just this past January (2016), specifically in Iriya, so I knew Asakusa and Senso-ji were nearby & walkable. Thankfully it was a very nice day for walking. I was searching for great ramen (stomach first before anything else) when I stumbled on to Senso-ji Temple. PLUSES: So many temples in 1 place! And really old ones, too. This is Japan. Architecturally, you can't go wrong with these amazing temples either. Nakamise Street definitely lives up to its fame, too. Lots of fun. I especially liked the bean paste dessert which were freshly made (but not their policy that you HAVE to eat it where it's made). MINUSES: None, except for that old lady who chastised me for eating the bean paste dessert in the wrong area. I forgot! LOL! However, the crowd may be too much for some. I went there on a Wednesday, early afternoon, yet it was still packed. I didn't mind it and I thought it added to the atmosphere. SUMMARY: Senso-ji Temple is a mix of the revered and the commercial, old school Japan still very much alive in modern day Tokyo. If it's your first time in Tokyo and want to see temples but don't have much time, Senso-ji is highly recommended. TIP: Half a day per location/attraction is my rule of thumb for Tokyo in terms of how much time to devote to a place. I have to say though that I spent most of my day here as I enjoyed Senso-ji a lot! Realistically, you can do 3 hrs. if you're rushing but at least 4 hrs. is ideal I think.

A world away. Senso-ji Temple is a wonderful experience. A large but not enormous complex with many buildings and gardens. When you have finished admiring the complex and soaking up the atmosphere there are street stalls with a huge array of interesting items. It is easy to find and close to the subway, free and I think a must see on any Tokyo itinerary

A temple of true beauty. We found senso-ji temple while exploring and it definitely caught my eye. The bright colours and all the small details of the temple were just amazing. Theres a small pond with fish in it, and small cute details around the temple making it such a relaxing place to visit

Asakusa. I loved Sensoji, and ended up visiting twice during my stay in Tokyo. Start from Kaminarimon, the vivid red entrance, (very close to Asakusa Station- pretty much just follow the crowd!) and walk through to the great temple passing by the colourful shops. There were souvenirs and Japanese snacks all along the pathway leading to the temple.I definitely spent more time at the shops than I did at the actual temple! I recommend drawing out an Omikuji (100 yen), showing you your fortune. I was lucky enough to get a Daikichi (very good fortune). A stroll through the garden was also refreshing, and beautiful in the afternoon. While you're at Asakusa, you must also take a glimpse of the Sky Tree and the Asahi Flame. You can get a really good view of both figures. The contrast between the traditional old Japan and the futuristic modern Japan is another thing that I love, and can be experienced here.

Really had a good time... It was heavy raining early in the morning to Senso-ji Temple, the temperature drop and it was so cold..We still can shoot beautiful things and see a lot of new things, with beautiful surrounding.. I can't forget about eating Takoyaki and Chocolate Banana under the umbrella in the heavy raining.. I wish i can repeat the memory.. Wish to come here again.. This is a MUST location you should visit.. :)

Another nice shrine to visit. As my previous reviews mention I am surprised at all the shops selling everything from food to souvenirs but I guess that is the way it is. The shrine itself is very detailed but I was surprised to learn these shrines have been continuously rebuilt due to fires and earthquakes but the shrine have been in existence for 100's of years in some form or another. Definitely visit a number of them to see the differences in architecture etc.

Get in touch with spirituality in Tokyo!. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo, and probably the most popular too. From its famous Kaminarimon, or thunder gate, to the main hall and pagoda, it is colorful, beautiful, and feels very welcoming, even for the first time visitors to a temple.There are many touristic shops and food stalls on Nakamise street which leads to main building, and it is super crowded with locals and tourists, which makes it fun for people watching as well. Once you get closer to the main hall you get to cleanse your hands with the fountain water and cover yourself with incense smoke, which is believed to have healing power. You can also get an Omikuji, a paper fortune, and finally offer your prayers and find some calm in this busy, shiny, loud kaleidoscopic city.

Nice and interesting. Beautiful temple, very crowdy during the day with a lot of stalls selling all kind of souvenirs. We went there again in the evening ( just across our hotel) and it was magic walking around the different buildings with no one around, very quiet and peaceful.

A MUST SEE, BEAUTIFUL!. Easy to get to on the underground train.
Beautiful temple to visit. Lights up at night. It's so lovely.
There are many stalls/shops around the temple. Some of the better ones I've seen in Japan.
Get some wasabi covered peanuts, delish!

Ancient temple. A nice temple in the city with high rise buildings all over.
One need to take note of time of visit to the temple as it closes early.
very easily accessible from city centre.

Fabulous temple precinct with tiered pagoda and market stalls nearby. We visited the Temple on a public holiday celebrating the coming of age and it was absolutely packed with locals. The temples and the Pagoda were beautiful and the walk up towards the temple was fantastic with a giant lantern first, then the alleyway lined with interesting market stalls, then the entry. All stunning picture perfect. This entire area is free and is alive day and night. There was lots of incense burning and the different types of incense signified different things and money was thrown for good fortune in a specific part of the temple. As it was exceptionally busy there were long line to enter but it didn't take long and it was well worth the wait. The sea of people around these buildings was incredible. The Pagoda and temple are well worth the visit.
Morning walk. Lovely site day or evening . Excellent to walk around and a very old, highly regarded site in a fantastic area. From here 20 mins walk to Sky Tree.

Beautiful, visit at night when it is all lit up!. I went to this temple and it was absolutely beautiful. I would definitely recommend making a trip to visit Asakusa and see this temple. I didn't pay for any entrance fees, and you don't have to unless you want to buy items from the surrounding shops. There are generally a lot of people there but it is still a very cool place to go to.

Great Tourtist Attraction at the oldest Temple in Japan!. Great tourist attraction! It's really easy to find and travel to! About 15-minute train ride from Tokyo station, (20 from Shinjuku, 30 from Shibuya or just 5 from Akihabara).Take Marunouchi Line to Ginza (which is only 1 stop) then from Ginza takes you straight to Asakusa. Walking out of the station, we ran into a rickshaw (tuk tuk) so we decided to hop on and our guide was AWESOME! He took us around Asakusa and to Sensoji Temple, his knowledge in history and the area made our ride so much better. Definitely worth the money to hop on one of these. All the guides are very nice, courteous, and super efficient.You will see a lot of people walking around in Yukata's, which was awesome! Be aware though, it get super SUPER CROWDED! We came here on a Tuesday around lunch time and it was full of foreigners. If you don't like crowds, highly recommend to try and come and not a popular time. Sensō-ji s an ancient Buddhist temple located in Asakusa. It's Tokyo's oldest temple, and pretty cool if I might say. There is Nakamise shopping street aka Nakamise-dōri (Kaminarimon) right nearby and it's insanely huge! A LOT and I mean A LOT of places to shop at or restaurants to try out! We tried Sushi Go Round, it's a conveyer belt sushi place and was AMAZING! Everything was literally $1-$3 a plate! Great area to shop for gifts as well =)It was pretty surreal being here, like a dream come true type of feeling ^_^

Must See Temple. This is a very nice temple/shrine and is well worth visiting. There are also lots of stalls where you can buy food and other touristy items. Getting there is easy - just take the Ginza Subway Line, Asakusa Subway Line or Tobu Railway and get off at Asakusa Station. It's a very short walk from there.

Beauitful temple, cool stalls. Went to Senso-ji in early January and because it was right after the New Year all the decorations and stalls were out. Go hungry! There are awesome snacks and sweets! You can enter the temple and make an offering/light incense if you please. Getting there is incredibly easy by Tokyo Metro. When I went it was incredibly crowded...but it was a very busy time of the year in Tokyo.

A place that could easily charge admission fees but doesn't. An amazing place that any tourist or local in Tokyo should include on their list. Very crowded (which is of course normal for Tokyo) but something that any art and history lover will thoroughly enjoy, I'm still surprised that they do not charge admission fees to visit the complex.

A must see temple . One of the oldest temple in Tokyo, when I was there there was a lot of people. The temple it self is really beautiful but around the temple area you can do a lot of shopping. There are a lot of Chinese tourist so be patient.

Crazy busy . We stumbled upon this temple, and my word it was crazy busy! There is the Asakusa Makamise shopping street out the front and it's jammed packed with human traffic. The shops are not that amazing but worth visit when you are in Asakusa. This area has loads to see and do, so it doesn't hurt to stop by even if you're not into all that temple and shrine stuff. We caught a glimpse of some traditional Japanese performance at the temple as well which was nice.

Festivals and great food. We went during new years and coming of age week, so there was heaps of market stalls everywhere. Out the front there is permanent markets that have good food and nik naks to buy, these can get busy but lines move very quickly. Great for photo ops and you get to see all the girls dressed in their kimonos.

Interesting. I would highly recommend visiting this temple early in the morning before it gets too crowded. It's easily accessible by metro. From the metro, it's only a short walk to the temple. There are several stalls lining the entrance to the temple.

Try a night visit for almost no crowds! . This temple is lit up spectacularly in the evenings so if you want to give the crowds a miss, head here after the sun goes sow for a stroll around the beautiful grounds. And don't forget to get your fortune too!!! During the day this is also a good spot to head to get some shopping done as there are loads of little markets packed with all the things you can imagine. Might not be the best priced but if your into one stop shopping then here is your spot. Good place to geisha spot too!

Busy place but a must visit!. This was the first activity in our self-made itinerary last week. It gave us such a blast for our Tokyo trip! Went there on a Sunday so that's probably why the place was extra busy and swarmed with lots of both tourists and locals. You may visit their tourist information area in front of the first big red door you see in the photo. As far as I can remember this door is translated as 'lightning or electric door" from my Chinese. anyway, it's really a picturesque view! take lots of photos. from the door, you'll see some stores selling both souvenirs, mochi balls (i suggest you try), sugar can juices, and other food! You walk to the opposite side where you'll see the main temple. There's an area where incense is being lit. They say you "surround", "inhale" (?) or "push" the air towards you because they believe it can give you more knowledge. you can also light your incense if you buy them at a booth. If you're into looking at the shops and take your time, I'd suggest you allot at least an hour at this area. If you're just into photos and a fast look at the area, 30 minutes will do.

Fantastic for the senses !!. Enjoy the crowds that come here... They are mainly Japanese and are the most respectful people you will ever meet. There is no sense of crowding or of being robbed or anything bad happening. it is a fun place to stand aside and enjoy the sounds, sights and incense fill air with the locals....
A must see in Tokyo.. Spend some time walking the grounds, and just enjoying the Japanese culture. Lots of great things to enjoy around it as well.

Exactly what a first time tourist is looking for. It's exactly what you think of when you think of Japan as a western person. The architecture is traditional, the colors and design are beautiful. There are many gardens near by and lots to look at in the surrounding area.
Senso-ji Temple. This temple complex in the heart of Tokyo is a worth a visit. Best get there early as crowds can build up also its free and that's a good thing in Japan.

Great place to be. Been there twice, once in the rain (quiet) and once at the weekend (heaving). Lovely complex to walk round. Saw a wedding on each occasion at the Asakus Shrine next door. One of the top places to visit in Tokyo.
A visit to Senso-Ji Temple.. Nice place to experience the culture, busy street for snacks and souvenirs. You can see people wearing Kimono / Yukata and take photos her. Will visit here again.

Go back at night!. Senso-ji is very busy in the day, but don't let that put you off! There are lots of great souvenir shops and places to eat in the area. Also great fun doing your fortune, which is in English and several other languages. I managed to visit in the day, then come back in the evening, and I preferred the evening! Its lovely seeing everything lit up, and with out all the people there you can really look around the place. It takes on a whole different feel at night. The main hall is closed at night, but you can still look around the exterior.

Get here early if visiting on a weekend. This major temple complex in the heart of Tokyo is a must visit item. Crowds build to subway squish levels by mid morning so visit early. Worth visiting the Amuse museum nearby too for the great view of Senso-Ji afforded from the rooftop lookout.

Temple looks fascinating!. Great Temple, it looks really huge, nice and I dont know much sbout Shintoism, the design of the temple looks very antique and it was nicely made!Lots of people!So many good things to see!

Crowded. I went there on a Thursday, but it was still so much people. Still worth it though. All these small shops with all souvenirs and exsiting food - it is just what you want and expect from a place like this. The hard part is probably to choose where to eat since there are so many restaurants in the area.

Temple of the Big Lantern. An amazing temple that has it's own standing security beside the faithful, it is said that if you say a prayer and throw in a coin your wish would be granted. To the faithful, Sensoji temple is said to be a marriage or love templeYou're probably in Asakusa to visit this temple, it is the nucleus of all the activity around it, surprisingly after you step to the temple's gardens and its neighbouring districts it gets really quiet and peaceful.

All in one!. It's a temple with the iconic big lantern at the entrance and lots of people want to take pictures with the lantern (tips: snap a good photo from a distance so you can snap that big lantern, you can hardly avoided the crowd but I think that's typically tourist spot). In the entrance to the temple, you'll find lots of Japanese shops. You might want to see and buy few Japanese souvenir, there are lots of varieties here, but I found that bargaining does not work throughout Japan. The temple itself has lots of good spot for those who like photography.

LANTERNS. Culture, history, architecture, food, shopping..... oh my, where do I begin???? So many photo opportunities... So fun, loved the entire time I was there :) Make time for Senso-ji.... it will be a SENSOry overload :)

Crowded. If it is a clear day, try and go to see the Sensoji Temple. The huge gates, red lanterns, elaborate temple are worth a look-see. It is a good place to see Japanese women in their ceremonial kimonos. It was January so they may have been there just for a special occasion, but from what we could see there were 1000 Japanese at the temple for every foreign visitor. And that brings me to the only negative - IT WAS CROWDED. Now I had been warned that the shopping aisles that lead to the temple were quite popular, and they are and it is a good shopping area. But I was not expecting the crush of people. We were there around noon - and if and when we return, it will be around 9 or 10 before most of the crowds.
