When you go - just assume you might get separated and establish a meeting spot (the temple steps for example) and everyone make their way separately.

Beautiful. Senso-ji is accessed via a long alleyway full of vendors peddling all sorts of wares and hordes of people all pushing against each other.
The shrine is nice however the pagoda is the most impressive aspect. The site is usually swarming with people but it's still possible to find a (relatively) quiet spot for some nice photos.

Very busy but very interesting !. Here in mid winter with iced snow still on the ground , the temple and its grounds were packed with locals & tourists. Fascinating place to walk around 100's of little shops on the pathways in are all interesting. The Shrine is beautiful and a Monk was conducting a mass , very spiritual.Make sure you go to the wells of smoke and wave the smoke over you to wash away bad karma.Give yourself about 3 hours to take in the shrine and surrounding areas. Many good eating places nearby.

My favorite place in Japan . I LOVE this place. I spent 12 days In Japan but I couldn't get enough from going to Asakusa. There are a lot of souvenir shops, it's a little bit expensive but that's usual in Japan. Also on weekends you can find a lot of delicious street food and that besides of yummy is really cheap. The temple is just amazing you can feel the energy there ~

Iconic shrine in Tokyo, a must visit!. Iconic big red lantern gates. Visited on New Years Eve and it was fantastic! Temple was lined with really great food stalls selling unique local delicacies. A must go.

A must do in Tokyo. Go early and have the place relatively to yourself...soon the place will be crawling with people. But that only adds to the experience. The shops near the entrance is mostly goofy tourist stuff but has a good mix of things. The temple itself is impressive and definitely worth seeing. Also...in a great location for food and other shopping.

Oldest temple in tokyo. According to a guidebook, in 628 AD two fishermen pulled out a golden image of Kannon from the water nearby. This temple was built to enshrine it. In front of the main hall is a large cauldron with incense smoking. People are surrounding the area so that the smoke drifts on them. The smoke is supposed to bring good health.The Kannon which is quite small is supposed to be inside the main hall and not in view. People throw coins and pray. Behind the gates inside, there was a service with people chanting and a man beating a drum.There is a fortune telling area prior to entering the Main Hall. It is requested that a person donates 100 yen into a container. Shake a canister that has long sticks and then let one fall out. There are characters on the stick and match it to the same character on the drawer. Instead the drawer will be either a good or not so good fortune. The fortune is written in English as well. If it isn't a good fortune, tie the paper on the nearby rack and do it again.There are many very reasonably priced souvenir shops lining the streets. Be adventuresome and try some unusual food. Also, we bought hot coffee in a can from a vending machine for 80 yen which was quite good. I would recommend going mid morning before the swell of crowds appear.

Just a great place to visit. I visited here twice when I was in Japan. Once in the day, which is great for the hustle and bustle and the great souvenir shops (great place to stock up as we noticed many of the malls didn't have those awesome kitchy souvenirs you bring home for family and friends hehe). Our second trip at night time was completely different. Most of the tourists have gone and the lighting of the temple and its surrounds is absolutely amazing. Definetly worth the time to go visit- would love to see it with snow!
ancient place. very busy place but u need guided tour to explain the history because hard to find someone speaks English

Beatuiful. A very busy place but definitely something people should check out. A beautiful shrine. There is a market just before you enter the grounds of the shrine. A large assortment of various shrines & buildings within the grounds. Definitely something to see. Beautiful!
Iconic temple. A must-see, but very crowded with tourists. Excellent in the evening (although you miss the souvenir shops) as it is quiet and serene.

One of the 'must see' temples in Tokyo. We took a ferry boat trip to Sensoji Temple which was an event in itself. Pretty stormy conditions and when we arrived at the docking area for the temple, the river was so high, it was flooding over the banks! Luckily the weather improved as we looked round Sensoji, which was a beautiful temple, inside and out. Well worth a visit, and great for photographs.

Unique vibe during Hatsumōde. The temple is located in the oldest part of the city, Asakusa. The area and the temple have a very unique vibe, especially during Hatsumōde (the first Shinto shrine visit of the Japanese New Year). The temple attracts large crowds in the first days of the year and it's the perfect time to experience the Japanese traditions while mingling with the locals and trying the food sold at the stalls placed inside the temple grounds.However, apart from the New Year's holiday, this temple isn't that special. If you visited other shrines, this one won't impress you that much.
Worth seeing. Interesting temple, spectacular for photographs when lit up at night, the surrounding area has lots of great food stalls and restaurants .

Three lanterns. The only difference of this temple from other temples are the 3 huge lanterns located at the entrance of this temple. We went in the evening and the lanterns and temples are brightly lighted up, but the surrounding stalls are already closed. Pretty sight!We walked to view the skytree thereafter.

Most feverite temple in tokyo. Everyone must come here.its the most faverite temple that traveller and japanese come.there are many people here come to make merit,bless god,foretell about future,buy fetish to protect or make good luck.and there are many good sweet shop in front of temple on nakamise street.

New year joy. We visited on 30th December, when locals where making their New Year visits. It felt really special to join in the celebration of a new year. Interesting facts and features pointed out by our Free Tokyo guide. Well worth a visit

Simone Templer. I would say its must to go and visit this shrine, so many tourists come here, its part of the tourist must see.There are a lot of shop and stores where you can buy souvenirs and something to munch on, many food snack shops..

Magnificently preserved temple. Walking towards Senso-ji is already an experience of its own. The rows of shops peddling beautiful artworks, trinkets, souvenirs and treats. Each and everything they sell if off the best quality and not the usual low quality fare that you get at other tourist spots.When you make past the 2 giant guardians you know you've reached the temple grounds. Be sure to cleanse yourself with the incense smoke wafting from the giant holder in the middle of the courtyard. Then make your way to the main temple to pay respects to Goddess Kannon.The main temple that houses Goddess Kannon is so intricately crafted that when you've paid your respects you should roam the grounds. Find the pagoda and maybe even get your fortune or charm for the year.

A must visit temple in Asakusa. We visited this temple after reading a lot of reviews and friend's recommendation. There is no direct train access from Shinjuku where we stayed, so we had to change several subway lines which are basically very easy to navigate due to an excellent public transport infrastructure in Japan. We also used our Google Map to navigate our way through. The place is strikingly beautiful, with its Kaminarimon gate visible from far away (you won't miss it). You may find arrays of smalll shops along the Nakamise-Dori before reaching the Sensoji Temple itself. Be prepared to spend a fair bit of money here as most of the souvenirs and snacks are pretty hard to resist. There are some restaurants and small cafe selling different kind of food and drinks.The complex area is a photographer heaven too. You can literally spend a few hours here.Avoid school holidays as this place can be very packed.

Really cool temple right in the middle of Tokyo. This is a really interesting temple / if possible get a Japanese tour guide to show you around and explain what all the writing means and also point out other things you might miss on your own.....

Its not just for tourists. I always thought that Senso-ji Temple is only for tourists since all tour groups will visit the site. However, when we visit the temple this time, we have find some fun and interesting things.
Getting to the temple by underground is extremely convenience and comfortable ride.
The best temple in tokyo. Very nice temple and so many local foods you can try at this temple in winter season.....must to visit.

初詣. I came back again:-)
I've been 20years ago.
We ate 釜めし(Kamameshi) again, too. It was delicious.
Recommend to anyone;-)
1.浅草寺 Sensoji temple.
2.おみくじ fortune cards.
3.浅草来たなら...Asahi beer build. It will break up nearly day. Check it out!
4.麻鳥 Kamameshi shop Asadori.
浅草に来ました。
親と来るのはなんと20年ぶり。
でも相変わらず浅草の麻鳥の釜めしは美味しい(江戸の味なので少し醤油辛いです)。
うん○ビルのあだ名で親しんだアサヒビールの隣のオブジェもそろそろ見納めなんだとか。
変わらないようで少しずつ変化する浅草。ちょくちょく来たいなと思います！

Great Historical and Cultural Heritage Site. This shrine represents the history, religion, and culture of Japan well! Inside the shrine, there is one main hall, where people pray, worship, and make offerings. Right outside the main hall, there are many shops, selling lucky charms and offering fortune telling (self served). For fortune telling, one needs to prepare 100 Japanese Yen, put it in the offering slot, shake the stick tubes till one comes out, find the drawer with corresponding number, then get a paper with the readings on it. If it is a good fortune, congratulations! If it is bad, one can tie it on the side, and the workers at the shrine will collect these bad fortunes, pray over them, then burn them. Either way, one should not be worried. There are MANY food options in the outer area of the shrine. Recommend the octopus balls! They are delicious! 500 Yens for 6 of them, and they fill one up well! My husband and I shared 6 balls, and we were full. Try other things too!

Blessings for good health from Sensoji ancient temple, Tokyo. Its very easy to travel in Japan using public transport and as such, we took the Asakusa subway line to arrive at the busy Senso-ji Temple.As with most visitors, the huge red lantern at the entrance was an attraction for family photographs. Visitors pray for blessings by wafting incense smoke. Said to be a charm against bad spirits, a giant straw sandal (waraji) made by some 800 people was displayed. Along the way to the temple, you can get sweet desserts or mochi beautifully wrapped as presents or souvenirs.
Hatsumou. Crowded place with fruitful Japanese traditional culture seen. Can try various traditional snacks at the shops alongside

Nice place when you come back at late night. We stay in this area so we got back at about 10 pm. The temple was empty but stunning! The shops were closed but it was a terrific scenery. So much different than the daytime.
great atmosphere . love coming here, as others have mentioned lots of crowds but that adds to the atmosphere of the place. lots of little stores with great food so make sure you try them!

new year's eve. We visited the Senso-ji Temple a couple of time during our stay in Asakusa. We went there for an afternoon early in trip and had a wonderful time exploring the temple and the nearby shops. Then we decided to join the crowd for New Year's eve to one of the first to visit the temple for the New Year. It was definitely one of more interesting sites while visiting Tokyo along with the shopping nearby.
Great area. Keats something going on in the area, located next to the markets and Japan always ensures its visitors are treated well.Good street food options

Magical temple, very popular. We walked through this area on December 31st and it was very busy. The color of this temple is magical. I enjoyed getting close and having the opportunity to observe the architectural detail.
Why?. I agree with some other reviews in that I don't see what is the big attraction. It was very busy but little see. The best part was the adjacent shopping area/market which was fun.

Most famous temple in Tokyo. This must be the most well known temple in Tokyo. Always lots of crowds but a must see for any visitor. This is also where the statue of Kanon, goddess of Mercy can be found.

Rainy but still fun. It was drizzling, but we were able to enjoy the time there. My family wanted to take the rickshaws and the guides English was hospitable and they were very nice. I was impressed with the building and how busy the place was. A place most people should try to visit once in Japan.

Not too sure what the fuss is all about. Like asakusua the temple was just insanely overrun with crowds, and not too convinced it was worth trekking all the way for. I enjoyed visiting meji jingu far more.

Great temple for workship. A Japanese temple for locals and travellers. Plenty of local shops for food and souvenirs. After visit, enjoy a stroll walk to opposite bank where famous Toyko Skytree Tower situates. Sakura will be blooming along the bank in Apri/May.

Grandeur and beauty. Easy to reach. The walk towards the temple was pleasant and exciting, with lots of stalls/kiosks with bazaar environment selling foods/snacks as well as Japanese souvenirs. The temple itself was grand and beautiful.

One of the few traditional gems in a modern capital. I guess everyone who has been to both Tokyo and Kansai (Osaka and Kyoto) agrees that the latter smells more Japanese than the former. In Tokyo, if you want to smell something Japanese in this cosmopolitan city, you really need to go to Senso-ji. Not only is it one of the largest temples in the capital, the covered alleys in front of it are swamped with restaurants and shops. I am sure you can spend an entire afternoon there! Simply take Ginza Line to the terminal (Asakusa) and you will find the temple easily.

Highly recommended. The Senso-ji temple is near the Tokyo Sky Tree, just one station away, if I recall correctly. Its an always crowded place with bazars and shops all around selling mementos and memorabilia. The buildings have been preserved since old times and are an ideal place to photograph oneself. Alongside one can find eateries offering small tid bits and drinks, but you can't eat while walking. I saw Japaneses people offering money to the temple and also praying for good health. The temple itself is very beautiful with various statues and decorations. Really colorful and eye catching. One is forced to buy stuff form here considering the vast majority of shops and the appealing stuff they are selling.

My favourite temple in Tokyo. I would say that this is the best temple in Tokyo. So big and beautiful, along with the 5 story pagoda, it's amazing. Wander along the street market, trying the different foods along the way, before walking through the main entrance gate into Senso-ji. Buy some incense from one of the vendors (c.100 yen) and place it in the central incense urn. You will see a lot of locals rubbing the incense smoke into their clothes (for good luck) - it smells nice but it won't come out for weeks! Well worth it for the experience though. There are a number of smaller temples inside the main precinct which are worth a visit too. Also, the water fountain (for washing your hands) is impressive and well worth a look.

A must see. It is easily reachable, the nearest subway station is Asakusa in Ginza line. The walk way leads to a market which finally leads to the temple. It is one of the oldest temple in Tokyo and architecture is grand.

highly commercialized. Before reaching the temple, we passed through a long stretch of market. Trinkets can be bought here, but prices are more for tourists. There are those huge lanterns as we passed through the gates/arches on our way to the temple, which is unique. There are several places to check your wishes/fortune.Even though it is highly commercialized, it is still a good option to visit because of the size of the activity.

Great Temple. Sensoji temple is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa. It is one of most colorful and popular temples.The visitors first enter through the Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate), the outer gate of Sensoji Temple and the symbol of Asakusa. A shopping street of over 200 meters, called Nakamise street,you can buy souvenirs along this street.

go early in the morning !. Great temple. Many interesting places surrounding it too. I liked ti when i went ealry in the morning at 7 am, just nice and quiet and some people already doing their morning prayers.

Must visit place in Tokyo. This just like a landmark of Tokyo which I have to come and pay respect to the Buddha every time U come to Japan. Street food and souvenier are good in both quality and price.
Nice. Big temple. Absolutely packed during new years period. Food and souvenir shops were awesome and had everything we needed.

Busy but pretty. As one who does not enjoy crowds, i didn't expect to enjoy the crush of people here. However, it was worth the trip and the people to see it, although it would not be top of my list if i were to return.
Avoid peak hour. Open 24 hour so either morning (8-9am) or evening (6-7pm) visit is a good idea to avoid the crowded.

A must see. Absolutely packed, but absolutely fascinating. You walk through an avenue of shops to get to the temple, and once there, you can make your way up the steps. It is a brilliant spot for people watching. To catch your breath, dive around the back of the temple and walk around the little garden, which is usually quieter. There were food stalls there, so a chance to have a nice snack - we recommend the potato wedges and the octopus balls.

Interesting and a Tokyo must-go. Visiting the Senso-ji temple is an interesting experience. The subway station is filled with old Japanese artifacts, you get the feeling that you are on the way to a historic place. If you're going from central Tokyo the subway is a very convenient to go to Senso-ji!The whole area feels really "old" in a good way, it feels like seeing how Japan could look 1000 years ago. However, it also feels a bit commercialized with all the shops etc. on Nakamise street. We were there during Golden Week so it was very crowded as well.After doing a bit of shopping we continued to the temple itself. When we were there there was a Shinto priest in there praying behind a net so that people could watch. The hall is full of art as well. Outside to the left is a nice garden and just bit from the temple is a tasty melon-pan restaurant called "Asakusa Kagetsudo Honten" which is definitly worth a visit! In addition, it's possible to walk to Tokyo Sky Tree from Senso-ji which is nice.The reason why this for me isn't a 5/5 experience is a lack of things to do in my opinion, compared to some other destinations in Tokyo. I felt it's simply the temple and shopping and not so much more. But I absolutely do not regret visiting it and it should be on any Tokyo tourist's route!

Very crowded. The day we visited the Senso-Ji Shrine, it was so crowded that even trying to get through the crowds back to the actual shrine was difficult. The Shrine, itself, is beautiful and we are glad we did go to see it but it is not something we would return to on a future visit. And for those who have a limited amount of time in Tokyo, the Shrine would not be something we would recommend visiting. We enjoyed our visit to the Meiji Temple much more than our visit to the Senso-Ji Shrine.

photos at night. Photographers go in the evening. It is beautifully lit.If you go in the late morning, you will be able to enter the temple and take photos of the ceiling. No fee required. There is a tiny charm shop inside.

A Great Place to Visit in Asakusa. If your visiting Asakusa, make sure to visit Senso-ji Temple and pass by the Nakamise street shopping. Place is easily accessible and lots of stuff to buy especially souvenir from Japan. There is a night barbecue as well beside the Temple. A must visit in Tokyo area.

Too many tourists. It's difficult to fully enjoy this temple as there were crowds of tourists when we visited. The place is also too commercial. There are a ton of stores out in front and souvenir shops that sell expensive goods.
I love it!. It was my first place which I've visited in Tokyo.It has many tourists and It was my first contact with the eastern culture.

New Year Eve Prayer. It was so cool joining the big crowd during the midnight for your very first prayer! It was surprisingly peaceful and delightful to line up and wait for your turn. You can enjoy the lively Japanese new year atmosphere well.
The oldest Temple in Tokyo. It was so busy when I visited which took away from the experience a little but because of it's historical value is a must see.

Oldest temple in Tokyo. This is a very famous and old temple in Asakusa. It has a nice architecture and the temple is very well maintained. The alter inside is very beautiful too.If you are in Asakusa and have limited time, this is the place to come to. You can visit a traditional Japanese temple and buy souvenirs along Nakamise shopping street during one visit.

Oasis of peace in a very busy area. Visited here as we went to all the areas in tokyo. Didn't like the area that much but the temple was pretty even though it was outshone by the ones in Asakusa. Worth a visit if you're in the area
One of the free-must-go tourist spot in Tokyo. It is one of the free-must-go tourist spot, easily access from Asakusa subway station too. Crowded most of the time.

Another underwhelming temple. Really you must go to Kyoto to see temples and shrines. But if you are in Tokyo you should see this temple. The buildings are interestingly designed. Wish there was more to do. Small koi pond next to it.
Great Experience, it is at Asakusa!. It is at Asakusa. It is a good experience as we saw what the locals do when they visit temple. Great!
You have to visit it !. Close to Asakusa, typical temples, can be very busy. Close to the river's embankment for Sumida boat tours.

Nice Scenery and Good for Photo Taking. Nice place to visit. You will walk through the street leading to the temple which filled with shops selling souvenirs and food. There are also a quite a number of small restaurants hidden around the corner that offers quite a good food.
Do walk the temple vicinity. You can see beautiful garden and scenery.

Shopping and sightseeing. We visited during the new year season, and the place was filled with locals and tourists alike. The long street that leads up to the main temple has tons of interesting shops that sell souvenirs and street food, one of the dango shops (with a bunny mark on it) seemed to be very popular. There are hidden shops here and there around the corners - we found a melonpan shop and it turned out to be great!The actual temple is magnificent with its huge red lanterns and tall towers. There was a giant incense pot releasing smoke from the entrance, and it seems like it's a tradition for the locals to get close to breathe in the incense / fan it towards their face. They also have booths with street food and Japanese charms - overall, a lot to see and explore. Don't miss it if you're around asakusa!
huge and nice temple. there are lots of food and souvenirs selling outside the temple, it's fun to just stroll along the main street and fill up your tummy with all kinds of street food

A Colorful and Cultural Experience. The Sensoji Temple is accessible via the Ginza subway line from the Kanda train station. Alight at the Asakusa subway station and exit via Exit 1. Once on street level, turn right and walk about 3 minutes. At the end of the row of shops and restaurants, you will find the entrance to the temple. It is impossible to miss the gate because of a huge red lantern hanging above the entrance.Many retail shops line the way on both sides of the walkway into the temple. Visitors can buy souvenirs, snacks and gifts while visiting the temple. A word of advise for foreign visitors to Tokyo, please do not eat or drink while on the go. It is deemed as rude and a socially undesirable thing to do so. Therefore, upon purchase of a snack or drink which is intended for immediate consumption, please move along to a quiet spot or away from the main thoroughfare to eat and drink privately.The colors of the decorations, buildings and merchandise on sale make the entire visit to the temple a very vibrant and pleasant one. It is a very crowded place on a daily basis. Be prepared for a tight squeeze at certain locations along the way.I highly recommend this venue for visitors to Tokyo.

Spectacular Temple. Loads of people so get here early as possible. The road leading to the temple is filled with shops selling souvenirs, food and other knick knacks. The temple itself is impressive and well worth a visit.

famous place. senso ji temple is one of the famous place in tokyo, lots of people come to visit and pay respect to god inside. the temple is not far from tokyo sky tree and easy to go from ueno station by walking or metro or bus.

Interesting temple. Senso-ji temple is one of the must go place in Tokyo but over the year this place has become more pack. I went twice once in the day and another time in the evening. Evening will be less pack and the temple is lighted, interesting as well but i feel it better to visit in the day. Yes, it will be pack but interesting thing here is you are able to see shops selling snacks and able to see how they make them. I was standing at the cake store looking at how the store owner make layer cakes. Souvenirs here are reasonable price too. Try Asamen - deep fried meat, taste good.

Well worth a visit. Lovely Buddhist temple. Enter via a main gate with an enormous red lantern and follow the street up towards the temple. The street is lined with shops selling souvenirs and many different food stalls selling different types of Japanese snacks. At the temple you can pay 100 yen for your fortune. Shake the box, pull out a long stick with a number and find your fortune in the box with that number marked. If it is good, keep it. If it is bad then tie it to the rack nearby and say goodbye to your bad fortune..Very busy but a must-visit.
An impressive must see!. Located in the center of Asakusa, it is a must see while in Tokyo, amazing architecture with a lot of bazaars selling traditional food and souvenirs.
Lovely. Great are to walk around and take in the culture. Stunning Japanese gardens and architecture. Great street market nearby.
Open Temple. It is a beautiful temple representing the old Japan. When we arrived tho it was crowded with both tourists and pilgrims.

Very crowded tourist attraction. Wanted to visit the famous Nakamise street for souvenirs and visited the Senso-ji Temple which was located there. There were hoards of people there so it was rather difficult to enjoy the experience. Lots of street food located just outside the temple and we managed to get the souvenirs we wanted at very reasonable prices.

Great atmosphere. This temple is surrounded by lots of market stalls full of tourists. I loved the Memorial garden next to the shrine full of interesting stones with inscriptions, carvings and trees. It's to the left, quite small but has a tranquil atmosphere.

Old temple in tokyo. The temple is in black and white with a huge lantern. Although it is old, it is well preserved. There were lots of worshippers and tourists. Lots of shops around the area. Souvenir shops sell fans, dolls, kimonos,slippers and scrolls.

Historic place in lively surroundings. The temple is both important to the Japanese, much visited and surrounded with shops where you can buy local food, snacks, souvenirs etc. Where many temples are surrounded by quite gardens, thus is buzzing with life.

A must visit for everyone who is going to Japan. The most famous shrine in Japan, a picture with the big red lantern with wording of 'lightning gate' 雷門 is the most Japan thing to do.There's many things to do and see around Sensoji. You can go to the viewing deck across sensoji for a photo of the wholr Nakamesi st to the temple, you can eat all those local delicacies they sell along the street, and you can even rent Kimono to walk around the area up to 4 hrs.Do go in the shrine and try out the fortune stick and see what is your fortune like. Just place 100 yen and shake until a stick with number comes out, go to the tiny drawers according to the number on your stick. The paper you get tells your fortune, and it has english explanation at the back.If you do not get a good fortune told, fold the paper and tied it to the iron poles nearby so that it will not come true :PThey also sell lucky charms for health, safety, study and etc available. It's really nicely done, a good choice for souvenir. Happy exploring!

Good place to visit. The temple itself is quite small but very beautiful.The most tourist attraction are all the streets around the temple. Full a small shops and restaurants.That was a very nice visit.Recommended

Well-preserved temple, crowded. This is one of the most picturesque temples I've visited in Japan. There are lots of tourists who visit this temple from early in the morning until late at night. Sweets and other local delicacies are also sold in the shopping area in front of the temple. Overall, this is a must-visit place to experience the local tradition, take some photos and buy some souvenirs to bring home.

Amazing place. We stayed in a hostel nearby which made it easier for us to visit the temple by day and by night! Extremely crowded during day time but a lot of food you have to try! During night its very quite and all light up, very beautiful so I recommend going at night if you dont like having to squeeze your way through the street but no vendors open.

Nice, but crowded . The temple was lovely, but extremely crowded on the weekend morning that we were there. There is a shopping alley near the temple that sells food and souvenirs - might be good for a snack, but not really for quality souvenirs. The little garden area and smaller shrines around the temple were less crowded and more fun to explore.

Very Nice. It is a nice temple, but if you have seen many others in Japan, then this one won't be any different or better. If you haven't seen any, then you will enjoy it.It's just a few minutes walk from Asakusa with access to the Toei Line, Ginza Line, Asakusa Line and rail network. There are lots of souvegnier shops and restaurants in the area too.The day we went seemed to be one of the busiest days in the year for whatever reason, perhaps it wasn't but it seemed it. One of the busiest temples i visited in all of Japan. This maybe ruined the experience a little as it looses it's aura with so many people.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple especially at night. Try to go inside and see (or join) the locals pray before the statue. You can also theow coins and make a wish.
Nice to see u again 2 nd times.. Every place is very nice, I am very impressived very times to visit Japan. I hope, I will there again & again..

Very nice !!!. It is VERY crowded, but definitely a great place to go. There is plenty of great food inside the market. A lot of places selling souvenirs. There are a lot of things to see around there. A must go!

Beautiful Shrine. Senso-ji Temple is a beautiful shrine and I would recommend a visit when in Tokyo. It was very crowded with patrons and tourists but orderly and peaceful. It is a very picturesque structure and there are tons of photo opportunities. Interesting history behind this place. It was fun to walk through the endless shops to reach the main temple Gate. Shops were selling all kinds of trinkets and foods/goodies that we were not familiar with.

A Beautiful Temple. The Sensoji Shrine defines part of Japan Culture. It is a must go destination if you are in Tokyo. However, the place is small. Its a 30minutes walk from the Main gate up to the Temple. Thats about all.

A must-see in Tokyo. The temple was very crowded but then again, it is a very popular tourist attraction as well as a temple for the locals to visit. The crowds were orderly and we really enjoyed looking at the pictorial story of how the Senso-ji Temple came to be built there. We also made a small donation to have our lots drawn.

Feudal Japan. Senso-ji temple is located in Asakusa Tokyo. It mostly resembles old buildings and architecture of Feudal Japan. The Temple was built by two brothers who fished the statue of Kannon the goddess of mercy. There is many places you can get souvenirs. Good spot to take pictures as well

Great temple. One of Japanese biggest temple.
Just right behind our hotel (super hotel asakusa).
You can see the warmth of the people here.
They pray & respect their God so deeply..

More than a place to pray. The huge area of Sensoji Temple in Asakusa invites every visitor to visit. The shrine complex is complemented by an approximately 1-kilometer-long passage full of souvenir shops. The prices of the souvenirs are here in relations to Tokyo through out as inexpensively. You really get everything to can prove that you have visited Tokyo. The Sensoji Temple itself is an impressive architectural ensemble and you will not to stop to make photos. Should you visit Tokyo, then a visit to the Sensoji Temple is indispensable.

A Must-see During your Tokyo Visit. The Temple is located next to the Asakusa structure - if I were to pick one place for a Tokyo tourist to visit, this would be it. Although very crowded, I found it to be quite peaceful to walk around. There were so many picture opportunities, as it is such a beautiful location with many features. From going up the steps to the Temple, to walking by food vendors, to browsing at the many shops set up, to viewing the amazing architecture. After window shopping at other locations in Tokyo, I regret not having spent more time going through the small shops lined up on the walkway up the Temple - you can buy very unique gifts not found elsewhere (trinkets, snacks, clothing, etc). A trip to Tokyo is not complete without coming here.
Open at night. Was looking for a sightseeing opportunity at night. The temple is lit up and beautiful but the shops close at around 5 or 6pm

Tourist place. OK, the corridor to the temple is lined with plenty of shops selling foodstuff to souvenirs. It appeared quite quaint but at the same time clearly touristy. Right at the main gate, there were plenty of street food peddlers which was off the mark.

One of the biggest landmark in Tokyo. If you visit Tokyo, there is no reason no to visit this place. Very crowded, flooded with tourists but it is a landmark of Tokyo. Spare some time to walk around the garden or the shopping street across the main street as you will find a lot of surprise there :)

Beautiful, but touristy. Loved walking around the temple grounds on arrival in Japan. You enter through the kaminari gate and then walk along a row of souvenir shops to the temple. There is also a tall pagoda and Asakusa shrine adjacent. Free and deservedly busy.

Senoji Temple (Guanyin). Upon exit from Asakusa station, it is a short walk. The temple is opposite the Japan Tourism Office in Asakusa via walking along the Nakemise street with many shops selling snacks, decoration items etc. Can go up to Level 8 of Tourism building to get an overview of the Temple & Tokyo skytree tower. Besides the temple, is the bus stop, where you can get free shuttle ride to Tokyo Skytree Tower & vice versa.

A nice spot in the middle of Tokyo. This place is a must whenever in Japan and you're only staying in Tokyo. If you have the chance to go to any other temples like the ones in Kyoto then you can definitely skip this one. It's very crowded but it's great for souvenir shopping. The temple itself is not as impressive but nice for been in the middle of the city.

Beautiful place, worth a visit.. We enjoyed ourselves at the Senso-ji temple. So many things to see, but and eat along the way. The temple was beautiful and offered people a chance to pray there. It was crowded though. We spent half a day wandering around the streets nearby. Definitely worth a visit.

Take advantage of festivals and other special occasions. Went on the 3rd of November, Culture Day, and got to see interesting rituals and processions. The famed white heron dance too. The best word for the actual grounds would be: grand. Quite breathtaking if you're in the right frame of mind, but also nothing particular to shout about. Packed like crazy but seeing the traditions and customs is why I visited, and I got it in spades.The shopping street and stalls are mostly a tourist trap - although I do recommend getting some roasted sweet potatoes to snack on.

Japanese Temples are definitely beautiful . We visited the temple soon after visiting Tsukiji fish market... It consider quite 'on the way' via the train. We reached about 3 pm and there wasn't a big crowd.We were approached by the trishaw man. The cost is expensive to ride on for our family of 4. And we rejected.Walking on the Nakamise street is definitely fun. My girls age 7 and 10 were so busy running from left to right lanes to view the stuffs in the stalls. In fact, this is the most interesting street in Tokyo...Selling from Japanese slippers, toys, assorted Japanese snacks, kimono, accessories and souvenirs! I specially like a shop that sells souvenirs that are dogs related stuff... From calendar, bags, toys to cups... As for the temple, we were there to pay respect to Buddha. Be it nice or not nice at the exterior is sure not to be an issue...But it's big and beautiful... With lots of ginkgo leaves all over....It's a place with very strong Japanese culture and history!There is a shop selling Totoro items opposite the train station exit. And a shop selling sushi candies outside the station exit.

Must visit in Tokyo. Beautiful temple with an interesting street full of interesting shops where you can buy souvenir and snacks. Interesting building structure and a feeling of tranquility in the temple.

Interesting, but Meiji is much better. The street leading to the shrine, with its little shops was a bit of a disappointment to me. I thought that there was a lot of cheaply made knickknacks and too few quality, original stuff. The shrine itself was nice, but there are nicer ones.

Nice temple and streets with food, souvenirs to enjoy.. This place is crowded as usual always but with good foods and restaurants. Different type of souvenirs available.Try not to go this place when is raining as the open street is kinda narrow and it is hard to walk around when everyone is using umbrella. Do not miss the front big red lantern at the entrance, is the landmark of this temple area. For photographers, it will be a nice place to take many shots.

The Must See Temple in Tokyo. The temple you must see on any visit to Tokyo. Very old and ornate. Maintained beautifully. Also very busy every day and evening. Good selection of gift shops for the souvenir hunters.

gorgeous temple. so many people you can hardly move, but still worth the trip, especially if you have a few days in the city. i'd recommend visiting in the evening, when it's a little less crowded and the temple is lit up. the shopping street in front of the temple has lots of good street food and is the best place in tokyo to buy souvenirs.

Beautiful temple in Asakusa. Very beautiful and peaceful temple but way too crowded. We were lucky to stay in Asakusa hence can get up early to visit the temple late in the evening when its way more quiet. The walk through old streets of Asakusa is pretty nice too.

A Tokyo landmark. If you're spending time in Tokyo, this is worth seeing. It's huge red lanterns are unique for this temple. It can be crowded on weekends. Nearby is a Shinto Shrine and streets with souvenir shopping.

A must see in Tokyo. I can't imagine visiting Tokyo without visiting the Senso-ji Temple. A beautiful peaceful site although very crowded. A tip: you can walk to the Skyliner from Senso-ji. It was a 10-15 min. walk away.

Disneyland Temple. I have visited a number of Buddhist temples and shrines over the past few years, this was the first one I found to be a bit a big disappointment. It wasn't just that it was wall-to-wall people, it was that Senso-ji felt like a completely commercialized superficial theme park rather than having anything to do with Buddhism or having historical value. I couldn't wait to escape this site. I know that it costs money to maintain these beautiful buildings, but this experience felt all wrong. Very disappointing.

A well-known temple and always crowded.. Lots of shops to visit especial snacks and made-on-the-spot delicacies are all worth trying.DO NOT touch OR even bother to ask anything that you are not ready to buy. Stall vendors were heard telling tourists off and ask them to get out.We were chased out of a cafe too as the owner of the old oil-smelling cafe demanded all 3 of us to order his sandwich as we only called for a coffee-sandwich set and another 1 coffee. He claimed that he runs a Japanese cafe and its expensive, if we want cheap we should go to a McDonald's where we could sit there even without an order. There were a little fierce word-exchanges. It's a place to give businesses to, not for goodwill visitation like other temple.

Away from the bright lights of Tokyo. I would recommend this temple and the surrounding shrines for those whose trip is limited to Tokyo. The religious sites elsewhere in Japan are much more impressive, as Tokyo is more of a metro city. Still, the senso-ji area is very close to the metro line and in the vicinity of the skytree and waterboat area. Plus there are some markets for shopping and food afterwards. The place is pretty busy with tourists but all the little monuments and shrines get little attention. The markets go for a while but are pretty much filled with souvenir shops for the most part- the ones nearest to the main temple and along the side streets are filled with the more unique items.

Beautiful temple with a nice variety of shops . Very busy but well worth the journey. There are lots of stalls where you can get food and knick knacks. Just be ready for the barrage of people when going during the peak times.

Easily a full morning here. Not only is the temple easily accessible by Asakusa station, it has two main pedestrian roads leading up to it that we found to be the best in terms of buying a wide range of souvenirs- we also felt the rpices were great too. Most of us actually went back specifically to these roads to shop. The temple itself is beautiful, pay attention to the fountain on the side and the ceiling painting on the inside. Closer to the temple entry theres many food stalls, and though we tried most of the food there was nothing to rave about - probably save your stomach for a proper lunch nearby. There's plenty of vending machines and a area to sit with toilets on your right. There's also a road perpendicular to the temple which is enclosed and provides more bargain shopping & restaurants. Overall a good day spent in the area.
Loved it!. Sucha beautiful view at night with a pagoda nearby. There are small souvenir outlets and eatries by the temple.

Great Visit. This was among the first temples we visited in Japan. We liked the market walk before getting to the temple were we had the chance to buy many different Japanese souvenirs. Once we got to the temple we were happy to take some pictures, especially with some Japanese ladies wearing Kimono dresses. Overall a nice attraction if you happen to be in Tokyo. Recommended
Nice. Go on Saturday to see weddings.. The grounds were nice. The temple is good. The real highlight was the weddings that passed through ever 20 minutes or so.

Our First Temple and a Good One. This temple is beautiful, but also was incredibly crowded with tourists. We saw people getting their "fortune" from the drawers with the papers in them and we stopped to do that, that was a fun experience.

sensational temple. It was crowded but lively which made the temple a fun and interesting tourist attraction. The markets were filled with tantilising Japanese food and various souvenirs which captures the culture of Japan.

Too crowded . This is Tokyo's oldest temple. Super popular for both tourists and locals. It does get crowded so don't say you weren't warned. It's a very nice place to visit. A lot of food stalls and little souvenir shops along the way.

Beautiful, rich in heritage . This has got to be one of my favourite temples in Japan. Be sure to visit at night because the temple will be lit up beautifully. Also try the rice mochi on a stick with peanut powder and the hot rice wine for a quick tummy warmer as you make your way around. The stall is found at the Main Street of Sensoji.

Very Very packed. Lots of eating stall,shops at the road leading towards the temple area. Right before temple entrance, lots of souvenir shops, unique souvenirs to buy. There are trishaw for hire. We came in late November, the place was packed with many many people. Interesting to see devotees coming here to pay respects, make wishes etc.
Amazing temple!. The temple is located right outside of Asakusa station. The temple has beautiful traditional architect, various shrines around it and you will find various shops in front of it.
A must see; go early or late in the day. Sensoji will be on every Tokyo itinerary, but go early in the morning or in the evening after dark to experience it at its best.

Pretty busy spot, but the grounds are cool... Go on a nice day, walk around and look at the markets stalls. Some great souvenir-type shopping. the temple if huge, and the ground are nice to chill out at. The area itself is very cool. Wear comfortable shoes, and take an umbrella incase. Highly recommend.
Great experience. Kids were wowed by the huge statues and of course the gates! Wonderful shopping streets around the temple area

Busy day as it was a festive for children but beatiful place. Beautifully crafted temple with rows of stalls for tourist outside the temple.. there are shops that sell really nice foods and we too bought some souvenirs for memoir and gifts..

Sensoji temple in the night!. Sensoji temple, one of the most popular and famous teple in Tokyo, is lighted up at night. You can feel more spiritual atmosphere in the night. Becareful the temple is closed. But still it is so nice to have a little walk along the temple.

Must visit. If you were to visit just 1 temple in Tokyo, I suggest visiting Sensoji, Unlike the other temples I've visited before, Sensoji is the only temple with a pagoda. Also a plus are the shops outside the main gate. You'll get a taste of what Japan has to offer. Literally, as there are plenty of food stalls and shops lined outside the temple. You won't miss it as you get to pass them on your way in and out. I suggest going into the temple first before doing all your shopping so you won't be carrying anything while you're trying to savor everything the temple has to offer.

Well Kept. An admirable trait of the Japanese that even though that the place was bustling with tourists and worshipers, the surrounding and building is kept very well maintained. The surrounding is well kept and provide many photo opportunities for future memories. There are also variety of goods to cater to tourist. Take time to stroll and spend a lovely evening.

Beautiful setting with great gift shops. Beautifully kept gardens & well planned out site that is pretty easy to get to. Great variety of souvenir shops to choose from (I did about 90% of all my gift shopping in Japan here) & lots of lovely food stalls onsite + great variety of restaurants, kimono shops & bargain gift-ware shops surrounding the temple grounds.

Busy area full of little stalls. To get to the temple itself you pass through a myriad of small stalls selling everything you would want as a tourist - food, mementos etcNear the temple there is a billowing smoke "well" where you waft the smoke over you for god luck. Try the sticks in the container where you get a fortune paper based on the stick that comes out of the container. You might need a local person to find your number though.Also chuck some money in the prayer "wells"I didn't go into the temple. It does cost money and I wasn't sure what would be in there.It's not far to the Skytree from here which is where I went next. I walked it at around 20 minutes but you could go back to Asakusa station and travel from there.

Most impressive. What immediately caught our attention were the gigantic red lanterns hanging at both gates. The structures of both gates were awesome.Especially eye-catching was the 5-storey pagoda which stood a short distance from the Main Hall.A lot of smoke could be seen as crowds and crowds of people were making offerings of incense.We could clearly see the famous landmark of Skytree here.This is indeed a most historical and impressive site to visit.

Awesome temple - don't miss it. We LOVED Senso-ji Temple. From the sheer size, the energy, and the lovely smell of incense - it made for a memorable experience. Don't forget to check out the surrounding neighborhood for cute shops!

Magnificent . A truly magnificent temple area where one can easily spend two to three hours wandering the temple grounds and marveling at the architecture and religious rituals.It's well worth performing a bit of research on Senso Ji temple prior to arrival to enhance your visit especially if you are self guided as we were.The area is typically filled with large crowds which is not at all a problem. There are also large market areas leading to the temple

Great Temple in Tokyo, Probably best and Oldest too Visit. Great traditional Japanese Temple and Gardens in Tokyo with load of shops leading to the temple. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds. Also visit the temple at night time, as the light from the tempe is amazing ( and the crowd are not there ). A must see in Tokyo

Lovely temple, a gem to visit with lots of little shops to buy souvenirs and stalls of food. Best stall was the Taiyaki stall with hot pastries filled with red bean paste, and instead of fish, there were many different shapes, including turtles and temples. Piping hot and delicious! Prices at the shops were good and much better than Tokyo Central or the Airport. Try to go to the side street to look for the best bargains. Lovely temple and carps swimming in the pond makes it a relaxing and enjoyable trip. What's more Asakusa is so easy to get to, being the final stop on the Ginza line.

Magnificent Temple...filled with people praying, visiting, burning incense.. I never get tired of The Senso-jii Temple (also known as the Asakusa Kannon) still a much visited temple. Its been around since 628 AD but the building you see today was built in 1945. Has an interesting story. They say two fishermen brothers 'caught' a small gold statue of Kannon, the goddess of mercy and happiness. Then the temple was built in Kannon's honor. My son loves to get his 'fortune'. You will see little boxes on your right side as you approach and you will see people shaking the can and pulling out their fortune stick. Then you go to the drawer and pull out your fortune. Just put the 100 yen coin in first. The papers are in English as well and my son still has his fortune. :) What I love about the temple is MANY MANY people milling about..some Japanese women in full kimono dress. There are amazing statues and one time when we were there we came upon a big food festival with tons of food including chocolate dipped bananas! If you only have a short time in Tokyo you should make this your first destination I think. Also if you have a few days pick a day that isn't raining if that is possible and you will enjoy it more. The street leading up to it is filled with little fun shops by the way. All outdoor. If you go on a rainy day the side streets are covered Atriums so don't despair.

Go at Night for Stunning Lights . I went to Asakusa at around 5pm (shops start to close on the Nakamise shopping street at around 6) when the sun had gone down and all of the lights along Nakamise leading up to the Temple were vibrant. The atmosphere was relaxing and the Temple is a beautiful sight. The craftsmanship will have you in awe, and the surrounding gardens are worth exploring.The Five-Storied Pagoda is to the left of the Temple, and from the right you can see the Tokyo Skytree.

Crowded but worth the visit. It was so full of people , but i still enjoyed the visit. The temple complex is very huge so within the complex you will not feel the crowds. After visiting the inside of teh temple you can roam around the temple where the crowd sort of reduces and so you can spend some time by yourself in a quite a peaceful environment.The roads leading to the famous bell was packed with people, both sides of the street lined with small shops selling souvenirs, food and everything.

Lovely old temple in the middle of Asakusa. This temple is found at the end of Nakamise shopping street in the middle of Asakusa. Around the temple is a nice picturesque area with shrubs and plants. The temple is quite busy and there are lots of visitors.It is worth a visit here is you are coming to Asakusa.

Bustling experience with interesting buildings. Contrary to some of the reviews here, Senso-ji is neither a shrine nor Shinto. It is Tokyo's major Buddhist temple and as such a bustling melting pot of locals and tourists, and in complete contrast to the serenity and birdsong of Meiji-jingu. The first surprise on passing through the initial gate with its guardians either side is Nakamisedori, a street of shops on either side of the walkway! Much is tourist fodder but I bought a nice pair of birth year chopsticks (in fact, I bought rabbit because it looked nicer than my actual birth year animal, which involved convincing the vendor that that really was my birth year!).On the left as you approach the main temple building is a five-storey pagoda, which is worth a look, as well as observing the washing and incense rituals that the locals are observing. The main building is impressive, though not as attractive as some other temples within a day trip of Tokyo, such as at Nikko. Once there, I recommend taking a fortune by donating 100 ¥, shaking a stick from the metal containers and matching the number on the stick to the corresponding drawer, which will contain a paper fortune with English text as well as Japanese. On this visit, I had an excellent good fortune - on my first trip years ago I was advised not to travel in the near future!On leaving, I was met by a small group of school children who had clearly been tasked with asking questions of gaijin in English (though I did help with a bit of Japanese), who have me a small token of their appreciation when finished. Very sweet :)Don't go expecting a similar experience to a shrine - the very contrast is a big part of a visit to Senso-ji.

So much happening in here!. Lots of people coming in to shop, to pray, and to look around - it was bustling with so much life! Wasn't able to fully enjoy it, but overall it was a good place to tour around. There are some nice food and souvenir stalls you can buy from.

Visit during the day and night.. The temple is busy and crowded during the day but visitors should still visit to experience what's going on. Outside the temple are a variety of shops selling unique stuff and plenty of food that I was not familiar with but I just tried everything and they were all good! Loved all the mochi flavoues (green tea and black sesame). I also visited at night and there were only close to ten of us around. The temple was well lit and so is the neighbouring Tokyo Skytree, such a good sight for taking night puctures.

Go early or late ... but go!. If you can get here early in the morning (i.e., before 8 a.m. or so), you will love walking around the beautiful temples and shrines in this complex. It is quiet and serene, and you'll be one of only a few people at each stop. If you are staying in Asakusa (which I recommend), you'll also want to come here at night, as the lighting on the temple and pagoda creates a compelling atmosphere.If I could choose only one time, though, it would be early morning, because at that time you can read the interesting signage explaining some of the shrines. It's also a chance to see the temple wake, as crowds begin to arrive, light incense, and throng the entire complex. You can slip away for eating or shopping then, feeling that you've had a more private experience.

very crowded. there is small market where you can buy for Japanese souvenirs. here there are also many japanese man offering rickshaw ride around the asakusa area, worth to try, they are very nice also they will not make you to pay crazy price unlike in other tourist-crowded place.

A different kind of Tokyo. This is a very fun area around the temple. There are 4 temples, not just the Senso-ji. In between the temples is a touristy shopping area, which is a great place to get souvenirs and street food. There are places that you can perform traditional rituals, such as a cleansing ritual at a water fountain.

Lovely shrine in the heart of the city. Accompanied with a food and present market called Nakamise Street (a few things are a bit more expensive than less touristy areas).As a tourist it's a great photo op and place to to interact with traditions.

Very popular and crowded temple. It is a beatiful temple, however there are too many tourists visiting the place. Would advise people to come earlier before 10am to enjoy the peace and beauty of the place before it gets too crowded and touristy.
Interesting.. Try to go in evening too you will see the difference and not crowded too. If I'm not wrong they are closed t 10pm.(I am not sure).

Good cultural experience. We visited the temple twice, once on a Sunday morning and the second time during the weekday. It was much more crowded on the Sunday morning since this is when most Japanese residents visit the temple, however, the good thing is that there were more street-side food vendors out. Even on a weekday when the street side food vendors aren't out, though, there are many small shops and restaurants on the main pedestrian avenue leading to the temple, as well as the side streets around the temple.

Really Interesting. This is a beautiful temple. Quite large and a few gardens nearby are also quite lovely. If it were not for the masses of shoppers around it would be even nicer. You can even see the Tokyo Sky Tree from here.

Liked the water thing where you do it 3 times. Very old temple. It's bright with a shopping area beside it.I like the water fountain type of thing you take water with your right hand then your left then you drink it and make a wish, must see place
The oldest temple in tokyo. Its a must to visit this temple. The only one oldest n famous temple in tokyo. Plus you can shop japanese stuff on that area

1 of The Most Crowded Place in Tokyo. I don't know why tourists love this temple so much though. Perhaps due to the Nakamise Shopping Street in front of it. But it is pretty easy to reach via Tokyo Metro Subway. And from this temple, we can easily spot Tokyo Skytree from a close distance (not really closed by walking though).

Must see. I can now understand why Senso-Ji is one of the top tourist attractions in Tokyo. The sheer size of the temple, coupled with it’s bright red colour, make it a very impressive sight. The air of spirituality and mysticism is reinforced by the smell of burning incense and the sound of gentle chanting.Lots of interesting little shops and stalls on the way to/from the temple.A must see experience.

Very large Shinto temple with religious services offered. There is only one main building that is accessible to enter for religious services. It's quite busy with large number of tourists visiting the Asakusa market. The temple is located in one of the main shopping streets of the Asakusa market. There are several train lines that can take you to the Asakusa Station. Excellent place for "street photography".

Simple temple with good history. While this is said to be the largest in Tokyo, The temple is simple and seems to have a good story to tell. For this visit, I relied on what the Japanese din when they entered and stepped in.

Excellent touch of Japanese Culture. Went there as part of our trip to Asakusa and we're not disappointed. Our friend took us here and thankfully was there to teach us how to "cleanse" prior to praying. Lots of tourists and locals alike but we didn't expect anything less. Plenty of street food around too and we had udon at a local store as well as trying heaps of the sweets and delicacy stalls.

Great Temple. A beautiful temple that is super close to the G19 subway station. Would recommend it you're in the area. A line of cute shops lead you from the Main Street up to the temple gates. Try to come early to avoid all the tourists!
Magnificent site, a must while visiting Japan. The shrine is big and colorful, there are options to getting to this place by metro but there is some walking involved, recommended!

Spectacular at night!!. We visited just as the shops were closing for the night and the Temple was all lit up. There were only a few other visitors so we could really enjoy the views without the crowds. The kids had a ball looking at all the statues under lights and we got some fantastic photos with the sky tree lit up in the background too. I would definitely recommend you visit after dark for a very special experience!
Beautiful temple in the middle of Tokyo. Senso-Ji Temple is a beautiful and active Temple in the heart of Tokyo. It has a beautiful garden surrounding it.

A must visit Temple in Tokyo. I love the bright red colour of the temple ...walking along the crowded Nakamise street ...the 5 storey pagoda...and also the Japanese garden surrounding the temple.Definitely a must visit place if you visit Tokyo city. Don't forget to try out the traditional Japanese costume - Kimono.

Evening visit is even better!. Senso-ji Temple is definitely worth visiting but if you go during the day be prepared to fight your way through the crowds. We enjoyed the area much more in the evening once the stalls were closed and it was less crowded. The temple stays lit up until 11pm and looks really pretty.

Spoilt by the crowds. As one of the top attractions in Tokyo not just for travellers but also for locals, Senso-ji Temple suffers from it's own success. The masses of people making it difficult to take in the place and unfortunately some lack of respect for the sanctity of a temple. There are a number of side areas to the complex that make up in some small way but overall I was a little disappointed.
Bright, interesting complex. It wasn't at all busy on a Sunday night and we enjoyed the beautiful bright colours. A real pleasure to stroll around.

Impressive. Well worth its rating as one of THE things to see in Tokyo..but go early (before 9 am) to avoid the big crowds and tour groups or alternatively go late at night when the temple is illuminated for great photos.
Serene and beautiful. Approachable by JR line. A must visit temple. Vibrant colors. Do make prayer wishes here or burn incense for peace.

Exceptionally beautiful at night. As I stayed in a hostel in a street behind Sensoji, I always passed by on the way to and back from the underground station. It was overcrowded in mornings but very quiet at night. However, the buildings and gates are very beautiful lit during the night time. They are glowing with reds and yellows under the dark blue sky. Was really attracted to it that my boyfriend and I lingered longer one night just to capture great photographs for memories.
power spot energy spot of Tokyo. I reat that Asakusa is the power spot of Tokyo, you can get luck here. Many people and shops here.

Best introduction to Japan. This was the first place we visited in Japan and I can't think of a better starting point. It's really beautiful and there is plenty to do. You cleanse or wash your hands before entering the temple and for 100 yen you can light an incense stick and place it in the sand. You can also sample green tea (hot or cold) for free. Then you can check out the endless line of shops. I bought a little round character in traditional clothing of some description. He is cartoon-like with big eyes. You fill in one eye while you are thinking about a goal you want to achieve and then you fill in the other eye when you have achieved the goal which I thought was pretty cool.

Overcrowded at peak hours. Senso-ji is one of the most popular temples in Tokyo, so mostly it will be very crowded with tourists alike. I mean literally crowded. The complex is quite narrow and along the Nakamise-dori are shops of all kind before you reach the temple so it's packed with people almost every time. Get off the peak hours by visiting it before 10AM or in the evening.
Must see temple!!!. What a beautiful place to be also saw some Street performances, very fun. And when you finish you have a great market just outside!!

Vibrant, must visit!. We reached around 9 in the morning but there were already a number of tourists crowding in front of the Kaminarimon Gate taking pictures but shops at Nakamise were still closed. The Kaminarimon Gate is actually the entrance to Nakamise, which is a long vibrant street full of local delicacies and souvenirs! At the end of the street, you will find Japan's oldest temple; Sensoji Temple. The place was vibrant! try renting a kimono and riding a traditional rickshaw for a more authentic experience!
Love this temple. Good to visit in daylight or evening. Nice decorating, and good for picture taking. Must visit place when you're in Tokyo

Beautiful Temple!. One of the best temples in Japan. Loved the Japanese architecture. Very Peaceful Place. Lots of market side stalls too selling everything from food to souvenirs. P.S. Get a bit crowded.

JUST CAN SAY WOW. best temple i have ever been, so amazing, dont know use what words to descripe tokyo, i been here and picked up one "taji" letter , its the best in the temple, you must try your luck here to pick up the future letter for urself , haha

Interesting, and the market is fun. The area is so crowded it is hard to see all the details that would make it special, so that was disappointing. Worth seeing though, as it is so typically Japanese.

Beautiful . Beautiful temple minus the stupid foreigners who ignored the signs saying 'NO PHOTOGRAPHS'
Not only was it incredibly rude for them to be doing that, it was annoying as well while trying to pray

amazing japanese !. This was one of my favourite temples that I visited in Japan ! It was very busy but worth it! Don't miss the market side and the variety of shops specially beautifully lit up at night!

Good Place, Good Fortune. Make sure to try the Fortune Telling Paper. It cost 100 Yen (Donation), you pick up a random stick and that stick has a corresponding paper which tells your fortune. Awesome place to visit.

WHAT A MAJESTIC TEMPLE. Why wandering around, i got lost to the aid entrance of the temple. After finding and asking the native folks, finally i found the main entrance. The first impression in my mind was that this entrance had a big sandal. There were a lot of people here and always smelt scent of incenses. The temple's structure was very beautiful and looked peaceful as well.

Interesting place. As other temples around the world this is also a inspiring place. Not much explanation is giving in English unfortunately, maybe you should look around for a tour if you really would like to understand.

Best temple in Tokyo. Senso-ji was the temple which we liked best in Tokyo. We stumbled over it a little accidentally, but it was a very positive accident.This temple is really pretty and especially beautiful at night when it is lit up extremely nicely. It also offers views of the Tokyo Sky Tree, which is a great contrast between the traditional temple buildings and the modern tower in the background.
Temple Tokyo. Reaching the point entrance till the temple is always crowded especially during the weekend. Highly recommended to visit and offer prayer for more peace.

It's more like a 3.5 dot attraction.. It's worth a visit when also visiting the busy and fun Nakamise Dori (traditional shopping arcade/street) that leads into and out of this temple. But there are of course many other more beautiful temples to visit in Tokyo and Japan; such as the Meiji-jingu. So, going to see Senso-ji alone may not be worth the trip but spending a couple of hours in the area as a whole should definitely be on your Tokyo trip agenda. Oh, and you should time your trip, if you can, to visit when the Asakusa Samba Carnival festival is happening; I think it is in August. Couple of years ago I was there for it and by no means is it Rio but it is still fun to see.

Amazing. I have visited this temple 5-6 times so far, and I will surely be going back the next time I visit. Although the buildings aren't the originals a temple has stood here for hundreds and hundreds of years. It is a great bit of ancient Japan slap bang in the middle of Tokyo.

"Oldest Shrine in Tokyo, Visually Stunning. Visiting Is a Must.". In late 2010 I visited Sensō-Ji, the air was crisp and the trees were crimson and picturesque. The shops were filled with old-fashioned Japanese light snacks, toys and charming souvenirs. For a 100 Yen, you can have your fortune told! Really great place for people who enjoy Japanese culture and history.

Visit this temple in Asakusa if you are in Tokyo. This is Tokyo's oldest and most popular temple dating back to the early 600's AD.It is located in the Asakusa area. If you take the Sumida River cruise it is very close to access when you get off the boat. There are incense burners and a purification process for the Buddhist who flock to this temple to participate. It is interesting to watch them and then to stroll along the pedestrian lane lined with many shops (almost like a flea market) that leads to the temple. It provides an atmosphere of Old Tokyo to help balance the sights of newer Tokyo. We took several really nice photos of women in kimonos, children playing in the street, and other activities. It is well worth a visit.

Slow day of our trip. It was a shopping trip for us and we took a slow day to visit this temple, still feels touristy but there was plenty of local students on that day praying as well. Interesting stalls all around the temple and before going into the temple. Near the railway so getting there is easy.
Amazing. I suggest to go there and spend some hours to see how beautifiul everything is!The temple is breathtaking!

Oldest Temple in Japan just don't go on a Public Holiday !!!. Unbeknown to my wife and I the day we went to the Senso-Ji temple was a public holiday and if it is normally crowded well that day was a hoot !!. If you can get past the crowds which we did as we were not in a hurry it is well worth it.. Great markets surround the temple also..my wife and I loved it...
Must Visit. Sensoji Temple is the oldest temple in Japan so it is a must see. Your Tokyo pictures will be incomplete if you don't have a photo of the entrances and the pagodas of this temple.

Spritiually calm, practically not. Wonderful sight to visit, but as you would expect its overcome with tourists and the hustle of people takes away from the majesty of the temple.The actual shrine is serene and beautiful but the approach is manic due to the souvenir shops leading up to it, and the clammer for gifts.Located not far from Asakusa metro, right on the main road.Must do sight but you'll only need an hour or so, the SkyTree isn't far though for something abit more modern.
Most Visit in Tokyo!!. Senso-ji temple is a great place.most to visit in Tokyo, you can see/learn all about Japanese culture.

Worth the effort. Senso-ji Temple's location and the fact that it is Tokyo's oldest temple are reasons enough to visit. Humungous people numbers and many slowed us a bit but no issue if you allocate at least an hour to take it all in. Plenty of diverse shopping to be had as you wander towards the temple itself, I know some people have advised that it's overpriced but it's not that bad versus elsewhere and there is a huge variety of items.
Nice temple. Nice very popular temple but surroundings are more like a tourist trap. Nice tiny Japanese garden next to it.
The gift shops are very overpriced . There's a lot more space and serenity if you go to Meiji. Also, the gifts looked much more expensive than the average prices in Tokyo tourist spots.

Crowded all the time, but worth it!. This Temple is accessed thru a shopping street that is always filled with people: students on their way to and from school, locals wanting to visit the Temple, and tourists, lots of them. But don't be daunted. It's worth fighting the crowds. And then wander around and visit the quiet gardens and smaller shrines. You won't regret it.

Nice temple area. Lots of tourists here as expected, but still a very nice experience! Beautiful temple and very close to the Nakamise souvenir street and Kaminarimon Gate. Easily accessible only 3 minutes from the metro station. No admission fee, but leave a few coins as a donation.
Japan temple. Just what I expected from a Japanese temple. Lovely little shops and good luck games to be played. Be respectful and observe the religion. Worth a quick look for 30 mins to 1 hour max
One of the religious landmark in Tokyo. Senso-ji temple or asakusa is the popular temple for tourist who visit Tokyo. There are many many shops there for sourvenir items and food.

great experience. the markets that surround the temple are great...inside the temple you can pay a donation and recieve ur fortune card....while leaving senso-ji i spotted a sumo wrestler and was able to get my picture taken with him! :)

Colorful shrine and surrounding area. In a small area, there is a 5 story pagoda, the main shrine, also called Asakusa and two large "gates., as well as the area to wash/purify before entering the temple, and a spot to burn incense. " Between the two gates is the shopping street. It is a lively area,

Nighttime there to see lightened Karinamon and Pagoda. . Being there at nighttime nearly midnight, it was very safe and so less crowded as compared with many tourist selfieing, taking pictures on daytime. There was a contellation of rows of lanterns lighted up the darkness. Also, splendid picture of the big lantern at the Karinamon gate. I recommend you if you want someting different.
Amazing temple. This amazing temple is close to Nakamise shopping street & Kaminarimon Gate. Easy access from the Asakusa subway

Must go twice ! Day and Night !. Everyone knows its a must go in Tokyo. But I would stay go there twice !
Once in day time for shopping and food and come again at night for less crowd and take some great pics !

Great place to visit, gets busy after midday. If you're looking for a lovely temple to visit, this is it. It is a very touristy attraction though so can get quite busy. The location is great, it literally is right next door to the Asakusa train station. I love those little shops that lines the pathway leading to the temple. There are heaps that one can buy as presents or if you fancy trying some local street food, there are plenty to sample from. All and in all, it's a great place to visit!

Overcrowded. Always. There's many more beautiful temples all over Tokyo if you go for a walk, this ones great if you want to wait in line all day and be surrounded by hundreds of tourists. Would not recommend.

Tourist attraction that is touristy for a reason. Some tourist attractions are so gimmicky and not worth it due to crowds or being blown out of proportions, but Senso-ji deserves it's popularity. Senso-ji temple located in Asakusa, Tokyo is in one word a marvel. The story states that long ago in the year 628 two brothers had fished a statue of the goddess of mercy out of the Sumida river. Each time they put the statue back into the river somehow it would return to them. Sensoji was built for the goddess of mercy, Kannon. Being Tokyo’s oldest temple and just the sheer size of it make it a popular tourist destination. When you near the main building wash yourself with the incense smoke to gain good health. Towards the temple itself there is a gigantic paper lantern and I mean gigantic. You can also ask the oracle a question by offering a suggested donation of 100 yen. There are 100 possible drawers and your answer is retrieved from one of them. If you want a visual look check out the web series Japan VS by vahidrvahidr on youtube. If the temple wasn’t enough entertainment and/or you’re hungry there are hundreds of stalls that lead from the second temple gate to it’s outer gate. You’ll be able to get your food and souvenirs if you are so inclined. Have a great trip!
Gorgeous, very busy on weekends. Gorgeous temple with grand ceiling paintings. Large tourist attraction, very busy on weekends. Recommend going during the week.
Oldest TOKYO Temple. Nice Temple, this destination is so many tourist, so many people pray, and hope something that GOD will be bless they... its nice to see they culture...

Magical by night!. I'm staying quite close to the temple, which makes it easy to just walk up to the gate, pagode and temple! At night it's far more quiet than at daytime ( during which you should visit and stroll also) and there is just something magical about the setting! Makes you forget you're in a big city! Watch the locals come up to the Temple and throw coins in a "box" and say a small prayer!

True authentic Experience. Don't miss this. Make sure you have your fortune read and also use the incense pictured here to keep beautiful and healthy. I recommend having a tour guide to have the full low down on what you will be experiencing.

Peace in the middle of chaos. I went to visit Senso-ji Temple after my visit to Sky Tree Tower, and I found that it was all that I had hoped it would be. I walked up Nakamise Street past all the vendors and went straight to the temple.I made sure to purify myself before entering the temple and used the 5y coins with the holes in them for my donation to the temple. I bowed my head and said a short prayer and paid my respects to my ancestors.I was surprised that there were a lot of people at the temple at 10:00am in the morning. There were several groups of school kids on an excursion as well, and I followed them along to see what they were doing. One group had small coloring pads around their necks and their teacher would stop at several locations, give them a brief lecture and then the kids would make drawings of the item that they had just seen. Cool!!I also went down some of the side street from Nakamise Dori, and those side street are the best. I bought some rice crackers and some bean cake.to give to friends. Good Omiyage. I also ran across a film crew that was filming something for a Japanese program. They had blocked off a part of the street so I turned around and went back to Nakamise Dori. I wasn't too interested in that, since I don't know anyone in Japan TV or movies.I had a terrific time at both Senso-ji Temple and Nakamise Dori, and it was a good way to see an important blend of 21st century technology and older ways of life.
