Nice place to see culture... very crowded. I really enjoyed my visit, There were a lot of tourists everywhere but it was still a great place to see culture as there are also locals at the temples and a good place to see wearers of Kimono.

magnificent. What a fine building, it is impressive during the day as well as seen at night, when there are far fewer people about. There were little girls as well as adults, dressed up in ritual finery - they were breath-takingly beautiful, like a story-book come to life.

Oldest temple in Tokyo . This is a must see when you are in Tokyo. The temple is beautiful but always packed with tourists. The Nakamise-Dori is a good place to buy souvenirs related to the temple. It also had some delicious street food and snack. Traffic can be a pain as people try to go both directions and no one really follows the stay left rule... Don't forget to use the o-mikuji (with 100 yen donation) and find out answers to your inquiry by shaking a metal enclosure with sticks. With the number on the stick you acquire, you can find your fortune from 100 possible drawers!

Superb temple. Went on a Friday morning to the temple and arrived early 9 am well before the crowds which started to roll up at 10 am there are lots of small stalls here selling a variety of foods and souvenirs all at cheap prices I.e two leather belts for 1100 yen really good quality
Nice, but overcrowded. The Asakusa itself is horrible, but the temple and 5-story pagoda look great, although the crowd ruins the experience.

Beautiful yet a lot of tourist and crowded. Beautiful temple which is well worth a short visit. There are a lot of tourist here though. Walking from the station towards the temple there are a lot of shops. Right next to the Five-storied pagoda and quite close to Kappabashi dori.
Beautiful Temple. Beautiful temple with amazing architecture.A place to take in the culture - seeing locals praying etc...

Nighttime visit. Went here after 7pm and was able to enjoy the serenity of the place. We took the metro and walked through as the shops were closing. Can't recall if it was a weekday or a weekend but purposely came late to avoid the crowds. The temple was beautifully lit at night along with other temple buildings and even the Tokyo sky tree which we could see nearby.We brought a Combi stroller for our little one (almost 5 at the time) which proved to be a good choice, because he tired himself out running around with mum, as he slept in it on the commute back to our place. Will definitely come back to visit during daytime to see the contrast but a great sightseeing destination day or night!

Great taste of Japan. The temple and the area around it are (as many other reviews noted) packed with tourists and locals on most days. We found it to be a very fun walk, and enjoyed seeing the diverse crowd among the little stores. We had a few snacks, got our fortunes at the temple, and took all the obligatory pictures. It was a fun couple of hours, and definitely a recommended stop while in Tokyo!

Crowded but beautiful temple. It is always crowded as the temple is a popular tourist site. However that should not be the excuse to tick this spot off your must-visit sites. There are plenty of souvenir shops outside the temple too.
Amazing Temple & Thriving Market. The temple and surrounding area are bustling with activity and culture. Many locals visit the temple in traditional clothing making it a most interesting experience.
Family visit. Great place to go to get a real feel for Tokyo. Lots of tourists, mainly Japanese, but not too busy to enjoy the sights. Beautifully manicured gardens and a very interesting history
Go at night to avoid crowds and see the beautiful buildings. We went there twice a day as we were staying around the corner. So beautiful and read all the little signs on the monuments

Worth visiting!. Rows of souvenir and food shops which lead to the temple was a crazy, fun experience on its own. We tried some local snacks and were not disappointed. You can do your souvenir shopping here, there's lots on offer.The temple itself has a nice architecture and well maintained grounds, with the buildings recently constructed. For an enriching cultural experience, try the water cleansing, do the incense ritual of waving the smoke towards you, and try your luck with the paper fortunes.I especially liked the spot where you can see both the Tokyo Skytree and part of the temple, a juxtaposition of the old and new.Don't forget to check out what's under the Kaminarimon gate and inspect the giant sandals.
Asakusa. Absolutely gorgeous. Very old style Tokyo. Go early morning and get great pictures before the crowds arrive

Stilts recommended.. Fantastic architecture and stunning details, but so very crowded that it was difficult to appreciate the complex properly. A late evening visit next day was much better - the many shops lining the route to the main temple were closed of course but the illuminated shrines and pagoda were magical. Lots of food stalls dotted around during the day, but nowhere to sit and watch and eat - eating whilst walking around is NOT done!

Beautiful. Easily one of the best sights you can see in Tokyo. The temple is beautifully coloured and constructed. There are many statues, buildings etc. on the grounds to see and it is free! There's a market with great souvenirs and cheaply priced compared to the rest of the city (you wont't find good ones in 100yen stores and the oriental bizarre is a little more expensive). Very easily accessed by Asakusa station (3min walk to the gate). Would recommend anyone going to Tokyo to make this temple a priority.

Nice temple to see. This is a nice temple, quite busy but a nice vibe. If you are looking for something more relaxed and less crowded then Meiji shrine is great. The streets around the shrine are nice to look around.

One of the beautiful temples in Tokyo. This is one of the most famous temple in Tokyo. Almost all tourists come to Tokyo visit there. The attraction is free to visit and it is few meters away from Ginza line Asakusa Station. The buildings are very beautiful and when you are there you feel the elegance

Lovely shrine with lots to see, but full of tourists!. Great shrine with plenty to see and do. Top things to do: (1) spend 100yen to get a stick from a silver container - the number of the stick shows you which drawer to open and will tell you your fortune! Me and my boyfriend both for a bad fortunes so we tied it up with the others and asked for better luck next time!(2) buy some incense and add to the giant pot of incense. It'll make your clothes and hair smell for a few hours, but great part of the culture and apparently good for your health!(3) wash your hands/face with water from the fountainThe temple itself is lively and quite impressive, we also stumbled upon a plum wine festival around the corner. Look out for people dressed as ninjas and geishas! One more thing, I had some yakisoba from a food stalls just outside (I'm always wary of street vendors, but it smelt great and I'd not seen yakisoba advertised anywhere else yet!) and it was lovely. I'd ask for no shrimps if I had it again though (they're dried and put on top, as they smelt quite strong I avoided that third of the noodles!!)

Beautiful Temple and nice place to Visit. I went to Japan for the first time, so i decided to go to Asakusa to see Senso-Ji temple.Its really beautiful, large historical building. Very crowded, mostly tourist. If you would like to buy some souvenirs then this is the place.Place is full of shops with different Japanese souvenirs from Japanese doll to rice crackers, nice experience. Good place to shop for souvenirs.Best thing is its very near to Asakusa station (may be 2-5 mins walk).

Such an amzing zen spot...PLUS GREAT Souvenirs!!. So last March My friend and I visited JApan for the first time.We stayed in Asasuka and absolutely loved it. We rented an apartment off Airbnb and the first place we visited was the Senso-ji temple. Such an amazing spot, so much to see and buy. One of the only places we found with souvenirs actually. The surrounding area has great food and shops. They even have a starbucks accros the street. I have two videos on my you tube page. " j lito diaz'.You can check them out to get some ideas of where to go and what to expect.

Crowded modern temple . After looking at the near by attractions from our hostel me and two friends decided to go to the sensoji temple.However expectations fell short when we got to the temple, I had a much older building in mind when it was described to me but what we have here is different: 80% tourist trap and 20% modern working temple, catering to the needs of the local community with blessings and good luck charms etc. No sense of atmosphere but still large powerful buildings with a spiritual connection. If you have an extra hour in your day stop by. If you have put it on your must see list, take it off.

One of a billion shrines in Japan. This is just another shrine in Japan. Yes, it is old and you can get your fortune told here and yes there is an interesting array of stalls leading up to it, but it is only worth a short visit. Dont waste any money on tour guides or the like.

historical landmark in Asakusa. very nice historic site for visitors who re interested in ancient history and life for native people. I would recommend going there before sunset to shop around the local street stalls for souvenir and local products. After sunset you can enjoy the illuminated temple. There are nice restaurants around the area which visitors can try after see the temple. my favourite place is the 100 year old tempura placebo

Beautiful. The temple is beautiful. There are a lot of people there but it totally worth it. They have fortunes you pay 100 yen and shake a box and then the stick that you pick has a symbol on it. You find the symbol on the cabinets and get your fortune. It's very easy and a fun way to experience Japanese culture. There are also a ton of little stalls with souvenirs and food.

A total MUST see for your first time Japan visit. This is a total must see for the first time visitor. Actually I still go here everytime. The restaurants and shopping area around the Sensoji Temple are fantastic. Also it's so easy to get to from anywhere in Tokyo.

Come here in the late afternoon to enjoy both the day and night scene. Quite an interesting place, with lots of things to see and do. There are many shops there selling souvenirs and snacks, gardens, and also the main temple to give offerings and pray. There is also an impressive pagoda here, but pity it is not accessible by the public. The night view here is a totally different scene - highly recommended if you visit here in the late afternoon. Just stay, have dinner, and go back here for the night scenes of the shrine and pagoda.

amazing ,awesome temple with the surrounding atmosphere.. As i walk in the area lots of shop with people every where, gave me awesome feeling after watching the big lantern hanging upright with a lovely wonderful bright blue sky makes a amazing day. must not miss it when you are in tokyo.

Be early to avoid the crowds. Enjoyed my visit here as we were really early. Shops has not opened it so it was so peaceful and we got to enjoy the temple. Lots of things to see here and the street food is amazing. By 10-11am, the place starts to be packed so be really early.
Lovely temple. This temple is a must see in Tokyo. Lots of people but definitely worth a visit!! Very close to Asakusa metro station!
Nice temple. I love the atmosphere here.The crowds and the shops along the streets selling souvenirs and food.Definitely love the food.

Cool and interesting. This temple is a mix of all the different temple I went to. It had cool statues, well maintained, and actual monks praying... However it is very busy so don't expect a peaceful experience. There is a fortune telling thing where you shake a box and take a stick, then find the matching number and get a fortune. It is good fun, cheap and the fortunes have English translations on them. If you get a bad fortune, you tie it on the rack and get another one. The temple is easy to find, it's at the other end of the shopping street to the gate house, which is also cool.
Nice place to visit . Great to visit as easy to walk around. There are lots of little stalls for some nice bits to buy for souvenir. Area is busy but feels very safe.

Busy Senso-Ji Temple . Be prepared as its extremely crowded and noisy. The main shopping street before the temple is okay though very pricey. I found the surrounded areas were much better.My memory from this visit is being lured into a shop to try a Japanese sweet bread. Awesome! And for only 200 yen. A must if your a foodie traveller.
Great food market. Really enjoyed walking around there streets. Some great places to eat and everyone was really friendly
Nice enough temple. We were in the area so visited the temple - nice but maybe not the trip there for only seeing the temple. Meiji is more worth a specific visit.

INTERESTING TRADITIONAL TEMPLE. You enter the precinct through a traditional gate and then walk down a long street lined both sides with gift and food shops to reach the temple proper which is still considered a holy place, lots of people praying. Many Japanese visitors in traditional costumes.Well worth a visit for souvenir shopping

Superb temple complex in Tokyo. This is a wonderful temple complex in one of Tokyo's more traditional areas. You will probably experience it by entering through the Kaminarimon (thunder gate) and walking up to Senso-ji (the main hondo) via the traditional shopping street Nakamise-dori. However, don't be tempted to think that's it - have a walk around the rest of the complex, especially early in the morning, and admire the beautiful gardens, smaller temples and shrines and various other elements. It is also quite magical in the evening.
Very interesting. Senso-ji can be really crowded but it is normal. Do your prayer following the instructions. Get your amulettes for luckiest.

must do in tokyo. this temple is 5 min walk from asakusa station it is a great place to buy souvenirs, it is very crowded on weekends however on weekdays is so much better to visit it not to many people.

Busy temple. This temple locate in the central city. It easy get there. It is very crown. Before you walk into the temple, you have to go through the shopping street. In these shopping street, you can find out a lot japanese food, and other little stuff, it is good for gifts to bring back home.

Beautiful and crowded. This is a gorgeous temple, well worth a visit. We were there on a Sunday and it was crazy busy. So busy in fact that we missed out on most of the shopping area leading up to the temple. To be honest though, the crowds are often part of the experience in Japan. As authentic as it gets!

Extremaly crowded. Senso-ji Temple is one of the most popular temples in Tokyo. During weekend is extremaly crowded so it's better to visit it during the week. You could also foreseen your future for only 100 yen and if you choose bad faith you shoul left piece of paper on the rack.Nearby are many gift shops, some of them offer nice stuff for resonable prices.

Gorgeous and simply breathtaking.. Words can't explain how amazing it is to go see Senso-ji and walk around it. I recommend a visit both at day time and night time. Senso-ji is absolutely breathtaking.

Visually-striking; crowded, heavy in incense. This is a very lively temple. It was very crowded when we went, and the burning incense was overwhelming for some members of our group, but the view from far enough away was quite striking, and the Asakusa area was fun to visit.

Worth a visit. This temple was a pretty cool place to see. Quite crowded, but as to be expected for any tourist attraction in Tokyo. Personally, I loved all the shops throughout the area offering authentic Japanese souvenirs. In the temple itself, you can have your fortune revealed. Definitely worth checking out.
super good. The temple is really big and pretty. A big market in front of it and nice foods and drinks. I would definitely go here

Lots of people so be prepared. Nice shrine but there were so many people you could hardly walk. I would definitely recommend visiting but the people can be a bit much and keep track of your little ones. If you plan on shopping be prepared to squeeze, bump, and fight your way in. Also please be respectful of the no photo signs. I saw so many taking pictures when you were not suppose to and that is disrespectful of the culture, the shop owners, and people worshiping.
Found Yatai Here. yes i searched all over Tokyo for a Yatai, which is Hawker in Japanese Version. Usually they sell food. And here i found one that serve Takoyaki for 500 yen

Must see and visit. Beatiful buddhist temple dated from the 7th century and located in Asakusa (at the end of an interesting shopping street). 2 large entrance gates are leading you to the temple who is surrounded by nice and quiet gardens. Even though there is always a lot of visitors, you can perceive an impression of quietness in this environment.

Great to see but VERY busy temple complex (on many tourists routes). As a tourist it's best to check out the special days when you can expect the complex to be overflowing with japanese visitors. Some of the special significance days can be really terribbile and the place is packed to the limits with people wanting to make an offer at the temple. The rows of shops in the surrouding area are very touristy and oftern quite expensive. sometimes it pays to walk about 100 metres away from the main arcade area and wander into some of the smaller side streets with little shops that are often overlooked, here you can find some nice little bargains and the shopkeepers are less stressed than in the overflowing torurist area. But great place been here a couple of times and the atmosphere is hectic but friendly.

Beautiful Temple. Like most of the Shinto/Buddhist temples in Japan, it is worth seeing - especially to experience the practitioners. The area around is a bit obnoxious and busy, but once you get inside it's worth it.You'll see lots of westerners ignoring the signs that say no pictures. Please don't be one of these that disrespects the customs and traditions of the locals.

Well Worth Seeing. We were on one of those dreaded bus tours from Yokohama (cruise port), with only enough time to get a glimpse of the important sights in Tokyo; glad this was one of the places we got to see. The architecture of the temple, the gates and all the shops was very interesting. The Japanese are so quiet, respectful and interested in the tourists who come to their country. The grounds around the temple were so clean - no garbage anywhere - in fact we were told that you are expected to take your garbage with you and dispose of it at home. There isn't any paper towel in the washrooms as people carry a handkerchief with them to dry their hands.

Good place to pray. I always come to Sensoji to pray and get a Omikuji. Very big temple with shops along the Nakamise leading to the temple. Goddess worshipped in this temple is Goddess of Mercy. May be a bit commercialized but overall, it`s worth the visit. =)

A must see. easy to get to on the subway. Packed with tourists but still worth a few hours, some of the souvenir shops actually sell some tasteful stuff (and some dont!!) . Walk down to the river, snap a few photos and hop on a boat ride for 1000 yen, good fun for a break from walking around.

Worth Seeing. What a great temple, with wonderful fun to look in shops that line the street as you enter the temple grounds. We were there around lunchtime and it was busy but not crazy. With so many things to stimulate allyour senses it is definitely worth a visit. If you like taking photographs you'll love this place.

Definitely worth a visit.. Bright and interesting temple complex, definitely worth a visit while in Tokyo. Our young children enjoyed the spectacle although it was quite crowded, but away from the main part, in the morning about 9am when we were there it was still peaceful in the outer sections. If your looking at shopping, not many shops were ope at this time on a Monday.

Too many people, for non japan traveler not a must in Tokio. I think this temple is attractive just for japan travelers. Many people there , lots of shops but the real peaceful atmosphere like in other temples is missing for sure i would recommend more Meiji Jingu ! I visited Senso-ji just because it was close to my hotel.

Big, free entrance. Well, its a temple which is very big.. Got lots of gate.. In front got the big Kaminarimon gate.. According to our rickshaw driver, this gate burned down and the only gate that is still original is the one at the back which used by king and high rank people back in the past.. Anyway, free entrance.. Very popular so got lots of people.. In centre of Asakusa..

the reflection of Japan traditional culture. If you want experience the Japan traditional culture, it's a appropriate destination. Although there are too much tourists, the shop still maintain their own style, preventing too much commercialize or let tourists feel too boring, you can taste the food and prey in the temple for good luck. moreover, the cart driver coachman looks handsome although they work under the sunshine, they still smile and passionate with people, it's a wonderful view that worth to recommend.如果你想要感受傳統文化的東京,淺草寺是一個直到造訪的地方,店鋪維持自身的風格不讓你覺得過度商業化,此外,人力拉車夫是一到不錯的風景,即便在烈陽下工作,他們依然保持親切熱情有禮的態度,這很難得。

Travelling with a 5 year old – tips for first timers. At Asakusa station, follow the signs for the Kaminarimon Gate exit (A3).Avoid holidays. We were there in Silver Week in September. The crowd was so huge that we were pushed along. We didn’t even bother going near the temple. We went back another day when it was not a holiday.Our son enjoyed sniffing the incense, pouring the water over his hands to purify them, and the fortune sticks (100 yen, you shake the silver metal cylinder until a stick comes out and then match the symbol on the stick with the fortune paper in the drawer. If it’s bad luck, you tie it on the nearby strings.) There are clean toilets a short walk to the right of the temple.The markets have a good range of souvenirs and gifts. This is good if your time is limited and you won’t have time to shop. However I found bags that I bought at the temple were 100 yen cheaper at the Hello Kitty store, and erasers were cheaper in the stationery and toy shops at Ginza. Wander into the side streets and you may see people making rice crackers and sweets. There are some great photo opportunities.You’ll most likely see ladies in kimonos while wandering around the temple. When we asked, they were happy to pose for photos with our son. We took some souvenirs from home (fluffy koala and kangaroo key rings) and gave these to them as a token – which they seemed to really appreciate.There is a small children’s playground near the Temple – to the right of it (not far from the toilets) but heading back towards the Kaminarimon gate. We didn’t find many playgrounds in Tokyo, so even though it is a bit drab, our son really appreciated being in a playground.A bit further along from the Temple, we enjoyed delicious treats from The Custard Lab (in the same street as the Rox building) – one of the yummiest things I ate in Japan! There is a rabbit café (“With Bunny”) and a bird café within the vicinity of the temple, if this is your thing.

A must see attraction in Tokyo. Just visited Tokyo last week and this would be the must-visit-attraction for those who plans to visit Tokyo. The temple is so crowded with visitors either buying souvenirs from the street located before entering the temple or people giving their prayers at the temple. Love the architecture and colours of this temple. For those who hunts for souvenirs like me, this will be a great place for you to get handful of souvenirs from food to their local products like chopsticks. A point to note-temple and shops close at 6pm.

Colorful and fun; a must see in Tokyo. We came here just for the market, and then found out that there is a big temple area too. First about the market area.It is one of the best places to buy your Japan related souvenirs. Seriously, if you are looking for something that tells you that "yeah, I've been to Japan" you will find it here. There are dozens of small shops here, all selling their unique or not-so-unique wares, mostly at a friendly price. The sellers speak the basic English, at least at the places we have been to. We didn't try to bargain, but maybe you can; it's up to You to find that out. Also, look for the shop where you can do a buy 5 shirts get 1 free for a really low price, absolutely worth it!About the temple(s):This temple was the people's back in the days, it was free for them to visit, and nowadays it stood true to this philosophy. You can get in for free, get a good look around, and just chill. We are not that into religion, still found it to be really pleasant.To sum it up: visit this place if you are in Tokyo!
A must-see. Be sure to check out the shops on the same street and there is also a fun fair ground just around the corner.

Must see and experience while in Japan. This place is very easy to reach via rail and the path to the temple is a long road with hundreds of vendor lining the street. If you can't find the gift for your loved ones back home on this street, they're super picky! Lot's of great food to eat on the way to the temple as well as all the neat photo opportunities, in particular a lot of people like taking a shot of themselves under the giant red lantern at the first gate.Once at the temple cleanse yourself and partake in the burning incense, then head into the temple for some prayers and test your luck with the fortunes!Mine was terrible at all the shrines I went to but I actually got a decent fortune here... your luck may vary :)Overall great experience, tons of people and opportunities to take photos. Recommended!

Picturesque but crowded . A touristy spot so don't count on getting a photo without someone photobombing(intentionally or not). You might be able to catch people in traditional costumes too. Once done at the Shrine, head to the shopping area nearby to buy souvenirs, food and others.

The largest temple complex in Tokyo. Living just behind the temple, I walk through the temple grounds nearly every morning on my way to work.It is historical but has been rebuilt a few times. It was burnt down during WW2 and rebuilt. The latest major renovation was completed in 2013. The temple opens at 7AM with the sound of monks beating the drums and chanting. This is the best time to visit the temple. By 8.30 AM it becomes very crowded. The temple doors close at 6PM daily, except in the New Year period.Photo opportunities abound but please take time to walk around. There are 7 temple and shrines in the same complex. Large and small. All have a historical background.One isolated spot has a few wooden lanterns (2m tall) that are original. Well worth a look.Allow at least 2 to 3 hours if you are a temple buff, there is a lot to see besides the usual tourist shops.We enjoy living near the temple although the rapidly increasing tourist traffic does create congestion on public transport.

Beautiful Buddhist temple in the middle of Tokyo. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. It was originally a wooden structure but has been burned down a few times and was last rebuilt using modern fire resisting materials. The gates are bedecked with huge red-paper lanterns. And it has a street with many souvenir shops and restaurants inside its grounds.
Tourist spots. A good tourist attraction in Tokyo. Full with tourists and locals. That was a great fun to mingle around.

Old Tokyo. Spectacular temple in Old Tokyo, this is a very interesting area, one of the most interesting areas, we visited in Tokyo, highly recommend, there is so much to see and do in this area, so visit the temple and then explore.

Busy Senso-ji Temple. Beautiful structure in a very busy part of the city at the end of Nakamise shopping street. Take your patience and a smile with you, stroll with the crowds instead of battling them, and enjoy the beautiful buildings.

Spectacular Temple.. This is a popular area, great for souvenir shopping and trying local foods. Enter through the Kaminarimon Gate and walk along Nakamise - dori to the main hall. Along the way, remember to waft smoke over you, from the huge incense burner, to keep you healthy. We enjoyed the rickshaw ride from Senso-ji to Skytree.

Crowded Senso-ji Temple. Senso-ji Temple is a must place to visit whenever you are in Asakusa area. The place is very famous and well expect large number of crowds visitng the temple as there are also shops in the area, perfect for souvenir shopping.
Traditionnal temple. This temple is great, very well situated near the river, many streets with little traditionnal or modern shops, a lot of restaurants, and all public transportations needed.
Must See. Most visited Shrine, very peaceful with nice gardens & small shops selling souvenirs & traditional Japanese goods - best place to buy rice crackers !!
Lovely temple and surrounds. This temple is lovely, ensure you go to the tranquil, small gardens to the West (left facing the temple) for the best view of the temple.

Busy during the day, empty at night. This is a great spot to visit in Tokyo. Lots of people and very busy during the day, but if you'd like a more calm and reflective visit, try going at night. We visited around 8 and it was virtually empty and quiet. There's also a great gyukatsu place across the street from Kaminarimon Gate!

Charming and characteristic site. I really enjoyed seeing the Sensoji Temple. I came via the Asakusa metro stop which sent me through the market area just south of the temple. I went at night (~7pm), and although the interior was closed, the grounds are still accessible and were actually pretty crowded. The lighting gave the buildings charm and vibrancy I'm not sure they would have in the day. There are several other shrines in the surrounding grounds as well. Definitely worth a stop.
Worth a visit. Touristy for sure, but still worth a visit. Beautiful temple and grounds surrounded by shops, restaurants, etc.

Beautiful temple but oh the people. Beautiful temple and pagoda. Unfortunately surrounded by a multitude of commercialization; and the masses of people. We had the pleasure of witnessing a marriage procession. The surrounding shops, neighborhoods, and alleyways stagger the imagination and are in and of themselves worth the effort. However if you are looking for a quiet spiritual moment; will probably not happen here. still loved it for the expierience.

Senso-ji Temple. Have been to Senso-ji Temple couple of times - the first time in the morning and second time in the evening. Yet another great temple in Tokyo. Worth visit. Lot of options for photography as well. There is a shopping street as well just outside the temple with a variety of food options. A great place to visit..
Very Crowded but still Beautiful. VERY CROWDED--even in the rain. There is a lot of open space though and the buildings are huge so no matter how many people anyone can enjoy the views.

Must-see Tokyo. This is a great stop for anybody visiting Tokyo - one of the essential sights or temples that should be on everybody's itinerary. That's why it's better to visit in the morning when there aren't a huge amount of tourists about and you can enjoy some peace and quiet at lease. Sometimes the inner temple is closed off for private ceremonies. But there is a lovely small garden to the left of the main temple to explore. Although things will be closed, it is still accessible in the evening and makes for some great night-time photography.

凶を良く引く（笑）　Fun! but Why I cannot pick <Luck> of Oracle. Every time I visit Sensoji temple, always pick <poor luck> or less when I challenge Oracle.Anyway! Sensoji is one of famous sightseeing points of Tokyo or even Japan.On the street in front of main hall, there are many shops for sweets, cakes, souvenirs, food stalls like baked chickens ( so called Yakitori).Foreigner must visit there then you cannot say ` I went to TOKYO`
Brilliant place to visit. It is a large open religious place in Japan connected to a long shopping street. It is the perfect photo opportunity and draws crowds from tourists to even local Japanese.
sensoji temple. it better to go at the morning if you want to take a picture but there are not much of store open at the morning.

Amazing place and early morning / late evening alot quieter. Our Hotel, Richmond Hotel overlooked this area so we walked through this area many times during the day/night and it was magnificent every time. With the adjoining stalls during the day can get very busy and night time or early morning brought more a sense of calm to this lovely temple and adjoining Shinto shrine. By the incense burner pay 100 yen to see if you pull out a lucky stick to bring good fortune, if you do get a bad luck one you can always tie it up nearby and leave it behind !
Very Nice experience of the temple. Nice traditions..you live in a very ancien culture of Japanese religion. nice architecture and stunning temples. take loads of Photos. and drink the water.

Lit up at night. A nice looking temple that attracts large crowds. I went toward night time and there weren't too many people. The temple looks nice illuminated and has a bunch of shops that lead up to it.

A special place. Whilst not hundreds of years old the Temple is still worth a look as it embodies everything we imagine about Japanese Temples.Accept the huge crowds and soak up the atmosphere.The free tour provided by the Tourist Centre is well worth taking.
One of the bext sights in Tokyo. A really attractive temple and gardens, all free to access and in a great shopping area. Lots of Japanese come here, it's notjust westerners.
Really love the culture. easily access because nearby metro station and JR station. near enough from Tokyo Sky Tree and have a lot of shopping district (Nakamise Street)
nice visit!!. the path to the temple is filled with shops selling food items as well as souvenirs n restaurants.the gardens around are nice as well.must visit i would say. truly Japanese experience!!

It's ok, 90 min visit enough. It's obviously a place of importance and prayer and a must see when visiting Tokyo. But 90 minutes is enough. Easily accessible by nearby train. Some really nice food and souvenirs can be purchased, and there is a little shopping district just 200m from the Temple. Half day visit is to the area is appropriate. If go late in the afternoon 3pm, can also do the SkyTower which is close enough to walk to.
Quite disappointing. Too much of a tourist spot and the commercially driven atmosphere blemishes the historical and cultral significance of the temple. Quite disappointing afterall.

Beautiful setting and neighborhood . The temple is located after a path filled with street food and lovely souvenirs. The place is always bustling with people, so get there early if you want to take good photos. I was there at 8 and it was just me and 20 more people.
Great area in Tokyo. The temple and its surrounding area is a great place to visit and to base yourself for a Tokyo vacation.

A great temple, both in size and beauty. A great temple, litterally. The two gates you can walk throu (the thunder god gate furthest from the temple and the second gate (cant remember its name right now) at the end of the procession path up to the temple, are both huge!Very beautiful buildings and a true sight if you want to see something very japanese! The sheer size of the temple building is with your time imo.Good to know:There are always alot of people visiting, bu thats some of its charm imo.There are many shops leading up to the main gate, but thats as it should be and has been for a long time.

Go early to miss the crowds.. Enjoyed the walk up to the temple with all the little shops. I didn't understand how to do the shaking of the coins for a wish and there wasn't any real explanation. However it was a beautiful temple ( although a rather recent reconstruction) and there was a service going on which added some drama.

Nice to visit. Buddhist temple with a pagoda nearby! It is usually very crowded so, you don't get as great sense of the place as at Meiji shrine but we still liked it! There is a also a small shopping lane where you can get japanese baked goods - highly recommend - Ningyo yaki - red bean stuffed confectionary! If you are adventurous, you can even get a green tea ice cream! Let's just say I would eat Ningyo-yaki ANY TIME!

Best visiting later in the evening. Really nice temple.during the day it could be crowded, but when you reach the actual temple, you'll be pleased to find it very peaceful. During the evening, take a compact tripod and your camera with a wide lens. You'll be rewarded with very nice pictures Enjoy! And take your time Please notice that it's not allowed to take pictures inside the temple

Nice temple in tokyo. One nice temple to visit in Tokyo, with plenty of souvenir shops outside leading to it. Relatively central though there are
Of course nicer temples in my opinion outside Tokyo, eg Kyoto but if you are just visiting Tokyo and want to visit some temples, this is definitely a good choice

Take time to explore streets and gardens around temple. The temple is great, but the streets around it are just as atmospheric - and packed with small cafés and restaurants for lunch. The seeet shops in the area are also purveyors of high art. Make time to see it all.

Crowded must see in Tokyo.. Senso-Ji is gorgeous, but it is super crowded which kind of takes of the magic.
It's definately a must see in Tokyo, and the history of this temple is interesting.
But I prefer the Meiji Shrine in yoyogi park.
Very nice temple, little bit crowded. Beautiful temple, close to the station. Lots of nice little shops on the way to the temple. It's a little bit crowded though.

landmark in Tokyo. This is one of the main temples in Tokyo. It's busy all the time which adds to the ambience. The walkway to the temple is full of stalls of food and souvenirs. The temple itself is huge and photogenic. Overall a must see while in Tokyo. The area around is also worth a stroll. Nearby is the Asahi building - also known as the one with the golden turd on top.

Beautiful historic temple!. Sensoji is the most popular temple in tokyo- and its for a reason!! It is big, beautiful and seeped in history. The street leading upto the temple is lined with shops offering some nice souveniers. The main temple complex itself is huge with lots of different building. Overall a must- visit in tokyo!!

A Good Visit when in the Area. While the temples I've visited in Kyoto and elsewhere on previous trips to Japan were far better and less crowded than this one, I still thought it was worth it to make it a stop on my walking tour of the area. I had fun walking down the shopping street to the temple, and lighting some incense at the big metal urn, before paying my respects at the temple itself. I won't say that this would be the sole reason for visiting Asakusa, but as part of an itinerary for seeing other sights... Yes, it's worth a stop, especially for the nearby Kagetsudo Bakery.

A must visit in Tokyo. Only a short walk away from Asakusa station. This is a must visit for everyone staying in Tokyo! A lot of good food, temples and gift shops in the area. It tends to be extemwly crowded during the weekends so I would recommend going during the week if possible. The best part is that it's free. So Just Do It! (Shia reference)

The biggest Buddhist temple in Tokyo. I love this temple, I've been there twice and the spirituality is dense even if the crowd of tourists may affect your perception.A wide entrance through the Kaminarimon-dori the major door to the Temple will project you in a commercial path a sort of sacred market where you can find all sort of typical japanese sweets and cakes, typical fan , kimono & souvenir shops.Finally you'll enter the second door , Nakamise -dori to be surrounded by devoted dressed up in traditional kimonos and Yukata. sacred incense altar will project you in a cloud of sacred smoke protecting you against sickness. The temple built in 7th century has been restored in the sixties, probably too perfectly colored ;-). A huge priest sandal hanging on the main door protect the walkers in their path. I had my Holy temple book signed with japanese calligraphy. Take the time to visit it if you are in Tokyo!
Beautiful at night. I visited once at in the day and once at night. The night is less crowded and I feel more historic looking due to the lights reflecting on the temples.

Nice but not spectacular - witness traditional weddings on Sundays.. This temple is a 10-15min slightly uphill walk from the nearest subway station through a forest. If you go in summer then you may want to bring mosquito repellant. You may also want to use GPS or get a map of the area as you will not immediately see signs pointing to the walkway to the temple. We were there on a Sunday and witnessed part of a traditional wedding. Some parts of the temple were off limits and I don't know if this was due to the wedding. Long story short: It is a nice but not spectacular temple but worth a visit.

Nice Temple and Good taste snacks. The temple is free of charge, so it's a good budget option if you can manage not to buy souvenirs! the walkway leading to the main hall is along with souvenir shops and restaurants. there are definitely a lot of touristy items, there are also unique items to be found in many of the stores

great place surrounded by souvenir shop and food stall. This place is good for travelers who love Japan HeritageYou can also buy some souvenir at souvenir shop around the shrineDon't forget to buy some food. I tried banana that covered by chocolate. That's so fun !
Very busy. Very busy temple with thousands of tourists. Very commercial entrance with lots of stalls selling souvenir crap. Much better temples and shrines in kyoto

Worth a visit... 1) it will be more meaningful if u rent a yukata/kimono and go around this area to take pictures. They have nice view of gardens and temple here for u to take picture. You can get reasonable & cheaper price at the shop near the exit of train after u reach asakusa. The shop will be across the street if u see the rickshaw puller when u reach asakusa,ginza line. 2) also can do some shopping for souvenir but its expensive here.3) must buy taiyaki (fish cake) with flavours (full cream is the best..!!)
Fab temple with plenty to see and do nearby. The temple was very busy when we arrived. But still a worthy place to visit as it gives you a great insight into Japanese culture.

Temple with a character. This is the oldest Buddhist temple in Tokyo and a significant one too. The street leading to the temple is filled with shops selling food and souvenirs. The temple is bustling with people offering prayers or just taking in the views. Sensoji Temple is not far from Asakusa Station and after visiting the temple, one can enjoy a meal at either one of the famous tempura or okonomiyaki restaurants nearby.

Beautiful Place. I went here by myself during my adventures around Tokyo and I really loved it, the temple is beautiful but very crowded so be aware if you are traveling with a family.It is easily accessible by public transport and really well signed from the train station. I actually stumbled across the temple as I was shopping in the Markets outside, there is so much to see and do you can spend half a day here! I highly recommend it.

Temple, Food and Shop. Whenever I'm in Tokyo I always find a time to visit this temple.Not only they have a beautiful garden surrounding but they also have so many shops along the way and you will find lots of interesting Japanesse goods and food.

AMAZING!!. Amazing Buddhist temple, very crowded during the day. It's not that hard of a walk from the Asakusa station if you google it first to ensure you're going the right direction you can simple go forward through the little dinning area and you'll run right into it it's that massive. Beautiful sight to see, amazing photo opportunities. Bought two bracelets from the shop and was able to pull my fortune, I'm glad it was good but if you get a bad fortune you're suppose to tie it and leave it there on the side. The hardest part was remembering the characters to match up to get my fortune, make sure you take a picture of the fortune because you have to put the stick back after you pull it so others can have a turn. Best temple I was able to see in my 10 days in Japan, would definitely go back!!!
Time to pray.. Senso-ji is the biggest temple in Tokyo and probably the most famous one as well. Totally recommend a visit and a walk through it's gardens.

Ancient temple. I visited this temple in July. The temple is historical and has an amazing feel about it. However, the path to the temple is packed with shoppers as it has shops on either side of the road. The shops sell food, souvenirs and other things of interest to shoppers.
Must see. This is one of the best temples I saw in Tokyo. It was so beautiful just to walk around and see the grounds.

A Fantastic Spot. Wound up in Tokyo for a day and 1/2 of sightseeing and this was right around the corner from my hotel. The grounds are beautiful and the difference between the crowded daytime and the empty nighttime make it entirely worth it to go twice. There is actually a a lot to see as long as you are interested in the culture and reading about the various statuary and gardens. Busy with several peaceful spots.

Senso-ji Temple. Beautiful temple and peaceful place after you pass the crouded streets with lots of shops. You just have to see the inner beauty of the temple, it cannot be described, at least not by me!There ard lots of shops for gifts and Japanese food. Depending on your interest, the temple can be seen in an hour or you can spend half day walking around the shops. Take your camera with a wide angle lens.
Beautiful . Beautiful temple in a beautiful area. A must see in Tokyo. We were there in winter and it was still packed with people but it was a great atmosphere.

Spectacular. This is without any doubt one of the best temples in Tokyo city. First recomendation: go early in the morning, and by early I mean 7.00 - 7.30 being there. You will be able to enjoy the surroundings without people almost and leave the small shops around by the end of the visit.To start, take some time to admire the different gates and move around the main building to the gardens and the pagoda. After that go for the main building that is as impressive as any picture you may have seen.Visiting the temple is free, you will only pay if you want to use any of the services such as the wishes or praying.Worth the visit, highly recommend the place

Beautiful, mesmerizing... if crowded. Senso-ji is probably the best temple in Tokyo - and people know it. Expect stunningly crafted buildings, beautiful cherry trees, a soaring pagoda, ponds, bridges. However, also expect what feels like half of Tokyo to be there. Funnily enough, I didn't find it to be bothersome though. As long as you keep an eye on your travel companions the crowds are perfectly fine and don't steal any of the magic. In fact, if you know nothing of buddhism, they can be fascinating to watch. How they pray, the offerings they make and which buildings draw the most attention. Either way, go visit. It should not be missed. The surrounding area is also full of shops and restaurants.

Wonderful...that is all.. Been here 4 times and cannot get enough.Sure, there are, what feels like millions of people there, but that's easy to forget about when you're in a place that is simply magical.Once you enter through the front gate, you'll find yourself on a street with loads of shops selling prints, bells, kokeshi (japanese dolls), lucky cats, kimonos, swords and pretty much anything else you can imagine. There's also a bunch of places selling street food.The next thing you'll see is the beautiful pagoda on the left and the main temple building itself with insense filling the air, right in front. Easily reached via the Ginza Line or even by water.

Nice vibe. Take a guided tour . Really enjoyed our time here. Look at the entry on here for the Asakusa Cultural Centre for details on how of a weekend to get on a free walking tour! Really made our time here much better!

Best temple and shrine to visit in Japan, great area. A great shrine at the end of walking along to Akasuka, well worth the walk and worth making a donation at the end, one of the best shrine and temple combos in Japan in my opinion.
Beautiful Senso-Ji temple. This is nice shrine, one of the oldesT & still in service. The surrounding of the shrine busy because of the vendor outlets. This is an must visit location when in tokyo.

Beautiful Temple that Easy to Walk Around and Get To. Lovely temple that's still used heavily by locals and visited by tourists alike. The grounds are beautiful and lush, though not too big. The surrounding neighborhood also offers a lot to eat and shop at so it's easy to plan a full day in the Asakusa area anchored around the Senso-ji Temple. The temple itself has enough interesting pockets but is not so overwhelming that you will get tired of seeing too much or walking long distances.

Sensible Senso-ji. Get your luck by shaking a heavy tin can and reveal a number on a chopstick. Match the number to the pigeon holes and pull out your luck. Humility is the request either reading a lucky paper or otherwise. Brightly painted and updated. Say a prayer and light an incense. Hey, you've traveled this far.
i will be back one day. very busy place to visit but worth the trip, spend time in the temples, shopping or eating.. say a prayer or receive a blessing.

Bustling Temple With a Lot to See. We got to the Kaminarmon gate which itself is an impressive structure. Being a Saturday, it was super crowded here, especially on the walk up to the temple. But once we made it through the Nakamise area with shops and food stands, there are plenty of smaller shrines and areas to explore. We picked our way through the area and sampled some tasty street food, including teriyaki crab on a stick and chocolate-covered bananas. We were never quite sure where we were “allowed” to eat or not. Never saw many Japanese folks eating on the go. Especially when you buy food from a street vendor, you would think that it would be acceptable to eat it there on the street. Nobody ever said anything to us, but there were a few signs in the area that food needed to be consumed at the establishment where it was purchased. Just be aware as to not offend, I guess.

Be there earlier to avoid crowds. Too touristy, too many people, if you like a quieter atmosphere, be sure to be there early in the morning before 9am so that you can enjoy the temple ambient with a relaxing mood.
Worth visiting. Famous temple worth to visit as it is quite spectacular. I guess it can be pretty crowded sometimes, but you still want to see that famous gate with lantern and 5-story pagoda

A Good temple . Well it's a temple, expect everything to be expected from a temple. Not much different from other temples I've visited. Unique shopping street along the road, but mostly sells souvenir which I'm not interested in, would be more interested if they sold street snacks. Overall good but nothing much impressive compared to other temples.

Must visit. I really love going to temples and historical places thus I love traveling. This one is a prepared itinerary for my family. Well, you can start educating your kids why do we have to visit this kind of place and things going. The architecture is awesome and pleasant. Well,definitely religious. You can try to burn incense and the fortune telling.Plus,don't forget your photo ops for to capture your moments.

One of my favorite places. I loved it. There's a market with souvenirs and different kinds of food leading up to the temple. It's a lot of fun to go around, and the temple itself is impressive, in my opinion. Overall, it was a great way to spend a few hours.

Great Shopping area - more to do than you realise - walk more find more. I mainly like the shopping around it - it is fun and busy and full of life - there are some great quirky shops in the arcades nearby and it is easy to keep walking and finding more.

One of the Must- See Temples in Tokyo. This was the second time we visited this temple and we were just as impressed!Located in the historic Asakusa district of Tokyo, this temple attracts foreign and Japanese tourists alike and was just as busy when we had visited previously in Winter. Like most other major Similar and temples in Japan, there is a long path leading up to the entrance which is lined by souvenir and food shops ( most of which are expensive). The most interesting sight is the ritual performed by the large numbers of local visitors, who all buy incense to place into the large incense pot, purify themselves in its smoke and then go up to into the temple to pray.
OK. So crowded. Not really that special when you have visited more temples. But would be a shame to not go to.

Great temple with many opps to blend in!. Don t be put off by the many tourist shops leading to the temple, they re cheesy but are good fun to buy cheap souvenirs that will make your friends / family crack a smile - just! The temple itself gives the worshipper and the western tourist to share similar rituals. Healthy smoke and purification rituals... You ll see when you ge there. The temple is also massive and nicely decorated. On the side is featured a nice pagoda although not as nice as the one in Kyoto but all the temple buildings together form a harmonized ensemble. Stayed there for an hour and it rained!
History and future of Japanese architecture at one place. At Senso-ji you can see beautiful Japanese historic architecture with the SkyTree as the future of architecture in the background.

A colourful shrine if a bit busy. This is one of the top 10 attractions in Tokyo and therefore expect it to be a bit crowded (even after dark). You can get a great elevated view from the tourist information building across the road from the entrance.
quite like it. beautiful temple this is the main place you have to go if you visit tokyo surrounding with many gift and souvenir shop

Crowded But Worth It!. If you are visiting Tokyo, this is a must do. While it can be crowded, the stunning architecture is worth it. Its amazing to see traditional architecture in the middle of a gigantic-ultramodern city. at the right spot, you can see the 5 story pagoda and the Tokyo Skytree!Plenty of vendors, and plenty of side streets adjacent to explore.Being a popular destination, it is very easy to get to. My only regret is I didnt stop by at night!

A spectacular temple to visit at night. While this place gets very crowded in the morning, try to visit it at night. You will get a spectacular view of the temple, flooded with amazing lights. Combined with the breathtaking view of the skytree by night at the background will make the night visit to the temple is unforgettable. The downside of visiting the place at night is that all the souvenir shops are closed. But we actually wanted to visit the tmple anyway. Not the shops :)
Stop by at Night. Sensoji is very beautiful and peaceful and night. Also no crowd! I recommend checking the night view at least once.
Super pretty. This temple is amazing to see! the inside is so pretty and the area is full of traditional things to see. We went as a young family and everyone enjoyed it

Japanese Buddhism. There are always tourist all the time. Here you can experience the Buddhism and it's different from Taiwan and China. Only the respect of god is the same:) You can make a wish and try a lucky draw to see what's god's direction.

Spiritual, energizing and tranquil...a must see.. My family and I took a the Tokyo subway from Daimon station to Asakusa station. It was about a 15 minute or less walk from the Asakusa station to the entrance to the temple. Upon entering the temple, you could feel it's spiritual nature. The place felt very serene. Very peaceful and calming. There are quite a few sites to see in and around the temple grounds. You can also purchase beaded bracelets that have the name of the temple (Senso-ji) inscribed in kanji. They cost anywhere from $8-16 USD. I believe the proceeds go towards maintaining the temple. Well worth it in my opinion. You will see an interesting fountain shrine that has water flowing out of it. People are seen washing their hands and also drinking the water. People were also seen burning what seemed to be white sage and saying a prayer. Then they would put the sage in a pot of sand. (See the pictures) Once you are finished walking around the temple and the ground, you can head out the back exit and you will see a street lined on both sides with food and souvenir vendors. There were a lot of yummy snacks to be had as well as souvenirs to be bought. I sampled a few of the sweets and my family bought some things to take home. No one pressured you to buy anything. That is not the Japanese culture. It was a very nice time. I hope to visit the temple again one day. This is truly a must see if you are visiting Tokyo.Positives:EverythingNegatives:NothingWould see again?:Absolutely, without a doubt.Thinks to remember:Lots of walking and bring an umbrella. The weather can be unpredictable. Bring a bag to carry any sweets or souvenirs.

A true place of beauty and tradition. You can't leave Tokyo without visiting the Senso-ji Temple !.A big, beautiful temple with beautiful gardens all around it.A true favourite of any local or visitor and as soon as you go there you'll clearly see why so many people love this place.A great place to see and learn about the history and culture of Japan and the Japanese people, but you can also see andvisit the latest addition to Tokyo's sightseeing hot spots" Sky Tree " which is only a very short train ride away.

Juxtaposition. Sensouji temple is amazing. There are shops along the way where you can buy yukatas and some souvenirs. We also spotted cute Japanese ladies in yukata every now and then near the temple. Also, the Skytree is visible from the temple. So, it is like a juxtaposition of old and new, of tradition and globalization, and of preservation and development. We strongly recommend to visit there.

Outstanding cultural landmark. Senso-ji is one of the few ancient temples that survived both the great fire of Tokyo, and the U.S. Fire bombing of WWII. U.S. Forces deliberately avoided cultural icons. You can take in Senso-ji and Meiji jingu on the same day. If you plan to take in several temples get a stamp book and have someone write in the temple name next to the stamp. It's woth the time and makes for great memories. Cheap eats are everywhere in Japan. Unless your budget is unlimited, stay at a Pension, Ryokan, or even a love hotel for real cultural experiences.

Beautiful, relaxing and cultured.. I visited here alone and it was a breathtaking experience. The old architecture was a wonder and awe-inspiring. There was a long pathway of market on the walk to Senso-ji where you could buy traditional Japanese street food, trinkets and kimonos (I bought one because I couldn't leave Japan without one!) My experience here was one to never forget. You can also see a fantastic view of the SkyTree nearby at some locations around the temple.

Feeling the Culture. Japan truly is an amazing place because of its culture, from lanterns, to temples, and everything. One of the nice places to visit is the Senso-ji Temple because it makes you truly feel that you are in Japan.

Popular crowded temple. Senso-ji temple is easily accesible via Asakusa station exit 1 or 2. The walkway to the temple is recognisable by the outer gate (Kaminarimon) and the crowd. Pass this, and the walkway passes through a long line of stalls selling Japanese handicrafts, sweets, biscuits, clothing, accessories etc before leading up to the inner gate and Senso-ji. Well preserved temple with many worshippers and prayers. Fortune-telling stalls are located on either side in the main temple grounds.

One of a handful of must-see temples/shrines in Tokyo. Located in the historic Asakusa district of Tokyo, this temple attracts foreign and Japanese tourists alike. Similar to all the other shrines and temples in Japan, there is a "shopping mall" on the streets that lead up to the temple. Lots of fun and tacky tchotchkes along with shops selling expensive Japanese items. Also, plenty of food booths though they tend to be expensive. So, buy some incense, purify yourself in its smoke, go up to into the temple, throw a few yen into the offering box, bow twice times, clap twice, bow one last time, and leave, knowing all your prayers will be answered!

Senso-Ji. Great temple. Its great to see something traditional in modern Tokyo and this gives you a little taste that's still very much on the tourist's path. Yah its touristy with people offering rickshaw rides and what not but its still a must see
Attractive. Clean and beautifulThe instructions are in Japanese. Perhaps there can be volunteer guides to help the tourists

Must visit. While shopping seems to dominate the area, Sensoji is a temple that has worshippers praying, lighting incense, checking their fortunes. Even non Japanese speakers can check their fortune because the sheet has an English translation. There is a park where visitors can seek refuge from the heat (it was almost 40 when I visited) and noise.

Old Temple in the middle of the city. Sensoji temple area is pretty spacious. In the morning you could see local people coming here to pray. I would say Kinkakuji is prettier, but I think its merely tourist destination. Here at Sensoji you could stroll around to see local people ritual.Its not a magnificent temple. But its huge and somewhat peaceful.

An impressive, if crowded, temple.. Senso-ji is surely the most crowded temple in the Tokyo area. It is very impressive, with multiple structures and shrines in the complex. On the way into the temple you pass through a crowded warren of stalls selling all matter of Japanese traditional items, from food to clothing. At one of the outer buildings you can get a beautiful calligraphy memento of the your visit.

A Popular Temple + Shopping Area Must Visit in Tokyo. Sensoji Temple, which also known as the oldest Buddhist Temple in Tokyo, is a popular spot to visit when you're in Tokyo. We have visited this spot two times in the last two years, and never bored of it. The Kaminarimon Gate (Thunder Gate) still looks attractive with its giant lantern that's hanging on the gate. Once you enter through the gate, you'll find (perhaps) hundreds of stalls or shops that sells cute and traditional Japanese souvenirs, including desserts and snacks as well. As you walked through the Nakamise Shopping Street, you'll reach the Sensoji Temple. The admission fee is FREE, but the temple only opens from 6 am until 17:00. You can check my website for full stories and more pictures of this lovely spot in Asakusa, Tokyo.

Very interesting temple. This is an interesting temple on the grounds of the Asakusa shopping area. The Japanese like to buy incense and burn it outside the temple. I am not sure how much incense costs but there is a place to buy it right outside so anyone can do it.

You can spend an entire day - lovely!. The temple is amazing. Outside in the forecourt is an area where you can have your fortune read. You are given a little piece of paper with the reading - very memorable. The temple is beautiful. The surround gardens are peaceful and very well maintained for the volume of people that go around the gardens.Make sure you have several hours to explo9re.

Must go!. Just a block away from Asakusa subway station. Hundreds of stalls of souvenirs. Toilets / place to sit and rest under the trees / ramps and lifts for prams / vending machines with refreshments - good place to visit for parents with kids. Really beautiful.

Sensoji Temple. Wonderful place, buzzing with local shops selling kimono, novelty items, food etc etc. Dont forget to know you future from here. There is also a pleasant boat cruise nearby a must do activity to explore the city

Great Cultural Experience in Tokyo. A cool and exciting temple in Tokyo surrounded by a vast shopping and food market. Beautiful temple which was fun to watch all the people worshipping, praying, eating, laughing and taking pictures. Lots of typical restaurants in the area and a big market selling souvenirs and other trinkets to locals and tourists alike.

Peaceful, beautiful, busy Temple. Yes it is busy and yes lots of tourists…but that tells you how popular it is. As you approach the Old Gate to the temple - more an arch really you will see a massive lantern hanging from it. Beyond that is the gauntlet of little shops as you look directly past the shops to this wonderful temple at the end. The shops are a mixture of traditional souvenirs and quirky. Try the Red Bean pancake and green tea ice-cream. The temple at the end is visually stunning. Make sure you follow the rituals of washing your hands and placing incense in the big urn and waving the smoke in your direction for good luck. After the temple wonder around the extensive grounds with many smaller temples which are not so crowded. Absorb the peace and respect the people who come to pray.
Cultural - great place to visit. Great place - must go while in Tokyo! Our two small children enjoyed their time here as well! It does get crowded but nothing that makes you not want to visit!

Beautiful location in the center of Tokyo. This was an absolutely amazing place to visit! Beautiful architecture, authentic cultural streets, there is really too much to say about this place. Although its really crowded, you have to visit this place! Kiosks everywhere selling traditional goodies to eat or bring home, delicious restaurants down side streets so you'll never go hungry, but most importantly a refreshing temple adventure. The gates alone are absolutely huge and in well kept condition. The temple was too beautiful and pristine and you could just see the hard work that went into this cultural attraction. It really is amazing and I just can't properly put into words how great of a trip this was for me.

Very crowded and a bit too rowdy. We didn't visit at night time when the lights are on but during the middle of the day when it is hottest (and busiest?). It was very crowded and seems very anti-Japan in terms of how you normally picture temples. Very much the complete opposite of a Zen feeling, a lot of burning incense and loud tourists.

The Secret Temple. On our first night stroll through Taito, Tokyo we more or less stumbled across Senso-ji Temple around midnight. We were walking down the Main road surrounded by shops, restaurants, hotels and other buildings when we found a nicely plastered street that we decided to follow. Midst in all the city jungle arose this great Temple and we were completely in awe. We didn't really go back during the day but being there late that night was very special hence there were no other tourists around and the place was absolutely peaceful. So in my view it's more enjoyable to visit by nigh.

A great temple to visit when in Tokyo!. My husband and I looked forward to visiting temples while in Tokyo, and Senso-Ji was on the top of our list.Senso-Ji temple has a large market set up in front of it filled with treats for all of the senses. Here you can buy all the kitchy Thunder Gate or Beckoning Cat magnets or key chains you want while munching on some local goodies. The temple itself swarms with people of all ages and many nationalities. Many are there for their prayers while others are there to experience this culture for the first time. Off to the side, you can pay 100 Yen in order to receive your fortune. While my husband and I were there we were stopped by a group of school children trying to complete an assignment. They had to interview us in English and write down our answers. We then took a picture together. As an English teacher, I found this whole interaction a lot of fun and a great way for these kids to work on a second language. I also appreciated the bravery it took for them to approach strangers who spoke another language and work on their own second language. My husband and I enjoyed this cultural experience and would happily stop by again the next time we're in Tokyo.

Nice Temple..... Tokyo's oldest temple its one of the biggest center of pilgrimage within the city and a nice visit for the tourists that wants to get involved with the japanese buddhist traditions. The big set up of small shops before the shrine and all the small food outlets there are a great introduction to the temple. The temple itself dates from the year 628 and its immaculate with beautifully maintain pagodas and halls. Try to imitate some of the locals traditions and buy some of the signs and local papers that they buy for good luck (its also a great souvenir). Mandatory visit for sure...
Center of Tokyo. A nice temple tucked away in the center of tokyo. Definitely worth a visit once when visiting Tokyo.

Nice cultural heritage attraction. Be sure to come early as tour busses begin to pile in quickly. It is hard to walk around when it is crowded there are so many shops and street food to pick from that you will truly enjoy your visit here

Worth the 1st Visit. A beautiful temple that is worth a visit if it's your first visit to Tokyo. But be prepared for the crowd as there are busloads of people coming here every hour. You won't be able to capture a shot or selfie without someone appearing in your photos. Visit on a weekday when there are much less people. I managed to capture a shot of the main gate in the evening when the crowd was gone. The stalls lining the path towards the main shrine are filled with the usual travel souvenirs and local snacks. After a visit to the temple, try exploring the alleys on both sides of the temple. There are plenty of snack shops and restaurants here. One particular one I like is a shop on the east side of the temple, selling Taiyaki, a Japanese fish-shaped cake that is filled with sweet red-bean paste. This shop offers other flavors but my favourite was the peach one. These are freshly baked and the shop is very generous with the fillings. This is the best I had from all those I had tried while in Tokyo. Worth a try!

A central area in Tokyo and the oldest temple site. The Senso-Ji Temple is in a major area in Tokyo. It was originally founded in 628 but the current version was built in 1692 to be fireproof. The story says that 2 fisherman brothers found a golden statue of the goddess Kannon in their nets. At the moment of discovery a golden dragon danced from heaven to earth. The 2 inch statue is enshrined here and each spring and fall a golden Dragon dance is held here. Throngs of people come to pray in this area and to walk the gardens. You enter and exit through the gates but the entire complex of temples and shrines and gardens is within a very small area of the city. Be prepared for crowds and go early.
Among the top 10 things to do in Tokyo. Many tourist only stop for photo-ops at the front. Go past the famous entrance and walk through the shops on the way to the temple.
Busy but worth it!. Visited during the afternoon and it was very busy. Definitely worth it though, especially with Asakusa market being so close by too.
A place to visit. Place plenty of life! Shops of all kinds with good prices to buy souvenirs, a huge lantern, one of the tallest pagodas and a temple. Really worth a visit!

OLDEST TEMPLE IN TOKYO. What a magnificent experience visiting this the oldest temple in Tokyo, with a history going back to 628 when two brothers found the statue of Kannon in their net while fishing in the Sumida River. The head of there village then turned his home into a small temple so people could come and pray to Kannon and as they say the rest is history. Now 30 million visitors a year come to visit this lovely Buddhist temple. It is worth the while to read it's history. When you walk through the grand entry with the huge red and black lantern hanging in the centre you are confronted with Nakamise Dori [street], this street lead you up to the temple which will take you a while not only because of the crowd of people but because the shops on either side of the street are soo interesting you will want to look in all of them. They have been here for generations selling to the visitors since pilgrims walked from all over Japan and beyond to worship to Kannon. You can just about buy any gift you want here and so many food places selling really traditional Japanese food. This is an amazing area and lots of fun.When you finally get to the temple you will be impressed, this place had the support of the Shogun from way back in the Kamakura period to the Edo Era so became wealthy and became the centre of Edo culture. There are lots of nice statues about the grounds and a lovely five story pagoda, it is all very imposing and colourful, one takes a lot of photos. You must visit this very historical temple when you are in Tokyo.

Dwelling to the past. If you are the type of person who enjoys the silence and dwell to the temple aura, go here by early morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds. Just made the right decision to stay in the Asakusa area during my Tokyo visit and pass this temple every day. Never get bored as it seems that I found different new angle everytime I see it.

Busy & Fun. It was a mass of people moving as one flow like a school of fish up river, that's how it felt as we moved around Asakusa on festival day. Saying that it was brilliant as everyone was in a joyous mood and the number of people in traditional costume made it all look so colourful. The temple was one of the places everyone went to at the end of a long row of market stalls. Being Buddhist there were the differences to be kept from the Shinto temples we'd visited so we had to be careful. It is a grand old temple and well worth a look and the 'party' atmosphere made it all the more pleasurable.

Don't forget to waft..... Apparent!y if you wave the smoke from the incense burner at the entrance to them shrine over yourself it will bring you luck. Certainly starting our visit to Japan here was lucky- this is a bustling and startling shrine, which looks beautiful and is very accessible, being right at the end of the souvenir street stalls. Use the water ladles to clean first your left then right hand, then rinse your mouth out. And don't take any pictures at the actual shrine itself. Just enjoy the commotion and get hurling coins to call! Down the gods.

Peaceful even when crowded. The entire complex is a treat but the temple itself offers a moment of solitude in spite of crowds. Take a moment to relax in the temple - light an incense stick and find solitude in the crowd.
The balcony offers a great photo opportunities with the temple structure and lanterns. Our young kids were enthralled with the temple atmosphere.

Busy but worthwhile to see. Senso-ji is one of the oldest temples in Tokyo, and is incredible to see up close. Arrive early as it does get busier during the day. Remember to cleanse your hands before you go inside! Apart from the wonderful architecture and beautifully maintained grounds, there's also the option (for 100 yen) to find out your fortune - which is a very popular activity amongst visitors and locals. Nearby Senso-ji there are an abundance of food vendors and gift shops. Definitely worth a visit if your time in Tokyo is short.

Oldest temple in Japan with a twist of souvenirs. This was a must see for me and it didn't disappoint. There were lots of visitors when we went but due to the extremely hot weather it wasn't as crowded as I've seen posted. To get here from the station is a little confusing as there are lots of streets that branch off. Luckily we found a fellow tourist who guided us. It's a short walk and you walk thru tons of little shops to purchase food products or souvenirs. Take your time and look at each vendor. They sell similar items so purchase it after you come out of the temple so you won't have to carry it with you, The temple is amazing and provides lots of opportunity for photo ops and to receive blessings by water (do not drink directly from the scooper...you dip the scooper in the water and pour it over the hand you will drink from then you pour water into your hand to drink...never put your lips to the scooper), smoke from incense (stand near it and wave the smoke over you), and you can also purchase amulets or fortunes, too. Definitely check out the large slippers that hang on the shrine. These are handmade and change about once every twenty years and replaced. Just a beautiful place to view and enjoy treats.

A Good Tourist Attraction. cool experience if you haven't seen one of these ancient temples. Took the subway and it wasn't too hard to get to at all. As soon as we exited the subway, the entrance to the temple is a block away. Bear in mind when I say entrance, it's a long entrance line up with stores. The stores are interesting. It has souvenirs and even umbrellas for sudden downpours.

Amazing. First of all, be ready with your camera to capture the place. You can try their fortune telling or wishing area before praying. On the way here, you will find different types of stores selling array if goods from breads to kimonos, key chains, shirts and others

Renovated Oldest Tokyo Temple - Highly Commercialized. SensoJi Temple and surrounding buildings appears to be modern and well kept place. It has been renovated since World War II and the worshippers and the tourists packed the temple grounds and the great number of adjacent rows of commercialized stores are just outside the temple grounds and catered for tourists.We've visited this place on Wednesday but there were so many people there that we often bumped into each other.Many signs describing the buildings and artifacts are in Japanese, Chinese, Korean, and English. Recommend taking time and educate on various aspects of this beautiful temple.The main attractions are the large temple building but I found there are more interesting facts and artifacts surrounding the building which most of the tourists were overlooking. There are many great photo opportunities.

Amazing during the day when they have the markets & wonderful at night. On the day we came they have a whole bunch of markets selling all kinds of wares including food. There's heaps of people about and you can see the different parts of the temple. At night, it's much quieter and you can appreciate the surrounds, especially with the lights creating an interesting aura.

Lovely place!! . Sensoji temple is a lovely place but crowded with tourists. It's a good place to spend sometime taking in the wonderful energy of the temple. Be sure to get your fortune from the boxes kept outside the temple. There are lots of lovely souvenir shops lining the main gate.
very touristic place. go there to watch the crowd of tourist and feel authentic atmosphere. visit small souveneer shops and enjoy little Japanese snacks on the way
The Oldest Temple. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. Don't forget to cleanse yourself with the water and long handled cup. This is sacred ground so be respectful.
