Stunning Architecture. A rebuilt memorable shrine with stunning red architecture and lanterns, lovely to behold. When in Asakusa, it is a worthwhile visit. And when in Tokyo, Asakusa is a must. There is a huge incense burner just before the main hall. Many people seem to be practicing their faith and it felt very spiritual. The inner hall is somewhat dark which makes it difficult to see. Well worth a visit.

Traditional Temple, worth a trip. If this is your first trip to a Far East Asian country then you should definitely go to Senso-ji temple. It is a very nice temple with typical architecture. Try to go at a time when it is less crowded, so that you get a good opportunity to take some snaps.

Tokyo at its historical best. The Senso Ji in Asakusa is one of the oldest temples in Tokyo, and worth visiting at any time of the day and year. I visited on a humid and hot day when Nakamise Dori, the medieval shopping street leading to the temple, was bursting at the seams. Although the temple is closed at night, one can walk around the gardens and the buildings. In spring the area is bright with sakura (cherry blossoms), and it is reputed to be beautiful even in winter.The main temple contains a reproduction of the Kannon (Chinese: Guanyin; Indian: Avalokiteshwara) statue which, according to legend and paintings in the Nakamise Dori, was fished up from the sea and established here in the early medieval period. The original cannot be viewed. The coffers in the ceiling have five beautiful paintings. The small garden outside has a lovely stream with koi, and a large statue of the Buddha in which he looks Indian.Also of interest are the five-story tower off to the left and the enormous lanterns which hang in the gates at the two ends of the Nakamise Dori: the Kamarimon and the Hozomon. Mitarashi dango (grilled rice balls with sweet fillings) is the traditional speciality which must be eaten here. If you are in the market for souvenirs, then Nakamise Dori is a reasonable place to buy them.

Very intetesting place.. Very intetesting place to visit.Lots of interesting food and shops you walk past if you enter under the big lantern. Big temple nice to see locals and tourists all along side each other praying.Plenty of little side shopping streets off this temple in all directions.Great way to spend a half a day. Also good for the Children to see different religions.Well worth the visit.
Very Authentic. This temple is alive with families keeping tradition sacred and adhering to their faith. Unlike temples in China that are historical and cold, this is hot with activity.

Absolutely stunning!. This temple is absolutely stunning! We arrived after closing hours but the grounds are open all the time. It's beautiful to walk around. The architecture is really neat and the giant lanterns... I still can't get over them! This is hands down one of my favorite temples. And I've seen a lot so that's saying something!

One of the best shrines. One of the best experience for this trip to the temple is the long street in front of the temple. It sells everything, I just walk up to every shops to take a look there. Also there's food stalls just before the temple and they are so good! Recommended to buy one or two street food over there! There's just a huge crowd everywhere but I doesn't really affect me for some reasons (I usually do). The temple was magnificent and I would recommend you too walk around the temple as there are little shrines and statues around the temple, which was quite satisfying!

Good souvenir shopping. This is a large temple in an old style part of Tokyo. The streets leading up to it are the most fun, though, with every type of souvenir on offer at very good prices. Several Japanese visitors told us it was the best place for souvenirs in Tokyo. There's a random little amusement park nearby which looked fun and incongruous.

Beautiful Temple worth visiting. This is another one of the famous places to see in Tokyo. It is a touristy place, but it still maintains a traditional religious temple. I also liked the whole district that surround it. Good place to wander around, look at people daily life. Very good for shopping, a lot of traditional souvenirs. The gigantic temple is colorful and elaborate structure inside and out. Nearby is a beautiful 5 tier pagoda. Arcades of shops and food stalls leading up to the gate and the front entrance of the temple. The grounds surrounding the temple have the famous cherry trees and are great place to people watch, locals and visitors. It's really a don't miss destination.
Unique experience . Difficult to describe how what the sensation in visit this temple !!!! High recommend ! In front of the temple there are market that sell food , candles and clothes

Impressive architecture. This was my first visit to a Japanese temple. The architecture was impressive. The street which leads up to the main temple is lined with shops selling all kinds of items. The flags all over add a special charm to the place. It was rather crowded on the Sunday morning that we visited. We tasted an interesting traditional Japanese sweet outside the temple. It's called taiyaki...made from flour of some sort with a sweet central filling of red beans I was told...it was rather interesting. I enjoyed the trip very much although it was shorter than I would have liked it to be.

My favourite temple in Japan. I loved everything about Senso-ji in Asakusa, Japan. Despite the massive tourist crowds, the temple was absolutely beautiful, and kept a sense of peacefulness and respect inside the main temple doors. A 200m long market leads from the entrance of Senso-Ji to the main temple. This is by far the best market/tourist shopping spot we found around Tokyo, so I would definitely recommend including some shopping time into your plan. The best thing about this market is that none of the shop owners are hawking their products, making the experience incredibly painfree. There are several different sites around the temple where people are throwing coins for good luck, so make sure you have some handy. A beautiful way to experience both a sacred temple, as well as some shopping.

Better to Visit At Night. I visited twice yet. Once was daytime and second was night. At night, the view and enlightments are much more attractive than daytime and you find more stores to make shopping. Skytree also looks very nice as its just next to Asakusa Area.

Nice tourist attraction. The temple area is a great attraction with loads of little shops before you reach the temple complex. The architecture is magnificent and there is also a very small garden.Best to go early evening when there is more atmosphere.

Beautiful. This is really worth a visit even if you are templed out. The road leading to it rivals Gatlinburg or the road to Mt Rushmore in terms of souvenir shops. There is nothing religious about this. There are hoards of tourists. We went in the evening and it was really nice. This neighborhood also has a lovely shopping area with many choices to eat

The highlight of Asakusa. This is a really happening attraction. You can easily spend 2 hours walking around and experiencing the Japanese culture. There are many beautiful monuments around and the area is very well decorated. Do not forget to get your fortune told for a 100 yen.

Very colourful with huge stues & lanterns. On our first visit it was raining quite hard and was very busy as it was a weekend, so our party returned a few days later on a brighter & quieter day. There is a lot to see in the area, lots of statues and small gardens with fish in the stream. Do allow enough time to explore the nearby market stalls & shops, they are quite extensive & full of fascinating things. We found this much more fascinating than the designer shops in Ginza, but then we do have Oxford Street, London on our doorstep!

Fortunes to be considered.. Immerse your senses at the Sensoji Temple and ask for a fortune via the numbered sticks. We had an enjoyable time roaming through the tourist stalls - lots of taste sensations to be had- banana custard filled pancakes shaped like a fish, crunchy rice ball snacks, donut type buns with sweet red bean paste. Local people wander through the precinct, lots of tourists but this adds to the scene rather than detracts. A beautiful temple precinct.
Must visit!. Must visit when you're in Tokyo! Great atmosphere and very spiritual once you stepped inside. There were great restaurants all over the area.
One of many places that you have to visit in Tokyo. One of many places that you have to visit in Tokyo... Don't forget to buy some local souvenirs and merchandise around the street...

Well Worth a visit to this Ancient Temple. The surrounding area to the Temple comprises of rows of small tourist type shops which were very interesting with plenty of places to get good and drink. It was very busy at the time of our visit but well worth the trip to see such an ancient temple.

Nice but nothing spectacular. The temple is rebuilt, so it doesn't feel like you're visiting an ancient world heritage site. It's a great insight into Buddhist culture and rituals and Nakamise-dori (the street leading up to the temple) is great fun. Worth a visit but there are more beautiful temples in Tokyo.
Stunning!. We loved this temple! The little markets surrounding it were great too. Make sure you have time to explore

Well worth a visit. The best time to visit is early morning or later in the afternoon once the tour busses have departed, otherwise it is very crowded – but not in an unpleasant sort of way.Firstly, make sure you go to the tourist information office near the Asakusa station and pick up a detailed map (also go up to the 8th floor viewing deck whilst you are there). We were glad we did because apart from the beautiful shrine, temple, grounds and frenetic main shopping street, we would have missed the lesser-known sights such as the handprints of Japanese celebrities, located nearby.Afterwards, we spent time walking along the smaller streets which crisscross near the temple. There are many small shops selling everything from kimonos and kitchen wares to very reasonably-priced restaurants filled with locals.We visited during the two day festival of the Hozuki-ichi (ground cherry pod flowers). The grounds were alive with flower sellers and food stalls. Once the rain stopped, it was a beautiful sight. If you are visiting during the Summer, then you would be advised to bring an umbrella with you or buy one locally (most shops seem to sell them – even local mini-marts).

Busy but worth it. We made the mistake of going here midday and it was crammed with tourists. I'm sure it's busy most of the time but I would avoid this time if I went again - try early morning or late afternoon. Still it was a lot of fun and the area is really big so you still don't feel too claustrophobic. The line of shops/stalls leading up to the temple is also part of the fun so make sure you take a good look around (but mind your handbags, you never know). Overall definitely worth a visit!

"Real Japan" within Tokyo. This extensive tempe grounds, so close to Asakusa Station, is accessible and enjoyable. Taking exit A-1, turn right on the street (NOT in the shopping arcade) and see the entrance within a few steps, just past the Ghibli store. This entrance is an outstanding spot if one needs to arrange to meet others. From then, going between the gates of Thunder and Lightening, a plethora of souvenir shops line the wide walkway to the temple. Most have good prices, one can shop with confidence. Reaching the incense burner, stop to "bathe" in the smoke. If you have time and/or interest, one block to the right is the best shop for large sized tradition socks, construction workers "shoes", and men's kimono. Tshirts of excellent design represent the "Thunder and Lightening" of this temple as well as the many designs of traditional firefighter. Back to the temple. climb the steps to fully appreciate this large, gorgeous building of worship. The grounds to the left include a stream full of koi (colorful carp) and walkways.
Worth visiting. Definitely a spot worth visiting, Asakusa is a wonderful place. There is a huge market by Sensoji which has many great souvenirs, and there is delicious food at the food vendors.

Lovely place full of magic. It is one of the most visited temples in Tokyo so you better visit this temple early in the morning or quite late to see the great illumination of the padoga and Senso-ji. You better "take a bath" with the incense at the entrance.

Beautiful but crowded Temple. A beautiful and well known temple in Tokyo. However, it's just too crowded! Full of local and tourists!!! Maybe because of peak sakura season. If you do not like crowd, you may go in the early morning. There is a shopping street infront of the temple, but I found the price just not for me...you know what happened at tourist attractions, right? lol ... Honestly, I just stayed for a while and leave after took photos because the crowd made me breathless ;)

Japan's oldest temple. If you're in Asakusa and want to visit Nakamise street, you've got to see Sensoji Temple. We visited Sensoji Temple early in the morning before it is enveloped by tourists from all walks of life. Many locals visit Sensoji early in the morning to offer prayers and to go about their daily lives. There are a lot of pedestrians and cyclists passing by the temple grounds. I was there to infuse myself in a little dose of culture and to kill time before Nakamise dori (street) came to life. As with most places of religious worship, I feel at peace here. Be respectful of temple visitors and not use your camera flash while inside temple interior.

Make sure you touch the giant flip flops.. Very busy with people. If you visit temples in Tokyo I would put this at the top of my list. No entry fee required. It looks very well kept and the market stalls going up to the temple create such a lively and bustling walkway. It would be hard not to buy anything from here!Not much to see inside the shrine but the whole experience is still good. At the back of one of the gates are two giant flipflops that allegedly bring good luck to walkers. On the right hand side of the shrine are public restrooms at street level. Just behind some trees.

Worth seeing. To get there, you go through a long row of market shops which sell food and souvenirs. The temple itself is worth seeing and the nearby garden is a good photo spot. It is certainly a tourist spot so be prepared for the crowds (we went on a rainy day so there was also a lot of umbrella dodging!)

beautiful Temple. It's in the middle ow the city. It is a great place to people watch and see them honour the god of the Temple. There is a market place in front of the Temple where you can get the best souvenirs. I bought many robes from a great guy whose English was amazing. They have robes in silk and polyester.

Historical Temple with lots to see!. We tour on our own without any tour guide. We reached on Fri late night and back on Sunday late night too.It is my first time to Tokyo and Sensoji Temple is my 2nd stop after Tsukiji Market. We managed to find it quite easily after come out from Asakusa of Tokyo Metro Line.As advised by online, we manage to see the craved dragon beneath the 1st lantern in center of the Gate.Lots people taking pictures. I love the First view after the 1st Gate. two rows of small stalls all the way to the Shrine Hall. Full of people in between the stalls.Dont forget to turn back to see the Gigantic straw slipper on the gate upon entering the 1st gate.We saw a stall selling the variety of ice cream on our right side which cost about 300 yen.We tried the Green tea flavour. Not bad. just the cons is we have to finish up the WHOLE ice cream before we move to the next stall. We respect their cleanliness. therefore, my advice is please buy them after you visited all unless you are very thirsty or hot.Along the row of stalls, we saw shops of souvenir,food and snacks. There is also a row of prediction papers where people ask for the love,luck and etc stuff. More closer to the shrine hall, on the right,we saw people crowd around a fountain of a statue and wash their hand, drank some of the water and put some water on their head. We didn't managed to get to know the name of the Statue but it is quite a view.There is a Pagoda on the left, it is said have lots of nice wall painting on the ceiling. due to limited time, we skipped climbing up the stairs. But i will definitely go up the Pagoda in my next visit.After paying respect at the Shrine hall, we turn to our right and there is a Hall for the Ancestor. We exited at the right side of the Temple to talk a walk by the riverside.

Cultural Peace. Entering to the 1,400 years old temple and enjoy the rich culture along the way. Start from the entrance, you'll see a lot of gift shops and local snacks around, tempting!! Try the Sakura moji if you are there around Spring, I was delicious. Entering the temple, feel the grand architect of Japanese and stunned with the lay out that give you peach of mind, too bad many tourist are noisy tho.I was lucky to get into the back of the building and spend sometime admired the story behind, thanks to my well known Japan friends.

Great site. It was a great sight to see. Loads of culture and active participants in the temple. I traveled alone and could have gotten more insight as to what was going on. There is a market from the street that leads up to the temple. My hands were bulging with bags by the time I go to the actual temple

Wonderful Temple and lively street. Lovely temple, filled with many people. I have never been to a temple livelier than this, which is probably due to its location. Leading to the temple, there are many stalls selling desserts, yukatas, souvenirs, and a lot of interesting things. Outside the area leading to the temple, there are also a lot of delicious sushi restaurants. A wonderful contrast. Definitely one of the highlights of my trip.

it's definitely for tourists. Surrounded by hundreds of shops of souvenir, gift, food, snacks, minimart, this place has attract domestic and foreigners to visit. There is a giant big lampoon donated by a ceo of a soho sosha company, whom once said he was healed his illness by praying there.

Exactly what I envisioned. I loved this little gem in the middle of the city. The temple towers over the little shopping area that holds several Tokyo themed keepsakes and souvenirs. There is a large main temple that holds religious services that you can see in process, and a side 5-tiered temple.

Worth a visit during the day and late at night. We booked our hotel in Asakusa so we could be in very easy walking distance of the Temple and all the shops and restaurants around it.The gates and temple buildings themselves are very impressive, and dwarf you as you walk through them. Its always very busy BUT dont let that deter you - there is still that sense of peace that comes with the temple. The smell of incense is lovely, adding to the atmosphere. One fab thing is the shopping street through the gate and on the lead up to the temple - its fantastic for buying souvenirs, snacks etc. We bought most of our gifts from there - ranging from cheap and cheerful to real artist works. if you go at night its a lot quieter, but the temple buildings are lit up, and its a lovely atmosphere. Nice for a late evening stroll.

A must during Sakura or during the "Coming of Age" day. First, this is the oldest temple in Tokyo.Then, it is very enjoyable to walk around and to eat in one of the small places close to the temples. During the cherry blossoms, the place is beautiful, even better than during winter. The other moment to go to Senso-ji is during the Coming of Age day, where a lot of ladies, who just reached the age of 20, will celebrate their first day as adult in traditional outfits. That was just beautiful !!!Like most of the other temples in Tokyo, you will soon forget that you are in the biggest megalopolis in the world.

Peaceful reflection in one of the busiest cities in the world.. Peace and quiet in a place that has more hustle and bustle than a Chinese farmers market! Tokyo is great for many things, this contrasting peace and hustle lifestyle is definitely one of them! The temple is grand and beautiful and quite impressive in terms of other things around there. However, the real great thing about this place is the park area around it, no matter who you are or where you are from people welcome you as you walk by. This is great for just taking a day to recover from a long flight or late night and still saying you accomplished something that day. My friend and I were nursing a late night's yields and trying to really experience Tokyo in the one week we had. Yes we were on vacation and. No we were not worried if we missed things in Tokyo, but that was because we were on vacation, after a day, I already knew I was going to be returning :)One thing that I found great about this area was the small hostel and bustle market of random Japanese goods outside the peacefulness of the park.

The Oldest Temple in Tokyo . There is so much history and tradition here. I enjoyed immersing myself in the culture and taking part in the rituals. Although it was raining, it was still crowded so be patient. If your looking for souvenirs, purchase them from the shops around the temple. Tokyo lacks in gift shops.

Love this place . We visited last year and wrote a review so I will keep it brief (I knew we would come back!)What a fantastic place - Tokyo's oldest temple has bags of character. This is a beautiful place and the Nakamise shopping market makes it well worth a visit alone if you need to get some touristy gifts/souvenirs. Already looking forward to our next visit!
Perfect place for shopping. It might not be the first time for me to be here, perfect places for shopping and warmful people!

Spiritually beautiful, but over-crowded!. We visited the temple during mid-morning. It was super busy! Lots of tourists and locals everywhere! However, don't let this detract you for visiting this beautiful temple. The surrounding market place on the road leading to the temple was very interesting - a great place to shop for souvenirs with a great atmosphere! The temple itself was stunning! Plenty of opportunities to partake in spiritual activities and pay your respects. A must see historical and religious monument when visiting Tokyo!

A dazzling Senso-ji at night. Another delightful building of Tokyo although the famous Nakamise Street was near closing and the main building was closed to visitors (after 5-530pm). However, the Hozomon Gate is more impressive compare to seeing it on photo. The temple has different look once the light is on at night. Will recommend to experience both day-time and night-time at Senso-ji.
Nice temple in a nice area. Nice temple, lots of interesting shrines nearby and it is at the end of a lovely market street which is well worth exploring
stunning. this temple is really really busy but its totally worth a see. you can even go into some of it. there are lots of little market stalls along the way to the temple and some food stalls also.

Fantastic. Beautiful place a must see in Asakusa. Nakimise shopping street leading up to the temple is filled with traditional souvenier shops. Matsuri in May is fantastic very close to transport link easy access to sky tree.

A must-see. A little gem. Even though most of it is fairly newly built it is a shrine with lots of history and some tranquility inside the hectic city. It was not particuralry crowded when we were there (a monday before lunchtime) but I assume it can be rather crowded and thus not very peaceful. The long row of small shops from the entrance to the shrine were touristic, but then again in a rather nice fashion. And in Japan people and shopowners are equally polite and never pushy.

Great temple. Traditional Japanese temple with giant red lanterns. Was more on the touristy side compared to other temples we visited, but still very cool nonetheless. Nice street of little shops as well.

Spectacular. Before visiting the Senso-Ji Temples make sure you read up on its relevance and history. This makes it much more interesting. Also arrive early as we did (7am) as there are no crowds. People/ crowds began arriving at around 8am.

Tourist heaven . Went on a rainy day, but well worth it. Lots of souvenir stall on the way in. Managed to get a few bargains. Grounds and temple were beautiful but very busy, especially with everyone and their umbrellas !

Spent New Years Here. Brilliant a wonderful experience and the massive volume of people attending is astounding. The food market and activities well worth visiting. Shoulder to shoulder people a bit tough but a beautiful temple, we visited during day also hotel 100m awary - fantastic

Impressive temple in a fascinating area of Tokyo. The Senso-ji is Temple is impressive and well worth a visit, but it's the Asakusa area that makes this a mandatory stop on any visit to Tokyo. You will see nicer temples in Kyoto and if you are looking for peace and spirituality you should go elsewhere (in Tokyo, the Meji-jingu feels more peaceful, for example). With the surrounding shopping areas and restaurants this can sometimes feel like a tourist trap, but it feels very Japanese, which is a good thing when visiting Tokyo. We also got a good laugh of the fortune "sticks" outside the temple, where you can try your luck to see if your future will bring good or bad fortune.

Fun visit. We were staying near by the shrine/temple. Therefore, we visited it in various times of the day. I have to say that evening is the best time to visit. Less busy. Great time to take pictures. We also took a free tour during the daytime from the Asakusa tourist/cultural office. It was a great way to get more in-depth information.
Love this place!. I love Japan and this is one of the places I visited last year. It was very cool to see the culture and arts of Tokyo. I will definitely come back soon!
Senso-ji Temple. Busy place. Lots of souvenior shops but the prices are high as they know only tourist will buy. You can go inside and make your wish and hopefully it will come true... :-)

A temple with many shrines and shops grown around it. I did come here in the afternoon, but so late, most of the rows of shops were closed or closing. If you are looking for gifts, this is a good place to visit earlier in the day. If you want to avoid crowds, then evening is fine and pretty quiet.I made my way here just before sunset, to give myself enough time to visit the temple and many of the smaller shrines surrounding it, many made to honor Kannon. Senso-Ji has it's own unique atmosphere and look, which makes it worth the trip. Of course, Hozomon should not be missed, since it is a symbol of Asakusa. The park area isn't as large as it looks on the map, since it is mostly concrete jungle.But as stated, the shrine is only part of the reason to come here. The vast number of shops and community which has grown around the shrine is amazing. Even as evening hits, there are a lot of restaurants, bars, and some shopping (there is a Don Quijote nearby). Just make sure to take some time walking around the perimeter of the park, to see everything the area has to offer.From here, it's pretty easy to get to Ueno Station, or down to Kayabacho and Tokyo Station. And of course, Tokyo Skytower can be seen rising in the distance, which makes this a perfect middle-stop in your adventure.
Good cultural experience. The temple is beautiful and there are plenty of buildings to see. It is quite crowded, but it is still a must see in Tokyo.

Must in Tokyo. This very crawded place is must see attraction. Oldest temple in Tokyo. Very good to combine this visit with river boat trip or take a metro to Asakusa. Around the temple many shops and restaurants. Maybe the Cousine is not original and more for tourists but I enjoyed this restaurant the most. Trying original famous ramen restaurant day before can not eat finish. Not my test. So I stayed with tourists and enjoyed the day.Recommended place and around

Amazing to visit at night. I visited the temple in the evening - it was not as crowded it was during the day - which meant wonderful photo opportunities and playing with the lights. I'd strongly recommend an evening/late night visit on a weekday rather than during the day.

Just beautiful, with a very calming vibe.. The street leading to the temple itself is sounique and positive.The little customs like taking out the stick with a number, matching it to a drawer that hold your fortune, or buying the fortune souvenirs, all very endearing.The best part was I was allowed into the actual temple where tourists are not and sat and meditated for 15 minutes.The temple has immense energy and a very positive vibe, so felt just lovely.Am not a typical tourist who like to do every thing touristy necessarily but this is a "must do"!
senso-ji temple. best temple, many spot you can reach in one places, there are many shop for shopping such as traditional Japan stuff, but this place is very crowded

Great temple and surrounding streets. Yet another temple for you to explore within Tokyo. Very easy to get to from the JR Asakusa station. As soon as you exit the station there are an abundance of pulled rickshaws with guides to take you around the streets there (smallish charge). I was approached by one (great english) and gave me a quick rundown of what they do, acting as a tourist guide etc. He was friendly and didn't pressure me to use him even after I declined his services.The streets leading up to and around the temple itself are fantastic with lots to eat and shop. It can feel a bit "touristy" though and we came here on a weekday and it was still very crowded. Heaps of tour groups seem to target this area also, so expect to have plenty of random people in your photos. It doesn't feel as "tranquil" as some other temples in Kyoto area.

Beautiful and Loads of Shopping. This is a great Shrine. Among all the places I visited in Japan, this place had the most visitors. The place is filled with foreigners and locals. Local come here for the blessing. It is a good opportunity to see their spiritual practices. Right outside the place, there are loads of souvenirs and mementos shops. The best part is, most of the prices are identical. So go to anyone and shop till you drop. Some of the shops accept credit cards too.This is a place not to be missed. You can get there easily by train. They even had trishaws as well.

Devotion, praying, fortunes, and more. wonderful place to get a sense of life at a Japanese shrine, from devotion, to offerings, to securing a seal, to insense and washing . Then there is the public side for food, drink, souvenirs, and sweets

Nice temple to visit. It is just next to Asakusa Shrine. They have big sandal on either side of the entry which are nothing but Paduka. They have one amazing fortune teller System as well. Unusual thing is every body waik in with there foot ware on.

Must do in Tokyo. Close to train station... Walking distance from most shops. The temple itself is beautiful... It reveals the old Japan and its majestic stature. A place of worship meditation .. Shops open around 9sh or 10 am. It gets busy... So the eRlier the better! I❤️ Tokyo
Beautiful ancient architecture. The most visited temple in Tokyo, full of small shops selling souvenirs and some food. From here you may want to walk to skytree, about 15-20 min.

Don't Miss This. Senso-ji Temple is a very nice place! :)
You will experience a unique Japanese culture. You can also buy Omamori for luck! Nakamise is also a nice place for buying souvenirs and for tasting the different flavors of Japan.
BEAUTIFUL. Must see for sure, in my opinion best in Tokyo. The temple is beautiful and theres a bunch of shops and restaurants around it to enjoy. Just splendid
Nice to see it. Nice to visit this temple, been a western not much in the shops around it though, thought it would be better ,

Must Visit. If you visit Tokyo then you must visit the Sensoji shrine for two reasons, one the beautiful historical temple area itself is worth visiting and two, the shopping arcades in and around it. The temple entrance and inside shrines are quite majestic and picturesque. The walk from the entrance to the other end is lined with shopping arcades, which are a bit on the expensive side; the famous Asakusa market. Lots of wayside eateries with fresh tempura and teriyaki. In between the walk you get a nice view of the Tokyo Skytree with some cherry blossom branches, though a better place to see it would be the waterfront a little walk away from the main entrance to the temple.

Nice temple, even better at night. The Senso-ji temple is a pretty nice temple, with the huge Hozomon, its 5 stories pagoda, its garden... I recommend to visit it just before the end of the opening hours, then go down to the Information Center at the entrance, go up to the last floor to drink a coffee and look at the sunset over the illuminated temple from the sky deck.Then, go back to the temple and enjoy its lights at night.

The place you must visit in Tokyo. Sensoji is accessible by the subway to Asakusa station. One of the oldest temple in Tokyo. The temple offering a great experience to be touch with Japanese traditional and culture.When you visit the temple in Japan, what you need to do is to clean your body with the holy water available in the temple area and then pray with the God and Goddess in the temple. On the way back, it is a believe that if you pulling the air with the smell of the incent in front of the temple in will bring you all the luck.In front of Sensoji temple is also the huge area shopping selling mostly Japanese sweet and dessert. You can also find some souvenir also but I suggest you not to buy it here as the price is tourist price which is about 15% higher than in the local market.

Beautiful but packed. Unfortunately, I visited this as I was running out of time on my second-to-last day in Tokyo before meeting someone for dinner. So I pretty much hustled from the subway station up to the temple, admired it, gave an offering, took some pictures, circled the temple and walked around some of the other buildings, and had to take off. It was definitely the most tourist-filled place I visited on my trip, but it's understandable and unavoidable. It was a beautiful architectural space and of a powerful scale to encounter first-hand. It would have been nice to relax and spend more time looking at all the buildings and green areas, so you could probably spend about an hour here. I didn't particularly love the shopping streets leading up to it, but I don't really care for shopping / cheap knick knacks, but if that's your thing, it's a good place to get it I guess. It seemed like there could have been some nice casual restaurants and cafes nearby though.

A delight to behold!. This is wonderful temple to visit simply because it is an active temple and very popular among the people. You stand there marveling at the space while people are praying all around you. It's located on large piece of land and there are many smaller temples and shrines to visit as well not to mention the hundreds of shops around the area.

Great if you like temples, but very crowded. Found it far too crowded, so we didn't stay long. Took a quick look at temple, tried to get a few photos and then moved on. The gardens are very pretty and well-looked after. Architecture of the temple is simply stunning.

Temple Highlight in Tokyo. One of the best temples in Tokyo. And if the temple and shrine next to it wasn't enough, there are may little food and souvenir stalls that invite you for a stroll and the shopping arcades are just branching off. In fact, the whole area is amazing and if you make it here in spring, you can see cherry blossoms. If you come a little later, in May, then you can be witness to the crazy Sanja Matsuri festival. A must see!!

You should go back here at night.. We arrived at 13:00pm on Saturday ,I must say this is a very bad timing ,too many people you can see nothing just step forward pushing by the crowd.so we decided to visit sky tree first.But when we go back at 8:00pm, and its very surprise to saw the temple is prettier and spectacular than in daytime,so if you have time in asakusa,please go find it in nighttime.

Well worth a visit. One place everyone coming to Tokyo should visit. It's in one of the few remaining traditional areas of Tokyo; a nice contrast to the modern skyscrapers of central Tokyo. There's a pedestrian only shopping street leading to the temple. There you can buy all sorts of traditional items from food, snacks, clothing, etc. The temple itself is quite incredible. Can get very crowded though.

Worth a visit . This is worth a visit on any Tokyo itinerary however it is a bit of a tourist trap! It's best yo go early morning or just before closing. I visited early morning after a trip to Tsukiji fish market and it was nice to see the locals passing through on their way to work, or children walking to school. It felt more real seeing it used for its proper purpose rather than just being bombarded with foreigners which is would be later in the day.
interesting. Very interesting place for European !Very strange for us !It is place where it is possible to rest !
Interesting. An interesting place to visit. You can make prayers or ask about your fortune there. Different experience from the more common shinto shrines.

Great temple and surrounding area. This is a great site to visit for a few hours. There are many market stalls before you enter the temple from the main road. You can buy everything from trinkets and t-shirts to small pastries and even swords. Before you come to the shrine after the market stalls, you can find out your luck. You put a small amount of money (100 yen, I think) into the box, shake the silver container, take out a stick with a number on it and open the small wooden drawer with the corresponding number to find out if you have good or bad luck. If it's bad luck, tie the small piece of paper onto the rail with the others to leave your bad luck behind. If it's good luck, take it with you! The shrine itself is impressive and colourful. It's is well worth a trip, not only for the shrine!

A crowded temple area but you mostly like it. Well, a nice to see the Gates, walk through those gates, passes so many food hawkers and gift stores, sitting on a little park to see the birds, hanging around to see some landmarks .. Tokyo Tower for sure, and i also tasting a sweet bread just came out fresh from the oven at the store closest to the right side before the main gate on the middle. So many people bought a bread, it is kinda popular here...i guess. Wonderful over all..
Lovely Temple. The temple was almost opposite our hotel and is well worth a visit, also lots of shops selling souvenirs and food, well worth a trip

Great temple and surroundings. Plenty to do here, the temple is beautiful and the surrounding gardens are even more impressive. Once you have explored this you can wander around the shops / open market stalls which are right next to this temple. There are plenty of places to eat lunch and good public toilets. We caught a bus from Tokyo Central station to here and walked less than 5 mins to the temple. Great morning out.

beautiful, traditional and lots to explore around. The main attraction has both the Asakusa Shrine and Sensoji temples next to each other. So be sure to cover both when you go,Getting there: take the Asakusa MRT (Ginza line) and walk along the crowded, but very local alleyways to get there. There is so much happening in the alleys that its worth spending some time to look around.How to explore: Start at the main gates, hire a guide if you can (but we found it very hard to find English speaking guides at the venues. You are better off reading about it early or using a tour operator). Then walk to the 2 main attractions and then the gardens on the left. Once you complete the gardens, continue walking till you exit. Outside, you will find more alleyways and eateries that are absolutely amazing!When to go: I would advise that you complete this early in the day, as most tourists then head off to the skytree right after (its a longish walk away). Even if you arent planning on seeing the sky tower or are afraid of heights, you should complete Asakusa in the morning (there isnt a night life scene anyway).

A worthwhile visit whilst in Tokyo. We stayed in Asakusa during a recent visit to Tokyo so wandered past the temple at various hours of the day and night for several days. It is a crowded area during most of the day but very pretty lit up at night. The area surrounding the temple is a maze of stalls and arcades of restaurants and shops but as is almost always the case in Tokyo although they may be in a prime tourist area the businesses have fair prices and there is good food to be had if you wish to eat in the area. A number of stalls have specialty food such as ice cream served in cakes and curry buns that are well worth trying. At least a few hours are needed to do the temple and surrounds justice and it is well worth a visit. There is a huge contrast between here and districts like the Ginza and Shinjuku.
a good temple. a nice preserve temple with the main attraction the big red paper lantern. packed with tourist and the souvenir shops.

Beautiful Temple. The temple is located in Asakusa area in Tokyo. We went in Hatobus. So dont know how to access by train. It was very crowded during Golden week. The Buddha Idol inside the temple was very beautiful. The outside view was also beautiful. Skytree was visible from the temple. Also can walk through the busy Kamigori street to get an experience of old Japan. Overall highly recommended.

A temple not to be missef. We took a train from Shinjuku to Asakusa and was really easy and fast. When we reached Asskusa station, there was a lot of men asking if you want to take the trishaws. They are not cheap though. After a short turn from the station, we went into the temple via the Kaminarimom Gate. Upon entering it, there were rows of stalls selling local souvenirs. Interesting stalls though and we bought quite a handful of souvenirs. Then next we entered the main gate. We just followed some locals to cleanse ourselves from the water in a small well at the side by washing our hands. We next bought a small bunch of incense at 500yen to pray. This place is worth a visit
tranquil oasis in the city centre. A beautiful temple in a garden surrounded by high rise towers .Surprises like this are a great find in among the concrete jungle of a huge city

Busy temple. An architectural representative Of a traditional Buddhist Temple. Ths one s special because is has over 500 years of history, the adjoining shopping streets leaving to the temple is a fun and good place to shop for authentic,, reasonably priced souvenirs plus it offers a lots for opportunity to try Japanese small bites as the place sell lot of favoriites Japanese pastries and small eats

A must see in Tokyo. This temple is in Asakusa and easily reachable by subway. It's absolutely huge! So interesting to see the beautiful things here and in the surrounding area. This is beautiful at night when lit up. A must see when in Tokyo.

The most popular Temple in Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is a very large and an extremely popular Buddhist temple in the Taito section of Tokyo. It is very easy to reach from the Asakusa Metro stop. A short walk down a shopping street where you can buy almost any souvenir and you are in the large complex. Go ahead and follow along and do what the pilgrims are doing. Purify your self at the large fire pot, Wash you hands at the waters. Check your fortune by paying 1 Yen. and then enter the great Hall. It is fascinating to see and do.

Marvelous Temple. This is the well-known,oldest,nearly 1600-year temple in Tokyo. There is the very beautiful and precious golden Buddha inside. Easy access by few subway lines. Lots of amazing local food,snacks and souvenirs along Nakamise Dori down to the temple. There are also delicious traditional japanese food nearby this temple too.
Most impressive temple. This is a great temple. When you come here, don't forget to take a look at the smaller shrine and temples right next to it.
Hidden gem. This is a great temple, close to restaurants and shops so lots to see and do around the area. One of the best temples in Tokyo, very very pretty.
Huge!. Big impressive temple. We were there festival season and the area was buzzing. Lots of touristy stuff nearby. Pedestrian area too.
Magnificent Temple. A truly beautiful temple surrounded by quaint shops and food choices. Much better to go during the week - the weekend is very, very crowded.

Famous but ordinary temple. The historic temple is one of the most famous temple in Tokyo and it is usually overcrowded with tourists. Although the temple has great history, it was quite common as most Japanese temple have long history dated hundreds of years, so it did not attract me very much.There are many shops around Sensoji temple so you can continue to spend your time, trying there sweet potato bun, sweet potato cakes or looking for souvenir to bring back home.

Extremely crowded and touristy. This is a nice temple to see, but its very touristy. The walk to the gates of the temple is lined with tons of little shops selling souvenirs. That's usually the first sign that the temple has transformed from a place of worship to a commercialized tourist attraction. This is a Buddhist temple as its a good place to visit. However, I am not sure its worth the trek filled with tourists and school-aged children. Not sure if going early would be the answer especially if you have to fight rush hour commute to get there. Overall, I would visit it for a brief look if its not full of people. There are other nicer and more peaceful Buddhist temple in Japan to visit
Very nice temple.. Temple Sensoji is very nice. The street Nakamise-Dori is great. The whole area is very nice at the night.

There are more authentic temples to visit. It was so packed with tourists and stands leading up to the temple, that it really didn't feel like an authentic experience. Pick a different temple to visit whilst in Tokyo

Famous temple in Asakusa. Sensoji is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa (old traditional Tokyo). It is a famous temple in a colorful and popular area. The temple includes a five storied pagoda. Asakusa is a must-see area in Tokyo.

Lots of people, but really nice. This is a walk in different steps : the gates, the market, gates again, and then the temple. Everything is impressive and totally worth the fact that there will be a lot of people. It's a good start in the large large Tokyo.

Touristy but worthwhile. A beautiful large temple although you can't go "inside". The surrounding area is very touristy with shops but still a fun place to walk around, watch people pray and receive a fortune for 100 yen.
shrine and teple in the center of Tokyo. the place is visited by big groups of Japanese people. It is one of the best places to see a buddhist temple and a shrine in Tokyo.

Check your luck. At the end of the nakamise street see the temple. Don't miss the very large footwear, the sticks that forecast luck, the hand cleaning ritual and the incense pot, and pay your respects. Along with the shopping street its a nice experience.
Perfect. If you only have a day to visit Tokyo, this is the place to go. From temples to shopping, from traditional goodies to souvenirs. This place has it all!

Popular place for Tourist. I like to see people walk around and go directly to the temple and walk back to shop souvenir for friends and relatives.
There is nothing that I didn't like except souvenir is more expensive than the other places.

Over crowded and commercial. This was the third of three temples we saw while in Tokyo and we are glad it was the last. We went to Meiji in Yoyogi Koen first, then the one on Takao-san, both of which were wonderful. Noth of those also had plenty of visitors, but they were peaceful places and the visitors were respectful and the commercialism kept to tactful levels. My husband and I went to Sensoji on a Thursday afternoon and it was packed wall to wall with foreign tourists. To get to the Temple, which is gorgeous, don't get me wrong, you have to walk a 1/4 mile gauntlet of people and shop stands. It is loud, crowded and as far from peaceful or respectful as it could get without being actively destructive. I honestly think the city should limit the number of people allowed on the temple grounds at one time and close 80% of the shops. I would recommend Meiji over this spot 100 times over. If you just MUST see this temple, take a detour around the block and enter from the west by the Mitsumine Shrine. This peaceful park area lets you see the Shrine well while enjoying a pond full of colorful carp and many smaller shrines.
Nice temple with market but go early!. Go early if you want to avoid the crowds as it gets very crowded once the stores open. Nice market, mostly souvenirs but you can find some good stuff too.

Amazing complex in middle of a busy shopping and restaurant district. Temple complex is made up of multiple buildings, and frequent crowds make it seem like there's always a party going on. The long shopping street leading from the main avenue near the entrance Gate is filled with gift vendors, and restaurants and bars abound in nearby shopping arcades.
Beautiful. It's a one of main attractions in Tokyo, so don't miss it. Nice looking, with beautiful garden on a side, gives you a chance to quit a city buzz for a while.

Tokyo's Oldest Temple. admission is free of charge. lots of shops and eateries line the streets leading to the temple. rather touristy but no regrets for visiting.accessible through Asakusa station exit 1. be prepared to walk, eat and soak up the atmosphere.

Beautiful Pagoda. This was the first place I went on my trip in Japan and after traveling around I think it was still my favorite. I returned here at the end of my trip and spent a few hours walking around the area eating and shopping, it is definatly worth a visit.

Amazing Temple. Although it is always full of tourists but definitely worth a visit. one thing you must try is the green tea stall located at the street heading to the temple. It is very refreshing especially if you are visiting the temple on a hot day.

One of the best temples to visit in Tokyo. It has a feel of Edo (old name for Tokyo). Has a lot of stores in front of the temple, and they sell great souvenirs for foreign tourists. drop by Daikokuya (tempra over rice) or/and Umezono(classic Japanese sweets). I am born and raised edokko (real Tokyoite) and love this place.

Beautiful temple - warrant a 2nd visit at night. A visit to Tokyo is not complete if you do not visit this temple. It may touristy and crowded but do not let this deter you. You will meet locals dressed in kimonos offering prayers at the temple. Apart from the main temple, there is a pagoda, a few other buildings, a garden with cherry blossom trees and a stream leading to a pond filled with vibrant coloured koi fishes. You will pass by Nakamise Street where there are shops selling local snacks, confectionery, crafts and souvenirs. The shops do not offer discounts therefore do compare prices. I visited the temple again at night, the shops may be closed but temple was beautifully lit up and there were less people around.
Super busy!. We went during Golden Week, so probably busier than normal! But well worth it. So many shops leading up to the temple and so much yummy food to try!!

Tokyo not concrete-only. Sure, it's crowded, jammed and touristy. But it's the heart of the Eddoko (born and bred Tokyo roots) spirit and culture and a reminder that people flocked to Tokyo for more than anime and pop culture for centuries. Take the crowds in stride, and make it a point to explore the many side streets and hidden alleys for interesting shops, restaurants, cafes and bars.

Full of little Shops.. Senso-ji temple has many little shops where you can buy many souvenirs. It is a very beautiful location filled with history. It is a must stop place for tourists. You are not pressured to buy anything from the shops. Once your at the temple, you can get your little fortune papers.

Cultural haven of Tokyo. Came here around new years in 2015 and the Yatai (Street food stalls) were all still set up, which brought so much life to the area and gave it a unique atmosphere. Its always busy however, especially around new years.

Super busy and touristy, but good fun. Be prepared for tons of tourists, and super commercialized souvenir stores. Sensoji Temple has a long and interesting history, from the three/four fingered statues in the front gate, to the 100yen fortune sticks. The streets to the left and right are full of interesting stores selling everything from kitschy trinkets, handmade fans and shoes, yukatas, fabric, and traditional candies.

Full of tourists, but very interesting. This place was packed when we went. We basically had to surf the crowd and struggled to take a good picture inside the temple. The large lanterns are particularly popular. The area around is also very nice for shopping and food. There are a lot of souvenir shops and we even saw a celebrity there. The one thing to caution about is the price of the souvenirs. They tend to be more expensive than ones found outside the area. The long street is filled with stalls and holds a lot of interesting food like ice cream sandwiches and fried mochi. The food is quite worth it. We also sat at a restaurant nearby in traditional style and ate udon. They do have a strict rule of eating. You're not supposed to walk while eating, and you must only eat in front of the store that you purchased from or eat at the side, but never in front of another store.

Historical, Religious, Cultural Experience. We had been to Kyoto prior to Tokyo, so I probably could have gone without seeing another temple or shrine. Regardless, we checked it out and I'm glad we did, there's a lot to do, see and buy.It's historically and religiously interesting, and if you go with a tour guide they will usually explain the significance of the site.There are also lots of restaurants and shops nearby, a busy tourist area. If you're only visiting Tokyo for a few days and you're not going to Kyoto, this is a great Buddhist temple to visit.

The Best Site to Represent Classic Tokyo. Sensoji (Asakusa Kannon Temple) is a must see for all visitors to Tokyo. Previous review of the Buddhist rituals will enhance your visit. You start you journey by passing through The Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate), a symbol of Tokyo known by all. You then walk down The Nakamise, a shopping street of over 200 meters, which leads from the outer gate to the temple's second gate, the Hozomon. You are now at the shrine and you can witness the faithful performing their rituals which you can do along with them. Your visit to Sensoji Temple is a great introduction to both Tokyo of yesterday and today.

Very busy, but worth it.... I've heard this Temple is always packed, it was later in the day when the temple was about to close and it was still busy, but I think that was part of what made it cool to visit. Japanese are very polite so it's easy to get around. The temple itself is beautiful, and there are lots of things to see right around it. Easy access from the train station, and also the ferry dock is right there. I recommend taking a ferry ride on the river, to there or from there when you are done. Also, there is a line of shops leading up the main path to the temple grounds, be sure to visit those. Area has lots of restaurants nearby.

Busy busy. Very crowded here on a Saturday afternoon, not sure what it's like at other times. Seems to be more of a commercial experience than a spiritual one as there are enless stalls and eating spots leading up to the temple. It's big but As this was our last temple visit after 2 weeks in Japan I may be forgiven for being a little jaded.
Nice Temple. It is nice temple to visit, one of best temple I visit in Tokyo, and a lot of souvenir and food near temple.
super busy and super tourist. the way to the shrine is a super busy, super crowded street of tourist shops: expect to feel like an 'ant' :-)

Sensoji Temple is a traditional Japanese place. Japanese Temple , a great eye opener for a first visit there , so many people from Tourist ( like us) to school kids ,locals , This sight is extremely busy as we found out , for a day trip (if your keen ) you can walk to Sensoji Temple from Ueno station about 30 min , with so much to see ,markets, local stalls, worth a visit but go early

A rickshaw for two. We took a two hour ride. Our driver was Lee. He spoke excellant English and was also very comical. He took us to all the sight we wanted to see including the place he bought his shoes with the big toe seperate from the other toes. Our course we bought a pair. Very comfortable. We highly recommend this method to see the city up close and personal and yet not strenuous walking. Thank you Lee for a wonderful day and we encourage you to continue with your Vetenarian schooling.
Tourist trap. Nice tempel, as most temples in Japan. Entrance is one alley of tourist shops selling all the same garbage and spoiling the view

Large temple with a thriving atmosphere. Visited this temple on my last day in Tokyo and really enjoyed the buzz and goings on around the temple itself. Good food stalls help to take in the breathtaking sights.

Beautiful but crowded. Having heard from many people about this ancient and beautiful temple, we visited it one afternoon when we were staying nearby in Asakusabashi. Though very ornate with large lanterns that invite an awestruck response, the place is quite crowded since the street leading up to the temple is narrow and thronged by shops on both sides. So expect hustling along and being shoved in your back if you are walking here. The ceiling of the temple has some extremely lovely paintings and the shops too have their share of souvenirs for tourists to take home.

Beautiful temple. The temple is nice,the road leading up to it is colorful and interesting with lots of small shops and a ton of people crowded. Nice to visit and find different spots to check out with buddhas, girls wearing kimonos, souvenir shops, and lots of people watching.

Definitely worth visiting!. That is another and one of the most famous places, to see japanese tradition and atmosphere. It is a touristic place but also their traditional religious Temple. I also liked the whole district around to wander, look at people daily life. Very good for shopping, a lot of traditional souvenirs. Also you may find there not expensive places to eat some traditional food, a lot of coffee bars. This place is on every map and definitely top rated to see.

Go early. I've been to Sensoji a few times. Bottom line: gorgeous, but I get a little overwhelmed and crabby dealing with the actually shocking number of tourists (myself included, of course.) Big Japanese sights tend to be packed with people in general, but Sensoji can be Kyoto-during-hanami levels of packed.This time, I went before 7AM. I recommend this if you don't mind the morning. It's nearly empty, so you get a feel for the scope and beauty of the buildings and grounds before they are filled to bursting. It's nice! Sensoji buildings are painted fairly brightly compared to other temples like Meiji-jingu.

Living Tradition of Japan. Sensoji Temple is a traditional Japanese place. It is giant and iconic with so many traditional kiosks all around. The best view is at night! :) There are cherry trees everywhere and it is all very atmospheric and romantic..

Beautiful Temple. Loved this site. Very busy and touristy, of course, but still a must visit. Throw some coins and pay your respects. Take the walk through the shopping area around the Temple, lots to look at !

Beautiful...crowded...but worth it!. The temple is worth the visit...even with the crowds. We were fortunate enough to visit following golden week so the crowds were not as bad as the days/week before (so we heard). There's an incredible strip of souviner shops and places to grab a snack/bite to eat...and a souvenir or two. We were staying in Shinagawa and made the trip via the water versus the train/subway. That was well well worth it and higly recommended.
Worth visiting. The most iconic place to visit in Tokyo, Japan. There are many traditional Japanese shops and restaurants around the temple, and the temple has a really great night view.

A Sea of Humanity in a Beautiful Setting. This gigantic temple is a colorful and elaborate structure inside and outside. The nearby beautiful 5 -tier pagoda could be imagined to be a bell tower for the temple. An arcade of shops and food stalls almost 1/2 mile long leads to the gate and front of the temple. Lots more shops on the streets parallel to and crossing the arcade. The grounds surrounding the temple have the famous Japanese cherry trees and are a great place to people watch, because the area is a sea of people, locals and visitors. It's really a don't-miss destination.

Not what I expected :/. Having just arrived in japan we decided to go to the number one tourist attraction; sensoji temple. I was actually disappointed by it.I don't know what I was expecting, having never visited a shrine or temple before but I wasn't blown away by it.I guess I don't see how it can be a spiritual place when there are literally thousand of people there. It was very noisy with heaaaaaps of tourists everywhere. In my opinion Meiji jingu is 10 times better.

crowded but must visit place in tokyo. Sensō-ji temple is very crowded but must visit place in tokyo. it is beautiful & big enough. the building is beautiful and attractive. not only tourist but lot of local people at there. in short, Sensō-ji temple is typical and traditional japanese temple.

Wish I'd had more time here. I came here as part of a Tokyo day tour and we only had about an hour to visit the temple complex. It was very busy because it was a national holiday, but this added to the atmosphere. There are plenty of food and souvenir stalls surrounding the complex and I would have liked to return here during my stay in Tokyo to spend more time just wandering around the shopping streets.

Popular temple for visitors. This is a well frequented Temple in Asakusa by both locals coming to worship, and tourists. I was there in peak season, and it was very crowded but you were still able to make your way around the temple and grounds. The pathway leading up to the Temple from the gate was lined with market stalls of all varieties, as well as some food stalls. The grounds are beautiful and quintessential Japanese. I was there in cherry blossom time (first week in April) which made it extra beautiful with the canopy of blossoms lining the pathway. Definitely add it to you "to see" list.

What a wonderful place to people watch. What a great place to go on the weekend. Loads of people but many dressed in traditional dress out for a stroll and happy to have their photos taken. Go back at night and photograph when the crowds are gone and the lights are on. wonderful

Definitely worth a visit!. Sensoji is located right by Asakusa station which makes it the perfect place to start if you're planning to check out Tokyo Sky Tree, or just visiting Asakusa in general. The alley leading up to Sensoji is lined with countless small souvenir shops with great omiyage alternatives for friends and family back home. The temple itself is beautiful and quite large, with many things to see and try! It's also surrounded by different food/game stands in summer; so kids won't get bored here. Yes, it can get quite crowded (especially during golden week) but if that's a deal breaker you might want to go to another city altogether ☮.
Amazing Very Spiratual, A must see!!. We were there in Golden week so shared the experience with all the Japanese, the atmosphere was so amazing, Asakusa area a must see, The older part of Tokyo

Too crowded. I arrived early in the morning on weekday (monday) but it was already packed with people. It was so crowded from the entrance until the end of the shop area and after that, it is still crowded but bearable. I cant really enjoy my visit to the temple. Most people come early so that they can ride the tokyo cruise to odaiba or to continue to tokyo skytree so it might be a good idea to do the opposite, to go to skytree first and visit sensoji later. Anyway I still think its a beautiful temple and a must visit place in tokyo.Asakusa is not served by Yamanote Line so the easiest way is to transfer to Ginza Line.

beautiful temple but just too many people!. Was there for the golden week; just too many people. There is even a line for preying in the main shrine . The shops before the temple all have similar stuff for sale; would enjoy it more if it wasn't so many people. Hard to get a photo without people walking in front of your face.

Amazing..... Stayed a 5min walk away so went early one morning to see in all its glory ! The blossom was at its peak which made everything truly magical ! Amongst everything else we saw, we saw a traditional Japanese wedding and a man walking a pig on a lead !!!
You have to go if you are in Tokyo. Typical oriental Buddhist temple, beautiful. You have to go if you are in Tokyo. Very crowded, you can find a lot of food and gadgets to buy.

A little culture and shopping. I visited this is a great classic temple in early April. Our host explained a little about the symbolism and history. It was very interesting and it led to many photo ops. There are lots of little shrines on the side streets. This was my only chance to visit a cultural site and I am happy we picked this one. You will only need 45 min here, 1 ½ if you do some shopping too.Right outside the temple is a very busy shopping area that is also great for people watching. Of course it was crowded, but that is part of the experience. It was also peek day for cherry blossoms so it was extra crowed, but again you just go with the flow. Lots of little stands with all kinds of inexpensive things to buy and food vendors too. They are not as pushy as other countries I have visited. The items I purchased were cheap enough that I did not barter.

A must see. Walking through the Temple gate there's a long market with many stalls on both side, another gate and the main Temple is before you in all it grandeur. There are several shrines and a beautiful Pagoda, don't forget your camera or you'll regret it. Entry is free plus you can even get a free green tea while taking a rest from walking round.. While there you may want to light a few joss sticks or find your fortune for just a few JPY

Best looking temple in Tokyo.. This is a beautiful temple, consisting of several shrines, a stunning pagoda and a beautiful and long market leading to it.The market vendors sell just about everything, and the prices are surprisingly good.The temple itself provides superb photo-ops, and as its atmosphere changes dramatically during the day, you are better off visiting it twice, in the morning and in the evening, as the experience is totally different.The place is always packed with locals and tourists alike, so get yourself ready for the crowds.

Best temple in Tokyo. There are not many top-class temples in Tokyo, but this is the best without a doubt. Lovely temple with a nice small garden and many many statues and sights to visit. Go early and give yourself time to enjoy all corners of the place.

Large temple and grounds in north Tokyo. This was the first site we visited during our tour of Japan. We visited this on our own and it's definitely a major tourist attraction. Actually it was one of the places that had the largest group of foreign tourists. We walked through the grounds, visited one of the smaller temples, visited the main building and walked near the 5-story pagoda. There was a small Japanese garden setup on the grounds which was pleasant. No entry fee, but can be very crowded. We visited around the 19th of April, 2015.

A must visit place. One of the real gems of Tokyo, this is an exciting site to visit, whether there is a temple service going on or not, and whether it is daytime or night time. Try to visit the interesting adjoining small art gallery (to the left as you face the temple) which has a quite exquisite Japanese water garden attached.
A popular Temple. This is a very popular temple and I suggest and early visit to try and avoid the crowds that build up by mid-day. Easy to navigate temple and signposted to assist the visitor.

Full of tourists. A must visit place to taste and feel the japanese culture. But be sure to arrive early as not to be swamped by huge crowds of tourists. there were so many stalls selling from hand made biscuits to traditional kimono.

Peace & Crowds. The Nakamise Dori, leading up to the Sensoji Temple is full of souvenirs and sweet treats and lots & lots of people! Its great fun and really interesting to see. The gardens surrounding the Sensoji Temple are beautiful and peaceful in contrast and the delicious food being fretting cooked all around means you can easily spend a couple of hours in and around Sensoji Temple.

Senso-Ji temple should not miss from your attraction list. We have visited many temple in Japan and in Tokyo during our holiday. Senso-Ji Temple is nice and located in an active tourist area like Asakusa. The Temple is as many in Japan, however being surrounded by many shops and well connected with other attractions (like the Tokyo Skytree just a station away) makes it a perfect stop over.Definitely it is worth a visit.
Very famous and beautiful!. I try to visit Sensoji temple every time I'm in town to pay the respect. Very famous temple. A must!!

Fascinating Mix of Temple and Busy Tourist Area. The Thunder Gate and Temple as well as small side gardens, are beautiful, peaceful and fascinating. I was not really prepared to the crowded jostling street, lined with little shops, leading to the temple. The shops have a range of gifts from day kimonos, to swords, inexpensive gifts and toys to great smelling food. I recommend dressing in bright colors to help keep track of people you are are with.

Worth the hustle and bustle. It is extremely crowded here in the mornings, but don't let that deter you! The temple is beautifully maintained and being able to see the monks perform their rituals is mesmerising. The gardens are beautiful, as are the other little pagodas and statues surrounding the temple. There are many stalls selling souvenirs, traditional Japanese goods and food. Do explore the side streets and get lost amongst all the wonderment. I ended up having fugu (poisonous blowfish) for lunch, which was delicious! And get in line for the crazy ice creams in traditional Japanese flavours such as matcha, black sesame & purple sweet potato. Many locals also like to come here dressed in traditional kimono/yakuta, which is very pleasant to see. Make a separate trip in at night. The crowds are far less (you almost have the place to yourself if you come around 8pm) and the lighting on the temple makes it look absolutely beautiful! None of the shops are open around this time though, if you're planning on buying anything.

Really Interesting. We went here on New Year's Day 2015 and it was incredibly busy. That said, it was very well organised and the crowds moved quickly. We really enjoyed the atmosphere as people prayed for the year ahead. Bring a camera!

Impressive buildings. The buildings are well maintained and impressive in detail, as is the Pagoda. A must for those into prayer. Well manicured gardens and make sure you see the statues. The street leading to the shrine is full of souvenir shops which taints it for me. Would rather have a more solemn entrance and the commercial side further away.

Beautiful and full of tradition.. The temple was beautiful and very busy due to Golden Week however everyone was respectful and somehow it was peaceful here. Lots of different smells, food, and sights to take in. Easy to get to if you have a good knowledge of the train system in Japan. It's definitely a must see.

Lots of people. Lovely temple but a lot of visitors. Best to visit earlier in the day, otherwise it will take a while just to walk through Nakamise Dori and the large number of souvenir shops that line the path.

The senso-ji shrine was an amazing experience to go see it.. Senso-ji shrine. The oldest temple in Japan. Just incredible. You will feel the experience of transporting yourself back in time. I just could not get enough had to go twice. Highly recommended when you are in Azakusa Japan.

Lovely, truly lovely.. If you can plan your trip at all, try to get to Japan during Golden Week. Our first visit to Japan was coincidentally during Golden week and the temple and gardens besides Sensoji Temple made thisPlace extra extra special. It is full of tourist and locals, and there are lots of vendors, but it is a surprisingly spiritual place.

Love this place. I have been to fews temple during my vacation at Japan. This is the temple that I like lots. I can feed harmony and people believe expressing everywhere in the temple. Easy to reach this temple using Azakuza station.

Crazy crowds for an amazing temple. Must see in Tokyo, great location and even greater experience, just try and see it on a weekday as it might be a little less crowded however there is plenty of room and chances to see everything even if it is crowded

Tokyo's main Buddhist temple. Before entering the temple area be sure to visit the Asakusa tourist information center at the beginning of the street which leads to the temple itself. There's a free observatory on the 8th floor with perfect aerial view of the temple on one side, and Tokyo sky tree on the other.On the entrance of the temple area is the Thunder Kaminarimon gate with a huge red lantern, a perfect photo spot. The temple is packed with people, both locals and tourists. It is very beautiful, and it's Tokyo's most sacred Buddhist temple. Stroll through the beautiful gardens around the main hall.Bear in mind that this is the 20th century original replica, because the original one didn't survive the II WW bombing. Entrance is free, allow 1-2 hours.

Too crowded. When I was visiting, it was raining as hell. Although I went on monday, lots of tourist were there. And it was hard to walk through those crowd under that kind of rain.But, the temple was fine, not many tourist were going inside the main temple, so I can look around freely :)And the temple staff were very nice, she told me a lot of stuff about the temple.

Busy, busy, busy...... A busy place for both tourists and locals, but a nice way to spend an hour or two. As my wife and I are keen photographers, this was a must. The temple itself is stunning along with the pagoda to the left, also worth a walk around the gardens as they are in typical fashion, manicured and clean. We combined this visit with a trip to the Skytree, which is only a ten minute walk away on the other side of the river.

One of oldest in Tokyo. It is located in Asakusa, a busy touristy area. This temple is on everyone’s itinerary so it gets really busy with many tour groups. There is a 5-story pagoda. The main gate is called Kaminarimon or “Thunder Gate” has a large red lantern and leads into Nakamise-dori which is lined with souvenir shops and other stalls selling various foods.

Not our favourite. Struggled through Nakamise street before we got to the Sensoji Temple, it was crowded and a long street full of shops. At the gate this street is called "the processional road". We were not able to get in to the Temple and could only have a look from the outside through a kind of wired fence. The pagoda was nice to see but nothing special, we enjoyed the little garden with a few old statues and a small pagoda - bronze Hokyoin-to - on the left of the temple.

Must see in Asakusa. Great and beautiful building... One of the attraction in Tokyo that everyone should see.. Try to see your fortune by doing the fortune teller ritual.. Believe it or not, just have fun with it...

Not to be missted... Nice temple.. Theres shop near the temple.. Should go there.. After spend time in the temple u can go shopping and theres so many street food.. Not so far with market in asakusa.. Theres good ramen restaurant.. (Forgot the name)
A pleasant Walk. Lots people because they have nothing else to do.Fairly impressive but not essential. Good for people watching though & interesting area that it is located in.

Not to be missed. As nearly everything in Tokyo and Japan the Temple was busy and crowded as well as the approach patch lined with junk souvenirs and sweet stuff. But still worth to go. The early morning visit would the best time. Side buildings less crowded. I went there during blossom season but this is not the best spot like Ueno park.There is no entrance fee and the temple can be visited any time as it is open 24 hours.5 minutes from Asakusa station, exit A5.

Interesting temple. With so many tourists pouring to the gate, we love to see traditional meet modernity. While strolling to buy souvenirs to family back home, we learned so many new things about japanese tradition, including the history of the temple through the tour guide

Crowded, but still worth a visit. Senso-ji is worth visiting, if just for the historical significance. I found it to be very crowded (as are most of the touristy things in Tokyo), but still pretty cool. I would recommend you get there early if you want to take uninterrupted pictures of the temple complex.

Busy busy but worthwhile. The mistake may have been going on a Saturday in April, but my goodness, we could barely walk down the road, let alone see the shops. That being said, this is a beautiful temple and worth seeing.It is easy to get "shrined out" so I highly recommend selecting a few special ones to see and this could definitely go on a short list being in a great district to begin with.This temple is also handy if you are traveling with someone who might have difficulty walking on the uneven trails or gravel at some other sites, as it was paved.If you're traveling with kids that are tired of museums and shrines, there is also a small amusement park nearby. We didn't go, but I could see it being a nice change of pace for families.We took the Maranouchi Line from Shinjuku Station to Ginza and then jumped on the Ginza Line to Asakusa!

Chaos & Giant Lanterns. Not my favorite temple in Tokyo but worth a visit. Giant red lanterns frame the entrances and make for quite an impressive sight and a great photo op. There is a long shopping arcade prior to the main part of the temple - tons of junky souvenirs and treats on sale. There is an over-powering scent of incense at the main entrance to the temple and the inside is rather gloomy. However, the cherry blossom trees added quite a bit of beauty to the scene and the temple is just a few blocks away from the Sumida River and Park.

Oldest temple in Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is the oldest temple in Tokyo and just a must to see while you are here.It was founded in 628. It has valuable items such as paintings on the ceiling and a five-story pagoda tower.Sensoji Temple is sometimes referred to as Asakusa Temple.Just go through Hozomon Gate Sensoji Temple, wich contains the very famous and massive red paper lantern.
