Hozomon Gate is the gateway to the Sensoji Temple.How to get here:Tobu Isezaki Line / Ginza Line / Tsukuba Express: Asakusa Station (Exit 1) and then round 5-10 minutes by foot trough the downtown area.
Temple is OK, shops are nice.. I enjoyed the shops around the temple a lot more than the temple itself. It was hard to appreciate the temple with so many people around.

Peaceful during the day stunning at night. I strolled through this sight taking in the architecture during the morning before it was overly crowded. It was peaceful and calming. Many details to look at. A few nights later I went back at night with a friend when we happened to be in the area. The lighting at night gives it an entirely different look. Glad I saw it in both aspects. Differently should go but make sure to plan other things in the area as well.

Check out the spirituality (among the souvenirs!). One of the few surviving old buildings in Tokyo - this is a classical zen temple compound with impressive gates and lanterns, teeming with people and approached through a diverting avenue of small stalls and shops offering all the tat your heart desires. Must see then stroll the river or catch a boat to the Rishiki across the water or head to Ueno.

Beautiful City Temple. You will be greeted by a huge gate with a huge lantern which is a very good spot for photo. After that is a long lane full with souvenirs & local snacks shops, before you get into the main temple. The temple is very well organize & maintain, despite the rain all day long, people were keep coming both the tourists & the locals. There are few temples in the Sensoji area itself for you to explore. It also a cherry blossom spot, unfortunately, the cherry blossom already fell off when I visited there.
Stunning. Definitely worth a trip while in Tokyo. Stunning buildings and gateways with cherry blossoms everywhere in April. So lovely.

Hmm - So-so. I'm in the minority on this one - yes nice shops, interesting gate, crowded as heck - but temple didn't seem to be anything special. Plenty of other sights to see that would be more interesting.

Loved it. I love Sensoji Temple with the shops and culture embedded together. I especially enjoyed the small garden area with the waterfall and koi pond. Wish they would put a bench there. Take a look at the bridge that is blocked off over the koi pond - you can see how people walking over it for over 100 years has weathered it.

A must see in Tokyo. This place will remind you of the past of Tokyo. Surrounded by modernity, The Sensoji was well preserved to remind people about the rich culture and history of Japan. A must see attraction and a good walking spot since there are plenty of shops to buy stuff. Well recommended :)

everything you want in a city temple. This temple is great, the entrance has many gates and a long arcade of shops. Some of the shops sell traditional items but it is mostly for tourists these days. The temple itself is very large with many minor temples surrounding it. I would recommend going really early in the morning when it first opens so you can get a better sense of space, be sure to stop by the minor temples. When you go there is a hand washing station and a smoke station so that you can cleanse yourself.Enjoy!

Nice to visit the temple, gate and shopping street but you'll see much better in Kyoto. Very close to Asakusa station (subway) and through the shopping street is this lovely temple, it has a few different buildings and gardens, though not too big, it's nice to go and visit and learn the history there.We saw much better temple buildings in Kyoto though, so if you miss out, don't be too worried.After this we went over to the Edo-Tokyo Museum - well worth a visit.
Very impressive site. Certainly a must-see for everyone who is in this neighbourhood, with lots of small shops nearby and a distinctly 'real' Japanese atmosphere.

A beautiful crowded temple and a must see. We drove to the Asakusa Senso-ji Temple, which is also known as the Asakusa Kannon Temple. It is the oldest temple in Japan being completed in the year 645 AD. Having two names confused me during our itinerary planning process. The place was packed with people browsing the many shops leading up to the temple. They were really good shops with lots of items that made good souvenirs and gifts.The temple itself is quite beautiful as was the pagoda close to it. The interior statues were protected from birds with fine netting; but you could still take photos. It was the prettiest temple we saw while in Japan for a week.

Lovely!!!. lovely temple and the 1 i loved most among those that I visitedit's very crowded, giving the whole temple a very vibrant and festive feel.if there's only 1 temple that i can visit, this will be itthe temple and the area around it, can easily take over 3 hours to explore slowly
Beautiful Temple. Big, beautiful temple area, when we got there was in the middle of sakura bloom so the garden was super beautiful.
The best temple in Tokyo...but.... The best temple in Tokyo...and a must see while there...but you will see better in Kyoto. Very crowded.

Nice... but New..!. A beautiful temple, set next to a thriving market, in fact the market stalls form a long entrance i to the temple complex... We went on a weekend which was VERY busy... (weekends best avoided, as this Temple is popular with the Japanese)... The temple itself is large and spectacular, but when you realize it was destroyed in the Second World War are has since been extensively rebuilt, it kinda loses some of it's charm... It does look "brand new", and as such wasn't our favourite.
Interesting Temple but crowded. Nice temple - a must see in Tokyo. Its beautiful during the Sakura season. Its very touristy and crowded.

One of the better temples. One of the better temples, it is colourful and in Asakusa which is a decent area. After visiting the temple we did a cruise of the nearby river, which is a different way to see Tokyo if unspectacular.

Too crowded.. This temple was too crowded for people who wanna be in peace for praying. But it's still a great visit, the temple itself was big and worth a look. There were big cannon or lantern? or whatever at the entrance gate which was very popular for taking photo with. In front of the temple, there were several souvenir and dessert shops which could eat up all your money so be prepared!

really interesting temple, market and area. we had a bit of an advantage because we had a private guide and she did a great job explaining the history and the current culture of the place. if you don't have a guide, do some reading before you go so you can really enjoy it too. the market area leading up to the temple is touristy, but authentic. sure there are tourist souvenirs like keychains and postcards, but also nice handmade items and lots of food. I usually avoid this type of schlocky stuff but they really had some nice mementos and all were priced well. at the temple, you can pay homage by praying, cleaning your hands and burning incense. there is a definite process so if you don't know what you're doing, watch other people first. the surrounding area also had interesting shops and restaurants. we really like the area around the temple.

nice temple. if your like me, you don't really give a damn about temples and such. This one was cool to see, it has a big red ball thing which is cool I guess. you can throw a coin in the temple and make a wish - hopefully it comes true!The area around the temple is nice and its a good place to check out. Do it

Crowded but still worth a stop. We did the temple complex as part of an organized tour. With only an hour or so to explore we made quick work of seeing the sights. The ceilings are done exceptionally well. Netting to keep birds out will obstruct your photos so be aware. The lure of the place is both the sightseeing of the structures and the people coming to use it for the intended purpose. Not everyone there is a tourist. The shopping arcade was very crowded but you can go down the side streets just one over to the left or right and be almost alone. There are even shops on those sides which you can enjoy for souvenirs or drinks and food.

A must in Tokyo. If you want to see temple in Tokyo. Here is the place that you should go. Sensoji Temple and Asakusa area is amazing place! You can come to see how faith of poeple to this temple, also surround with all interesting shop and restaurants. Mostly are keep in the treditional style. From sweet to Kimono, you can find almost everything here!

Very glad we visited. My son and I included Sensoji as part of our 45 hours in Tokyo and were very happy that we did. The neighborhood is different from the other areas we visited. It feels older, more traditional. I was glad we saw the huge lanterns, as we had seen photos of them before. The little shops and stalls we fun to browse, and the street good was delicious. We got some steamed dumplings that were amazing. Later I wished we had bought a few more. The temple was very busy, but it was fun to see the hustle and bustle. Most of the tourists actually were Japanese, including tons of school kids, all having tons of fun getting their fortunes from traditional walls of fortune drawers. It was interesting to see the traditional purification rituals being done by most of the visitors, as well. Even my son enjoyed exploring the ground for an hour or so. We were really glad we visited. I will stop by again if I am in Tokyo.

Beautiful Goddess of Mercy temple. This small but beautiful temple has a humble history behind it. Having just completed a restoration, the temple looks new and beautiful, Many locals come here to pray to Goddess of Mercy. There are also many shops around the temple. You can find souvenirs, Japanese snacks and many more stuff in the shops. Take your time and walk through the streets surrounding the temple. You may find something interesting.

Sensoji is the place to be. Really great example of traditional Japan in the heart of Tokyo. Sure, it's mobbed by tourists, but this is one of those places where it adds to experience.The temple is free to visit, which is a boon. You start by entering the giant gates. They lead to the old shopping street, where you can many treats and tacky gifts. the treats are nice, but the souvenirs are pretty lame. At the end of the shopping road, you will find another set of gates. Enter, and you're in the temple area. Great place to spend an hour. More if you explore the area around the temple.

Great old age architecture,not so much spiritual. It's a sudden transition to an ancient world in the middle of a busy new age city. The Buddha's statues standing at the entrance of the busy temple are the only peaceful sights. The quaint temple attracts a lot visitors, don't expect great pictures here.

A must visit when you are in Tokyo. This temple holds special significance to the Japanese, and is the oldest temple in Tokyo. Goggle the story as it is well worth it. Leave via the North entrance of Asakusa station and you will be delivered onto the road that leads to the temple. This road is pedestrian only and full of shops for trinkets, Japanese traditional gods and food. Lots of food mainly sweet treats. One thing you must try is the Japanese sweet bread. Wow, that is something else!! A walk to the temple and a most amazing building awaits you. With lots of local devotees and tourists the mix is quite exhilarating. Make sure you have your camera with you. We spent over an hour just at the temple.Afterwards explore the surrounding streets of Asakusa. Hint. Plans your trip to coincide with morning tea so you can sample the sweets. Remember you cannot walk and eat at the same time as this is considered bad manners. Then, after the shrine find a little restaurant for an authentic japanese style lunch. There are literally hundreds of them in the surrounding streets.

Blessed visit to Sensoji Temple. A remarkable old temple built in 628. The pagoda, main temple, massive lanterns & dieties. It's beautiful places ..gets very crowded on weekends. To get here...just take the train to Asakusa station. Exit & right across the road is the Kaminarimon Gate ( you can't miss the oriental arch with the giant lantern )and the 2 dieties that guards the entrance. Walk along Nakamise Shopping Street...ending at Sensoji Temple.

cool neighborhood, cool but crowded temple. I believe strongly that crowded places can be a bit tiring. In this case I went with my friends on a sunday so there was soooo much people. It was hard to walk and take pictures (which I love). But besides from that, the road to the temple is super cool, full of small shops to buy souvenirs or eat the most fun japanese street style food. I don't even know what I ate, I just said yes to my friends and opened my mouth haha. Everything was delicious! And the temple is beautiful, and there is the 5 stories kind of pagoda building, which I didn't see anywhere else. Also a lot of fortune papers to choose from!! hahaMost of all I liked the mood of Asakusa as a whole. Lots of things going on, tourists but also native people having fun, eating proper japanese, taking fortune serious, and just strolling down the streets <3

Definitely worth a visit!. Must visit even if you are not Buddhist. It is a rarity in our modern age to have an historic building preserved, maintained and frequented by multitudes of visitors daily. The surrounding area will satisfy everyone in your group from photographers, history buffs, shopaholics, thrill seekers and foodies.

Night visit. I visited at night to take some photographs. The area was very quite as most of the crowds had gone and the local shops had closed. All the local,attractions are lit up so I was able to get some good shots.

A beautiful shrine in Asakusa. A beautiful shrine in the center of the Asakusa ward. The temples and shrines are well maintained and very popular with tourists and locals alike. Great food and trinket shops are also found on the grounds.

My favourite Shrine. Asakusa is my favourite place in Tokyo and Senso-ji is a great place to visit. Not only is the Shrine lovely, there is so much to do. The shopping arcade leading up to the Shrine is a busy and colourful place and there are over 80 stalls that sell fantastic souvenirs and food. Also, don't forget to get your fortune at the Shrine .... Also very popular!! There are some seating areas scattered around the shrine to rest those weary legs which are godsend (with vending machines of course), and there are also a number of restaurants around. Don't miss this ..... You won't regret it.
Lovely. We were lucky enough to be there when the blossom was at its peak.... Gorgeous and well worth the visit

Don't miss it. This is a breath taking glimpse into the culture, history and spirituality of the Japanese people. Did it during Cherry Blossom bloom, but I imagine it's stunning on almost any day. I will never forget it.

Beautiful Shrine & Fun Shopping Street. Sensoji is a very pretty temple at the end of the colourful and chaotic Nakamise shopping street. As with most shrines, this one is very pretty and is the center of a complex like structure with other smaller shrines surrounding it. It has interesting bronze sculptures around, including the first one of a woman I saw in my ten days in Japan. All temples have mini gardens of their own which are gorgeous - mini streams, lush trees and bushes - it's a wholesome experience.

Beautiful and an amazing experience!. This was such a beautiful temple and a great experience. Walking up to the temple, you pass through a row of souvenir and snack shops. We wish we would have had more time to explore this area but were on a tour and only had an allotted period of time. We rushed through the shops in order to spend time at the temple. We were shown by the locals the way to wash your hands and face before entering the temple. Once in the temple, we were able to light prayer candles and get our fortunes from a system where you shake a box until a stick comes out and then finding the corresponding drawer to your stick, which contains your fortune. We were lucky enough to both receive a good fortune! The temple itself was beautiful and ornate. A must see when in Tokyo.

Very Busy Shrine, Worth A Visit. This shrine is absolutely gorgeous! It is amazingly well kept. Everything looks clean and very well detailed. Only downside was the throngs of tourists (and some of them rude, pushing you around) and the shops, many many shops. The shops take away from the whole temple feeling. This complex is gigantic and has a lot of things to see.

A lovely change from shopping. This was one of the first places that I went to in Tokyo. I had a really nice morning there. The approach to the shine is frantic but fun with lots of snacks and gift shops along the way. When you reach the shrine it is excellent and there are some great photo opportunities. We went in April so the cherry blossom was a wonderful addition. I would recommend it.

Spectacular day or night!. The temple and its surrounds are beautiful and so accessible. In the day in peak season it takes a time to walk the main parade (past all the small souvenir shops) but at night cycle round the area with little pedestrian traffic and the pleasure of the pagoda and temple lit to perfection.

Well worth a visit. The whole temple complex is very interesting, with many small shrines and gates in addition to the main temple, shrine and pagoda. There's also the market which has some interesting twists on foods.

Popular place for pilgrims. Beautiful place in the heart of the bustle.Go in the evening to really appreciate the atmosphere. Loved the history and architecture but it gets really crowded after 11 am.

Worth the trip!. This temple is farther than some want to go but an easy ride on the subway. Unbelievable history. A 5-story pagoda. It is busy on the weekends with locals and tourists alike. Worth the trip!
Historic cultural . Lovely view. Excellent for photos. Be mindful to be respectful to the landmark. Tons of shops around to buy souvenirs and gifts and food
Beautiful and Great shopping. If you're looking to buy souvenirs while in Tokyo, go to the temple. The street before it is lined with great shops and the temple itself is beautiful!

Worshipping crowds with turists mingling around. Lights crowd on a Friday 10am. Many shops are still being opened. The incense is surrounding visitors close to the temple. The lesser crowd makes it easier to climb the stairs and see the inner temple.
The streets and galeries around are worth the visit too.

Walk Through Asakusa come to the end of this temple. Lots of shopping for tourist and can see the temple at the end,
A big massive beautiful building like Shrine.
Giant lantern, Lots of candles, You cannot go in as it is blocked but can view it. Lots of people there. As you would expect to see in every temple. Building very colourful architecture design were Wonderful.
Very nice temple and hall nearby.. The first Japanese temple I see so I cannot compare but on a sunny Sunday morning it just looked the best .

temple or market. the temple pagoda and garden around was very nice for travlers
the small shops around for tuorist -dislike

Best to visit during the week. I was able to visit the temple and shopping area twice during my visit. The first time was during the week and it was busy but manageable. I went back to pick up some sovuniers on Saturday and it was packed. You definitely want to fit this into your visit but perhaps save the Harajuko district for the weekend.

Like a Festival. I visited here with my family. Nakamise Main Street, penetrating between entrance gate and main temple, was crowded with tourists. There were a lot of shops selling Japanese traditional sweets and drinks, and I tried them four times during the round trip between the gate and temple.I recommend to try sweets and drinks, and to enjoy eating and drinking, I also recommend to come here between meals such as around 10:30 or 15:00.
a beautiful shrine. As you walk up the path there are some beautiful very large wooden gates, the shrine itself is very symbolic. Well worth a visit

Breathtaking, especially at night. I visited twice. Once at night and again in the day. At night the lighting makes the temple and sorrow sings even more breathtaking.It was also quieter at night, but even in the day, although busy, everything kept moving.Shinto and Buddhist temples are next to each other and it's well worth finding out about the history of them [temples] both.

Crowded, but beautiful. This is a beautiful temple complex, but because it is one of the most famous (apperantly) temples in the city, this also makes it one of the most crowded. Many tourists but also locals.

A little disappointing. I visited this Temple on a Tuesday morning and it was very easy to find from Asakusa Station. I must say, I was disappointed. The shopping street leading up to the temple was so busy with tourists and many shops selling Japanese souvenirs, not good quality, very kitchy. The temple itself was also very, very busy. I read it was a reproduction because the original temple was damaged in the war and it looked like a reproduction - all shiny and new. However, there were some quieter, nicer areas to the side. It did not have the same spiritual, calm feeling like, for example Zojoji temple.

Culture at your door step. If you're into temples, it's a must see. If you're not into temples but are staying nearby, it's a must see. It is beauty and serenity in the heart of the city. The grounds and gardens are beautiful and it remains an active temple for worshippers.The gates are also magnificent and the shopping and markets that surround the temple are also great fun. Easy to sort the really kitschy-touristy from the quality and not hard to see where the locals shop as well.

very tourist location but still. it is a major attraction and it takes alot of tourist during normal hours.if you go early, you will find a lot of peace. alot of zenit is a functional temple and thus, as always be courteous in our actions in the property
Nice temple to pray and shop later. Liked the Japanese novelty stores along the temple, fried food like mocha tastes great, they have excellent souvenirs

Gorgeous Ancient Buddhist Temple. Well preserved Buddhist Temple in Asakusa where one can practice traditional Buddhist religious acts. Fortune telling activity on the side, incense for evil cleansing in the middle and prayers while throwing some coin offering. After which, lots of photo opportunity around the temple.

lots of people and places to eat. holy placenice to see at night toono entrance feewill come againlots of eateries or places to eatu can see skytree at a distancevery safe and will come early since there are so many people

Beautiful, but messy. Senso-ji was the first temple we visited in Tokyo. I would say it is definitely not the nicest. The Buddhist temple itself is impressive, but so full of visitors it gets hard to calmly contemplate it. One thing that called our attention was how the city grew around and squeezed it, which took some of its beauty. Adding the hundreds of small souvenir and food shops around it, the whole thing becomes the typical tourist program. Go for it, but make it quick and save time for other temples.
Big Lampion. Nice place with traditional Japanese architecture, there is Cherry blossom blooming around temple. there is also garden with many flower and tulip. I love this temple and ambiance.
Excellent. Combining with Nakamise vendor street, the scene with full of red lantern is the most appreciated place in Tokyo. Cheap and plentiful souvenirs a well.

Souvenirs and Street Food Galore!. The best place to shop for souvenirs! You do not need to go far, as this place sells all kinds of souvenirs you need, from wood block prints, Kokeshi dolls, Furoshiki, Ninja weapons, Pottery and local arts and crafts.This place is also teeming with street food...Takoyaki, Mochi balls, flavored Kit-kat, Rice cake with Nori, Grilled Octopus, Tempura, Suhis, Ramen, Udon...you name it, they have it here!They even have make-shift bars that do not welcome tourists...just exclusively for locals...Restaurants are abundant in this place. We stayed in Richmond Hotel which is just about 100 mtrs from the temple. We never ran out of places to eat or street food to try.

Nice place. The place is near subway station. There are lots of stores selling foods and different stuff before you came to main temple. Touristry but the place is still nice. You can also see the tokyo sky tree from these place.
Beautiful. well worth a visit and don't miss visiting the shrine as well. Really enjoyed this temple though very busy with tourists

I luv this temple. The temple is so big.
You can find the souvenir shops in front of the temple.
There is the famous tempura restaurant around the temple.

Touristy but still nice to visit. I know many people say this is a touristy place, but even though it is to some, I always like to visit this place. The temple is beautiful and nicely preserved and I just love to walk through Nakamise Dori towards the temple. I always go for the green tea ice cream that's sold at more than one vendor there. Lots of food booths and shops full of knick knacks. I always end up buying my dog a japanese costume from one of the shops selling dog items. You can also veer off to the covered street mall that has more shops and restaurants. I just love strolling through there along with locals and tourists. Everyone seems to be courteous to each other and it's good that when we visit there we follow the Japanese customs. Picking up after oneself and being conscientious of your actions is appreciated since much of that is being lost elsewhere.

Simply Beautiful. When I visited it was warm and very busy with locals and tourists, it was possible to take park in some sort of religious bathing as well as write prayers and hopes on a a kind of tree. I just wanted to see everything and take it all in so didn't bother with washing/prayers. Don't miss a chance to go and see this for yourself it is truly wonderful.
Sensoji Temple. We went to view the temple in the late afternoon. We went back at night and it was more beautiful with the lights on.

Well preseved. Lots of temples and little small shrines to pick anyone's interest. Lots of people milling around the temple ground and the main temple. Great place to see how the locals practice their faith and traditions.

Festival spirit. We were in Tokyo during cherry blossom time and the street in front of the shrine was covered with decorative flowers. It was quite a crowd there at around 5 p.m. and lots of young people wearing yukata. Mostly girls, but some boys too. I liked the atmosphere there, it was one of the moments to feel other life style and habits as a foreigner in a new country.

Wonderful service, great food. I really enjoyed the visit to the this temple. So much to do and see in the area from shopping to experiencing the temple and exploring the surrounding gardens and statues. Not all of the fortunes are good fortunes if you decide to try it.
A must see!. Very busy when we went, but an awesome cultural sight for japan, if spending time in Tokyo and you want to see something semi-cultural, here's your place

Tons of things to experience!. Walking into Sensoji, you are greeted by tons of vendors selling gifts, snacks, and well.. anything you can possibly think of. An overwhelming smell of sweet treats is a great way to start the experience. It is crowded, obviously since it is a great tourist spot. The area has a lot of places to pray. It includes tons of small things to do where you donate a few yen, and can even get your fortune told. Surprisingly the fortune I chose has proven to be correct. Funny how things work out! There are tons of places to go even outside the area of the temple. So you'll be able to spend a lot of time here.

Beautiful temple in the middle of bustling Asakusa!. Really loved the contrast of Japanese history to modern day culture - you really feel like you're in another world when you're on the temple grounds. Check out the outdoor market just outside the grounds too!

Sensoji temple a great place to visit. The first time I went to Japan in 2006 the first place our tour guide took us to was Sensoji Temple. I have been back to Japan 8 times since and most of the trips back I have visited Sensoji Temple because it is such an amazing place to go to. It is always busy and exciting place to be. It is easy to get to as has several subway stops less than a five minute walk away which will are connected to Ueno station from which you can easily access most places in Tokyo.
Sensoji ji!!. Absolutely loved the atmosphere here. had a wonderful time walking around and looking at the buildings in the grounds. A photography dream!

Must go. For your good luck, This is the first place that you should visit when you arrive Tokyo. The temple is surrounded by many shops and restaurant. Although there are so many visitors but it seems lively than crowded.

Interesting temple and garden complex with a good mix of restaurants around it. We visited on the first week of January and the place was packed! But yet, we were able to find some quiet space and enjoyed the temple ground. Crowd control was well managed. There are also plenty of good restaurants nearby and the Asakusa station is less than a block away! This is an older neighborhood and we enjoyed observing the local people doing their groceries shopping! Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful temple with an air of tranquility. If you're seeking refuge from the overwhelmingly hectic environment of urban Tokyo, head to this area in Asakusa around the Sensoji Temple. It has a really peaceful, meditative vibe, especially once you untangle yourself from the throng of people viewing the shops nearby and find yourself near the burning sticks of incense.Make sure you get a fortune from inside the temple, which requires you to download a little money—the recommended amount is ¥100. It's an interesting process where you have to shake a tin filled with think wooden sticks for as long as you feel is necessary to enhance your good fortune. Then you slide out one of the sticks from a little hole at the bottom of the tin. There are some Japanese characters at the top, which you can match to one of a set of drawers. Each drawer has a different collection of fortunes.
The place to go. At first it seemed too touristy, but it has an interesting mix, of food, souvenirs, temple and stuff. Must see.

The Great Fortune of O-mikuji. Go here.. there are many resto to eat, many shop to buy... and the walking path to the temple are pack with souvenirs shops. Finally you can enjoy the templeEntering asakusa, you will be welcomed with the big lampion, then walk to the shops/resto area, then when you finally can see the temple, the souvenirs shops are there. At the main gate of temple, I like the BIG pair of zori (the sandals made from dried grass). I also enjoy the pagoda. the sakura, and the temple. Sadly, I cant enter the temple, it's closed when i was thereThe great one is, I go and try O-mikuji fortune. when I got the stick I was confuse to look where the number since I cant see it at first. Finally I saw - or 1 in arab numeric. when I saw the paper, it said Great Fortune..yeeehaaa... and I really got some good news/things afterwards.oh yeah, the souvenirs shop closed at 6PM. I almost forget this since I found it out in 2013 when visit Kiyomizodera and almost cant buy all the list my sis gave me. hehehe

Huge Temple With Tons Of Snack. Walking along the main alley that leads to the temple is a temptation. On the left and right you'll find a lot of stalls selling light bites. Anything from Ningyo-yaki to Rice Wine. If you're heading toward the temple, there's a stall on your right selling hot off the pan Ningyo-yaki that's hand made. Take time to stop and watch the process. It's a beauty of the Japanese, they take full dedication on one subject and make it perfect. The temple itself is super crowded, in the center of the entrance you'll find a place where people 'cleanse' themselves with smoke. A very nice streetphoto subject.
Amazing vibe. Great vibe with hordes of Chinese visitors for New Year. Lots of quaint old Edo style shops, amazing temple and gate.

Great!. Everything here was really cool. I love Japan and love seeing different types of temples. I have been to temples in different parts of Tokyo, this was my first time here. I was not disappointed. We had a good time!

Very busy area, nice temple. I visited this temple early in the morning, before the crowds. I mean to offend nobody but I much prefer Zenkoji Temple in Nagano. I am not quite sure, why this is so popular.

Sensoji, THE Best Temple in Tokyo. If you have time to see only ONE temple in Tokyo, it MUST be Sensoji! Tokyo's oldest temple is home to the spirits of Tokyo's ancestors so it's an important pilgrimage site for the Japanese people. The smoke of incense swirls about, adding a fragrant, mysterious aura to the atmosphere, as many locals drop by to pray on their way to work or school.Even though most of the temple buildings are relatively recent reconstructions since WWII, the craftsmanship in the architecture is so exquisite, you'd swear you were amongst lovingly maintained ancient structures.Sensoji is an absolute beehive of both reverential and touristic activities most hours of the day. But, if you show up soon after sunrise on a weekday, you'll practically have the temple grounds to yourself for an hour or so (please see my pics). I dropped by via the Tokyo metro after a dawn visit to the Tsukiji Fish Market since I was already up super-early!A breeze to get to ... simply pop out of Exit 1 at Asakusa station on the Tokyo Metro Ginza line. You'll then to walk up pedestrian Nakimise-dori on your way to Sensoji, a jam-packed shopping street with everything from the kitsch to the sacred, from the sweet to the savoury. Great fun.

Good fortune. Lovely temple, I did my fortune and got number 92 - Good Fortune - which is pleasing. It was very busy but that did not detract. For a good view of the neighbourhood it is worth going to the top of the Information Centre nearby where the view is brilliant and you can also get drinks and lunch.

great overview. If you only have one day to see the sights, this is ideal as you see traditional and if you have enough time you are close to other things as well. Great for souvenirs and I have lived in Tokyo 23 years.

A lovely walk in central Tokyo. I lived in Tokyo for several years and visited this temple on various occasions, If you exit the North of Hamamacho station and head west it is about 10-15 mins walk on route will be some traditional Japanese restaurants, the "gate" and cherry trees or blossoms depending what time of year it is, from within the temple grounds is a great view of Tokyo Tower which makes for a great back drop for photo's of the temple and is another 5-10 mins walk from the temple, to the north side where is also an interesting display of stone children many dressed and holding plastic windmills. this temple is typically not too busy and great for photographs.

Dynamic. There's a bit of something for everyone here. The entrance is spectacular. A huge hanging red lantern flanked by the guardians of the temple. The path up to the temple is lined with a variety of shops selling their wares, from rice crackers to yukatas. It's a must see if you are visiting Tokyo!

Tokyo's oldest temple.... This temple was founded in 628A.D. and was destroyed during WWII. It was re-built with donations from the Japanese people so it is a much beloved structure. It is mainly famous for its beautiful main gate, where a giant lantern hangs. This makes for a great picture if you can get all the other hundred of people to move aside. To get to the temple, follow the Nakamise Dori, which is the narrow lane lined on both sides with dozens of shops.

More interesting for the atmosphere than the temple. The temples are worth seeing but what really makes the place is the atmosphere. To get to Senso-ji, take the Ginza metro to Asakusa. Exits to the temple are well marked. Once you enter the monumental gate, around which many people are milling, you enter a long avenue lined with shops selling all sorts of knicknacks and snack items. It is, to say the least, very colorful. I believe all the temples as well as the gates are reconstructions. There are plenty of Japanese people who come to the temples for spiritual reasons, and it is nice to see that these are living monuments.

Lots of shops, temple is a post war reconstruction. I have visited many Buddhist temples in many countries I found this temple disappointing for a number of reasons:1. The approach to the temple is littered with hundreds of small shops and stalls mainly selling tourist tat which distracts from the religious nature of the temple. 2. The temple was unfortunately destroyed during world war 2 and the post war reconstruction while retaining the overall shape of the original lacks in character and artistic merit.The best thing about our visit was we got a glimpse of a traditional wedding ceremony in one of the smaller side chapels.

Busy but a must-see. Possibly the most famous Buddhist temple in Tokyo, so it's worth seeing. It is however incredibly busy with tourists. To get there you walk up a long street containing many stalls of souvenirs. Make sure to go off the Main Street to find some more traditional shops.

Traditional temple, lots of tourists but free of charge. Ok, it is not the hidden gem in Tokyo, but its also not something to miss. The Sensoji temple is big, has a lot of open air, numerous shops in the vicinity for souvenirs and Japanese art, as well as little side gardens with shrines and eateries. Best of all, its free of charge and if its your first time in Tokyo and Japan, it is the best opportunity to see crowds, Japanese snack cuisine and temple culture.

atmospheric and picturesque. My husband and I visited one of Tokyo’s highly ranked attractions; Sensoji temple. Getting there was easy enough as the metro is steps away from the Kaminarimon gate that leads you to the temple. There was a lovely atmosphere leading up to the temple, with a many small shops and other things to see along the way including many small Buddha’s in the tree area in front, the 5 story Pagoda and the Sensoji shrine. Immediately in front of the temple was also a pit in which incense was burned. We watched as many people attempted to waft the smoke over them. We believe this provides good luck and fortune. A similar ritual was carried out in a water fountain on the right hand side on front of the temple. A must do as we did, is opting to pay 100yen to get a fortune reading. You do this by selecting a wooden stick with Japanese symbols out of a box and then you have to match it to the boxes in front where you will find your fortune. I was given with the ‘best fortune’, although my husband was unlucky enough to pull out a bad fortune. This is located on the top of the stairs on the right hand side. The temple itself does not provide you with much information on its history and so it is best to find this out yourself before you visit.

join the crowds. It is said to be Tokyo's oldest temple and is seemingly the busiest too. The crowds are part of the fun and mean that there are many stalls for tourists needs. The shops keep traditional Japanese architecture and add to the always festive feel. Prices are not inflated, i.e. marked up for tourists, and it is a convenient place to get souvenirs to take back home. There are many events and as one recent reviewer stated it is an active temple and you get a sense of old Japan while in the heart of Tokyo. If you have any interest in seeing a temple while in Tokyo, this is the one.

an old temple. It is like temple complex. It has a temple and 5 storey pagoda behind.There is a incense burning place. It is believed that the smoke if touched to the parts of the body having problems is good.

Worth Seeing and Free. Well, free is subjective! There are many ways to find tours and some are free, some are not even for the same attraction. If you go across the street of the museum at the Information Center, at 11 am, there is a free tour to this temple. It is one hour long. Be careful not to be distracted by the many shops on your way because you are given one complementary tour and the guide will disappear after so. You can always explore the shops after your guide leaves. Also I rated this as free but like I said, there are tours that charges. It is worth seeing with all so ancient history and a true representation of Japanese culture. The guide will tell you some "unwritten" culture and traditions such as, In Japan, it is impolite or improper to be eating while walking and he also told me how the buddhist pray. Explore this city and learn how they are so unique in their own way, how their culture is so admired and preserved.

Stunning Architecture and a Living Shrine . Amazing architecture in this very active shrine which plays an active role in the lives of many Japanese. Arriving at 06:30am and visiting all of the buildings including the pagoda - it was the steady stream of Japanese that impressed me most. Their devotion and prayers and respect show at several of the smaller shrines in site is inspiring. I am here now as I type this and feel at peace. This is a top site to visit and must not be missed.

Nice at Night. There a lot of souvenir shops before reaching the temple. We visited the temple early evening and there were a lot of people amazed by the temple including me and my hubby. One of the best temples we have visited so far especially with the night lights that added to the beauty of the temple. Definitely a place to visit when in Tokyo.

Wonderful temple, but very busy.... Unfortunately it is very busy here, but absolutely worth the visit... the temple is wonderful and it's quite a unique experience - especially for photographic opportunities...

Popular temple with loads of food vendors on the way. This was my first place to visit when I arrived in Japan, and it was a good one. The temple is very big and beautiful. Inside the temple, people are throwing coins into this big box and they pray, so beware of arms waving and coins throwing everywhere. Outside the temple there’s an area that you can get your fortune told by shaking a stick out of a metal container, very neat. The fortune is on a piece of paper with Japanese, Chinese and English explanation. However, the English explanation did not make sense to me, but it was fun to try. Also the area is very busy, so be prepared for crowds. Along the way to the temple, there are many food vendors that sell all kinds of delicious food. My friend and I bought sweets, fried chicken, seafood skewers, seaweed snacks, and things I don’t even remember. It’s a great area to visit.

Beautiful and impressive temple. Boldly coloured, elaborately constructed, thick and strong while artistically designed, this temple lasts in the memory. I only wish there were somewhere to sit and observe; no doubt this would be awkward on busy days however.

Definitely worth a visit!. We were lucky enough to visit this beautiful temple for New Years Eve 2014. There were lots of night markets and the nearby Nakamise Street stalls. Everything is lit up at night, making the views even more stunning. Some great photo opportunities and a chance to get amongst the locals!

A special place . A very vast and beautiful and well taken care of Buddhist temple. Lovely souvenir/gift shops and food stands in the grounds. We enjoyed lighting incense and praying and getting our fortunes which were luckily excellent ones! A must visit in Tokyo.

Worth visiting at night. During the day when all the little shops are open on the street leading to the temple, this area is very crowded and busy. If you visit at night when everything is lit up it is much more quiet and very picturesque (although you won't see inside the temple).

Interesting and beautiful. The temple has a real presence in the area and is surrounded by beautiful grounds with plenty of interesting things to see. We walked though this area everyday of our week long stay in Tokyo and found something new and fascinating to see every time.

Beautifull Temple. Actually is a big and beautifull temple, and lucky for us, we can see the traditional praying ceremony at morning. There are several good photography objects inside the temple too.Unfortunately, this temple is becoming the number 1 attraction for tourists. It's not bad, it's just kind of loosing its serenity as a temple. It's crowded and it's noisy.This temple can be reached via Toei Asakusa Line, stop at Asakusa station, choose exit 1 (Kaminarimon Gate).

Don't forget to visit the shopping arcade. This is such a popular area and once you are caught in the wave of people heading toward the temple one can quickly think that all the souvenir shops lining both sides of the path are all there is in this area. After visiting the temple, be sure to pay your money and select a good / bad fortune from the many stands surrounding the temple. On your way back to the main street be sure take time to stroll through the shopping arcade the branches off in both directions from the path near the front gate. There is much to be seen.

Beautiful Temple. Beautiful old temple. Very clean surroundings. Nice street leading to the temple where you can buy small nick knacks. In spite of the rains, lots of people seen here. Must see this temple when in Tokyo.

Easy to get to, worth the effort. This was lovely, the temple is beautiful and huge and guards let us take photos of the gong and the temple itself, they were very friendly and welcoming even though we couldn't understand each other. The market outside is crowded but varied and a short stroll from the Asakusa line. There are restaurants before you enter and the food is delicious. A really good day out.

My fav place in Tokyo!. This is the place where I really felt that I was in Japan. Other than seeing this beautiful temple, you can also see in the area the "jinrikisha" or the human powered rickshaw. You can also try here the variety of street foods especially my favorite "takoyaki". They have the best here. Souvenir items abound and you should have at least a half day to wander in the area. Location is great also, very near the asakusa line station and near the asahi beer headquarters.

Well worth including in your itinerary. I love coming here …. Colourful Sensoji temple – a street of wonderfully tacky tourist stalls (though an excellent Woodblock print stall in the middle of them) – some pretty temple gardens and - if you have a bit more time - Kappabashi Food Town nearby.

Bustling Temple. This is a very busy temple with people moving every which way. The Temple is lovely and every one is praying and throwing money, but what I like most was the various stores outside, I tried toffee mandarin and my son had toffee strawberries. Just like a toffee apple but the toffee is thin and the fruit is delicious. Also I wanted a soda water which I received in a strange bottle with a ball in it - tasted great. An excellent visit for everyone.

Sensoji Temple just off of the Asakusa line. I had a plane to catch in six hours at Haneda International and decided to take the train to Asakusa first to see the Sensoji Temple. It is very easy to find because the Temple is the last stop on the Ginza Line, and once you get to street level it is literally fifty yards to your right when you exit the station.  The first thing that you see is Nakamise Dori, which is the shopping street. Be sure and try some fresh rice crackers or a small cake that is baked right there in a small cast iron "griddle". They are really delicious! This area will be packed with people making their way to the temple. It will be crowded, but that is part of the fun.

Crowded but everyone enjoy it. So many people here but fun. You can buy some souvenir and Japanese traditional snack here but i think the price a little bit expensive. In front of the temple gate, you can found traditional transportation of Japan like a pedicap. The price about ¥500.

Worth the visit but pay heed to the when you go.. The Sensoji temple complex is quite beautiful and worth a visit not only for itself but also for the surrounding alleys full of stores, restaurants and bars. I also recommend going there is at least two different times. One during the day and another at night. During the day the place is extremely crowded and quite lively, but you can still see anything you want shop everywhere without too much hassle and grab lunch in one of the many restaurants around. Later at night after the little stalls and shops have closed, there will be much less people around but the temple remains quite beautiful to watch thanks to flood lights and in contrast to the day it's quite a relaxing atmosphere.I was staying in a hotel close by so I got to experience the dawn day dusk and night of the temple and I have to say that it's the most beautiful at night, though the temple itself will be closed.

Too "Zooey". Too long a walk to the venue, too many people to enjoy the site, too many little kiosks in too small a space.... All these led to an uncomfortable experience which began with a very crude restroom situation. This site could easily be skipped. It was the worst stop on our tour!

Ok, ridiculously crowded. I enjoyed Meiji Shrine much more. Much more authentic experience without hoards of hawkers and tourists. But it is nice I guess. I like the nearby hamburger steak place called Mont Blanc and going to the Asahi brewery (building with the golden poo on it) much more. It is nice that you can do all 3 within 10 minutes walk of each other

So so busy and crowded. We visited this shrine on a Sunday which was a blatant mistake as it was so busy and we couldn't move.We were not really into 'cleansing our souls or saying prayers' so this visit was just about seeing the temple.The shrine is huge and very impressive but felt we couldn't appreciate it to its full greatness.There are so many shops but they are for tourists so will be more expensive than normal.

A great temple complex with loads to see that is well worth a visit.. The 'Senso-ji Temple' was founded in 628AD and is the oldest temple site in Tokyo and the capitals spiritual epicentre and as such it gets busy with visitors coming to pray as well as a far number of tourists looking for some culture, like me.The best way to get to the temple is to use the Tokyo Subway and take a train to Asakusa station. The main gate that leads up to the temple, ('Kaminari-mon Gate'), is just a matter of metres away from the station exit on Kaminarimon-Dori (Street). The gate itself (Thunder Gate) is interesting in itself and has a huge red paper lantern hanging inside it and it's flanked by two gods, Fujin and Raijin. Once through the gate you walk up Nakamise-Dori which is packed with stalls selling fascinating traditional goods and souvenirs. At the top of this street you will hit the huge 'Hozo-mon Gate' where on the walls of the gate facing the temple you will see two huge straw sandals symbolising the traditional footwear of Buddhist pilgrims. You will also see a giant bronze incense burner where you can witness the faithful burning incense sticks and wafting the smoke over themselves for good luck.In this area there are some outbuildings with little drawers in and you can select a draw, make a donation and the piece of paper in the drawer tells you your fortune... Great fun and I recommend you have a go. I don't believe in that kind of thing at all but never the less it was certainly a fun and a traditional thing to participate in.You then head up to the Temple's Main Hall with it's lavish interior and gold and lacquer altar. Look up at the ceiling with it's colourful dragon motif surrounded by angels and lotus flowers. This really is an awesome place with it's huge lanterns, bright decorations and large pillars that hold up the stunning roof structures. After leaving the Main Hall I headed to the Eastern area of the complex to see the deep red coloured 'Niten-mon Gate' built in 1618, and an important cultural treasure. Also in this area is the 'Asakusa Jinja' shrine built in 1649 and guarded by two lion-dog statues that honor two fishermen.Also worth a look is the 'Nade Jizo' a bronze bodhisattva statue which is said to relief aliments if you rub the part of the body that troubles you. Again a nice bit of superstitious fun! There is also plenty of other things to see, lanterns, an interesting bronze warrior statue cum drinking fountain with water coming out of dragon heads round its base, numerous shrines and two large Buddha statues made in 1687 to repay a debt of gratitude to a rice wholesaler family.It was pouring with rain the day I visited but even so I enjoyed it immensely and in short I highly recommend this excellent cultural attraction and the whole area in general with its traditional gift shops and restaurants.

Crowded, but fun!. Sensoji temple is, as usual, crowded. But it is always fun to see people from all around the world who marveled on Japanese culture. The park around with small shrines were also very nice. You've got to see some Japanese family in traditional kimono as well :)

Popular temple in Tokyo. We visited in January 2015 and as other reviewers have said, it was very busy. It is an impressive looking temple but we visited the ultimate example in Nara (which was better in our opinion). But if you are in Tokyo only, then it's certainly worth checking out (especially the area where incense is lit). There are also plenty of stalls selling street food if you're feeling a little hungry. There was a bit more tranquility in the small water garden which was close by and some fantastic photographs to be had of the pagoda.
Very nice. A great cultural experience. Be aware it is very busy on New Year's eve and New Year's day, the queue to get in can be 2 - 3 km.
Great introduction to Tokyo. The temple of forgiveness, its history, the crowds, the wishing well and the wall where you can get your fortunes

Crowded!. This temple gets really crowded, and for good reason! It is historic being the oldest in Tokyo and because of the Nakamise shopping street or strip as I see it as a stretch of stores leading to the temple. It was just nice walking around the temple grounds even with a lot of people there.
Another Lovely Shrine. Beautiful and lovely shrine in the middle of the city's bust. Wont spend here much time as there's a lot to see in this wonderful city.

Experiencing Japanese Culture. I learnt that Japanese culture was made of Shintoism and Buddhism. The Sensoji is the largest Buddhist temple in Tokyo so I decided to pay a visit to learn more about the culture. There are few gates to enter the temple but I used the Hozomon gate notable by two straw sandals hang on both pillars. There is a big hall at the center of the temple for worshipers and a 5-story Pagoda located on the west. It was second day of new year, the temple was throng by locals. I believe it was a new year festival. Locals came here for prayer and donation. Many also came for fortune seeking. There was many stalls selling local foods. I tried the Takoyaki, yummy and fresh. For me, this is a good place to experience traditional Japanese culture.
Marvelous and magic. We loved the atmosphere, the people and the temple. The food in the food stands around is amazing. Don't go on 1st of January if you don't like the crowds though.

Amazing!. Though there are simply too many people, we still enjoy it. We like the old, traditional Buddhist atmosphere, how pious worshipers are and how they pray for better luck, etc. We also like the lunch we had in a nearby old restaurant, where they offer traditional Fugu hotpots. Then we alos had some traditonal Japanese deserts at a teahouse. But there are simply too many shops around that we don't have enough time to visit. By the way, don't forget the illustration windows along the road to the Temple. They show the history of the temple with delicate paintings.

Lovely Temple - Asakusa area nice to visit. Visited here as part of a bus trip and whilst we had nearly 40 minutes to visit, it wasn't enough time. It's enough to visit the temple etc, but not go through the endless market shops located in the same precinct. We went back the next day ourselves and spent hours trawling through the side streets and many restaurants. Enjoyed lovely food and great souvenir shopping. Best place we found in Japan for souvenirs - so definitely buy them here.

Must See in Tokyo. I love the Asakusa section of Tokyo. It is more laid back, less hectic and you can see more everyday life here than other parts of the city. The Senso-ji temple is a must see. Don't miss the opportunity to get your fortune near the main insense burners just outside the temple.

Great Traditional looking temples. As far as temples are concerned it was great. (Im not an expert) But as a tourist it as very nice to see something this old and traditonal. The surrounding souvenirs shops were great. Also there is a ramen shop very close to the temple with was great too. I just wish I knew the name, I would write them a review. Anyone starting off their travels in Tokyo, This is a great place to start. Get a lot of the traditional stuff out of the way, and souvenir buying, Then enjoy the rest of the vacation

A Highlight of Asakusa. This beautiful temple enshrines a golden image of the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy. At the entrance to the temple complex (which also has a shopping area) is the huge, red Kaminari-mon or Thunder Gate. Great photo opportunity! Be sure to breathe in the incense smoke, which is supposed to cure ills, and buy a fortune (but beware many of them are bad!)

Crowded. Being on e of the most popular places in Tokyo, the crowd at the place is huge or maybe it was just the day we were visiting. Anyhow there was huge crowd around the place when we visited it. The shrine is a traditional beauty and offers a unique experience. There are a whole lot of snack stalls around the place too. It is a good idea to actually visit the place while you are here.

Nice place to walk around at night time. Asakusa's main attraction is Sensoji,a very popular Buddhist temple along the Nakamisa shopping street. This street have over 50 shops which offer souveniers and local specialities. And has a very nice view at night.
Place worth visiting.. One of Tokyo's oldest temple with a unique history. Breathtaking view surrounding the temple makes it worth visiting.

A Must Visit While in Tokyo. This temple was on the top of our list to visit in Tokyo. We weren't disappointed. Although the temple was a bit crowded, we enjoyed offering prayers and strolling around the temple ground. The walking street at the entrance is lined with shops offering local products and foodies. Don't miss this place while you are in Tokyo!

Food, gifts and temple experience. Really enjoyed our visit to Sensoji temple. There were a lot of little shops selling different gifts that you can buy for your friends or yourself, and a great variety of snacks that you can eat on the spot. The temple was also very nice and beautiful.
amazing temple. full of people, color, activity at all hours any time, but particularly astounding around new years.
Pack with people and a real experience. The temple the streets around it were all immensely packed on the day we were there but it is well worth the visit. A highlight of out time in Tokyo.

Eat Around Sensoji. There is a lot of food on the walkway called "Nakamise". Icecream, japanese bun, japanese traditional sweet, sweet potato, tempura, Unagi irokawa.
Sensoji Temple located at Asakusa Station. This place is the most famous in Tokyo, you shouldn't be missed.

Must see. Crammed with tourists, foreign and Japanese alike, but a wonderful sensory overload. Asakusa, especially sensoji was one of my favorites. If you have the chance, take the Sumida River water bus to get there, or away. Try some of the traditional sweets (dango) or rice crackers (sembei) along the way into the temple as well.

Beautiful. A wonderful place to visit in Tokyo. Very busy at times, but still very spiritually present and stunning. Also quite compact so does not take long to see. The surrounding area is also great for souvenir shopping and arts/crafts. Recommend taking the Himiko/Hotaluna ship from Odaiba Marine Park to Asakusa on the way as an alternative to the underground.

New years preparations. Enjoyed seeing people waft incense on themselves in preparation for the new year. There were fresh cut green bamboo and pine branches tied by rope made from hay. It was a very cultural experience!

Good place for experiencing Tokyo culture. I have always visited the Sensoji Temple on my trips to Japan, and it is also a place I would strongly recommend to first time visitors. With most other parts of Tokyo just like many other metropolitan cities, Sensoji Temple (and Asakusa in general) adds something different to the experience. In the morning you could see many people praying and making offerings, as well as explore the Nakamise walking street which sells anything from Daruma dolls to rice crackers, manjuu buns and sweet sake. It is also easy to buy souvenirs here, such as one of the talismans/good luck charms they have on sale in the temple. One of my favourite parts of Tokyo!

Beautiful temple in the heart of Tokyo. Sensoji is definitely worth putting on any Tokyo itinerary, in my opinion! There's something here for everyone - those after a cultural experience can wander around the temple and shrines, while those more interested in souvenirs can amuse themselves along the large shopping street leading up to the main temple. Visiting the temple is completely free, although you're encouraged to leave a donation should you so desire to.It's quite easy to get to - you can take the Ueno Subway line from Ueno station. Unfortunately, all the stations close to Sensoji are not covered by the JR pass, so keep that in mind.

shake a fortune!. the temple ground is spectacular! you cant might the gigantic lantern hanging at the gate.shake out a fortune at the little counters for good luck! i picked a lucky one and my friend got a really nasty one. but you can tie the bad ones on a string. i tied mine there too. T_T

Lucky temple...?. Whilst you're in Tokyo do as the Tokyoites (?) do. Slight exaggeration I suppose... It was crammed with tourists and you can get a 'fortune prediction', which is fun... Well I think so :)Mine has proved to be quite accurate!

Excellent. The atmosphere approaching the temple is a very festive street market. The rice crackers on offer are a popular souvenir. Approaching the temple and inside the temple lobby are places for fortune telling which does attract many tourists. This is an active temple; house of worship. Make sure to dress appropriately and don't be one of the people taking pictures of those who are praying. The adjacent gardens are gorgeous and the shrine in the northeast corner is well worth a visit.

Famous temple in Asakusa. Sensoji is a Buddhist temple. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. At the main entrance, a huge lantern hanging at the gate. Kaminarimon is the first of two large entrance gates leading to Sensoji TempleThe words “thunder gate (雷門)” has become Tokyo’s iconic landmark. There is Nakamise street on the way to Sensoji Temple. You can shop and eat here. Although weekday, there always crowded. This temple is free entrance.

Nice Temple. This temple was nice and free of charge. It is in Tokyo, and near the place that I stayed in (Raizan South). Nothing too special about this temple except the giant lantern. Look at the bottom of it and you can find a carved of a dragon and flower. I suggest you to come early in the morning to avoid the crowd. There were many stalls/shops. If you can find a store that sell an Ice cream with sake taste, I recommend you to try it. It was good.
A Temple. Perhaps it is because we have been traveling for 2 months, but to us it was yet again another temple. However, it was interesting to watch a wedding there!

One of the good places to see. This area is a mix of traditional and modern stuff. A lot of stalls and restaurants can be seen around the place. The temple itself looks impressive. Explore the area in a leisurely place, but do plan an hour or two as there always seems to be crowded here.

Temple which survived the WW2 fire.. Dedicated to Boddhisatva Kannon ,it is serene temple with a fortune reading area which is accurate .The narrow crowded front lane has numerous sovenier shops selling kimonos, memorabilias ,ivory jewellery etc.Japanese sweets like Taiyaki ,rice crackers,flavoured ice creams are some to name a few of the eateries around the Temple.

Must Visit!. Sensoji Temple is one of the must see attraction in Tokyo. You will love everything this site have to offer. From the traditional snacks, shopping and culture.You can also purchase some omamori at the temple. The description is translated to English so you wouldn't have a problem purchasing the amulet that you wanted. On the left side facing the temple, there would be a line of food stalls. The food varies by season so please check that out as well.

Must see while in Tokyo. Whenever I travel anywhere for work I make sure to get out of my hotel and see some of the local sites. Well, when traveling to Japan you'd have to be total idiot to stay in your hotel the entire time. Tokyo is meant to be explored and seen!I'm an American, and I was still adjusting to the time change. I woke up at 5am and couldn't sleep anymore. So I got ready, headed out and took the subway out to a station near Senso Ji. The place was practically deserted when I got there and was prime for taking some excellent photos.The temple isn't as old as you might think, but a great deal of Tokyo, and the rest of Japan suffered greatly in World War II and many historical sites were lost due to bombing. However, this was still extremely interesting and great to visit. Some of the signs in the area had English in addition to Japanese so I was able to learn about their history and why they were important.DEFINITELY must see this place.

A little overrated perhaps.. So we stopped by this place on the way to Tokyo Skytree. My friend who is a native basically calls this the "foreigner temple," because, essentially, it's packed with tourists on any given day. The shrine is huge and so is the pagoda nearby. You can see shops lined up leading up to the Senso-ji Temple. They sell all sorts of souvenirs, keychains, yukata, kimono, crafts, samurai swords, along with to-go eats like ice cream, rice crackers, agemanju, and ningyoyaki. A word of advice: I would not go ham on souvenirs and goods here. Alot of the things they sold to tourists are obviously overpriced and you would be better off at another store elsewhere in Tokyo or even a Daiso. Do check the smaller side streets though. Also, check the place out at night!

Excellent immersion in Japanese culture!. We visited with a tour group so we only had a very small amount of time and I'm a little disappointed that we never had time to go back and have a more in depth look. The temple is definitely a must-see, it's crowded but that just adds to the experience. Its a sight to look at and despite the bustle, as other travellers have said, it has a sort of relaxing ambience about it. There are little shops and touristy market stalls sprawling out from the temple, though as we were on a time crunch I didn't really get to have a good look at them.If you're only going to do one cultural or historical visit during your trip, this should probably be it.

Absolutely a must see. A must see and do when you visit Tokyo. It is one of the few areas that is historical and reminiscent of old Tokyo. Take your time and really enjoy the sights and experience the Temple and shopping area at the entrance.

Famous temple in heart of Tokyo. Well, Sensoji temple is quite well-known among travellers and locals alike. The result is that the place is generally crowded. The street leading to the temple is lined by touristy shops selling souvenirs - dolls, fans etc. It is quite pricey out there. The gate leading to the temple is quite imposing and have large lanterns. The temple itself is huge with a relaxing ambience. The gardens surrounding the temple are quite picturesque, especially with autumn colors.A place worth visiting while in Tokyo

First time Tokyo tourist Must Visit. This is a typical of the traditional must visit location. Situated close to the JR Asakusa and Ginza line. Easily accessible. During winter season, the place is packed with exciting view of everything any tourist would wish to see. Strolling during the cold season is a pleasant experience. One must see it to understand it.

If your traveling to Tokyo, this is a must stop. My wife and I stopped at Sensoji Temple in the morning, this is a classic Buddhist temple. There's a lot to do at this temple, so bring a comfortable pair of walking shoes. There is shopping and restaurants within walking distance. You can easily spend a couple hours at Sensoji Temple. I would recommend going in the morning time as I understand this temple becomes very crowded as the day goes on.

One of the must visit temple in Tokyo. This temple is located near Asakusa Station. It is accessible using the subway or train. A few minutes walk from this station will bring you to the famous Nakamise Street where you can find lots of souvenirs and foods in particular Japanese famous snacks. Sensoji Temple is located a the end of this street. There are a few temple inside the Sensoji area, a pagoda and statues of Buddha.

Must not miss in Asakusa...... This is accessible using ginza station line. Last stop at asakusa station. Stop by at Kaminari-mon gate and admire the statues besides it. Also, the temple is quite beautiful...Then you will find very nice shops along Nakamise street with very nice murals. Less crowd during weekdays. Alsmost eveything is here if you want to have a quick tokyo feel - temple, shops, souvenirs, food trips, malls etc...

Go early morn to avoid crowded. Located at Asakusa station not far from Tokyo skytree tower; These are 1 hilight must visit of every tour agency.A Big giant Japanese alphabet Lantern at front gate; Before enter a long walkway foods/dessert/souvenir shop kiosk; then 2nd gate and yeah...A stunning big temple.5 or 6 pagodas in an area.

Tokyo's Oldest Temple. No need for a history lesson, since so many other travelers have described Sensoji already before me. But I will say that visiting this historic temple in Asakusa was an amazing experience. Senso-ji was one swinging temple! There is a long shopping mall crowded with pedestrians selling lots of souvenirs and many different wares such as shoes and even weapons. There is the main gate, Kaminarimon, along with other areas like the main hall and a small Shinto shrine nearby as well. It's very crowded by day and a bit more relaxed late in the evneing once all the vendors have closed shop. Once the crowds go away, you can feel the mystic charm lying all around this area. Even though some areas weren't brightly lit, I never felt in danger at all. This area isn't far from the riverfront, which is a walk down south. The pagoda here, when lit up at night, was mesmerizing! You can even breathe in the incense that burns in one of the pits near the main temple, which everyone seemed amused to be doing. If you love people watching, this place is for you. Always activity all around! There is no fee to just walk around and explore, unless you go to the altar for an offering.
Worth a visit. This was a pleasant walk from our hotel and certainly worth a visit. It was very busy and clearly a popular site but I enjoyed the hustle and bustle. The bell is quite spectacular.
An amazing historical place. Not only is there a beautiful old temple, with other old shrines and buildings there is a shopping area in front of it with food trinkets clothing etc

historic temple!. Asakusa Kannon Temple (Sensoji) is the oldest temple in Tokyo, built around 7th century (628).This temple have 2 gates. Kaminari-mon (thunder gate) is the main entrance in the temple...the end entrance called Hozomon (treasure house get)... getting trough the Kaminari-mon, Nakamise-dori the lively 300 meters, long archade is leading up to the Asakusa Kannon Temple..... The big lentern hanging from the celling the gate is covered with letters meaning the name of town adherent to the temple....and also in the main building enshrines the statues of the Kanno Goddess of mercy which is said 5 cm tall. It is easy for us to get caught up in the rows of small shops selling traditonal Japanese items eg. paper umbrella, key chain, magnetic refrigerator, fans, dolls, toys and Edo style wigs too he...he...
Tokyos oldest temple. Been there in 2007The temple is crowded but still you ll enjoy embracing the zen atmosphere with the fish pond and the garden

Nice, but crowded. The temple itself is very impressive. I am definitely happy I went there. But wow were there a ton of people, so be prepared. It's a bit commercial, as some others have noted, but that's how many of these popular tourist destinations tend to be. Not the peaceful, serene characteristics that you see with the temples we saw in Kyoto, but still beautiful in its own right. We arrived at the Asakusa subway stopped, walked through the shops/stands in Asakusa and then to the temple and back, which ended up working well. If you're going to visit one, I'd suggest visiting the other since they're so close.

One of my pref. Places in Tokyo. The oldest Buddhist temple in Tokyo, and one of the most amazing places in the City... By the entrance the amazing Kaminarimon Gate, and then you will see Nakamise-dōri, a old-Japanese-style street with souvenirs and traditional sweets shops... Just amazing... Plus this area (Asakusa) is so local you can fin tons of good Japanes restaurants!Bonus: close to the temple there is a Don Quijote (ドン 木ホテル) which is quite original an non-common Japanese supermarket (must see).

Cowded but still worthwhile. Start your tour at the Tourist information office, catch the lift to the top floor and it gives you a great view over the shopping street leading in and the gate/temple. Yes the shops are touristy but they are catering for the market.

Too commercial. The temple is impressive but the shops outside are selling souvenirs that are priced higher than most places.If you have not visit a shinto shrine, go ahead but don't buy anything unless you have no choice.We walked from Ueno JR station to Asakusa, i rather enjoyed the walk as we passed by many interesting shops, selling beauty flowers and delicate japanese potteries.

Can't be missed. As all of Asakusa you can breath the old Japan. Backstreets filled with local restaurants and many thinks to discover, get the river boat or one stop and get to the new shopping center for a pop up to the tallest new Tokyo tower... 600 mt high.

Sensoji Temple. Biggest and Oldest Buddhist temple in Tokyo restored - somewhere very special indeed. Nakamise Street leading up to the temple sells everything the visitor could want to take home with them, plus excellent freshly made cakes. Yummy. There is a wonderful sense of peace in the crowds that visit here.

Tokyo's Oldest Temple!. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo! Visited this temple on a Monday afternoon and it was so crowded! Can't imagine how it will be like during weekend. The temple is easily accessible by subway, just a stone's throw away from Asakusa subway station. There are rows of shops outside the temple, selling food and souvenirs.Be sure you check out this temple when you are in Tokyo!
Understand history. You can visit the temple along with shopping experience whenever you are here. A must visit attraction in Tokyo. The local Japanese shops are located just adjacent to temple.

Fair but very crowded. Billed as one of the main sights of Tokyo, I suppose that it has to be visited. However, it is very crowded and tourism seems to be as important as religion. There are many groups of many ages, including Japanese ones. The Nakamise-dori " Walking Street", along which you access the temple, is a long line of crowded souvenir shops. The temple itself is mildly interesting. It is right next to Asakusa Station which is the final eastern stop on the Ginza Metro line. As you face the temple, on the left side there are a number of alleyways where there are a number of eateries, many of which seem to represent value for money. The temple is also known as the Asakusa Kannon Temple.

Chanced upon the Kinryu-no-mai. I went during the late afternoon, and chanced upon the tail end of the Kinryu-no-mai, Golden Dragon Dance held during the Kiku-kuyo. I'm not sure if it's as crowded during normal days as it was then, but even so this didn't detract from the place. There seemed to be as many locals as there was tourists, and it was lovely just to sit on the stairs and watch temple goers and tourists alike come and go.

Great market, Temple overcrowded. The market area was great and very pretty when all closed up for the night.
It was very overcrowded and less enjoyable at peak times.
A bit over the top and lacking the traditional temple feel.
Still an amazing place and well worth the visit.

Verry, Very Busy Place-Lots of people!. The Temple was a great sight and was very, very busy and fast paced. I mean bumping shoulder to shoulder crowd. Just beyond the temple are very small crowed streets of outside tented shops. We tried to shop & go down a few, but english was not a choice of language in any of the shops. Little to busy & crowded for me, but was a great experience of thier culture.

Hardly serene, but still impressive. We visited late afternoon on a Tuesday and the whole area was packed with tourists (like us).The lantern is certainly impressive as are the fearsome statues guarding the entrance. Well worth a visit even just for the enjoyment of the esthetics of these beautiful structures.

Beautiful temple complex. Go through the Kaminarimon gate, rush through the rather touristy Nakamise's souvenir shops to enjoy this wonderful temple complex. If you don't like the crowds come at night where the whole temple complex is illuminated and just feel the special atmosphere.

Yes, worth it. Loved the crazy junky market. Shrines are beautiful. Great location. It's fun during the day, but even better in the evening after sundown with cool restaurants blocks away to the west. Don't miss getting your fortune from the little drawers!

If you do not mind the crowds because of free entry and market nearby. After coming out of Asakusa station you enter the temple through the busy Nakamise market.Lot of Japanese stuff to eat in the market.The souvenirs are slightly expensive.In the temple it would be worthwhile to buy candles and light them inside glass enclosures.There is a 5 storied pagoda in the premises and another small temple where marriages are held.There were also few make-shift shops inside the arena.There are other structures also in the premises and you can also see colored fishes in one.The fact that there is no entry fees is an incentive enough to visit this temple which otherwise really gets crowded.
Nice temple. Go by subway to the asakusa neighboouhood.Enjoy the temples and the markets in the area.one of the fun and typical places to go in tokyo'
