Great destination in Asakusa . Make time to wander around this gorgeous magical area. Be sure to take a rickshaw ride around the area. It'll make the temple even more fun
Asakusa and Sensoji temple. Buddhist temple "must see" in Tokyo. Try to go early or during the weekend. Weekend is crowded. You can pick up great souvenirs on your way to the temple.

Huge Tourist Attraction. Very crowded but enjoyable. Liked that we were able to taste some old Japan such as rice crackers made on a grill and mochi on sticks. Multiple souvenir stalls along the street to Sensoji temple. They also had chrysanthemums on display the week we visited. The Temple has multiple options to procure good luck, pay homage or learn your fortune. They also sell good luck charms with a variety intentions.

Sensoji Temple. Sensoji or Asakusa Kannon Temple, one of Tokyo's best tourist spots. Best way to approach the temple is thru the Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate), then passing thru shopping street called Nakamise w/c have hundreds of establishment running both sides for the tourist attracted to buy Japanese souveniers or local traditional snacks like osembe (rice crackers) or sweets like agemanju (battered & deep friend cake with red bean paste inside). It is always teeming with lots of people and recently have an added bonus scenery of the Tokyo Sky Tree on the side. There are also lots of eatery outside Nakamise with real 'shitamachi' (old town feel) so try and do some challenging walk around Asakusa area. Its free and open whole year round.

Very busy but interesting. Visited sensoji temple as part of out Tokyo itinerary. The place was teeming with people.. Mostly tourists. There's a kindergarten school also just outside which in itself was an attraction with several moms picking up kids in cycles. A super touristy market leads the way to temple. The temple itself is quite nice and impressive. Easy access through metro.

Typical Temple. If you only visit one temple while in Tokyo, then you should visit this one. It is not the best or the most tranquil but is representative of temples in Tokyo. Expect to be jostled by people as there are huge crowds here but you get to glimpse everyday Japanese people. There are a number of shops and food stalls leading up to the temple that sell many different types of souvenirs. There are a lot of good photo opportunities.

History and geocache combined. My first experience of a shrine in Japan. Although touristy, not tacky at all. Very interesting little shops on the way. Pretty temple.Origami geocache. Whatever your age, you would love it. A must.

Good visit !!!. The temple is nice and if you are visiting only Tokyo is a nice choice of making a cultural visit. In the temple you can find a box from which your lucky stick comes out and you read your luck. If you've got a bad luck just leave your paper there so your bad luck stays in the temple.I adored the small shops around the temple with a big variety of souvenirs.

Not the best Japanese temple or shrine experience. If I were only visiting Tokyo in Japan I would probably make sure to visit the Senso-ji. But after all the wonderful temples and shrines of Nara, Kyoto, Nikko and elsewhere this seemed a let-down as a visitor experience, and hard to imagine it has much appeal for overseas visitors seeking a spiritual experience. The main temple building itself is, I think, a 1950s structure, the pagoda 1970s, the garden closed to visitors, and more interesting were some of the outbuildings and monuments. The whole area was vastly crowded and busy, especially with teenagers showing as much interest in the hundreds of ho-hum souvenir shops spread out in all directions as in the temple itself.
Good cultural visit. The shopping streets near the temple offer a lots of souvenier. Worth a visit. Please go early as there were too much people if u come later.

Amazing Temple Surrounded by "Shopping". Tokyo has many temples but Sensoji and Meiji Jingu were the most impressive in so many (and different) ways. One can not help but appreciate the history that the Sensoji Temple represents. The mass of people and the tourist stalls leading up to the Sensoji temple take away from the tranquility of the Temple. At the same time, these stalls provide an opportunity to see a variety of souvenirs that vary in price and quality (not much negotiation) that were actually hard to locate in Tokyo as a whole. I certainly found a variety of unique gifts (tenugui towels, carvings, prints). There also seems to be a variety of sweet snacks for sale (I found a great sweet bread loaf in a ice cream shop/bakery to the right just before the temple). The Temple and the Pagoda give one a real sense of Japanese culture and architecture. Do not miss this temple and the surrounding area. One could easily spend a half day in this part of Tokyo. Easy access using the Ginza metro line. Get there early as the area seems to fill quickly with people.

Magical temple!. If you desire peace and tranquility amid the hustle and bustle of life, this is the place for you. You can either participate in the worship, or merely light a candle. The choice is yours. But the experience changes you for ever.

Beautiful Buddhist Temple complex. The complex includes gated approaches on two sides, a large main temple with a line of people waiting to pray, a tall pagoda, and ancillary buildings. It is surrounded by shopping streets with numerous vendors stalls and restaurants. On the weekend, the place is packed with people. It's a wonderful experience all around.

Amazing. This was the first place I visited during my Japan trip and it was pretty amazing. Both the Buddhist and Shinto shrines are beautiful. Dont forget to cleanse yourself in the water before entering. Also, dont neglect the cool little shops running up and down the streets near this area, so many great buys if you look hard enough for them.

A Lot To See In This Area. Our second stop in Tokyo was the Asakusa district where the most famous Buddhist temple Senso-ji is located. We passed under the torii, a traditional Japanese gate commonly found at the entrance of or within a Shinto shrine, where it symbolically marks the transition from the profane to the sacred. Then, we were able to perform Temizu using the hand washing basin. This involves taking the dipper in your right hand and scooping up water. Pour some onto your left hand, then transfer the dipper to your left hand and pour some onto your right hand. Transfer the dipper to your right hand again, cup your left palm, and pour water into it, from which you will take the water into your mouth (never drink directly from the dipper), silently swish it around in your mouth (do not drink), then quietly spit it out into your cupped left hand (not into the reservoir). Then, holding the handle of the dipper in both hands, turn it vertically so that the remaining water washes over the handle. Then replace it where you found it. We explored the grounds a little more and then walked around the Nakamise shopping street that is the front entrance to the Senso-ji Temple. We bought a couple souvenirs and tried some bean paste pastries.

Liked it so much we went twice. Beautiful old temple. You can get your fortune told for 100Yen. There are lots of small restaurants, general stores etc, Sumida River with cruises to Obaida. Easy train & subway connections to Central Tokyo. Great way to spend an afternoon.

Worth the Trip. We almost didn't make it to this temple being exhausted after a week walking around the sights of Tokyo but we were glad we did. It's great just walking around the streets near the temple. A little bit of of old town Tokyo and a very impressive temple. Some interesting shops and some great restaurants. Our lunch was fantastic. It is very crowded though. Make sure you include this in your itinerary.

Very much worth the time to visit!. We visited in October 2014 on a rainy day and were surprised at the number of local people and school children that were visiting this great relic from the past.The whole experience, the temple of course, the little shops with souvenirs and the ambiance of this place make it a must for anyone visiting Tokyo. Well recommended!

Oversized. Such a beautiful temple but not the slightest bit quiet. Everything is big. Likewise the crowds and the street sellers are everywhere. Get your fortune told for 100Y.Its a great place to people watch if you have the time as it is extremely popular with the locals.

Traditions live on at Tokyo's oldest and most famous temple. Located in the traditionally working-class district of Asakusa district, Sensoji is Tokyo's oldest temple. There is a fascinating legend about how this 1400-year old temple came to be built on the site where a statue of Kwan Yin (Goddess of Mercy) was found by two fishermen. Real or not, in excess of 30 million local and international visitors come visiting each year. While its history and traditions are undeniable, part of the appeal probably also has to do with the Nakamise, the passage leading up to the temple that is lined with a fascinating range of shops. Coming off the main road, one passes under the Kaminarimon, a single tier gate that feature a pair of fierce protective guardians that dates back to the 13th century. At the end of Nakamise is a grander-looking second gate, the 10th-century Hozomon, which features two tiers. Once through this gate, the main temple of Sensoji comes into full view. This is is the newest section of the complex, having been rebuilt after World War 2. Admittedly, it isn't very large and with all the visitors that come daily, the temple and its forecourt can get quite crowded and especially so during festival time. But there's no sense of hassle and every visitor more or else finds his or her own pace. A good cross-section of society make up who comes here but there will often be tour groups and collections of schoolchildren, either in small groups or on a class excursion. If there's enough time, it's not a bad idea to check out some of the buildings the surround the main temple, including the 10th-century 5-storied pagoda, several prayer halls and also the Nitenmon or east gate, the latter often bypassed by most visitors.

Many halls and shrines in this huge complex - all should be visited. Senso-ji precinct - tourist central!Amazing that in the midst of all the tourists and gawkers there are those here who actually come to honour the Kannon statue housed in the temple and to pray.The Main Hall of the temple is huge, the statues in the gates are huge, the lantern is huge, the crowds are huge - everything is super-sized.After strolling the neighborhood, walk up Nakamise Dori and gaze at the items for sale both, sacred and profane. When you finally arrive near the entrance to the Main Hall, join the crowds wafting the holy smoke over their hair and face, go to the basin to perform ablutions, toss a coin, and finally brave the crowds and enter. It is difficult for us to feel particularly holy here since one is always being jostled by others jockeying for a good position from which to see within. The big columns should be patted so that you can realize that this temple is a reconstruction, constructed not of wood but of concrete. We visit Senso-ji on each trip to Tokyo, and in recent years we have spent more time visiting the other halls and shrines in the temple precinct.Chingodo Shrine is worth a quick visit. Chingodo Hall is dedicated to tanuki (raccoon dog), said to be a guardian against burglars and fire. We read that this small shrine was built to appease the raccoon dogs who were living at Senso-ji. It is a small quiet shrine, worth a quick look. There are many tanuki statues, with gigantic testicles, wearing the tanuki hat, and holding sake flasks. Some signage is in English.We looked through the perimeter wall into the garden of Dempo-in, which we had read was closed to the public. A very kind woman visiting the Chingodo Shrine told us Dempo-in garden was open and there was an exhibition going on now and that we must go visit there. So we did. Dempo-in is open forin March to May. For 300¥ entry, we saw the exhibition of temple treasures in the main hall. In addition, the gardens were open to visitors and tea was served. The paintings and artifacts exhibited were wonderful, all the more so since we knew that this very special place is rarely viewed.The garden is serene, lovely, and peaceful - a quiet place in the Senso-ji precinct. The pond and cherry trees were very photogenic. You can walk a circuit around the pond, cross a small bridge and wander under the sakura. Some say it is reminiscent of Katsura. The main hall was closed to the public, but from its interior tea was produced for all visitors. There is also a small tea house on the grounds. Unfortunately, though some may find it amusing, you can see Sky Tree from many spots in the garden, in addition to the Five Storey Pagoda. Seeing both together makes an interesting photo.
Sensoji Temple. Great temple to see. Beautiful and surrounded by a lot of great touristy shops to buy neat souvenirs and great food stalls.

Quiet temple in a busy area. Our first visit to a temple in Tokyo and on a rainy day, it was still filled with lots of visitors. The night before was more quiet and colorful. It was near our hotel in the Asakusa area.

Good Religion & Cultural Site. In Tokyo, Temple & Shrine visiting are must!This Temple is amazing, it's crowded with people, yet you still find yourself comfortable and peaceful in the temple compound.Beside the Temple, there are plenty of eateries that sells local snacks. Make sure you tried some! Some of them, have taste that I can hardly find words to describe.I spent at least 3 hours at this area, having lunch then to temple, then shopped at the street in front of the temple selling touristy staff (well, I don't buy souvenirs hence is window shop) and tried many local snacks.

Lovely Temple. in the midst of super urban and modern Tokyo there is a one lovely temple... a bit crowded but that is all part of an experience... take a walk along the picturesque Nakamise-dori street and explore this whole lovely neighborhood...

Great historical monument. The temple is amazing, A true historical view into old Japan. On certain days you can see the temple being used by Tokyo citizens. The gardens and shops around the temple are amazing.

Crowded... Visit early in the morning. This is one of the places I liked the most in Tokyo.I recommend to visit it early in the morning. I went there twice, the first time around 9.30 am on a weekend and by the time I was leaving there was A LOT of people. The second time I visited it around 8AM on a week day, it was a lot better and was able to take better pictures and enjoy each section of the complex.

Beautiful Lighted Night View. Located in the beautiful asakusa area, we arrived here by night time. To my surprise, the view was even nicer. Not too crowded yet so grandeur. On the way to the temple, you can see many small stall selling food and souvenirs.T he temple was beautifully lighted and was a sight for night photo. The temple is also closed to the asakusa night market area. Also seen is the beatiful tower of Sky Tree, highest tower in tokyo. To me, it is one of the best temple in Tokyo area.

Varied Colourful Complex. This calming complex was built in 1649 and comprises an 8 story pagoda, shrine and gardens in which a plethora of spiritual symbols are housed. I visited early before the tourists arrived by the bus load, so crowds were not a problem. Tiny shops sold the usual souvenirs. Food is available is surrounding streets.

Beautiful, though a bit crowded. This beautiful temple in the heart of Tokyo resembles much of the beauty of Japan in the eyes of foreigners - the combination between a sacred place to the masses of tourists, locals and foreigners, visiting it, the abundance of stores, with local food or souvenirs, the ability to stand quietly in a corner or be lost in the crowd. It's certainly a "must" for anyone visiting Tokyo.

Beautiful but very crowded. Sensoji Temple is beautiful. Colorful, full of culture, genuine. The grounds are big and much to see and explore. Very busy, a lot of tourists. Located in Asakusa which is a nice neighborhood with little streets, traditional houses. A must while staying in Tokyo.

Be ready for a large crowd.. The Temple and surrounding area were huge as was the crowd. There was plenty to see with the Main Temple Hall, Nitenmon Gate, Hozomon Gate, Kaminarimon Gate and of course all the shops and restaurants. You need plenty of time to see everything and it is well worth while. The shops are generally different to most tourist areas and the food was great.

beautiful at night. i went there during the day, it was very crowded. there were many shops and we did some souveneir shopping. but went there again at night, there were very few people and all the shops were closed. thats when i noticed how beautiful the temple was - all lit up and quiet. the shutters of the closed shops have beautiful japanese paintings on them. the whole place was serene and stunning.

Doesn't feel as tranquil as it is very crowded.. The walk to the temple is great- there is an alley full of shops where you can find great souvenirs. The temple itself is very busy so it doesn't feel as tranquil as other temples in Tokyo. Nevertheless it is very beautiful and is good to see when you are in Tokyo.

Crowded. the place is crowded with tourists..but i've gotta say that the place is very clean and well-guarded. People are very polite and are helpful towards assisting tourists. A great place to look for souvenirs too!

Great temple to visit . Went to this temple in the afternoon. Was very busy especially at the entrance. They have an alley of shops leading up to the main temple. You can find all sorts of snacks and souvenirs. The temple itself is great. Very busy, but a must see. You can see priests praying behind the gate in the main area. A unique experience.

Beautiful & Enjoyable; a must do. Very easy access through the metro services, stone's throw from the station Asakusa. The Nakamise avenue leading to the temple is a sight to behold both at daytime as well after dark. One can buy good variety of reasonable priced eatables as well as take home souvenirs.The area of Asakusa shrine is crowded and it's difficult at times to get a glimpse inside the shrine; however be patient ,you'll get your turn.The beauty of this shrine is also in it's surrounding area which is wonderful to walk around and get a feel of the town and it's culture.You may see street artists perform, fresh snacks being made and served etc.A really enjoyable time for me.

Beautiful but over commercialized. The temple is located at the end of the Nakamise shopping area. The gate and trmple itself is beautiful. The lanterns and colors are stunning. There are rows and rows of shops that you would have togo through before reaching the temple. You can eat, buy little gifts and enjoyany different kinds of traditional Japanese sweets. We went on a Saturday and there was a ton of people there and the narrow streets became very crowded.
Most Popular Tokyo Temple. It's not a very large Buddhist Temple but it's very famous because it's located in the busy Asakusa area which is a major tourist attraction in Tokyo.

Nice complex...worth it but crowded. Nice place to spend a bit of time. Convenient metro stop, lots of choices for food and shopping. I enjoyed walking down some of the side streets to get a better feel for the area. There is a shop nearby where they dress people up in traditional clothing whom you can see strolling about.

Beautiful at night!. It's definitely a different view when the spotlights come up at night. Sensoji temple is famous during the day, but stay later or come when the sun sets, the shops start to close, and the temple lights up. You'll notice details you never notice during the day and without the hubub of the sellers hawking their wears and the tourists gawking, you'll have a view of the lovely temple, the night sky, the moon, and the Sky Tree lit up in the distance. It's just a gorgeous view. The lanterns are lit up and when it is quiet you can almost feel like you're in another world ala Miyazaki's 'Spirited Away'. There are the denizens that come out at night and they are a sight to behold as well, but really, they're just nice to pass by as you take in the view of the temple.As for the vendors, also try the side streets for cheaper food and wares. There's a couple of little shops that sell a lot of little cat merchandise like cat shaped purses and knickknacks.

Busy, but impressive. This temple is in the middle of a very busy and crowded part of Tokyo. There's even a street of shops in it! Yet it's very impressive and it's possible to find quiet areas in it. The main temple is a wooden marvel as are the gates around it. The incense bowl is a centre for many people. I wasn't quite sure, like others of the religious significance of all the areas. The pagoda was impressive. Nearby there was a quiet garden with a stream running through it; I could see this as a place to contemplate. Around the temple are many shops and small restaurants providing for a wide range of tastes. People watching was my favourite activity here as there were so many people around.

I don't know what I'm looking at but its all impressive. From the main entrance to the main temple its all an experience. Having someone there to explain whats appropriate and how to do it was great otherwise I would have been lost.

Impressive. The Sensoji Temple is worth a look when visiting Tokyo, as is the nearby Kaminarimon Gate and the shopping area in between. It's a very impressive temple and most of it is available to see without formally entering any religious areas or having to pay a fee.

Great Temple but Too Crowded. This is definitely a quite picturesque temple located in Asakusa. Great neighbourhood nearby and there are many small restaurants around. This wasn't a long visit as I felt that there were just way too many people for my own taste. If you want a pretty sight, try coming here after sunset. There are less people and they lit up the temple and pagoda. Very cool.

Big temple with garden here and there. Big temple with lots of open space and small gardens. This give you space to look around beside seeing inside the temple. I particularly enjoy the small garden and small waterfall on the left side of the temple.

Impressive temple - a must visit. This place keeps you captivated from the moment you walk through the first gate till you reach the temple. Amazing design, full of history and tradition, this temple makes you bow on admiration. You also get to walk through a great market full of souvenirs, so make sure you take some cash with you!

Bustling Throbbing Cultural Heart. Bustling, Busy, Exciting. This huge glorious temple is located steps from the subway. Following a stroll through countless small shops which all seem to sell the same basic souvenirs one arrives at the steps of this awe inspiring massive temple. Incense bundles can be easily purchased to make offering and augment the billowing blessing-bestowing cloud of fragrant smoke. Despite the hustle and bustle of the pathway leading to the temple, those fortunate to visit find a serene setting.
Huge!. + A truly Japanese temple complex experience. Many restaurants and a enormous shopping area. - Too crowded.

Great Temple. Sensoji is a great temple and collection of buildings. The two guardian statutes at the gates are quite a site to behold. The koi pond is delightful and it is a bit relaxing in the middle of Tokyo. It is interesting to see the statutes/buildings that have been relocated here from other parts of Japan. There are nice shopping streets around the temple and it is very easy to get to via public transit.The only real problem we ran into near the temple were some con artists trying to scam money from people, posed as buddhist monks. We were alerted to the fact that these people were scammers by the shopkeepers in multiple stores and by an old lady who passed us by. The were looking for large amounts of money. Apart from this, very enjoyable.

Not like every other temple. Asakusa's most famous temple has a LOT of history. Hard (painful I would say) to miss when goin to Tokyo. Awesome souvenir market just past Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate). Knock yourself out.
Wonderful place to visit. A unique and special place. This temple is not to be missed. Great spots for taking pictures - quaint shops and small restaurants abound.

Nice. Very pretty but I had seen so many temples already on the trip that I wasn't in awe. Limit the amount of temples you see or you may begin to loose interest. (however i was 18 so opinions may very)

What you think Japan looks like!. Even though this temple is one of the most amazing temples in all of Tokyo, it is still not up to par with most temples/shrines you will see in Kyoto. Nonetheless, it is still a must see while in Tokyo. You get there through metro and get out at the Asakusa stop and have to walk about 5 to 10 minutes depending on how fast you walk and how many pictures you will take from the metro to the Temple. The Temple itself is absolutely beautiful and reminds you of what you would expect when thinking about Japan and its architecture.The area around the Temple is dedicated for prayer and reflection and you will see a lot of locals and tourists take part in ritualistic behavior. The Temple stands tall in the middle of the square and is an absolute great sight to the eye. It is an absolute must do while on a short or long trip to Tokyo.

Lovely temple. This is a beautiful temple and must be visited on a visit to Tokyo. As you have read other reviews you have a good idea about the temple and the surrounding area so I will say something else. This is a very busy temple and the surrounding area is commercialized so the area is packed with people which I wanted to avoid. I got there at 8.15am on a Monday morning and it was bliss, the temple was virtually empty and the market stalls virtually all closed. I walked around the temple and took pictures in peace without having to avoid lots of people. I then walked across the river to the Tokyo Skytree to get there early and avoid the queues and then walked back to have a look at the market stalls before going on a river trip. Well worth getting there early

average. you will first reach the Namikarimon (thunder gate) where heaps of ppl flood the front to take picture with it. Then you will walk through the long long Namikase shopping street (full of souvenier shops) to get to Sensoji. relative to other temples in Japan, Sensoji seemed a tad bit new in terms of the building structure. I was hoping to see more culture but didn't see it. If you like to have a sky view, go to the Asakusa Tourist Information Centre. gives a great view of Sensoji with Namikase Street along with tokyo skytree

Always Worth a Visit. This has been one of my favorite temples to visit for many years. The long shopping street walk up to the temple is loaded with great finds. Look for the Studio Ghibli Shop near the entrance, or the Purple Potato ice cream stand off on one of the side roads. The temple grounds themselves are extensive, lovely and full of atmosphere. Plan to spend most of an afternoon here.

Tokyo's most sacred..... Tokyo's most sacred shrine. The street leading to the shrine is very 'commercialised' with many 'tacky' stalls. The shrine itself is set in lovely gardens and an oasis of calm......except on public holidays which we inadvertently chose to visit on.

A visit here everytime we are in Tokyo. Visit this place, say a little prayer, buy some stuff along the way and feel blessed by the oldest temple in Tokyo.From here it's a short train ride to the Tokyo Skytree

A Must visit in Tokyo!. This temple was one of the first places we visited while in Tokyo. We visited as part of a tour. I would recommend going up to the information center across the street and going to the 8th floor viewing deck before visiting the temple. The shops between the first gate and second make for great souvenir shopping. Once at the second gate, you are able to see the masses of people preparing to enter as they cleansed themselves with water and burning incense before entering the temple. The inside of the temple is very beautiful, especially the painted ceiling.

Very spiritual. A very nice place to visit - spiritual and calming. I'm not a religious person, but the presence of other people praying did have a humbling effect on me.The temple is very clean and well looked after - I think this is one of the main tourist attractions in the area, and is worth going if you're religious, but otherwise you may just find it a bit so-so.There is an incense stand near the front as well if you feel like cleansing yourself.The location is right at the end of a promenade with tens of dozens of shops and stalls (where you could spend a little bit of time buying stuff), so you really can't miss it either.P.S. Don't forget to take change to put into the donation box at the entrance!!
No need to take a tour, DIY. Easy to get to from the subway/metro rail and enjoy it around sunset to see it in the evening light and after dark

Iconical Lantern. You cant miss this hugh lantern hanging at the entrace of the temple. One of the tourist attractions in tokyo that you cant miss. Visiting during the noon time was really hot, so try to go during evening or early morning. There is a lot of shops selling snacks and souveniors along the two side alleys. Small reaturants or cafe are located at the back of the alleys. Pray sincerely and see what your future holds at the temple.

Have your future told at the temple. The temple, the shops, the entire experience is wonderful.
We had a nice talk with one of the monks and had our future delivered in a small piece of paper.
Walking along the street and looking at the shops adds to the experience.
Many small restaurants around the site with delicious food.
Must See. Sensoji is one of the main tourist attractions in Tokyo. Very busy all day and into the evening. Were lucky enough to see Sumo Wrestlers visiting this shrine.

A must in Tokyo. There are some thing syou MUST do/see in tokyo, otherwise it's hard to tell other people that you have been to Tokyo, and this Sensoji temple is one of those.Its famous gate with the big lantern is a icon of Japan even.It appears on so many posters and postcards and you cannot refuse to have a look there yourself.Outside the temple there is a market with many stalls selling snacks, souvenirs etc.I know there are also some shops that you can rent the tranditional "Yukata" to wear, but I didn't try...The temple itself is beautiful and also offers some interesting services, such as making a draw for Fortune-telling, and you can also pay and buy their praying to reduce your bad luck/future. ;-)Overall, it's an interesting experience and also a symbolic place to visit when you are in Tokyo. :-)

Beautiful place . I went there at night and the view is stunning. And the level of cleanliness ťhese people maintain just blows your mind. The temple is big and the view of sky tree from here too is awesome. No entry fees and one should visit this if you got nothing to do in tokyo.

Walk through history. Asakusa in general is one of my favourite places in Tokyo. Sensoji has to be one of my favourite temples. The long walk from Kaminari Mon (gate) down the Nakamise (shops) filled with people and great souvenir shops only builds the anticipation even more. Once inside the temple complex you are met with so much brilliance it's hard to decide what to do next. Architecture, history, art, beautiful gardens, ponds and the famous koi. I would not suggest going there on the weekends nor the middle of the day as Sensoji is one of the most visited temples in Japan. Early morning is probably the best before endless loads of buses begin arriving.

A Must See! . I stayed near the temple so was able to visit both at night and early morning. Missed the crowds and the shopping frenzy, which was more in keeping with the purpose of the temple anyway. Lovely any time of day, I'm sure, but I found it very spiritual at those two times without the throngs of people milling around. And in the morning when the temple was open, the altars were visible and the incense was burning, it literally brought me to tears. I visited a total of 9 shrines and temples during my 5 days in Japan (Tokyo and Kyoto) and I only experienced that emotional depth at Senso-ji. Even if it doesn't affect you the same way, you'll be impressed.

Nice temple. The temple is easy to find and just a few steps after the train exit of Asakusa and has many tourists. There are souvenir and food shops around the area. The temple is visited my many Buddhist locals and tourists and is near Shinto Shrine and Asakusa Shrine. No entrance fee charged.I am not Buddhist but I still enjoyed my tour in the area and appreciate the differences in their culture and mine.

Fully packed shrine.. Luckily for me I had entertained 200 meters far away from this beautiful temple. The Sensoji temple in the Asakusa district, easily reachable from any point of the city thanks to the large underground tram network. Sensoji is a place rich in art, and a tourist place extra crowded at almost all hours of the day. Absolutely free, you can roam as you please within the small park and among the temples located here. In front of the main temple there is a long street where you follow for about 100 meters several souvenir stalls, to arrive in front of the tourist information point. For me this place of temples was the starting point for exploring the city. A must to see.

Hundreds of angles for photographs. The temple is surrounded with souvenir shopping shops, museum and neat garden - a unique combination of tourism place. The temple building is quite nice with its giant Lantern and Thunder gods statue, completed with a beautiful Pagoda beside, and some Buddhist ritual praying and forecasting equipment, dominated by red color, decorations and beautiful paintings on the ceilings. There are hundreds of angles can be captured around!

Tourist death-trap but still fun!. SO CROWDED!! But, the stores around it are full of trinkets you can bring back. The locals come here too, so you can catch men and women in traditional outfits. A tip I'd share is to take to the alleyways to the right of the temple for food. There are tiny restaurants and cafes tucked in there and away from the bustle of the main temple street.

A must-see if you're in Tokyo. Seeing the large lantern in actual doesn't compare to the internet pictures. The temple was impressive. Quite fun to try to have your fortune told by picking a stick that has a number and you get the pre-printed fortune in the drawers for just a 100Yen. The souvenir shops lined near the entrance of the temple are quite cute (but a little expensive). Try the mochi and the red bean cakes they are selling. Best time to visit is early in the morning before the tourists (groups) crowd arrive.

If you can ignore the hundreds of tourists.... ... then you can even get to pray. It's a really beautiful temple and you should take some time to walk around the gardens outside, light some incense, bathe in smoke (pull it to the body part you feel needs some help - in my case it was my very tired brain). Walk around the shops right in front and get yourself something seasonal to eat. Just try to enjoy yourself while forgetting you will probably be doing a cameo in a hundred pictures from a hundred strangers from all over the world. Just think they will be in yours too!

Picturesque. The temple and the surrounding buildings make a great photograph. It definitely gets busy during the day with visitors. There are lots of shopping vendors near the temple for a souvenir and lots of places to eat as well. I enjoyed taking photos at the temple during the evening when it was empty.

The oldest. The Senso temple is the oldest of all of Japan (as far as Buddhist temples go) and it doesn't disappoint. It's quite big and so is the Torii gate that marks its entrance. There is also a line of small shops that fill the road that leads the way to the temple itself. The shop owners here speak fairly good English. There is a large pagoda to the left of the temple that is said to house some remain of the original Buddha Shakyamuni. Settled in the middle of downtown Asakusa, the Sensoji is a beautiful monument that brings back a traditional Japanese atmosphere to a highly developed city.

Nice and crowded!. It's a very attractive temple in Tokyo near Asakusa station, they hold one of the most interesting weekends on the spring (MAY), which is enjoying a festival with performances of geishas, yakuza's members showing their tattoos, dancing, etc. At night they hold like a little market where you can enjoy the regional dishes, sweets and grab a beer while you watch how the japanese enjoy a family night.

Awe inspiring. The pictures you will see on the internet will never compare to actually having this amazing temple before your eyes, trust me, the colors, the smell of the incense being burned, the noise and everything make it a one of a kind experience. Walking the streets that lead you to the main temple is perfect for those of us who love to take pictures of everything. The temple is one of the most visited spots in Tokyo so recommendation is to go either early in the morning or late at night (when you can take more awesome pictures). The restrooms are very clean and half of the toilets are traditional toilets and the other half is western style (what we are used to). Make sure you wear sun screen and a hat, we were at the end of July and it was very hot and got sunburned. There are a couple subway stations nearby, to get here get off on the asakusa line.
Great temple!. It was super close to my hotel, and this was much even better, taking nice pictures of the temple and its sorroundings

Decent, but less than I was expecting. Not sure why but I wasn't particularly impressed by this visit...now, having said that, Sensoji temple is a TEMPLE, so it shouldn't really be judged as a tourist attraction, even if that's what it's become over the years. The architecture was impressive and it was definitely worth visiting, but it was a very brief visit, there simply isn't much to see and do here...it makes a good stop on your way to the Tokyo skytree, though. As others have said there's also a HUGE shopping area immediately south of the temple, lots of souvenirs to be had.

Real Japan!. This so important and interesting Buddhist temple is located in Asakusa, a particular and typical area, rich of souvenirs and food shops.The architecture of the temple is particular of this kind of temple, mainly in red. You cannot enter in the prayer area, but you can take a look of it from outside. Before the main building you can find and try the “fortune sticks”, where you can read, in English too, you good or bad destiny.There is also a big brazier where some incense burns and gives purification to devotee who breath or drive it to their sick body parts.Really nice the gardens all around the sanctuary and all the other smaller temples.P.S.. Fantastic the toilette: many and clean! Perfect for any...urgency!

Amazing culture!. This place is just awesome. I absolutely love the traditional architecture. It was extremely busy with many tourists, but still, it was a great experience. Many great photo opportunities. This area, is also fantastic for shopping too, especially if you want all the touristy stuff!Highly recommended!

Best of Asakusa. Entering this temple complex through the massive torii gate is quite an experience. While the huge crowds take some getting used to, the incredible architecture of the buildings cannot be ignored. I quite enjoyed watching religious tourists/worshipers going about their rituals. If you are looking for gifts/souvenirs, there are plenty of stalls/shops lining the alleys adjacent to the complex - and lots of good eats as well!

Great place for a traditional visit. You can see lots of people here. It's interesting to see their culture, follow what they do to have a feel of it. There is also traditional feel to it as leading up to the temple is a Traditional japanese shopping street. You can find lots of interesting and nice stuff here. And if during summer, its quite common to see them in Yukata, sometimes you might see some foreigners or tourist in it too.Everyone should come here at least once, not to mention the surrounding areas also have good food. But that is another review aleady :P

Sensoji Temple. Sensoji Temple is a beautiful temple. The temple is really beautiful during at night. The five story pagoda is cool. However, the pagoda doors were closed when we went there. I believe it is closed to the public. Nakamise-dori, the street leading from the Thunder Gate to the Sensoji Temple itself, is lined with small shops. Great for souvenir shopping and trying random treats! There are a few chopsticks stores here that are inexpensive compared to other areas in Tokyo. There are also a few great restaurants in the area. Be warned that restaurants close early (8:30 PM or (9:00 PM).
Must See. Beautiful and easy to get to. Crowded, busy, but interesting to see. Great photo ops, not forgetting this is a shrine.

One of the highlights of our trip. Such a fantastic place for Photo opportunities and spiritual experience. There are loads of souvenir type stalls/shops with a great selection of merchandise. We found the shopkeepers and people of the area very welcoming and helpful compared with other areas of Tokyo. All ages seemed to be enjoying the area.

Great temple and nice view around. I visited this place in the afternoon, this place a little bit crowd that days. This place have a big temple and high-tower. There are so many great spot to take pic. One interesting entertainment that day was a monkey show. In the corner of the temple there was a man with a mic speaking in local language and direct the monkey to perform.The monkey was so clever, they can jump high like an athletes, then he can rolling backwasr-onward, and one of my favorite's action when they walk with bamboo. A long-bamboo. And the monkey get dressed too with japanese traditional clothes.

Best souvenir shopping in Tokyo. Fantastic finds all around this temple. Also, great iced green tea. It was extremely hot when I was there in August and the cold tea was fantastic. The temple itself was beautiful. I loved the gate, pagoda, and grounds as well. If you go to Tokyo, you must go to Asukusa and the Sensoji temple.

Beautiful Temple In the Heart of Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is located beautifully in Tokyo, A wonderful opportunity to take in the sights, sounds and tastes of Tokyo. Lovely temples surrounded by high decorated ceilings and an array of small shops makes for a wonderful experience. Nearby is a lovely Japanese Garden. Well worth a few hours of your time in Tokyo

Tourist`s Favorite Place!. It is a place not to be missed while in Tokyo.This is the oldest temple ( built in 645) in Japan & the most significant for its people!This was destroyed by bombing during the 2nd world war & rebuilt later as a symbol of rebirth & peace!While visiting the Temple you notice in the courtyard a tree which was destroyed along with the temple bombing;a new tree has grown from the husk of the old destroyed tree.This signifies the spirit of the Japanese people & reinforces their faith as this Temple being a symbol of them!Its a must visit site for all tourist & one finds them in large numbers all the time as it is also abutting the famous Nakamise street shops & the Asukose shinto shrine.The whole area gives a wonderful view as well as an opportunity to combine one`s spiritual & commercial side in one close by place!On entering the shrine you smell the aroma of the inscence & on the ceiling an impressive dragon with three fingers.Within the Temple there is a distinctive Japanese style serene garden.You can also consult the oracle for 100 Yen for answers to your life`s problems!The Temple looks very impressive at night & a great photo opp.The colorful surroundings & the symbolic statement of the Temple for the Japanese people is very impressive & a visit not to be missed!
Beautiful temple. Really easy to find and some lovely places to sit and people watch. If you can find it, buy a melon-pan from the little shop near the temple, they are AMAZING!

Must see, must do, when in Edo.. The Temple/shrine itself is incredibly beautiful but the area is great as well. When in Tokyo it was one of my first visits and I had a wonderful time . Whithin the temple precinct, there is a padoga as well and many different buildings. The crowd is incredible and it attracts thousands of tourists who come to visit and have a good time in the nearby shopping discrict. The small shoppes are plentiful and it's a wonderful experience . The area is really safe and there are hundreds of eateries and souvernir shops. What is amazing is the opposition of today's life and tradition. That's something the Japanese are really good at. I remember being interviewed by a group of Young pupils carrying out an interview . They were interviewing non Japanese so as to find out what they/we thought about their country. Nice experience. They were really friendly as they were asking me if I loved Japan and what I loved in Japanese culture...Sure they must have smiled when I answered " sushi" and " Temples"..

Crowded Temple... I visited this temple with my extended family during summer (Aug 2014).. The temperature is very hot and you will need to walk around ~400 meter of Nakamise Street before reaching the temple.. The temple itself is very crowded with people, maybe because it is an opened temple (no entrance ticket) and the complex (Nakamise Street) is full of shops. If you would like to have a peaceful time in the temple, I believe this won't be your first choice... Nevertheless, I still enjoyed my visit to the temple, it has a very big red lantern in the entrance gate..

Like most temples, but so worth seeing. Senso-ji is the oldest shrine/temple in Tokyo, dating to the 7th century BCE. The buildings are not that old, but a shrine and temple have been here for that long. That's impressive enough. The Thunder Gate is visually impressive, with its enormous red and black paper lantern, leading into the long (and ever busy) arcade of shops that provide religious items. It ends in a plaza with an large incense brazier. Being so historic, schools groups fill the plaza and on my visit sprawled on the pavement to draw pictures of the lovely pagoda. Laid out like most temples, but more richly decorated than many, the complex is a feast for the eyes, clearly a favorite among locals, and thus someplace rich with experiences and memories for visitors from everywhere.

Sanja Matsuri Festival in May. We were lucky when we visited Sensoji Temple (浅草寺, せんそうじ). Senso-ji is Tokyo's oldest temple and an important center of worship. It is also known as the temple of the Asakusa Kannon. It attracts around 30 million visitors from all over the world every year. The legend was started by 2 fishermen who found a statue of Bodhisattva Kannon while fishing in the Sumida River back in 628.It was so crowded when we walked out of the Asakusa station. We did not realize that the date was the temple's most important and famous Sanja Matsuri festival in May every year. The surrounding roads were closed to traffic because of the festival. The festival is held in honor of the three men who established and founded Sensō-ji: Hinokuma Hamanari, Hinokuma Takenari and Hajino Nakatomo. We were there on Sunday, and it was the last day of the festival. The 3 main mikoshi touring around the districts of Asakusa were fun and entertaining. We also saw the children mimic the adults with their mini version of mikoshi; it was so cute and a good way to pass the tradition to the new generations. Every mikoshi parade had a music float that played the traditional Japanese music of the festival. The musicians sat on the floats, and people pulled or pushed them. The heavy mikoshi was carried by around 40 men and women on four long poles secured together with ropes. We were lucky to have a close encounter one of the mikoshis while waiting outside a restaurant in an alley. It was my best opportunity to take good photos of the mikoshi.Before you can see the Main Hall of Sensoji Temple, you will pass the Kaminarimon Gate (Thunder gate). The gate is guarded by two gods, the Fujin (God of Wind) and Raijin (God of Thunder). You will not miss the large red lantern with black letter “雷門” (Thunder gate). After passing the gate, you will immediately find Nakamise-dori (Nakamise street) – a 180 m (590 ft) shopping street where you can find almost all of the Japanese souvenirs you would want. Of course, a variety of snacks is everywhere. Head down the street, and you will reach the 2nd gate – Hozomon (宝蔵門). On the left, you can easily spot the beautiful five-story pagoda (五重塔) and finally, the Main Hall of the Sensoji Temple. The Main Hall is always full of worshippers and visitors of different nationalities. The Main Hall was restored in 1958 because the original temple was destroyed during WWII. You may not be able to see the statue of the Bodhisattva Kannon because it is taken out for public viewing only on December 13 of every year. Don’t forget to look up at the painting on the ceiling. You can also try to take the photos inside the main hall without flash, but it is challenging due to the multitude of tourists.The Asakusa Culture Tourist Information Center is another place you should go if you would like to have a bird-view of the Sensoji Temple. It is located opposite of the Kaminarimon Gate. Go to the roof, and you can have a fantastic view of the surroundings. The best way to get there is taking the subway and exiting at Asakusa station.

Beautiful with lots of shopping around. The temple is beautiful. There is a lane of shops leading away from the temple. Prices at those shops are pricey but toward the end of those shops, you will come upon a covered area full of more shops and lots of places to eat.

Great temple!. We didn't actually go inside Sensoji as it was late in the evening when we visited and closed when we got there. However, it is lit dramatically at night and was very interesting to see at this time and take photos. It's not for those who like quiet and understated temples - it's painted a rather garish combination of black, gold and red and draws crowds late into the evening but the sheer scale and statement of this place is very impressive.

Very crowded, souvenier sellers everywhere. This was kind of a dissapointment. Like sure, the temple was very beautiful, but most of it was not original and renovation had made the temple look a bit "fake". Also there were too much souvenier sellers around the temple premises, particularly along the way to the temple and that made the place turistic and unoriginal in my opinion.
Sen-sational-soji!. Stunning temple, grounds and amazing cultural impact. Loads of great small shops selling all sorta of artifacts and yummy foods!

Enjoy wherever your interest lies. When you come straightway from the main gate, you can see various shops on both sides: souvenir shops mostly, shoe shops, toys, snacks, kimonos and happy-coats, and everything. But you better visit the temple first and then enjoy looking at them. In September you may see chrysanthemums artificially designed and arranged inside the space between the gate and the temple. Then you see the smoke and smell frankincense at the centre; you can be healthy bywaving the smoke, only when you buy the incense sticks by yourself. In the temple, you may see a magnificent picture of a dragon on the ceiling. It grasps a crystal ball in its three fingers (as a demon it has only three fingers). Two cherubim are drawn on both sides of the dragon.If you have time, you may buy a set of postcards which include the traditional pictures drawn on wooden plates to be offered to the temple, or you can buy a fortune slip to pray good luck.

Nice temple, good foto opportunity. I went on a Sunday afternoon with friends to find the entire area filled with tourists. It was nice anyway, we saw the temple, got our fortune in English and enjoy the nice neighborhood. A must see if you go to Tokyo!

Authentic and beautiful temple area. Though it's a bit touristy, the actual temple and surrounding gardens and buildings are fantastic to see. Easy to get to from the Asakusa subway. Be sure to try the good luck fortune for 100Y. A nice experience overall and a must-see in Tokyo.

Great tourist spot. Lovely bright red temples. You can probably see them all in about a half an hour. Fantastic place to get souvenirs - you could spend hours strolling through the stands (at least I did).

First contact in Tokyo. This was my first attraction in Tokyo. It's a really great temple when you can realize the influences of the Shintoist religigion over Buddhism. The street that leads to the shrine iteslf is called Nakamise Dori and is an important part of the visit.

Much more "commercial" feel vs other temples. This temple is nice to visit if you only have time to stay in immediate Tokyo area. There are a LOT of places to buy gifts and toys, etc.The temples and shrines in Kamakura (1 hour by JR line) are much less "commercial". If you visit to Kamakura, the Sensoji temple loses its appeal quickly. But, if you are on tight schedule and only have time to stay in Tokyo, Sensoji Temple is worth a hours time to visit.

Great market and fantastic temple!. If you are focusing on a few temples in japan this MUST be included. The atmosphere was bustling (almost too busy), the market packed and the temple amazing. The market has your normal souvenirs but the ice cream and sweet bread sandwiches on the eastern edge are AMAZING and worth the stop alone. The surrounding sights (pagoda and various statues) were very nice and the temple itself was stunning. Make sure to stick around for a service as it adds a nice touch to the whole experience.

Main Tourist Spot. Sure, it is touristy but you still can sense Janpaneses' way of life by observing Japanese people in this temple. However crowd is inevitable. It is worth visiting if you visit Tokyo as it is seen as one of the symbols in tokyo already.

Favourite temple in tokyo. Loved this amazing place. So much bigger then I imagined! Just giant! So beautiful with the giant lantern and giant sandals you have to jump to touch for luck. Plus the healing smoke from one of the pots seemed to cure my boyfriends ear ache ;)

Nice temple in the middle of hustle and bustle. We went to Senso-ji after a very rainy day trip to Nikko. We arrived just before dusk and enjoyed wandering around the temple complex taking a few pictures and taking in the atmosphere.The temple complex itself was very busy but didn't need more than 15-20 minutes of wandering around exploring. If you are in the area then it's worth a look here and the neighbouring Nakamise shopping street.

Know before you go. Early in the morning of March 18, 628, when the capital of Japan was Asuka (present-day Nara Prefecture), two fishermen, Hinokuma Hamanari and his brother Takenari, were fishing in the Sumida River. Suddenly sensing something, they pulled up their net to find a statue of Bodhisattva Kannon. When Haji no Nakatomo, village headman of Asakusa, heard about this, he immediately realized that the object was a statue of the important Buddhist deity Bodhisattva Kannon. Taking vows as a Buddhist priest and remaking his home into a temple, he spent the rest of his life in devotion to Bodhisattva Kannon. In 645, renowned Buddhist priest Shokai Shonin built Kannondo Hall upon visiting the Asakusa district during his travels. Following a revelation he received in a dream, Shokai decided that the image should be hidden from human view, and this tradition has remained in place ever since. Asakusa began as an obscure fishing village along an estuary of Tokyo Bay, part of the vast wilderness of the area known as Musashi. The district later thrived as people arrived in increasing numbers to worship. When Ennin (794-864), the highest-ranking priest of Enryaku-ji (head temple of the Tendai School of Buddhism) visited Senso-ji in the mid-ninth century, he created a statue identical to the hidden one that could be viewed and worshipped by the people. During the Kamakura period (1192-1333), the shoguns, who held the true power in Japan during this time, demonstrated great devotion to Senso-ji. Gradually, other historically prominent figures including military commanders and the literati came to follow their example. Enjoying the protection of these illustrious individuals, the temple buildings were refined. During the Edo period (1603-1867), first Edo shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu deemed Senso-ji the temple where prayers for the aspirations of the shogunate would be offered. As a result the buildings were imbued with still greater dignity, and the temple complex flourished as the center of Edo (present-day Tokyo) culture. Senso-ji is Tokyo's oldest temple. Known affectionately to people all over Japan as the temple of the Asakusa Kannon, it draws some 30 million visitors every year, remaining an important center of worship.

Average. The temple complex is rather small. It is vividly painted on the outside with some nice ceiling paintings in the main hall. We have visited China, Tibet and Thailand so have been spoilt with beautiful temple complexes. This was very underwhelming in contrast. You can get a couple of nice shots here and in about 10 minutes will have completed your visit.If you enjoy hustle and bustle or want to go souvenir shopping then the temple is situated at the end of a shopping street. It is very crowded and you have to make space to move around the tiny shops. Prices seemed reasonable - not all shops charge the same for the same items though. Quite a few shops do take credit cards. If you need cash there is a seven- eleven near the subway entrance/exit.

Many tourists, but still a wonderful place in Tokyo. The Sensoji Temple is located in Asakusa, which used to be the most important entertainment area in Tokyo. It's a beautiful temple, with an adjacent pagoda and beautiful gardens. The area is extremely lively, always packed with tourists and locals. Having stayed in a hotel nearby, I had the opportunity to see the place at different days of the week and times of the day. It's always very crowded, but the weekends are much worse. Close to the temple there is the Nakamise shopping street, where all kinds of souvenirs (cheaper than in other areas) and typical food can be found. The visit to the temple itself can be fast, but most people stay in the area for hours, shopping, eating, taking pictures or walking through the gardens.

Great experience, lots of local shopping and eateries nearby. One of two temples I visited during my stay in Tokyo. Where as Meiji Jingu was quiet and peaceful, Sensoji was lively and exciting. There was huge crowd at the temple when I visited, both locals, native tourists, and international tourists. The temple grounds was extremely beautiful, featuring traditional gardens. The temple itself was very lively, there was a large crowd waiting to pray at the temple, although everything was very orderly (as expected of Japan).The main attraction for me however were the shops and eateries along the street leading to the temple. There is a huge selection of local goods, foods, and souvenirs. The prices were also very affordable. I bought a kimono from one of the shops and am very satisfied with the price and quality.Don't be afraid to skip lunch and come to the temple, you will eat more than you fill if you try out the eateries along the way to or back from the temple. All of the eateries featured something unique, and many of them offered snacks you can eat on the go, but please for the love of god don't litter.
full of local product. the site is very beautiful plus there is many store for food or local product. you can buy special cake or chocolate. you can buy signature tokyo bag or ornament

My favorite in Tokyo. Although it is always jam packed with tourists this busyness can add to the fun of Sensoji Temple. Make sure for 100yen you get your fortune as you near the temple entrance as they have them in English.

Popular sight and shopping. We decided to spend our last day in Tokyo with a visit to this Temple. Read that there were many vendors and shops along way to the Temple. We were not disappointed and in fact impressed with the number of quality goods and food items to purchase. Found a good pair of geta slippers at reasonable price. We also found a short cotton yukata with matching shorts for male. Prices ranged from $22 to $35. Vendor sold 3 pairs to us for $20 each. This is the place to buy fresh rice crackers, manju and mochi. While we did see manju being made at other places, this was first time we saw how rice crackers are made, They sold hot crackers wrapped in nori. It was delicious and quite filling. There was a soft serve stand advertising 30 flavors. Another vendor sold a delicious curry wrap of ground pork and beef. We would have liked to have spent more time there shopping. Would definitely return on a future trip.

Way more than a temple!. We took the 30 minute walk here after visiting the Tokyo Skytree. There are lots of things to see and do. Make sure you make a wish and read your fortune! Also, take some time to was through Asakusa and get your fill of souvenir shopping. There aren't many other other places in Tokyo with this sort of concentration of souvenirs so take the opportunity to load up.

Make a wish!. Just beautiful and dont forget to make a wish and see your destiny. It only cost of few yen and was great. The temple although busy is worth walking around. We also saw ladies in traditional japanese dress.

Nice place with a fair amount of walk. You have to walk a fair bit to reach the main place from parking. Japan historic is all over the place. During my visit there was a Japaneses marriage going on. One of the must visit to view the Japan culture and history.

historic temple. This is a beautiful and historic temple that has roots going back to the earliest times in Edo (old Tokyo). The temple has been rebuilt many times, most recently after Allied bombing during WW2. The approach through the Kaminarimon Gate, both inspires and distracts, as Nakamise-dori, the street you approach on, is all shops selling souvenirs and trinkets. There is also a funfair next door! But my main impression of Sensoji is that it is very much a working temple, with a strong place in the hearts of Tokyo people. Approach it with respect.
Amazing. Second time round and still amazing. Love it. It's a busy area with shops selling tourist wares but the temple has a serenity about it. Very safe area and a must temple to visit.

Great place, lovely sights.. Visited with my teenage daughter, and even she had to admit that it was beautiful and impressive.
My personal advice is not to miss the small garden and stream to the left side of the Senso-ji (main building). The rest is pretty obvious...

Amazing, come at night. Came here at night, around 2am on my very first night in Japan (couldn't sleep lol). I saw a random temple/park thing on a local street map and found my way there. Streets were abandoned but felt totally safe. Upon arriving, I had my official "Oh Wow I'm Really In Japan" moment. Only later do I find out how culturally important the place is lol.

Busy and good for both ritual and markets. This temple is coveniently located near the Asakusa stop of the Hibiya line (Tokyo Metro) station with its distinctive entry gate. From the station there is a short stroll to the harbour also with the Asahi Beer building easily identifiable. The temple itself is not huge but very busy with bona fide worshippers. Between the outer gate and the temple itself is a busy market selling mostly souvenirs with the inner stalls appearing to be more reasonably priced (but generally not by much). The permanent buildings to either side of the markets house more art/craft stalls as well as restaurants. Plan to spend at least 1/2 a day if you plan to shop.

always the attraction!. This is definitely a faved visiting spot for tourists and locals alike. If one starts with some traditional spirituality, this Buddhist temple (the famous Sensoji 浅草寺Temple) is a must! This is my 2nd trip over the past 15 months. :> Rebuild many times this is the capital’s spiritual epicenter. Enter through the imposing Kaminarimon Gate (the massive Thunder gate) which houses a pair of ferocious protective deities (Fujin and Raijin). The very obvious red lantern with the ‘character’ (雷門 "Thunder Gate) has been pictured in many photos, wall papers.. Painted on the back is the gate’s official name, Fūraijinmon (風雷神門). Follow by shopping along the atmospheric Nakamise Doori, touted as Japan oldest shopping mall, probably need not much elaboration… Not to be missed is the giant straw scandals hand on the walls of the Homoz-mon, the scandals symbolise the traditional Buddhism pilgrim. And ahead and one will reach the main temple. Freshly renovated main hall in December 2010 the interior is lavishly furnished and here s a richly decorated gold altar. We have been here twice (different timings) and noticed that the crowd of worshippers never recede. An interesting part nearby is the large incense burner, a crowd puller. Many believe wafting the smoke towards oneself will bring very good luckThere is also a lovely pagoda and gardens and statues to wander around and admire. Walk down through the Denbo-in garden and on the left you will come upon lovely roads lined with traditional shops- this really feels like a walk back in time- a very different and historical part of Tokyo. The Shitmachi-feel.Depending on your ternary/timing exploring the neighbouring is not to be missed. With such a large crowd of both locals and tourist this is still a #1 visit site for many a travelers (to Japan)!

Best Shrine in Tokyo. My family loved Sensoji Temple. It is beautiful and historic. We learned a lot of rituals such as washing your hands with the little tins before going up to the shrine, and the proper prayers to say at the shrine. There was even a wedding taking place there in traditional costume. The street leading up to temple is overflowing with vendors selling merchandise and is half the fun of going there. A must visit in Tokyo.

Full of interesting sights. From the gate adorned with a huge sandal (to frighten potential attackers away) to the sculptures of the Buddhas to the healing incense urns, this temple is filled with interesting things to see and learn about.

Perhaps Tokyo's #1 Tourist Destination. The place is quite touristy, and the pathway leading to the temple is sprinkled with a lot of stores selling souvenirs. The Buddhist temple is the highlight of Asakusa, and in there, you can offer prayers. For 100 Japanese Yen, your luck can be determined by choosing random sticks that corresponds to a prediction - this can be done before you actually enter the temple (right side).There is a pagoda in the area as well, which looks very grand and the Tokyo Sky Tree can be seen as well. The area has perhaps the oldest Town Center in Tokyo. You can appreciate it more with a tour guide telling you stories about the temple. Small children might not appreciate the place.

A bit touristy, but still beautiful and bustling.. Sensoji temple is one of the must-go to attractions when visiting Asakusa. It's the oldest temple in all of Tokyo. It starts with a massive gate in front with the two guardians in front protecting the temple. A few relics line this gate including a traveler's sandal you touch for good luck in your travels.After a street lined with tons of markets with souvenirs and food lead the way to the main temple. This is a good chance to get some souvenirs for your loved ones back at home. Some places were more expensive than others, so be on the look out.The main temple was a big beautiful Japanese Buddhist style red temple with a pagoda nearby. An incense well nearby allows you to bath in the smoke of temple for good fortune. You can pray, make wishes, or donations, and take tons of pictures with.If you have a chance, visit the Shinto shrine just nearby the temple to see the other common Japanese religion. It might be a little quieter.

Definetely a temple to Visit in Tokyo. It was one of the temples i wanted to visit in Tokyo, and i was globally not disappointed.The way to the temple is really interesting, as you would find old Japanese architecture and old shop too, going through the Market.At the Temple, well the usual. But here the interesting thing, is that it's big and there is a lot more to see.The only point that i disliked and it was normal, it's the fact that it was crowded.

True asakusa Tokyo style. Amazing and genuine local and traditional temple with awesome vibe and a smoke bath in the crisp morning is perfect.Situated right next the Richmond asakusa hotel which is also superb is a great combination and I highly recommend .

Massive. This is probably the most visited temple in Tokyo. It's quite awe inspiring. We twice during the trip ans it's always buzzing. You also always see people in tradiotnal outfits, young and old, which is fab to see.I however find the modern stalls too much. Would have much preferred some old traditional huts, rather than their modern rebuild. But as far as modern rebuild go (if you like those, then they're on the great side) ...
Magnificient. This temple is beautiful and one of my favourite spots in Tokyo. The area around it too is very nice, even though it is quite touristy.

Amazing. Finally, i saw the great kannon temple. Lots of people came by, so dont think you'll get a good space to take a pic. But the view was wonderful as there was a big and fascinating lantern and became sumbol of the place. Your tokyo tour meaningless without a picture in here ^_^

Captivated by the Kaminari-mon. We took the Ginza line to Asakusa and went out through exit 1. We were heading to the Sensoji Temple, Tokyo"s most visited temple which houses a golden image of Kannon ( the Buddhist goddess of mercy). According to a legend, the statue was miraculously pulled out of the nearby Sumidagawa by 2 fishermen. Before reaching the temple, we had to pass a few gates. There is always a big lantern hanging at each gate. People were touching the lantern and taking photos. After the gates, we passed through Nakamise-dori, a shopping walkway where you can buy all sorts of souvenirs. At the end of Nakamise-dori, we spotted the 55m Five-storey pagoda and then we climbed up the stairs to Sensoji temple. There were lots of worshippers who were placing their josssticks into the large incense cauldron, after praying to Kannon. From the stais, we spotted Tokyo Skytree.

Oldest temple but also crowded. There are many temples in Tokyo have better 'ambience'. It is worth to visit only you are in the neighborhood. The temple is very crowded, and very commercialized. This is one of stops in our Hato Bus tour, once is enough for our visit.

Impressive temple.. Sensoji Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa,Tokyo. It is the oldest Temple in Tokyo, very colourful and busy. Even though there are crowds of people it is still a must see.When one is approaching the temple you first walk through a market place, (the shopping street has been here for several centuries!) a very interesting experience, as stalls sell everything Japanese; from snacks to souvenirs, and delicious ice-cream! A helpful tip; eating or drinking while walking down a street is considered rude. As is talking into a mobile (cell) phone while on a bus or train. The temple is architecturally interesting and beautiful, there are other buildings with in its vicinity that are also interesting, such as the pagoda. Beautifully clipped azaleas, lovely trees and small gardens add to the charm of this place.

Didn't love the crowds and tourist trinket shops.. I went to Sensoji Temple after visiting many other temples in the Kyoto and Nara area, so maybe I was a bit spoiled coming in. I actually have little recollection of the actual temple, since I spent most of my time pushing through crowds. The shops in front of the temple are your typical tourist shops, which I had seen enough of by that point in my trip.It was walking distance from my hostel, so I don't regret going, however, if I had limited time in Tokyo, I'm not sure I would go out of way to visit.

hectic. The building is impressive and the history behind it is also special, but holy crap it is busy! Any time of day, any particular day, it will be busy. Hawkers selling the same kind of souvenirs everywhere, smell of moon cakes, it's an interesting place. Don't allocate a big chunk of time there, you'll only need an hour.

Favorite place, but too crowded. I just love this temple. Been visiting since I was a little girl, I don't know, there' s this joyous atmosphere there, with it's own aisle lined with little shops selling weird Japanese-ish souvenirs and snacks that are fun to eat leading up to the temple. Sadly, this temple has become a major tourist attraction, so now adays, it's always terribly crowded. You have a tight schedule, the crowd can become very annoying.

Beautiful Active Temple in Lovely Area. We were so lucky to have been in Tokyo while the cherry blossoms were in bloom, and it made Sensoji Temple even more outstanding. Although the buildings were beautiful, the garden areas and how they have incorporated sculptures into the garden was fantastic. Plan extra time so you can visit some of the many shops in the area.

Great Complex to visit especially at night. I walked down the shopping street that leads up to the temple in the early evening and it was definitely beautiful. The temple and pagoda were all lit up and the crowds had pretty much left because the temple itself was closed. It is a great place to start as you begin your time in the Asakusa area.

Biggest temple!. Very nice view, very nice temple.
There is a market in front of the temple that sells very interesting souvenirs.

Awe Inspiring. Decided to go see the Temple for myself and was not disappointed at all. The grounds are beautiful, the Temple is a wonder, and knowing that the original temple had to be rebuilt after WWII really gave me pause. Word of advice: It is very crowded. The strip of shops between the Thunder Gate and the Temple was hectic, but the crowds moved pretty quickly.Something I did notice though, by my fellow travellers was something that made me very uncomfortable. When a young Japanese Girl and maybe her boyfriend are visiting the Temple and she, maybe even he, are wearing Yukata, for the love of all that is holy leave them alone. I witness some American ladies oohing and ahhing over one of the young ladies and asking then posing with the very uncomfortable looking girl. Yukata is not every day clothing, but it is clothing to them..not a photo opportunity (unless she speaks really good English. This girl did not and looked very confused by the attention).

Tokyo's most impressive temple. This is tourist central so you will need to battle the crowds and walk down between several shops selling largely overpriced souvenirs, but it's worth it to see Toyko's premier temple
Ok but way to commercially crowded. The temple was nice but the walk through all the tourist trap shops was a little too much. Go early to avoid the throngs of school kids.

Very impressive!. This stop was also included in the Tokyo Morning Tour i had booked. The day I went was very busy so it was quite hard to get a proper look at everything. Nevertheless, this Temple is absolutely stunning and very impressive. I highly recommend to maybe come on your own time though since we only hab 30 minutes there because of our tour which is not nearly enough to see everything.

Very busy place. It is a very popular destination for visitors to Tokyo, and it does look good indeed. Unfortunately the crowds does mean there is very little serenity to be found. It sort of feels less like a place of worship than a market, but that's OK.

Exciting!. Sensoji temple is one of the biggest tourist hotspot in Tokyo. So do expect it to be crowded all the time! But apart from that, its a lovely place. Check out the street peddlars and shops in front of the temple. They sell anything from candies to takoyakis. Walk around the grounds as well as you might be able to catch a few street performers :)

Beautiful temples but crowded. Only a couple of minutes walk from Asakusa metro station this is a beautiful Buddhist temple. For me this was the best temple and grounds in Tokyo, although they have been rebuilt after they were near but destroyed in WW2. You should enter via the Kaminarimon gate which features a massive paper lantern. From there you are led down Nakamise Dori which is the street on the approach to the temple grounds where there are various stalls selling all sorts of different tasty snacks, I tried the green tea doughnuts which were surprisingly good! This is followed by the impressive Hozomon or "Treasure House Gate" which is the inner gate and has 2 large guardian statues. As you pass through don't forgot to check out the two huge straw sandals on the back face apparently weighing 900 lbs each! You then reach the actual Senso Ji temple which I have to say is probably not as imposing as the Hozomon gate or the 5 story pagoda that sits aside, but still very beautiful. I visited mid morning during the week and it was still busy so its probably best to go early morning or late evening, but despite this it was a very pleasant experience.

Impressive but surroundings are overly commercial. The actual temple and shrines at this well-known site are beautiful and quite impressive, but I feel the rampant commercialism of the many shops/stalls right inside the gates take away from this historic site. The first time I visited I was with a formal tour and got helpful explanations and descriptions of what I was seeing from a tour guide; that was helpful. The second time I visited I knew to go straight through the gauntlet of stalls to see the important stuff. Both visits were on weekdays and there were many tourists and school groups, so photography is a challenge. But overall this is a must-see for travelers in Tokyo.

Pretty but crowded. Not too big, but beautiful. Not far from subway station.
Went there around 2pm, which I guess was the prime time for visitors. It was a little bit crowded. I felt sorry for people who actually came to pray, because the center area was packed with tourists taking pictures...

Lovely at night!. During the daytime, you will not have much space to move, due to so many people! But visit at night and you will have it almost all to yourself (and well a few serious photographers, and strollers). The temples are beautifully lighted! You will love it at night!

Go Draw a Divination Stick. I almost always visit the Sensoji Temple whenever I am in Asakusa, Tokyo. There are fewer people in the evening, because by then most of the shops are closed. But surely you can still get some senbei (rice crackers) to go. Every time I am there, I always like to pray and draw a divination stick (100 yen) to seek some advice.
