The reading (in Kanji, Japanese, and English), though in the poetic form, is not difficult to interpret and understand. Believe it or not, what it says is fairly accurate!

Beautiful temple. I've been here twice now and both times were were great. It's really beautiful at night when it's all lit up. Try to go on a Friday or Saturday because the busyness adds to the affect I think. Overall, a must see for Toyko.

Worth a visit. If you don't get to make it to Kamakura, the Sensoji Temple is worth a visit. Grand and elegant, it's an insight into Japanese traditions and the surrounding shops in the backstreets are worth a visit. Make sure you walk down them, it would be a shame to just to the main boulevard there and back.

Must visit - unique experience. Sensoji temple is on our itinerary. We took train to Asakusa station. You can find it easily and try to go on weekday so less crowded. to reach to the temple, there is one long street called Nakamise street and they sell many kind of Japanese snacks and some traditional Japanese stuff. Its very interesting and unique. Tried their fried mocha with cold green tea for JPY100.
Inspiring and tranquil!. There were many, many people here on the day, and it was drizzling with a light rain - I felt the tranquillity and beauty of this place............

An early morning walk. Since we were staying near by and were up early, we decided to go for a walk around the area and of course ended up at the famous temple gate where so many tourist pictures have been taken. Early in the morning it is a quiet and lovely spot, before the tourist crowds hit. Afterwards, we did enjoy walking through the nearby streets with all sorts of little shops. Some were quite touristy but others I found to be quite reasonable with some items that I didn't find elsewhere in Tokyo. You definitely need to get your picture at the gate and then just follow your nose to all the freshly made treats nearby.

Can't enter. You should know that you can't actually enter the Temple. This limits you to the grounds (much the same across this country), the gate (really cool!), and the garden (really nice pictures in Cherry Blossom season). We were repeatedly disappointed in the Temples & Shrines throughout Japan, not being admitted entrance meant that the experience was limited to the grounds, which were very much the same, time after time. It's always interesting, but not captivating like China or Thailand where you can enter to see the Buddha's and the artifacts and......all the things you came for. Judge your time accordingly. There were a couple of young students who offered to escort us through the museum and the gardens, at no charge. We expected that they would "hit us up" for a fee at the end, but they were, surprisingly, true to their word, and did not!. So the students here do this as a way to practice their English skills (something we also encountered in Thailand).

Soso like many big tourist attractions. If you have never been to Asia before, you will love this place. But if you have been hanging around Asia for years, this temple is very disappointing. First, you can not actually go inside. Second, it is full of tourists. Third, it is surrounded by tacky stalls selling overpriced eats. A bit like visiting Buckingham palace and only seeing it from the outside, it left me with a feeling of "well, seen it now, but there must be something more worthwhile to be doing in Tokyo". If the inside were open, it would be different. By the way, not much of the building is original, and the eldest sections are kept out of view.

take a step back in time and be enchanted. it is the oldest Buddhist temple (628) in Tokyo that is also known as the Asakusa Kannon Temple. The legend says that in the year 628 two brothers fished a staue of Kannon, the goddess of mercy, out of the Sumida River, and even though they put the statue back into the river, it always returned to them. Consequently, sensoji was built nearby for the goddess of Kannon. The temple was completed in 845. It's clearly a major tourist attraction.The temple is famous for its main Kaminarimon (Thunder) Gate where a giant lantern hangs. When you have seen every corner of this you're steps away from a shopping street called Nakamise and this leads to the second gate, the Hozomon
Fascinating!. An amazing experience! I really would recommend anyone to visit Sensoji Temple! Amazing history, architecture, art, atmosphere, anyone visit Tokyo needs to see this!
Beautiful Japanese Culture. Really nice place to visit. Packed with tourists and pilgrims. The structures are fabulous and there is s \o much to see. Highly recommended

Oldest temple in Tokyo. Senso-ji is the oldest temple in Tokyo and obviously held very dear to locals. The first buildings on the site date back to 942 AD, when a statue of Bodhisattva Kannon was found by a couple of fishermen. Today there are several temples within the grounds, some have burnt down and since replaced. The towering five storey pagoda for example was only rebuilt in the 1970's. You enter the temple under the famous Kaminariomon Gate with the huge lantern. The character on it means Thunder. A parade of shops leads to the main temple area, look out for the giant sandal, lots of people jump up to try and touch it for good luck. Throwing coins in the main temple is another activity every seems to take part in.

So glad we came here. Having seen it on photos, this was towards the top of the "to do" list when we visited Japan and I am so glad we did. Senso-Ji is beautiful and the nearby Nakamise market on the approach to the temple was so good, we went back a second time to go and buy some souvenirs and gifts. We will definitely be returning to Asakusa in 2015. This place is brilliant!

Great Cultural Visit. I really enjoyed visiting Sensoji temple, the surrounding small shrines/gardens, and the surrounding stalls and shops. We got there just before 9am, so it was still early, and it was not crowded. It was peaceful. Most of the stalls were just opening. By 10am, the place was really packed especially the souvenir and food stalls. Go early to experience the peaceful spirit of Asakusa.

Wonderful. Had only an afternoon for sightseeing and so glad this is where I went. The temple is magnificent, and I loved that most of the people here were Japanese. Not tourists--people visiting the temple to pay their respects. Surrounding area of shops and stalls is a great place to buy souvenirs, and it's very easy to get here on the subway.
Lovely. The temple is beautiful, we visited it for Sanja Matsuri and It was really crowded but It was a great experience.

A hive of activity. A great place to fill in a few hours or a full day; be prepared for big crowds if visiting in peak tourist season or on weekends but definitely worth the effort. Traditional Japanese culture on display, combined with a range of interesting food choices and eateries plus souvenirs a plenty!

Good Temple. I visited so many temples in Japan. This is a good one. The famous feature of it is the big red lantern!! With a long street of selling things, you can walk to the temple. You will find it quite amazing. I prayed and drew divination sticks at this temple, and I got #99 which is extremely lucky!! Love this place.

NIce Temple. It's a nice temple and it's free. Surrounding it there's lots of attractions too. Food and shopping are everyone.
Found a strange stone outside the temple near the toilet at the smoking comer. Looks like for guys to urine.

See downtown Tokyo. This temple is in the middle of Asakusa, downtown of Tokyo. You will see how much Buddhism is at the center of Japanese people.
At the shopping corridor that leads to the temple, you will be able to find all of your Japanese souvenirs.

Beautiful Complex, Best Late Afternoon. This is a stunning temple complex set in a bustling area with plenty of small bars and eateries. I am sure you have read up on the history of the place so I won't go into that but if you do plan a visit and are also thinking of doing, for instance, nearby Akihabara I would recommend Akihabara first and then, late afternoon, on to the temple. You will be able to see the beautiful lights and combine your trip with drinks and dinner.

Good Souvenir Shopping Area. The temple is adjacent to the Asakusa shopping area, which together with the temple is a really buzzy and a tourist hot-spot. The temple is interesting, but read up on it first so you know what you need to see, for example, the symbolic painting on the ceiling. You probably won't need more than 30 minutes for the temple, but there are numerous market-style shops leading to the temple, which are good for food and souvenir shopping. There is a river cruise departure point about 200m away, so combine a visit with a boat trip.

SENSOJI - OLDEST TEMPLE OF TOKYO. Its a nice place to get around if one is willing to know about the Japanese culture !!A renovated place after World war-II and oldest temple of TOKYO !!!A Museum opened between April-August is a worth watch as it gives lots of information through antique paintings which depicts the types of culture in all aspects.A lane of more than dozens of shops entertain you with various types of Japanese foods(both veg and non-veg). However A vegetarian had to doubly ensure about having food there.WORTH A VISIT COMPULSORILY FOR A FOREIGNER !

Start here. That was the best advice I received before arriving in Tokyo. Sensoji is magical in the morning. It was a great introduction to Japan, with it's overwhelming scents, spirit, food stalls and souvenir stands. Start here!

Spiritual center of Tokyo. A stunning red structure, Sensoji is located in the midst of the working class neighborhood, Asakusa. Go and spend an hour or two wandering through the temple grounds and nearby Nakamase Dori (the street leading up to Sensoji). Nakamase is a site in itself lined with little stores selling handmade crafts, food and tourist tat. A tip, check out if there are any events or festivals happening at Senso ji during your stay in Tokyo. Ask your hotel/guesthouse/hostel staff to look into it for you online! Festivals are housde here often throughout the year and offer the chance to witness Japanese traditions at their best.
Sight for eyes. Can visit the temple and say a blessing or try some food at the market inside the compound. Also in the distance is Tokyo tower.

Lovely temple. Lovely temple but very busy and crowded and definite tourist hot spot. We enjoyed the street market and buying biscuits proved fun - not really sure what we were getting until actually trying them but they were delicious if not quite what we expected

Beautiful temple. There's a shopping street before reaching the temple. There are many souvenirs and street food shops that attracts you. There were lots of tourists although it was a weekday. There are also quite a number of very old traditional restaurants nearby.

Go at off peak hours. My sister and I went twice. First on the weekend and then on a weekday evening. On weekends it is PACKED. Ever wondered what it would be like to bump shoulders with the locals and try to push your way into the shops? Well, weekends make for quite the experience. People watching was very entertaining. Everything from Sumo wrestlers to Harajuku girls showed up. On week day nights it quiets way down. Shop owners are not as stressed and more able to help you with care and attention. The sun set beautiful on this site and makes for a more spiritual experience when you finally get through all the shopping and reach the temple. The Sensoji Temple is so beautiful and colorful. It's interesting to watch the locals throw smoke on themselves as a cleansing and go about their prayers. After watching the ritual a few times, I gave it a try. Culture is definitely alive in this spot. Whether you want to see it all hustle and bustle or in a more zen state.
Nice temple in central Tokyo. Nice temple with no fees. Close to the market where you can buy souvenirs. Lots of nice little restaurants close by.

well worth a visit.. The main entrance to this extensive Buddhist complex is through a large ornate arch from which a street of stalls and small shops selling a range of foods, trinkets and goods lead to the main grounds of the temple. This small shopping street of some 200 metres is part of the temple precinct and is said to have centuries of tradition of selling wares to pilgrims approaching the temple. Now, of course, they sell to the hundreds of tourists that throng the area.The main temples area includes a five-storey pagoda (reputedly the largest in Tokyo) an attractive ornamental arch and various small gardens and lanterns within a spacious forecourt (which also has good toilet facilities). The forecourt also had a number of trees with cherry blossom, which looked very fetching until closer inspection revealed that it was imitation (fabric) cherry blossom wired to branches that had been nailed to the main trunk! As it was cherry blossom time I doubt whether many noticed, but I did wonder whether they keep them there the whole year for effect?None of this is original, of course, as earthquakes have meant rebuilding several times over the years, including after the aerial bombing of World War Two, which destroyed most of it. However, it has been fittingly reconstructed and it affords a pleasant and interesting hour or so. This is well worth the visit, even if it is now packed with tourists and probably lacks the religious atmosphere, original structures and ‘wow’ factor of many other temples and shrines throughout Japan.

beautiful temple. lots of people and tourist especially the shopping streets from the main road right up to the temple itself. not to be missed is the temple grounds and pagoda. was there in spring the cherry blossoms were still around a very beautiful sight

Beautiful temple, fun area to browse in. Asakusa was a fun town to browse around in. There are lots of interesting little shops, restaurants and of course the Sensoji Temple is there. The temple itself is beautiful. It is surrounded with rows of shops that sell kimonos, various foods, lots of Japanese souvenirs and skilled candy makers that you can watch as they mold and make their goods. You could buy Japanese fans, sun powered bobble headed sumo wrestlers or geisha girls. Darma heads or Maneineko cats statues of various sizes. There were the trinket shops along with the higher quality more expensive shops. Being that it was cherry blossom season there were lots of people. But that didn't matter because as we have found while we've been in Japan is that the people are very kind and friendly. They aren't pushy and aggressive. I loved being in Japan!
Pretty temple . A pretty temple, with nice grounds and a good street market selling a range of wares on the way. V popular with Japanese as well as foreigners (at least at the weekend).

Beautiful temple. I visit Senso-ji every time I come to Tokyo. The temple itself is beautiful. The streets around are full of shops, street vendors. and restaurants. It's always full of people, which is (for me) part of the fun. You can take a trip with a rickshaw and it's driver will show you around and tell you about the temple.

It'll blow your senses-ji. Huge and beautiful temple complex!-I recommend getting your fortune in an omikuji for 100 yen. Look for みくじ written on top of a stall made from small wooden boxes and a big metal cylinder. The way to do it is to shake the cylinder until a wooden strip comes out. It has a number written on it, so you put it back into the cylinder and open the drawer with the number you pulled. Take one slip of paper and that's your fortune! (Even written in English)-You can visit the adjoining Nakamise street for a festive atmosphere, cool souvenirs and traditional stall foods.
Good street character. Worth visiting, streets around make for a great walk around experience. Good yo combine with a sky tree visit.

Great temple!. The greatest temple/Shrine we visited between Osaka, Kyoto, Hakone and Tokyo.It is huge, beautifull, mix of Shintu and budismo - a must if you are visiting Tokyo. Full of people...After the visit you can shop in the streets japonese articles.We used the opportunity to walk to skytree (almost 30 min) - better to take taxi.We also did the trip by boat on the river (ok, but nothing special).

Very nice experience. Visiting Tokyo this was the first visit at a temple. It was an interesting and very nice experience. Apparently we were not the only one; this is the most in Tokyo. The current structure dates from 1950. Their is a very beautiful pagoda next it as well as a garden.The walk from the first gate at the street to the temple was an experience itself. So busy and so many things for sale. So please consider this visiting Tokyo.Note: this is within walking distance from the Tokyo Sky Tree.

Lovely experience. We visited there on the Buddha's birthday (8th April) when people were giving away orchids and all sorts of festive stuff was going on. Lovely place, lovely area and do visit in April!

As atmospheric as it was busy!. To get there from the subway just follow the numbers of people. This one is very busy and the numerous stalls provide a real buzz to the temple. Not a calm experience but the enjoyment and enthusiasm is here in spades full.
One of the most popular temple in tokyo. we can enter the temple through Kaminarimon Gate, but also through Nakamise shopping arcade, there's a asakusa shrine next to the temple.

Only recommended if you go early to beat the crowds. This is like a temple plus a mall.Honestly, there were so many people it was hard to enjoy. In contrast, i was one of 3 people at the Zojoji temple and was really able to appreciate the beauty and serenity.I would recommend going as early as possible or not at all.

Crowds are an integral part of the temple. People complain about the crowds but I don't understand why, even though I normally avoid them. As always in Japan the local people are good natured and behave impeccably. There is no pushing or shoving and if they have to wait for a few minutes they are perfectly happy to do so. You never ever feel unsafe as you may do elsewhere in the world. I went on a Sunday at the height of the cherry blossom season and it was heaving, but I loved that aspect just as much as the place itself. Tourists really should just chill out and go with the flow i.e. behave as the locals do - there is no stress here, other than that you might create yourself!!Senso-ji is a beautiful temple complex, even if it is a post-war reconstruction. The shopping street leading up to the main gate has all small shops, some of which have been trading since the 19th century, including an excellent wood block print shop.If you are going to visit only one temple perhaps this is it.
Nice temple. So many tourist but worth the visit. You will see Japanese doing their rituals and tourist tend to follow ;) lots of people , lots of cheap souvenirs, lots of places to eat and buy
Must-see temple and arcade of stalls. Very atmospheric. Good photos with the temple and Tokyo SkyTree in the background. Shops selling local souvenirs. The "senbei" biscuits are good.

Must Visit. Very crowded but beautiful temple. Must visit "Nakamise" the shopping street in front of the temple. The stalls sell lots of souvenir stuff and cookies. There are also lots of local snacks sold there.

Nice temple, though crowded. The Sensoji temple has a large area with a nice design. Though it becomes crowded in the weekends, it is still worth a visit also for the street that comes up to it! It also has food and souvenir stalls in the ground.

Lot's of Souvenirs. Spent probably 10 minutes taking pictures of the shrine as well as the sake drums, spent more time at the souvenir shops. Be sure to check out all the little stores before buying, some stores may have one item 100 to 300 yen cheaper than another store, and another item 100 to 300 yen more expensive than the same competitor. Also had a lot of food vendors selling takoyaki, yakitori, and various sweet snacks.

Really good temple to visit. The oldest temple in Tokyo, and perhaps Japan, this temple is definitely worth checking out for its history and for its distinct design. Obviously, it’s always packed so get there early and you can visit the many food and souvenir stalls located around the temple

Spectacular temple by Shinto Shine & many free, related sites. This is a remarkable area drawing thousand of people. First there's the temple, which is right next to a Shinto Shine, showing people with different beliefs can get along. Next, there's a pagoda which is quite dramatic.Then there are dozens of shops with souvenirs - of widely varying quality.Amazing place. Lots of energy here.

A bit of culture in the middle of the Town. The Temple is just one of the finest in Tokyo. Perfect if you want to see some cerimonies. The atmosphere is great in early morning.There is a nice garden and the gate looks also great.
Very crowded but still interesting. The streets approaching the temple are bustling with people and souvenir shops. It was very crowded on the day we went which was a sunny Monday in March.

Busy, bustling temple with plenty of atmsophere. Despite the crowds, the Senso-ji is a great place to visit. You approach via a street of shops selling all sorts of tourist tat, but also home-made rice cakes and fried beancurd cakes, both local specialities. The temple is ornate, and there is a scent of incense wafting through the air; it is burning in a huge cauldron and people immerse themselves in the fumes for good luck. There were people milling around, several in kimonos, most offering prayers at the main shrine; on the side there is a quiet garden where I found some gorgeous camellias in full bloom. I bought some rice cakes, beautifully wrapped, to take home. Great atmosphere.

Best site for Souvenirs. This temple is always crowded. Recommended place for purchasing souvenirs. Upon entering the main temple, look for a "well" looking area. Scoop some water and pour it on your hands and mouth (traditional cleansing of body and spirit when entering a temple)Then try your luck with Omikuji by offering 100yen on the somewhat donation box and doing the instructions posted in English. After that, head directly to the main temple and use 5yen(their lucky coin) toss it in the big box-like where everybody's tossing it, clap your hands twice, bow and make a wish.

Great temple complex. This temple is defined as Japans oldest Buddhist temple for ordinary people. Be prepared to share it with many thousands of those people ... the crowds are quite overwhelming, especially today, the birthday of Buddha. On entering we were given a free Thai orchid flower display to leave with our prayers. In itself the temple is somewhat disappointing in that the Kannon image is hidden away from us mere mortals. But the charm and delight revolves round those who visit ... we too waved the strong incense smoke over ourselves hopefully to cure all our ills. It is a large complex with a lot to see and there is a lot of English signage to help you understand the history. We did not hear the monks beating the drums at 2pm as advised by numerous guidebooks. A lot of shopping & food opportunities in the streets nearby

Extremely crowded, but enjoyable.. This is a must see place if going to Tokyo. Perhaps the most famous temple in the Tokyo area. I have been here 3 times. Always crowded. But if you can get yourself up early and get there at 7 or 8 am, then you will have a much more pleasant time if you don't enjoy crowds. Also it's easier to take some photos without interruption of people passing in front of you. I find the crowds here to be part of the Tokyo experience. So they don't bother me. After viewing the temple there are many knick knack shops to look at and treats to try. This place has a good vibe and I like to go here every time I come to tokyo.
Enjoyed our visit. This was the first Temple we visited in Japan so enjoyed it. It was fun to wander through and then see all the markets and all the things available to buy.

Very Nice Temple in Tokyo, Very Crowded. I thought this temple was very beautiful and a must while in Tokyo, but I went in the late afternoon and while I was tired from the day the crowd of people only made it worse. I don't normally mind crowds, but this was a bit much. I would suggest going during low-points in the day to avoid excessive crowds. The temple itself is amazing and the surrounding pagodas, fountains, gardens, etc are great as well.

Oldest temple in Tokyo. Sensoji is the oldest temple in Tokyo and the main attraction of Asakusa. It is also the most significant temple of Tokyo. Directions, Take Tokyo Metro Line to Asakusa Station (A18/G19), Exit 1, 5mins walk. Overall, it was a great sight! We tried the Omikuji section too. Omikuji is a paper that has fortunes written on it. Nakamise shopping street is just nearby and there were so many things to shop and eat! For more food & to go places in Tokyo! http://jacqsowhat.blogspot.sg/2014/04/tokyo-japan-day-2-senso-ji-temple.html
A must see. The past linked to this temple is very interesting,this place has a completely different feel to it..

One of the main sites in Japan. Taste traditional treats, buy nick nacks and stuff to bring back home in this area. Not to be missed. This is a fair look at the place and how it feels to be there: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9MFxFw-NZjc

A top sight in Tokyo. This is the capital's oldest temple and it gives a view of bygone Japan. It was extremely busy when we visited, with lines of small children waiting to go in. It may have been a feast day of some kind as there was a procession leaving the Temple as we got there.In the temple precinct is a large and vibrant market selling tourist items. There are also many eating places around the area.

A great New Year's Eve!. We visited the Sensō-ji many times, since it's a must-see in Tokyo.But it's really *the* place to go at New Year's Eve.A huge, huge, huge number of people gathers in line in front of the temple, waiting for the opening at midnight and attend the first visit to the new year. Despite the number, the organization is excellent (you're in Japan, remember...), and if you're not interested in the queue, there are a lot of stands around the temple where you can eat, drink, and buy some souvenirs and amulets.Then, after a small countdown, the doors open at midnight and people can run towards the entrance to do a small prayer, and go back home. The whole area around the temple remains open all night long, with its itzakayas, restaurants and shops.A great way to start your year in Japan!

We loved this experience. This is a definite must-see for Tokyo, away from the modern marvels. It was fun to look into the fortune boxes outside the temple to see our fortune, and all of the markets nearby were fun as we'll.

Old japan in modern tokyo. Just about a block away from the asakusa subway station, asakusa feels like stepping into feudal japan. I loved the cherry blossom lined streets and the magnificent sensoji temple is a breathtaking sight. It is definitely worth a day on its own with many souvenir shops and even a theme park.

Beautiful temple. A Buddhist temple that is overcrowded, but learn to enjoy the architecture and the culture of praying. If you don't mind, follow what the locals do when they prey. When you enter the temple you'll see a huge incense pot with people around it. You see the heavy smoke? Try to sort of catch it and rub it onto your body, wherever you need help with, for example if you have problems with your lungs, you wave and catch the smoke and send it towards your chest. Then wash your hands with the water from the fountain with the bamboo ladle, then rinse your mouth. Then prepare some 5 yen coins that have holes in the middle(5 yen is pronounced 'go en', meaning good fortune). You can throw them into a box right in front of the praying area, then clap your head and do a simple prayer like the others. Or you can skip all these and just go sight-seeing around.You can also try out the o-mikuji, or fortune strips, if you have someone to translate the Japanese for you. It only costs 100yen.

Must see. We came here on a saturday. This is a must visit. My wife loved the small stands selling souvenier at the entrance. Towards the end before entering the temple, on the right hand side there is this dessert place with long lines. I decided to get a few things there. It was so delicious. I'm sorry I forgot the name and the desserts i bought. It seems like stuffed mochi on a deep fry batter. The temple itself is amazing. We took a lot of pictures there. On the way out, on the smaller alley to the left..we ran into this soba shop. The man inside a glass room making fresh soba caught our eyes. We then decided to stop here for lunch. I have tried many soba dishes here in LA. I gave it a 10 out of 10 rating as compared to 6 out of 10 from the best soba here in LA. The soba is just simply delicious. The soba is tasty. I wish i can find a soba this good in LA
Full of atmosphere. This place is always bustling and atmospheric. It gives a taste of a more authentic Japan for those who do not visit beyond Tokyo.
Crowded, but a must see. One of the only places in Tokyo that isn't modern and flashy. Nice to see a little history. The crowds pick up in the afternoon so go early in the day.

Crowded place but some good souvenirs. It was super crowded when we got there. Nothing much to see about the temple. Road leading to the temple sells a lot of Japan souvenirs that you may find interesting though.

Tokyo in the past. This famous temple is a must visit in asakusa. You can feel the other side of tokyo (in addition to modern tokyo). There are many people entering the temple ( i guess they perform ritual or wish for something). I appreciate the architecture of the sensoji temple and its surrounding. They have multiple layers of clock tower and pagoda. They also have a big board with something written in japanese. Just take your time walking around here and do not forget to take photo with sky tree as your background. You can see the tokyo sky tree clearly from here too. Tips: there are lots of souvenirs shop around sensoji temple. The price is cheap too compared to other attractions. Get them for your family and friends especially the ones made in japan. The souvenirs are nice!
THE BEST EVER!. Walking distance to good tour attractions and shrines. We will stay again. We will recommend to anyone.

Captivating, calming, beautiful.. I was able to experience some beautiful cultural sites, witness Japanese spirituality, try local cuisine, and go shopping. There was quite a number of people, but it was definitely nice.I will probably go there again when I make my way back to Japan for all the different foods and the easy to find souvenirs for those at home.

Fantastic. The shrines are captivating. Lots of locals also visiting to pray etc which was awesome to watch e.g. lighting incense and watching different people go through their rituals, washing your hands at the 'dragonman' fountain, putting a coin in the wishing well etc. Good to capture the essence of Buddhism. Good photo opportunities. There is an orange tree growing by one of the shrines which was just full of big and bright oranges... perhaps the healthiest orange tree I have ever seen!The main pedestrian only street leading to the main shrine has many snack and souvenir shops, but there are also cross streets with just as many things to see. One particular street had beautiful japanese lanterns ans street speakers playing some japanese string instrument which was so relaxing as you walk the street.

Nice temple. Busy with people.. Nice place for a stroll, snack & just watch people. Lots of shops sell Japanese crackers fresh here, so maybe it's the best place to get them, but be aware of the tourist trap shops. This is not the place to bargain.
Lovely. A lovely temple in the heart of the city, great place to walk and check out. Be sure to get some good photos.

Sensoji Temple. Wonderful place to visit and experience. Although it is very commercialized at the beginning with shops lining the way to the temple itself, still a nice experience. Plus one can get all the souvenirs one needs in just this one place. From candy to food, to clothes, to trinkets, to swords and just about anything else you can think of. There are shops with food to eat as well. Plus regular shops in very close proximity. The Thunder Gate entrance is amazing but very crowed due to everyone wanting a picture. Temple is very impressive and lots of people taking it in. Grounds are nice with lots to see and capture on pics. Pagoda is impressive to. Recommended.

Beautiful temple beside shopping area. The temple was very nice and picturesque, and had a solemn atmosphere to it despite being regularly visited by throngs of people. Before reaching the temple, you will pass by a long street filled with stalls selling different items, from Japanese wares to Japanese food and souvenirs. We went there on a Saturday and it was crowded, but we had a great time

Interesting mix of temples in a busy site. The temple area is reached by a street lined with stalls selling traditional Japanese wares. The area attracts many local worshippers as well as interested tourists so is a great spot for people watching. Close to the river boat stop so can be easily combined with a leisurely trip down river

Very cool!. We visited the senso-ji temple on a Sunday afternoon & it was PACKED! Never the less, quite an experience! My fiancé and I love Japanese history, and this being the oldest temple in Tokyo is worth the trip if you are too. I would suggest maybe a weekday morning to avoid the crowds. If your looking for those "traditional" Japanese trinkets for souvenirs or home decor - this is the place! The buildings & structures are breathtaking. IMO - a must see!

got "the best fortune" here. all the people get the enough power to go out after the heavy snow,so there was so crowded around asakusa area.looked around the shop sold interesting japanese stuff,and picked the best fortune in the temple.Hope me and my family all the best in this year!

Crowds of people, but very cool spot for your Tokyo trip.. I'm here on business, but had time to do some sightseeing. There's a long walkway behind the temple where you can shop for trinkets and get some snack type food. A worthwhile stop in Tokyo.

Temple in a downtown setting. This is temple is not as interesting to visit as the Meiji Jingu shrine across town. It is in a more urban setting with buildings all around. It is interesting to see all the worshipers coming to pay their respects. But overall it felt more commercial and closed in than I would like. If I had to choose between the two I would go to Meiji Jingu instead.

Great buy for souvenirs. Temples are nice and preserved. This area is also a good place to buy souvenirs and taste some light snacks. You can also tried the fortune box, I tried the fortune box where you will donate 100 yen and u can get a stick and match it with a box of fortune. Nice experience though. This is one of the crowded area I've been so far but its worth to visit specially if you are looking for something for souvenirs. It is also close to a subway so going there by train is not that hard.
Beautiful temple. Sensoji is a must see in Asakusa. I recommend that you go and see it during daytime and also at night (the lights are beautiful).

Fantastic. Sensoji temple is the oldest one in Tokyo. It is in Asakusa district, close to Asakusa metro, 20 minutes of walk from Tokyo Skytree and 10 minutes from Ueno metro station (by metro). It is also known as Asakusa Kannon Temple. Nearby the Sumida river, in a very touristic but still authnetic area, this temple remains in memories fro ever. Just go there and see it.

Go for the markets. We went on a saturday morning and found a great range if food stalls. No idea if they happen everyday but we had a great time. While the temples were great relic to look at, they aren't super interesting unless you're interested in that kinda thing

Worth a quick walk-through. I came here for New Years Eve 2001/2002. It was smokey from burning joss sticks, and lined with Japanese waiting to toss in a coin, clap twice, bow twice and pray.When my wife and I visited in winter 2013, it was even more beautiful in the daylight. This is a well-maintained, convenient attraction in the middle of bustling Tokyo. 15-20 minutes is plenty of time to marvel and snap some photos. We came here on our way to the Sky Tree.

A great place to buy souvenirs though. Sensoji although it's crowded with tourists it is a must see if you are in Tokyo. Many locals come here to do their prayers and do join the tradition such a fanning the smoke to your face or wash your hand with the water at the temple etc. I think the best part about this visit is you can get all kinds of Japanese knick knacks for cheap. There were many shops lining the path to Sensoji temple and some shops offer cheaper prices than others.

Beautiful and crowded temple. Sensoji is very beautiful, but also pretty darn crowded. Despite the crowds it is still quite atmospheric, with incense smoke wafting through the air. Don't forget to find out your fortune on the way to the temple - although you can tie your fortune there, the paper also makes a great little momento to bring home. Try to be respectful when you enter the temple itself - it was pretty zoo-like and I felt sorry for the priest and others who were trying to get on with things and are there for a different reason to us tourists overrunning the place.If you combine this with Nakamise Dori (hard not to) I'd allow about 2 hours total.

Busy, but impressive. I stayed in this area, and I really enjoyed being about to walk through this area to get to my hostel. It's very easy to find off the Asakusa line (there's another line, but I can't remember the name) and there are tons of little shops and things in the area. I highly recommend walking through both during the day, and in the evening when the shrine and shops are closed. Very different atmospheres, but both are nice.

Great tourist attraction. Awesome Japanese traditional architecture! Impressive temple, very nice place for a tourist to visit. Also there is a market with lots of interesting local stuff to browse through, so a perfect place to buy presents & souvenirs to bring home.

Beautiful at night. Unfortunately I arrived at Sensoji Temple after the majority of stalls etc had closed for the evening, but the temple still looked beautiful lit-up against the night sky. There's some very interesting shops and restaurants nearby, and of all of Tokyo Asakusa retains the best example of old-world charm and is worth visiting. The perfect site for a postcard Tokyo photo!

Nice temple surrounded by super tacky shopping. I stayed next to this temple for a week. The temple itself is a very nice bit of architecture and quite impressive to find in the middle of the city; however, if you're going to Kyoto, I would say it doesn't really compare to any of the temples/shrines you see down there.The shopping street around it sells the tackiest, trite souvenirs you can imagine (good place if you want those), and it's oppressively crowded. If you want temples with an authentic feel in Japan, go elsewhere.

Awesome Japan photographic temple in heart of Tokyo!. The temple is preceeded by a great little street full of sweets and touristy knick knacks. I quite like the atmosphere of the area, although some people may be turned off by the spoilling of tranquility. The thunder gate at the front is awesome, and you have some nice views of the Tokyo skytree closeby too. Highly recommend the visit.

Quintessential Japan. After what we had read beforehand, the Senso-ji Temple seemed like a must-do in Tokyo, and it certainly lives up to its reputation. The temple is beautiful, as are the grounds around it - it's like postcard views everywhere you turn. Having both a Buddhist temple and a Shinto shrine next to each other highlights the relationship between them - until this visit I hadn't really appreciated that they are so complementary to each other in Japanese culture.Sure there's lots of people around, but it's definitely worth visiting for every part of the experience, from the row of shops leading up to the temple, to observing the rituals and admiring the architecture of the temple and surrounding buildings. Must do!

A bit too commercial but awesome. The Asakusa Kannon Temple is a "Must" if you visit Tokyo. Its beautiful architecture (both of the main temple and minor shrines around it) is really something worth to see, like the great red lantern at the entrance.The area is quite full of restaurants so if you get hungry you'll not starve for sure.For Totoro lovers: just before the entrance, on the right, there's a shop you'll fall in love with ;)Pros: Astonishing architectureCons: too many shops

Very good experience!. It was the first temple I saw in Japan and I was extremely pleased by this experience. It was easily reachable, close to the centre, packed with tourists, but still very genuine. The temple itself is a good sight, but I really enjoyed the two rows of shops that lead to the temple, too. Actually, since it was my first day in Japan I didn't buy many souvenirs and I regretted it later on 'cause it was not too expensive and full of different items.

Good experience. Come here on weekend and you can hardly swing your arm walking with all these crowd. Walking your way to the temple you will find souvenir and pastry shop on both side, then streetfood, mostly selling the same kind of food.I was so full before I even reach the temple... There's a station there where you donate 100 yen for your fortune telling, shake a cylinder that will give you indication which fortune to read, and if you happen to get a bad fortune... Not to worry, you can always tie the bad fortune to a post so it will not follow you home.Sometimes you will spot some cute Japanese girl walkingdress up in full expensive Kimono, ask them politely to take picture with them, they will obliged, very nice.The temple itself are very well maintained.

Must see in Tokyo. This is not my first to the Temple but you feel like going back again whenever you are in town just to feel the ambience of Japanese culture in Tokyo. This time I came early morning so that the temple was not crowded. As always you can see these little shops selling Japanese handcraft and snacks. Recommended for first timers.
Excellent. An absolute must if you are visiting Tokyo! Easy to find and just walking up to it is amazing! I will recommend this to anyone visiting!

A must do in Tokyo. My husband and I went to Sensoji Temple on a holy day (and a Sunday). While it was extremely crowded, we absolutely loved the place. Our hotel was located by Shinagawa station, so we elected to take the river to get to the temple via a tour boat. It was a nice combination as we were able to see some of the city from a different vantage point. We basically followed the crowd to get to the shrine, passing through a parade as we went. It was lovely to see the costumes and people carrying statues and the like! Since we didn't have a guide, we had to rely on what we'd read. Upon entering the temple area, there is a big smoking incense pot which you are supposed to use your hands to cup the smoke and "wash" yourself with to prevent illness, harm, etc. Of course we took part in this :) Then there are the fortune sticks to do. There are several areas to put your coins in, grab a shaker, and shake out a fortune stick. (Just watch other people to get the gist of this when you get there). Your stick will have a corresponding symbol, which is printed on a draw. Open the draw and take out a piece of paper with your fortune, it is written in Japanese and English. Quite fun to do! When you've taken the appropriate picture of your fortune, tie it around the wire on the stand close by. (you'll see others doing this, so just follow along).On to the main temple, which was a mad house. We made our way inside and threw money, alongside hundreds of other folks. (this has to be big business!) We walked around the side to witness a baby being blessed, which was a nice bit of authenticity - this is an actual temple, after all.Walking back thru the maze of shops and people, we stopped to have a snack. We opted for chicken yakitori, which was pretty nasty - I don't recommend it. We had excellent food all over Japan, ACCEPT for the chicken. Chicken in Japan has a lot of fat, unlike the lean meat we are used to. The beef or pork was always a better option. If you like fatty chicken, go for it! It was an enjoyable walking afternoon, I'm glad we did it! :)

crazy mad....lots of people....worth the trip, imo. finally went here...even though i studied in tokyo in the early 1990's........got there early...but i want to go back at night...so that i can get some night time pictures......don't forget yoru camera!

If you must choose one shrine to visit, pick this one. Beautiful shrine, very busy and crowded. The street from Asakusa station are lined with stalls selling food, souvenirs, every kind of trinkets. It`s an interesting and fun visit, a must do in Tokyo.

A great visit to do with the locals. We went here with a Japanese family and they went through the customs with the smoke and fortune which we really enjoyed. To fully understand the Buddhist traditions I would recommend visiting the temple with Buddhist friends. A beautiful temple and great market right near by.

Go for experience. We went here on a weekday but there was a lot of people. The temple is nice but the parks surrounding it were nicer. Next to the temple there's a souvenir shop which sold cheap Japanese happi (coat). Good souvenir to bring home to.

A must in every visit to Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is the most popular tourist attraction in Tokyo. The temple is beautiful, elegantly decorated. And it is always very crowded, so much that it can be stressful (especially if you want to take a calmed picture). Besides, the street from the metro (Asakusa) to the temple is full of food, souvenirs and charms shops, decorated according to the season. The temple complex is really beautiful and a must when going to Tokyo. Tip: go find the huge O-Waraji, a couple of huge straw sandals (4.5 meters), a charm against evil that will protect you during your trip.

very crowded...bought porcelain cat doll. a week ago we go there... it is very cold but very very crowded so we went back to hotel in Ueno..Two days later we go there again, but the crowd it is the same so we start walking along the Nakamise Dori.. we see many souvenir and snack... we try all the snack a long the street while walking.. till we arrived to the temple, it is beautiful temple, we takes so many pictures...And at the end, we bought some porcelain cat dolls, the sales said the meaning of the doll is money and happiness
Serene, beautiful, busy.. On an ordinary day its quiet and peaceful, when the markets operate its busy, and when its the equinox in march, its full of activity and life.

The temple itself is great but the crowds are ridiculous. Viewing the temple from afar was much better than being in the temple! It was ridiculously crowded (and this is not even on the weekend). We appreciated the architecture of the building from a distance and seeing it amongst the trees is beautiful instead of being in the temple where mostly is sparse.So many tourists here that you become one of the many sardines in a tin. All the pushing is not nice.

Get all your souvenir shopping here. The entrance is to the temple is via a long street, called Nakamise Dori. There are hundreds of little shops selling ornaments, Japanese souvenirs, arts and crafts, food etc. I tried an ice cream sandwich in some Japanese mint flavour, which was fantastic. I also bought a porcelain Japanese doll, some personalized chopsticks, intricately decorated candles made of Japanese wax (which supposedly last longer than normal wax) and bamboo bookmarks, which were all well-received back home. At the end of the street is the temple itself, which is beautiful. In and around you'll find a lot of entertainment - there was a monkey acrobatic show in the temple garden - and you can easily spend an entire morning here.

Huge temple. great place to take some pictures and to offer prayers. they have a lot of shopping area as well in the compound and surrounding area there's a lot of food stalls and snacks. a major tourist attraction.

Festive & Quiant. Temple located in Asakusa area. Easy access via subway. Along the way, you will walk pass many shops selling different product especially their fame fortune cat in different design. Nice & colorful.

Beautiful, historic temple in Tokyo. Sensō-ji is an ancient Buddhist temple located in Asakusa in Tokyo, Japan. Tokyo's oldest temple, and one of its most significant - it offers beautiful architecture, design, and is one of the most famous sightseeing spots in the city. Suggest arrive very early in the AM to avoid crowds, though vendor stalls past the Kaminarimon (or Thunder gate) along the pedestrian lane (Nakamise Dori) leading to the shrine, a mixture of traditional shops and souvenir stands, will not as yet be open. Easy to access by train / metro or taxi. No fee for entrance. See pics at "www.flickr.com/photos/daviddmoore/sets/72157639023105535/".
Very we'll maintained temple. If ur nearby should go visit but not really worth to travel a long way there there are some good food nearby and a street where u can buy some souvenirs

Must see temple in Tokyo!. Yes, it's touristy and goods are overpriced, but if you avoid the main street that leads to the temple, you will find side streets, hidden restaurants, theaters, even a small amusement park! The entire grounds are beautiful and I can get lost for hours discovering the different statues, ponds, bells, gates, etc. Don't forget to walk around the neighborhood! You'll find traditional,old school Tokyo just waiting for you. No crowds, no tourist traps, just pure peace and tranquility. If you want more tourism, walk to Skype Tree from the temple grounds, and/or go for a ride in a jinrikisha.

Very interesting but very busy. Great temple, but very very popular with tourists. Be warned, the sourveniers in the markets around the temple are VERY overpriced and the same stuff sold elsewhere for much less.

Beautiful. I had visited the shrine in the wake of a beautiful morning and was lucky enough to catch the place in pure serene. The shrine in itself isn’t something that you won’t see in whole of Tokyo. The only problem is that the place gets crowded with lots of vendors that tend to be a bit heavy on their marketing strategy.

Beautiful. Extremely beautiful place, everything perfect, calm and relaxing. Great place for my 1.5 yr old toddler with large spaces to run around and relax, beautiful chrysanthemum plants for the kids to view.

Another tourist trap!. The temple and the shrine look pretty cool. The Nakamise street is filled with vendors with street food and expensive souvenirs often crowded with tourists. This was my third time going there because it was part of the bus tour. However, I probably won't go there again. Vendors pretty much sell the same thing.They sell geisha, shogun, samurai dolls, silk kimonos, etc. they also allow you to take pictures, Every time a vendor makes a sale, they clap as these dolls are quite expensive. Most tourists just want to take pictures and not buy.If you're planning on buying food or souvenirs, don't buy them at the first shop you see at the entrance. They get cheaper as they get further into the street.

Great Place to Visit in the Morning. Yes, it's true-- if you've already been temple-hopping around Japan (especially in Kyoto), then this will look pretty familiar to you and won't blow your socks off. I suggest taking another look and enjoy the temple as the locals do. Go in the morning and watch and listen- you could be treated to a beautiful sunrise hitting the top of the pagoda, the smells of incense wafting, and the softly muttered prayers of the faithful. It was one of my favorite early-morning experiences in Tokyo, and well worth the wake-up time.
A great experience !. Working temple, wonderful shopping & market around the temple. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Asakusa

A great two hours!. Enjoy the hustle and bustle of one of Tokyo's most active temples (partly because of the tourist crowd?), where all the ornaments are super-sized.Added bonus: see both Tokyo's old and new together, with the Tokyo Sky Tree in Sensoji's backdrop!Also: the complimentary rest area next to the temple offers good, free, green tea.

Just another shrine/temple, but some good shops/street food. The shrine/temple is another Shinto shrine in Japan. It's easy to get to since it is in the middle of Asakusa, but I don't recall any clear signs pointing the way to the shrine (perhaps we missed the signs), so be sure to bring a good map or use your GPS. Either way, I still think it should not be too difficult to find, especially if you can find your way to Nakamise street.We arrived on a weekday afternoon and it was still quite crowded. Like other Shinto shrines, it was mostly focused on selling charms and taking money from folks, an aspect that I dislike especially since that seemed to be its main focus. There were plenty of places to buy the charms. The shrine itself is quite beautiful. There are many beautiful architectural elements to the shrine and it was the only one in Japan where I saw actual people going into the shrines to pray. But otherwise, it's a standard shrine.The shops that lined the streets just outside the shrine were a bit more interesting, especially on the Nakamise street. Plenty of food shops with Japanese sweets and other food vendors selling their concoctions are available, along with many souvenir stores.

An OK attraction if you have been to the temples in Kyoto. The place is very crowded during holiday. Easily accessible by subway with lots of shopping around the temple. It is an interesting place but the temple itself is not spectacular compared to those in Kyoto.

Lots of Unique Shops. We were on a JTB / Sunrise Tour. We really liked all the unique shops that lined the street. One of them even could personalize chopsticks for us in minutes, which was really cool. The temple itself is very busy and popular. Remember to wave the incense towards you for good luck. There is also some interesting sites to the right of the temple. If you are a knick knak kind of person, then this is the place for you. While it may not be the cheapest souvenir area, it did have everything you needed to take home from a trip to Tokyo.

I expected more..... Well I thought it will be something really amazing, place where you can feel history, religion… place with soul…. In the end I had a feeling that I’m on a market instead of temple. Thousands of tourists, boutiques with souvenirs. I was there but never go again…

Feel so tourisy. Somehow, I'm not wow-ed by this temple. I don't know why. Maybe because Senso-ji Temple is open and free type of temple and became one of the main tourist spot in Tokyo and so crowded, so it lose its solemness ambiance. I'm not saying its not beautiful, but it just miss something.But I love the architecture of the temple, the red color, the black and gold streak. The Temple with its main gate (in front of Nakamise Street Market) and behind gate still feel majestic though.

Where Tokyo Began. This is where Tokyo began (named Edo at the time) and it was as consecrated as it was entertaining. This is still true to this day.Enter through the Kaminarimon, or Thunder Gate. On the day of our visit the giant lantern was not on display, though.The Nakamise-dori that leads to the main temple is a 200-meters stretch of street packed with souvenir shops on each side. Souvenirs sold here range from magnets to key chains, from Japanese dolls to handheld fans, from candies to senbei (baked Japanese rice crackers), and many many more! If that's not enough, there's Shin-Nakamise, a side street that cuts through Nakamise-dori, which has even more shops and restaurants!The main hall of Sensoji is glorious and, personally, I could feel tranquility in the main temple area although there were probably 500 people around me at that time. I recommend coming on a weekday morning to be able to enjoy the temple and its surroundings while it's quiet and serene.In Sensoji there are also the five storey Pagoda, Awashimado Hall, Yogodo Hall, Yakushido Hall, Bentendo, Chingodo, Nitenmon Gate and Komagatado Hall.If you want to experience a daily life in Edo, try riding one of the rickshaws usually found just outside of the temple grounds. A must visit when you're in Tokyo!

A Majestic Temple!. This temple was the very first temple I visited on my first visit to Japan, and I thought it was absolutely breath-taking, majestic, and grand -- one of my personal favorites in Japan and a must-see. Its royal red color and typical Japanese architecture makes it all the more special. You must walk through the Nakamise Shopping Street to reach it, however, which is a destination in itself!
Great very interesting. Most visited tourist site in JapanTake the free tour from the info building opposite 11am sat and sun

Great culture. Good place to learn about japan culture and belief. Its a must to visit place once u reach tokyo. Take picture at d gate. Next to the temple there is a Nakamise street where we can buy a lot of unique japan stuff.

Original Place of Edo=Tokyo. When you visit Tokyo, you should visit the place where it began, and this is it. Many years after the foundation of the temple, this place became not only the sacred spot but also the most entertaining place in the city. You would see that it still remain the same. You can enjoy shopping, dining traditional Japanese cuisine and having fun at the small and oldest amusement park "Hanayashiki". Never miss it!

Visit Sensoji only if you have extra time. I wasn't really blown away by this temple. It was massive and free, but I thought the bland surroundings and crowds really detracted from it. If you have a JR pass, you can easily get here by taking the JR train to Ueno and then transferring to the Ginza line to Asakusa. If you're on your way to Kyoto, there are definitely better temples there with prettier surroundings.

My reason (as if I need one) to return to Tokyo. I looked forward to visiting Sensoji Temple. As I walked through the souvenir stalls, the afternoon sky got dark. Wind and heavy rain followed. I didn’t see much of the oldest temple site in Tokyo after that. I’ll have to return to Tokyo, to visit the rest of the temple grounds. (I did manage to buy a few souvenirs and eat warm red bean paste filled cake before the rain. So the afternoon was not completely lost!)

Must see spot in Tokyo. When you see anything about Tokyo, Sensoji comes out. It is a very famous tourism spot in Tokyo. It is one of the biggest temple in Tokyo, it is like going to St.Peters Basilica in Rome, Notre-Dame in Paris or St.Pauls in London. You just cannot miss it!

Really nice area. Sensoji temple with pagoda next to it was really nice. I arrived when it was already dark so it was really nice lighted up. Probably best to arrive before dark to see both. Next to it there are great small streets, you can have nice walks, good food & drinks.

Beautiful & Grand. Senso-ji is a must. The striking red with gold highlights, makes the temple stand out from far away. Approaching from underneath the gates passing the many shops with treats and trinkets, one starts feels the energy of modern tokyo, but as soon as you step inside the complex, there is peace and reverence. Past all the tourists, shops, and sounds, this is a house of worship, where the faithful come practice their beliefs. Unlike other historical sites, the temple looks at though it was completed just last year, it is timeless.

Amazing!. A must see!! As you walk through the first gate - Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate) and then the shopping area called Nakamise, you will come to the second gate, the Hozomon with the giant red lantern. After the Hozomon you will see the temple's main hall, beautiful inside and take a look up at the ceiling murals. We were told that in the evening the temple is lit up and even more beautiful than in the daytime. The shopping area Nakamise, has really great little shops...worth checking out. Also, stroll down some of the side streets..it will take you back in time.

Busy on a weekend, but worth it. Even on a busy Saturday this temple is big enough to not feel too crushed, and there are great opportunities for watching the locals going about their business. The street leading up to the temple from the station however can be a scrum. There was an amazing display of customised motorbikes and sidecars there the day we visited (just what you'd expect in the grounds of a temple, right?)

Felt like I traveled back in time!. First off, how cool is the big red lantern!? I've been wanting to go here all my life after seeing countless pictures of that famous lantern. If you go to Tokyo and you don't stop at this temple, then it was like you never went to Tokyo! An absolute must-see!

Better by night!. It's true the temple is packed by day, especially when there are events on, but head back in the evening and there are much less people / tourists! It is spectacular when it is lit up at night and you get amazing photo opportunities of the guardians and buildings you couldn't during the day time.
Fun shopping street. You can try some Japanese sweets or original tempura. One of the best places to shop gifts for your friends and family members.

slipped back in time!. Sensoji is one of my favorite temple in Japan. It is in Asakusa, near Ginza or Ueno, famous cities in Tokyo. Unlike these cities, Asakusa has a different taste. It has old Japanese cultures, I mean old buildings, you may feel as if you were slipped back in old Japan. Sensoji is a temple. The temple has a huge lantern on its gate. It's really big. When you through the gate, there is a wide and strait street. There are lots of shops on both street sides. You can enjoy yuummy Japanese sweets or funny goods. If you want some great and fun souvenirs for your friends or family, I think Asakusa is the place. I strongly recommend you to visit Sensoji at night. The illumination is fantastic and the street looks more beautiful, though almost all the shops are closed when it's get dark. Yet, it is worthwhile to visit there at night, I think.Next week, I'm going to visit there with my friends again. When you visit Japan, then visit Sensoji!

great place for its architecture and to observe buddhist worshippers. If you can't make it to Kyoto this oldest temple in Tokyo will console you. beautiful architecture, lots to see and to take pictures of. I went during day time when it was quite crowded but returned at night just before they closed down to take some stunning pictures of the illuminated temple (with very few people around). don't forget to check your fortune with one of the sticks out of the silver box for 100 yen! even with "great curse" there is no reason to become desperate: tie the paper on the nearby rack and ask the gods for better fortune!

A very good example of the Edo period with interesting sightseeing all around. Asakusa is located in the eastern perimeter of the metropolis, therefore a little quieter but offering interesting shopping (especially traditional Japanese clothing, souvenirs, delicacies and cookware), theaters and amusements together with a glimpse of Tokyo’s past (dating to the Edo period 1603-1867) and significant historical buildings. The principal feature of the area is the Asakusa Kannon Temple in Senso-ji, past the main Gate. The gate features a huge paper lantern which hangs in the middle and is flanked by the typical deities which protect the Buddha. The street leading to the temple ('Nakamise', 260 metres long) is a souvenir shoppers’ paradise. The Asakusa Kannon Temple features a five storey pagoda, a familiar element in Buddhist sanctuaries and it is dedicated to “Kannon” the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy. Although an ancient site (originally built ca. 628), the present buildings date to the 1950s but have been faithfully restored to the original. The roofs feature grey tiles rather than the imperial cypress bark. A characteristic feature of the temple is the heavily decorated gilded altar and what appears like a swastika symbol right at the centre, often encountered in ancient sites throughout the world. On the approach to the temple I followed the tradition and bought an “Omikuji”; a paper fortune obtained by putting in a token donation, shuffling the bamboo sticks in a can and turning the can upside down. The stick that drops contains a number which corresponds to a box that contains a particular paper fortune. On reading the paper fortune you may decide whether it is good or bad. If not good you may tie it up to a tree and let the wind blow away the bad fortune. I have kept mine; it was OK (sic!). The whole experience is representative of a nation that embraces superstition, albeit with humor and kindness. Another temple close by (“Asakusajinja Shrine”) is less grand in scale but equally ornate in typical Buddhist architectural style.

Worth a visit. We were lost when we stumbled upon Sensoji. We were out of money and were looking for a money exchange place, (which just so happened to be opposite Sensoji). Unfortunately the giant lantern was taken away for repairs and replaced with a picture. As we walked in we saw lots of lights and stalls/shops lining the way down the path towards the temple. We spent a fair bit of time wandering through them and checking out their wares. Found some brilliant things to buy, every thing from keyrings to Kimonos.When we reached the main temple we were awestruck by it's beauty. It was a truly amazing experience, really worth going to.

A Large Touristy Temple. Visited it during the culture week, it was very crowded. Probably recommend a weekday visit. The temple itself is touristy with shops lining outside its gates. Nothing much to see around as well. Though entry is free.

A must see, while you are in Tokyo. The Sensoji Temple is at the end of the Asakusa Pedestrian Shopping street. It is a big temple in the middle of the city and includes also a small garden, many statues and different buildings. It is definitely worth it to visit. Especially, if you are anyway in Asakusa (e.g. to go to Sky Tree or the Shopping in Asakusa).PS: At night it is even more beautiful and not so crowded. Though shops are closed.

Lovely temple and old neighbourhood. We spent a wonderful afternoon at this stunning shrine and in the connecting shopping district. The small streets around the shrine are full of little shops and restaurants. Great for reasonably priced souvenirs. Good, cheap stop as the shrine is free.

Beautiful Temple. My husband and I enjoyed this temple. The architecture is beautiful, and the color of this temple is quite striking. There were lots of shops and places to eat in Asakusa. We saw some kimono robes and cute trinkets in shops. You can also get woodblock prints from the shops. It was quite neat to look at the various prints. We enjoyed walking around together and taking in the beautiful views. We enjoyed watching the koi fish swim under a bridge here too. You can see the Tokyo Skytree from this location as well.

Good introduction to Japan's many temples. Visited first day in Tokyo. It's easy or get to and across the road from the tourist info centre - which has good toilets and a good free viewing platformApproached dwn a twaditional street that as a mix of tourist tat and real apanese stuff plus plenty of food options.it s intellectually accessible and although very busy is large enough to get a good view of what is going on. If temples are not your thing then do this one and go shopping.

Free visit to the temple. This is a good stopover when you are in the Asukasa area. While going in, there are a lot of souvenir shops and food stalls. The architecture is beautiful. After touring the temple, there are a lot of restaurants nearby where you can take your lunch/ snacks. Asakusa is known for their tempura so try to grab shrimp tempura while you're at it. No entrance fee for this attraction.

The Senso-ji Buddhist Temple, Tokyo. THE SENSO-JI BUDDHIST TEMPLE, TOKYOA centre of culture as well as of worship, the Senso-ji Temple at Asakusa, Tokyo, is visited by 32 million people a year. The temple has a main hall dating back to 628 AD, while some of the gates came up in 942 AD. The newest structure – the Yogodo Hall – was built in 1998, to mark the temple’s 1,200th anniversary. The temple is located right opposite the Asakusa metro station , which also has a well-staffed tourist information office. Entrance to the temple is through the Kaminarimon Gate (Thunder Gate) , which has large wooden statues of protective Buddhist deities. It is followed by the even larger Hozomon Gate to worship Nio, who is said to destroy the enemies of Buddhism. It has a huge two-tier roof, and is the main gate to the Main Hall, which is the earliest part of the temple complex. Of particular interest is a five-storey pagoda, with the fifth storey holding a bone relic of the Buddha, presented by Sri Lanka. There are numerous other gates and halls, big and small, as well as the Denboin – the residence and office of the Head Priest of Senso-ji Temple. Along the temple paths are huge shopping arcades, with everything from eatables and clothes to music CDs. It is also an opportunity to get to know the wonderful Japanese people. Right next to the temple is the Shinto Asakusa Shrine, which is a less elaborate structure, but is also worth a visit. Another attraction nearby is the small but beautiful Edo Shitamachi Traditional Crafts Museum, featuring authentic Japanese handicrafts. (Entry free).

Beautiful at night!. Go in the evening as Asakusa Sensoji Temple is just beautiful at night with its soft lights. However do note that the souvenir shops at the popular Nakamise Street closes early. We found it the Ideal place for us to do our last minute shopping for souvenirs and bargains. There are many eateries here with several covered shopping streets selling luggage, handbags, clothes/etc. Ginza is the nearest subway line as it has an exit just next to it.Tip - The lighted up Skytree can also be viewed from here.
Great Site. The temples are very beautiful and the architecture is great. The adjoining gardens are very nice also well worth a visit if you are visiting Japan. And they are free to visit

Gorgeous at night - visit twice!. This is the place to come to experience all the sights and sounds of a temple in Tokyo! Enjoy the variety of souvenirs and tasty treats available in the shopping lane leading up to the entrance! Gawk at the people going about their worship - Pick a fortune! Dust yourself with purifying incense smoke! Secure your safe return trip with a charm for travellers! Or just enjoy watching everyone else doing the same - either way, Senso-ji is an experience not to be missed. Make sure to return at night, as the temple is AMAZING all lit up, too.

Worth a Visit. Being as one of the major attractions in Tokyo, it definitely calls for a visit. Since Tokyo Skytree tower is close by, its better to plan it accordingly.
Good views, close to Metro or JR station makes it very comfortable.
Will usually remain crowded.

Cool place. Sensoji Temple is a great place to see typical Japanese architecture and culture. Next to it is a five-storied pagoda and the walk to this temple is filled with a lot of shops.
This is a great place to go to.

Beautiful gardens. The shrine is busy on the weekends, very interesting, but the gardens that surround it are lovely and quiet. Be careful on slippery aggregate walks. I took a tumble and the camera was history! Still worth the trip.

Lovely architecture!. We spend our last day here before going to Skytree (3rd tallest building in the world!must go!). As the name suggest, it's a temple so on normal day, the temple is full with Japanese Buddha who come here to pray.We did go into the temple and took some picture inside. The architecture was nice with lovely painting almost everywhere.

Is okay. You will see many temples in Japan, and this one is okay. It is very popular with tourists and the are markets nearby that add to the vibe. I would only visit if you have 3 or more days in Tokyo. Not a must see.
Very Japanese .... Visit Sensoji Temple in the evenings where the lighting will give you a more dramatic feel. Walk around the back alleys of Asakusa to get that old traditional Japanese vibe.

night view is beautiful. it was just few minutes walk from my hostel and coming at night for a jet lagger was the best option but i got the chance to take nice photos while just few people were around .
Magic. So much there. After 6 trips to Sensoji temple, I'm still finding new things to explore. Magnificent !
Love The Temple. If you go to Japan. This is a place that you must visit. It is a historical temple for more than 100 year ago.

Wish I had more time!. Unfortunately I came across this gem on my last day in Tokyo and didn't have time to explore it in any great detail. The shops in the area sell everything you could possibly think of that represents Japan. It's a colorful whirlwind of activity and one of the more popular temples in Tokyo so arrive early to beat the crowds. It's in a really cool area of Tokyo very close to sky tree and other amazing examples of architecture you won't see anywhere else in the world.

Tokyo Panda Bus Adventure. After visiting the SkyTree Tower, we ventured into the Asakusa area to find the complimentary Panda Bus, which stopped right in front of the Sensō-ji Temple. Upon arrival, both sides of the long narrow street leading to the temple were filled with vendors selling items from tourist souvenirs to local Japanese snacks. At this very popular temple, we prayed followed by washing/cleansing our hands in the area right outside of the temple. We didn't try all the local snacks, but I would recommend buying some of the red bean paste pancake like treats that were made fresh with machines from one of the vendors along the road on the way in or out from visiting the temple.

on the way to Senseju Temples. Sometime the road to the mountain is a good part of the trip, sometime most of it. We left our hotel, 10 min north of Minamiseju metro station, and walk slowly south all the way to the Temple. And it was great to cross neighborhood helpfull peoples confirming we were on the right path.It was our first Temple complex in Japan and even with a cloudy sky we enjoyed walking around the beautiful buildings, Main Temples and Shrines with worshippers peacefully forgetting the crowd into their own world of reflexions. All together, recommanded.If you are not going to walk, get off at Asakusa Station (Asakusa line #18, red / Or Ginza line #19, gold)

Traditionally Japanese!. I read the cartoon and fell in love this the traditional temple of this country.Sensoji Temple was very famous in Japan. How could I miss it?I came to this place in the morning. Not too many people as it was not a festival or anything else.Very impressive.I rang the belt. I prayed and throw the coin.I also had some lucky charm from this place.I bought some beautiful souvenir for my family.I did have a great time here.
good. it was an interesting place, very close to the chisun inn hotel - a walking distance, and its free which makes it better

See it from different angles!. First timz that I went it was night time, it was pretty majestic!Second time was during day time, lots of people but all the shops are open till 4:30After visiting the temple, return up to all the shop and cross the street to get to the top of asakusa culture info center (8th floor) U'll have nice view of the temple / sky Tree/ flaming ornement

a must when in Tokyo. Go there early in the morning to beat the crowds. Sensoji is one of the most popular temples in Tokyo. The grounds are lovely - and certainly the main temple area is impressive, with some of the minor temples quiet and reflective even with crowds of worshipers and tourists just steps away.You can see people praying and washing their hands in traditional way.There are many dance and music performances on weekends. We saw a performance involving a monkey.Sensoji is definitely a must see attraction if you're in Tokyo.

Great Ambience. This was a great temple to visit and photograph it also had lots of different activities to enjoy and a bustling market nestled in the back area of the temple. The market had interesting food stalls and shops. Great place for families. It is crowded and busy but that is part of the fun. You can find quiet spots to sit and watch the passing traffic and people worshiping at the temple.

Lots of stuff to see here.. I enjoyed this temple very much. There is a lot of little attractions in the area, also, such as really good food and some of the best souvenirs I found in Japan, including some really nice and inexpensive kimonos. There is the old temple, and many surrounding things accompanying it. There are a lot of little ceremonies that you can do here, such as drinking from a cool fountain, cleansing yourself with incense smoke, finding out your fortune, watching the old Koi pond, looking at old statues and architecture, good photo opportunities, etc. I nice place to spend half a day.

Definitely For First Timer. This temple is historic and magical, I really like the authentic-ness of Japan in this temple. The traditional gate greeted us when we walked in, and along the way to the temple, there are a lot of shops, so it's very crowded.The temple is beautiful, dominated in red colors, and big columns of wood. I took an "omikuji", it's a fortune slip, very fun!And along the way back, I can't stop buying fried custard mochi until my coins ran out. VERY DELICIOUS, you should try.Over all, Asakusa Temple is a must for Japan first timer, you will get a lot of fun there, also you can buy souvenirs, there are a lot of good shops there.

A perfect location to get an impression of Japanese Religion. An interesting place associated with the Great Buddha and Bodhisatva Avalokiteshwara who is referred to as Kannon in Japanese from which Cannon company has derived its name!It is a big Japanese style Budhdhist temple and there is a small pagoda style temple also beside it. You can also see the skytree from here. It was very nice lit up at night, with lots of stalls selling souvenirs. It has marvellous little shops selling Japanese handicarfts, kimonos, delicacies at affordable prices.

big temple - one of those things u want/need to do to tick off your "I've been to Tokyo list". big lanterns welcomes you from the Asakusa end. then you walk past the barricade of touristy shops until you reach the main temple proper.

My little heaven of treats!. Better prepare enough time to visit this temple. If you like little shops and food, you'll spend hours in this temple. Along the way to the temple there are plenty of food stalls, make sure to try dango, deep fried manjyu and nuraeokaki! If you're looking for souvenirs, the shops price are reasonable and I think quite cheap compared to other touristy places. We visited this temple twice in 1 trip :P
