A sight to be seen, but just once!. I recently visited Senso-Ji temple on my first visit to Tokyo. Having avidly read the guide book (Senso-Ji merited a double page spread) I was keen to see what all the excitment was about. We travelled out from central Tokyo and, as described, it was a very short walk from Asakusa metro station. The area was very crowded and when we reached the Kaminarimon gate it was absolutely crammed with sightseeers. The gate itself is very impressive and we proceeded through, we were at one end of a long arcade of small shops and stalls. These shops were selling a huge variety of souvenirs, from the tacky to the more tasteful. One of the better ones was selling Ukiyo-e woodblock prints,cards etc. The merchandise on sale here was lovely and good quality but the majority we just bypassed. They were crammed with tourists, mainly from cruise ships, seeing the major sites and shopping for souvenirs. We eventually managed to reach the temple itself, a series of pagodas and temple buildings with statues of the Buddha dotted around. Although there were still hoards of people, there was a different atmosphere inside the temple grounds. This is a place of worship and all around people were posting prayers, wafting smoke from the insence burners over themselves for good health and openly praying. Although not a Buddhist myself I was appreciated the atmosphere and found myself drawn to the religious rituals. Inside the main temple building, I was rather disappointed to find that, because I was not a regular worshipper there, I was unable to go into the inner part of the temple, I had to look through a screen. Outside again, we visited the little shrine dedicated to the fishermen who had found the statue to which the temple in dedicated and which is housed inside.Of course, I did the tourist bit, touching the well worn Buddha statue for luck, I am a spiritual person and find commercialised religious sites distasteful and disrespectful. I'm still not quite sure what I feel about Senso-Ji. On one hand there was the over-commercialised shopping street which is a definite part of the temple complex and on the other the spiritual religious site which was so obviously a part of so many Buddhists' lives. I would have appreciated the chance to at least observe more of the religious life of the shrine. It was very hot and humid the day I visited so I probably didn't explore outside as much as I could have. I still have mixed feelings, It is all very bright and fresh (a lot of it was rebuilt, having been destroyed during WW11) with the gaudy, tacky shops, but inside there was definite a sense of the spiritual. It was not my favourite temple in Japan but was still well worth the visit.

A must-see in Tokyo. The temple is a mere few mins walk from Asakusa station. The huge red lantern at the entrance is hard to miss. Walk through the row of shops selling souvenirs and snacks to the main hall and you can see the pagoda. Bustling with lots of people and it's wonderful to just soak in the atmosphere.

Arguably Tokyo's premier Temple. Conveniently located just minutes from Asakusa station, your arrival at Sensoji will be heralded by Kaminarimon Gate and its magnificently large, red lantern, flanked on its right by the god of wind and its left by the god of thunder. It was intended to make a bold statement and it does.Nakamise Dori is a wonderful lead in to the temple. While filled with trinkets and souvenirs (some cheap, others no so - for example chopsticks) there is an overall carnival atmosphere, which is always a welcome change after walking the concrete canyons that make up most of Tokyo.The temple itself is as bold and magnificent as the gate that precedes it. Off to the side is the Five-storied Pagoda, which I was unable to figure out the entrance to but which does exist if you know where to knock.A large majority fail to venture off the path to wander the grounds and gardens surrounding the temple. There are numerous, small shrines and Buddha statues and even a small Japanese-style garden with a running stream and stone bridge.A tourist trap it is not: It is an active temple visited by significantly more local Japanese (who worship there) than tourists. It is a dazzling sight with its bright red paint. The effect it gives off changes with the time of day and position of the sun. I happen to prefer it when it is gleaming the last remaining rays of late afternoon.As to the experience you can expect: Visit it during the afternoon on a weekend if you want a beehive of activity and enjoy the frenetic activity and energy that is prevalent. Visit it towards the end of the afternoon on a weekday if you want a more relaxed atmosphere with significantly less people. Overall, it is a sight not to be missed on a visit to Tokyo.

So-so attraction. I grew up around temples in Thailand so this one was a let-down. The temple itself is pretty simple and looks newly painted. Nothing much to see except the gates and the Japanese architecture on the ceilings/ roof. I like the Meiji Shrine much better.There's a prayer place on the left with five pagodas that I thought looked nice but it's closed to those who are not regular worshippers. It is right next to the Askusa staion and it's pretty close to the Ueno station which has a train going to Narita so I saw a number of tourists with strollers probably making a last stop before heading home. Nakamise street (the street that leads to the temple) is worth visiting to pick up some trinkets from Japan.I visited on a Saturday in the morning and there were hoards of people.

Worth A Visit. If time allows, visit the tempura restaurant called Daikokuya. It is situated near to Sensoji temple. I personally finds it a bit pricey but the tempura is really good. In the temple, you can pay 100 yen to tell your fortune. Interesting experience for me. And also there are many locals who bent over the huge incense burner to inhale the smoke. I suppose it brings them luck.
Many stores at the entrance. The place is neat, but always crowded so I would go at night to get some great pics at the entrance. But if you'd like to check out the shops, probably in the morning.

A glimpse of history. I loved that we (unintentionally) decided to visit the shrine on a Sunday - when it was crowded. Loved the energy. Loved the shops on the street leading up to the Sensoji Temple. Something completely mesmerizing about the inside of the shrine itself with the gold leaf work over the idol stored in a box. I bought a lovely hand fan from one of the stores, and we had some snacks from the food vendors on the street. I even tried my luck at the fortune telling paper thingi... but I didn't like what I got, so I tied it on the wooden stands :) which is there for that exact purpose. A very kind gentleman came to us and explained a few things to us about the customs and traditions.

Great tourist attraction. I think I liked the shopping street (Nakamise) that leads to Senjoji Temple more than the temple itself, but it was still a great area to explore. I liked seeing the lantern and just watching people visiting the place. Definitely a good picture-taking area. Senjoji is definitely one of the better temples to visit in Tokyo.

Glad I been there. Like many others Japanese temple, there are stairs to the main hall of the temple. If you have a push chair like us, it could be a challenge sometimes. When I told my Japanese friend that I was visiting Asakusa, the first thing she asked was 'did you visit Sensoji?' It just look like a must do in Asakusa, and you have to respect the fact that it was built in the 7th century.
Historical site with shopping area. A place to visit as it is one of the famous shrine in Tokyo. There is also shops along the way, where you can find typical Japanese souvenirs to bring home.

great cultural experience. After several days of shopping in central Tokyo. This is attraction was a welcome change of pace and easy to get to using the subway. My 19 and 23 year old sons and I loved this attraction. There is no fee to enter. Small fee for candles and incense . We enjoyed the ceremonial rituals of lighting the candles, incense and prayers . Great experience of ancient Tokyo. A must see in Tokyo .

Truly The Temple of the Tourist. A fantastic temple but it is also a tourist trap. It's a great place and well worth a look but it was very busy when I was there first thing on a Sunday morning. The path up to the gates is lined with shops either side and a lot of stuff is just cheap tourist souvenirs.The small temple gardens are well kept and there are some interesting bits to look at but if you can go to a quieter temple you will get a better experience as at one point a tour guide went past with yelling out the history of the place to her tour party.
great temple. walking distance from K's Oasis, perfect for the first day with jetleg..a good way to start getting in touch with japanese culture

Beautiful Shrine - worth a visit. The Shrine is conveniently located about 5 minute walk from the station. I was initially dis-orientated with the area as it is the suburbs. However, its a nice location to see some of the old of Japan. There are many rikshaws outside if you want a ride. But note, they will not pester you, hassle you or tout in anyway. As with all Japanese custom - everyone is respectful, humble and extremely friendly. They even helped me with directions without forcing me to go on a rikshaw. As you exit the station you can see the sky tree behind you. So if you want to use the "special" monorail to get it to it, you can add this to the itinary on this day. It is attached to a mall (so if you like the shopping this could be ideal).On the approach to the Shrine, there is a huge row of "market" stalls with souvenirs of sorts. These range from carvings, food, samurai swords, kitchen collectables, clothing and of the like. Its a wonderful vibe and it was hugely crowded. But this added only to the really nice atmosphere. Customer service as always was impeccable. There was no insistence by anyone to purchase. Lots of smiles and good vibes throughout the shops here. I must admit the pricing is no less than anywhere else. But you will definitely find something interesting and/or quirky to take back home. I purchased a few kitchen magnets and keyrings.The temple itself (on this day around 11) was also very busy but people are happily and respectfully praying, making blessings, taking pictures, meditating and moving along. There are lots of opportunities to take photographs of the beautiful architecture as well as elements inside the shrine from the incense pot to the various areas of prayer. Note you are not obliged nor are you asked to to contribute any money to "make a wish" or "make a prayer" but it was interesting insight to participate in the culture and I was happy to pay my respects.I would DEFINITELY put this shrine on your list to visit as its a beautiful place and really encompasses the heart of the old within the new. Note - it will be busy during tourist periods but its not a hindrance in any case. This is a place for everyone.

Great temple experience in Tokyo, but avoid the souvenirs. An ideal site to visit if you want to get away from the hustle of Tokyo. The entrance is lined with stalls selling everything from dried package foods, warmed sake, and a host of other souvenirs. Be warned though, everything here is overpriced compared to Nara and Kyoto. Nonetheless, its an easy place to grab some mementos.There's a pleasant garden in the area, and most of the signposts are in Japanese. There arent regular tours, but you can probably get away with some info from the net over a tour which wouldnt go longer than an hour. Don't forget to go inside the temple- making a small donation grants you the opportunity to select a parchment that reads your fortune, which you can take home.Though if temples are your scene, you'd be better off heading to Kyoto (an anagram of Tokyo, go figure!).

A tourist trap at best.. If Tokyo is your only stop in Japan, this shrine in Asakusa is well worth it. However, if you have been to Kyoto or Nara, then skip this place as it’s hardly as beautiful or interesting as those on offer on those places. Also, keep in mind that this shrine is also a severe tourist trap.

Go at night when it's so peaceful. Everyone I know who visits Tokyo goes to Sensoji. This is a must place when you visit this city, sort of like the Eiffel Tower in Paris or the Statue of Liberty in New York City. It rightly is an important landmark of one of the world's great cities. Dating back centuries, the temple compound and buildings are in remarkably good shape. This is amazing when you see thousands of people converging on the area daily. The high heat of August had no apparent effect on the number of visitors when we went.I like the way everyone is respectful of the place and what it stands for in Japanese culture. There is a deep sense of reverence, especially in front of the main temple building. Of course, you are invited to partake in the traditional Sensoji experience with the lucky wood shake and standing in front of the altar waving incense smoke to you. For me, however, a better experience was just walking quietly around the compound taking snapshots of various undisturbed objects and people. The photos in front of the big, red hanging ball is a prerequisite, but there is so much more to Sensoji just a few steps beyond it. Our hotel was within walking distance from Sensoji. We were delighted to pass through it about 20.00 hrs. one evening when everything was quiet and peaceful. We could take beautiful photos and enjoyed the serenity that was a far cry from the bustling crowds at midday.Sensoji is not just an old temple by the shopping mecca of Nakamise-dori, but an integral part of Japan and an experience not to be missed.

Asakusa is perhaps Tokyo's #1 tourist destination. (Except for the Akihabara crowd.)The standard route is from the temple's Kaminarimon down the Nakamise shopping street (take your time) to the temple itself.
Free site, accessible and a must see.. The best part of this site is it is free. Gotta love Japan for that! I avoided the crowds by touring the place very early in the morning.

Interesting. An interesting place associated with the Great Buddha and Bodhisatva Avalokiteshwara who is referred to as Kannon in Japanese from which Cannon company has derived its name!It is a big Japanese style Budhdhist temple and there is a small pagoda style temple also beside it. You can also see the skytree from here.It has marvellous little shops selling Japanese handicarfts, kimonos, delicacies at affordable prices. It is worth strolling down the busy lane!
A must see in Tokyo. It's a wonderful mix of sacred and mundane, the shopping is amazing, the whole experience is quite peaceful for such a busy and frequented place.
beautiful. so great, wonderful photo ops, a real treat, we were there during cherry blossoms and the place was super crowded

Won't disappoint. You can see why sensoji brings in the big crowds! This was my first temple in Japan and I definitely get why people visit. The whole experience from the shopping street right through to the temple itself is awesome. By the time I went into the temple, bought some souvenirs and lazily strolled it easily took over an hour. But definitely worthwhile

Must for all tourist in Tokyo!. First of all, you will be surprised to see the huge lantern at the great gate. And small shops lined to the passage from the gate to the temple. You can find very Japanese souvenir there, from traditional fan to littie budda, tea cups and HAPPI ( festival coat ), even cheap kimono. But make sure if it is made in Japan and proper kimono even for Japanese people, otherwise you may get disgusting cheap Chinese fake kimono with poor quality in vivid color.There are several foods shop which you can buy and eat while you enjoy walking. My recommendation is deep fried MANJYU, dumpling which ANKO ( Azuki bean paste ) inside. There are some variety of pastes, but the plain one is the best. You can also get NINGYO-yaki, lovely shaped little sponge cake. You can choose w/wo Azuki bean paste inside.The other interest of this temple is the food wagons. There are so many kinds of food wagons everyday that you can enjoy tipical Japanese wagon food anytime. Takoyaki and starch syrup lollipop with dried apricot, BBQ Squid etc. But they are expensive. Most Japanese people has memories of their childfood... had asked parents to buy one of these but never been bought because they are expensive. But worth to try, they are still Japanese people's most fevorite special festive foods.You can see people try to pour the incense smoke over themselves. It is said that if you get the smoke onto the parts of your body you suffered, it'll be healed. Most Japanese don't seriously believe it, but still they just do it for fun and bet. The other fun is a written fortune. Shake a box filled with sticks, and get only one to see its number. They are usually written in Japanese charactor, so you shall ask someone around you which number it is and what is written on it. Kind Japanese people will help you to get the paper from the little drawer and explain what it says in their poor English, but with pleasure. Although you get bad fortune, no need to dissapoint. Simply tie it on the board, you can find nearby, then bad luck will leave from you.They have special event every month on 18th, and some festivals. Especially in July and December, they have the biggest and most popular one. July 9〜10 is HOZUKI-Ichi, many stalls to sell Chinese lantern plant ( ground cherry; a husk tomato ) . December 17〜19 is HAGOITA-Ichi, also many stalls to sell decorated battledores. New year's eve and holiday are the greatest fair in the year.I always take guests from overseas to this temple and spend a day here. Everyone says this temple is certainly the best to go in Tokyo and Japan, and its memory unforgetable. Check their website and enjoy your trip!http://www.senso-ji.jp/about/index_e.html

Gorgeous. This temple is amazing. It is definitely worth a visit. Take the time to visit the surrounding gardens. We found a quiet little garden alcove with beautiful wooden benches and stone sculptures. There was no one else around and we could just take in the surroundings from our private hideout.Take note that the main deity of the temple actually isn't on display. There are rumors that She may not even be on the property anymore.There are also fun fortune telling areas (you'll see lots of drawers). Our little one had a good time with them.The shopping is also quiet good on the nearby pedestrian streets. A lot of it is tacky but some nice shops, too. We found a beautiful paper shop at the end of the main road and off to the left.

A must see for all first timers to japan. A gorgeous temple and if you are a photo addict like me you will love the opportunity for lovely photos. The nakamasi street is just outside the temple u have to pass it to get to the temple.....worth to ahop for souvenirs and a must try is the sweets. ...try anu sweets u can get your hands on for a good price....try out the vanila and green tea ice cream...its to die for !!... and if you see ladies dressed up in kimonos do ask them if you could take pictures with them. ...they happily obliged!!

lots of shops. Of course amazing temple and don t forget while u r there to see urban luck if u had good luck take the paper with u if not hang it with other papers, u 'll found people shaking a wood box and see the number from inside that s how u get urban luck. Around this temple u 'll found all u want from souvenir, don t forget to buy a cat raising hand it bring fortune or good luck

good for souvenir-shopping. it is a very good place for first time tourists in Japan, Japanese downtown,opposite of Kyoto. there are famous traditional restaurants and cafes. also (ameyoko) is very near here,where you can see the proof that Japan is indeed in asia.

Temple plus side streets. Although Sensoji is a major tourist attraction in Tokyo, that draws the crowds, it is still one of the clear favorites in Tokyo. The Buddhist temple with the generous decoration and the continuous flow of ceremonies all year round is a must see for first timers or a visit with friends. The Main Street with all the small shops selling souvenirs is not my favorite, an approach through the side streets is more interesting, as there are real shops that sell traditional Japanese goods. There are some restaurants that are frequented by locals and you may imagine that it is like it has been hundreds of years ago.

Makes you feel you are in Japan. Lots of tourists, but an easy trip while you are in Tokyo. Part of my 'one day tour' starting at Tsukiji, then Hammamatsucho, water taxi to Asakusa, Sensoji, subway to Ginza for dinner.

traditional Japanese downtown feeling. It is fun to visit Sensoji. There are many small shops from the temple gate entrance to the main temple building. this place is filled with people, and if you have time, visit Amuse Museum near by: http://www.amusemuseum.com/english/index.htmland see BORO collection. You will be struck by the art which was created by the poor farmers of northern region of Japan many decades ago.

Exciting and historic Buddhist Temple. First do not go on a weekend or holiday as it will be overflowing with people. It is a very popular attraction for locals and visitors and on any day it will be busy. The temple is also called the Asakusa Kannon Temple. There is something about it, maybe the crowds that gives it an aura of history, excitement and intrigue. If you are in the Shinjuku area, take the JR Chou line to Kando station and change for the Ginza line to Asakusa station. The temple is across the street. Best to walk the city street and then enter the temple from the side. This is the outer gate and leads right into the temple past the shops, which you can save for when you leave. This is the oldest temple in Tokyo. It is the oldest Buddhist temple also. It is very colorful with lanterns, bells and many building to visit. There is the main building and the Asakusa shrine, five story Pagoda, and to the left of the main building the building with Buddhas. All very informative, interesting and historic. Try your fortune buy making merit and pulling your lucky numbers out of the draws. On the grounds are numerous food outlets and beverage stands. When leaving walk the long walkway, called the Nakamise dori. Here there are hundreds of shops selling everything imaginable, all very crowded but always something to buy. This will lead you out thru the outer gate and the street.

Nice Temple, but really touristic. It's the nicest temple in Tokyo, but it has so much tourists! The streets with the souvenir shops in front of the temple shows how touristic it is. Other temples in the south of Tokyo haven't been so crowded.
Best Temple in Tokyo. It was a very pretty temple, with lots of stalls selling souvenirs. Nice place to visit in Tokyo. It was very nice lit up at night.

Vibrant. It's true that this is a temple just like any other temple but there's something about this place that makes it a must visit for anyone. And not just if you have time to kill. Even the souvenir shops that line the streets leading to the temple seem to arouse my curiosity more than the usual fare.

If you have seen temples elsewhere in japan, skip it. It is super crowded during the day, and really there is nothing unique about the temple itself. It just happens to be in tokyo and everyone on their guided tours will stop by and proceed to take 300 photographs of the same thing.

a must see in one of Tokyo's best neighborhoods. The Asakusa Kannon Temple is one of Tokyo's oldest and most important Buddhist Temples. The buildings are gorgeous, the traditional shopping street is fun, and the entire area is one of Tokyo's best. Go visit!

Blend in with japanese daily life. This was for a us wonderful experience, we just wandered around looking, observing many Japanese particpating in their rituals. With so many people it was still quite. I could have spent hours just watching the the Koi fish in the ponds. I couldnt find any western toilet - and the japanese ladies had me guessing..(im still holding on.) There are markets nearby which are fun to wander as well. we wandered around the area and found some fabulous little restaurants. - no english but who cares, the food in japan is wonderful. Up the road from the temple is the tourist information, and also the river. I highly recommend catching the boat down to the imperial gardends then walking through them. The subway is at the end to find your way back to your accomodation. Japan is on my must go back to list.
Just a Must. A perfect location to get an impression of Japanese Religion. Spend enough time to watch and learn. The temple is the place, not the alley of shops.

A busy marvel. As everyone else has mentioned, this place tends to be overcrowded. Even so it's pretty cool to see. I just hope you aren't addicted to personal space because you won't have any. Between the locals trying to pay their respects and the tourists trying to snap pictures, it's something you gotta see to believe.

Real deal. I did the temple Sunday July 7, 2013. Meandered upon the temple BEFORE the crowds. Some people were worshipping, and I got neat pics. Went back later that morning and witnessed the crowds and Tokyo in a heat wave. Did not really study the history of Sensoji until after my trip. A lot was damaged/destroyed during the war (so goes much of the city). Really enjoyed the entire section and even the throng of shops, restaurants, and touristy shops has a historical significance.

Very touristy, very crowded; a must visit however. I visited Tokyo during Sakura season, so I guess the massive crowds that throng the site is pretty normal for that time of the year. The lanes leading up to the temple are lined with traditional gift shops. This is one of the most popular temples in Tokyo.I found an excellent Turkish Kebab joint in the area (I know Tokyo is full of Turkish Kebab carts, however after having tried over a dozen such joints I think this was the best). As you walk away from the temple, and out of the market area and onto the main road, you will see a line of hand-pushed rickshaw carts (see picture). On the opposite side of this road is the Turkish place. Its like a small restaurant, with a window for take-away. Best kebabs ever!Sensoji is also a 20 minute walk from the famous Kitchen street (Kappabashi Dori). So one can do both the sights in one morning.

A must see, especially if you can't get to Kyoto. This shrine has a very nice vibe. Lot's of tourists, and everyone seems happy. It is quite beautiful too. Lot's of souvenir shops and food just outside. If you have been to Kyoto, (we had just spent 4 days there, seeing the amazing temples, shrines and gardens), this temple might seem a little different and maybe less impressive. But I enjoyed it. Hope you do too. The surrounding streets are Ok to wonder around, and we had a great ramen lunch in one of the little places with a line up of locals waiting in line outside. We had to wait about 15minutes. But it was worth it.

a sight to behold at night. I was fortunate to have seen this temple during the day and the evening. The temple was a shortcut we use when walking from our hotel to the ginza line subway station. It was fun, crazy during the day since it was teeming with tourists and the souvenir shops were open. it has vibrant energy in the day from the sheer number people on its grounds. On one late night back to the hotel, we were pleasantly surprised that the temple grounds were still open with only a handful of tourists roaming around. What's more, the temple and the grounds were lighted up and the glow was just perfect for that photo memory you wish to take home with you. I would have wished to see the temple against the twilight sky but we were never back at our hotel that early.

Impressing but crowded. The temple is worth a visitbut it is crowded with tourists and visitors. The alley to the temple is full of souvenir shops and standa. Quite fun to look at all the stuff! The surrounding area is quite charming with shopping arcades, small shops and restaurants, totally different to Harajuku, Shibuya etc.

Worth going despite the crowds. This is definitely worth a visit and is easily accessible from the Asakusa subway station. There are many tourists and it gets very crowded, but the visit can be more meaningful if you read about the temple beforehand. Also, check out the old paintings on the street leading to the temple. The surrounding halls and gardens on the temple grounds are also interesting. Going earlier in the day is better. No fee.

Crowded. Tip: go early in the morning. Crowded.Beautiful temple. But when I visited it was so crowded that was hard to see many details. It's located next to a market where you can find nice items not so expensive.

Nice temple. But there are so many of them.... Very busy temple. And of all the places in Japan where we have been, this had certainly the highest percentage of Westerners. Not that there is something wrong with that. Yes, it is a beautiful, large temple, with many people milling around, sightseeing and praying. Also interesting are the surroundings. Make sure you have a Hoppy in the restaurant area right next to the temple. But even if they taste like weak beer and go down easily on a hot day, be careful, the Sochu which is the alcoholic part does pack a punch!Also interesting are some of the shops in the area. Tthe guidebooks talk about the restaurant supply shops which are interesting. What I liked even more at the, for the lack of a better term, shrine supply shops. You can buy complete shrines with figurines, votive candles and everything else you need to start your very own religion. Even life-sized figures are there, complete with a (very high) price tag). I liked the temple but I liked these peripheral little discoveries even more.

Sugoi. Definitely a tourist trap but i loved it. Lots of omiage (souvenirs), lots of temples, lots of places to eat and easy access. This site is worthy of at least a 1-2 hour visit. There is a long row of stores selling a huge variety of things. You can't avoid the shopping as there are even more on the side streets. Don't forget to buy a good luck charm or buy a good luck "wish" from the metal tins.

A must visit in Tokyo. Sensoji Temple is more of a chinese temple housing the Goddess of Mercy (Guan Yin). Many locals and tourists come to offer prayers and asking for blessings. There are more than a hundred shops near Sensoji. You can get souvenirs, snacks, traditional handicrafts from these shops. There is also a very popular tempura restaurant nearby.

Great - even on a rainy day.. The day I went to Sensoji temple it was pouring buckets, which may have kept some of the crowds away. But not many, the approach (and all of the shopping there) was brimming with tourists. The temple grounds were stunning, and the fortune/predictions that you can get before you pass the incense burners are all printed in multiple languages - don't forget to tie it up!
Wonderful. Not as good as Kyoto but fab none the less. Free of charge and lots to do in and around the area.Beware of crowds and the neat, but otherwise great

Certainly worth a visit.. Certainly worth visiting. There are also some interesting shops nearby.Can be quite crowded but its still a Tokyo 'must see' if you are in town for more than a couple of days.

Worth the visit. Worth to visit the inside of the temple, very beautiful and a contrast with the modern buildings of Tokyo.There were several people inside, some just looking, other throwing coins so it can get a bit crowded with lots of people coming in and out.The surrounding area is also worth to spend some time there, with several restaurants, shops and a small garden.

Sensoji Markets & Food. It was easy to find from Asakusa Station, there were endless markets & restaurants the temple itself was beautiful and on a sunny day provided from great photos and an atmosphere.

Beautiful & interesting!. Senoji Temple was one of the places I listed to go visit first as it was very near our hotel. I ended up going to visit there nearly everyday, to soak in the atmosphere, buy omikuji, write on the ema board and so on!- Go in the morning. Between 7-10 is probably the best as the crowd starts to pick up after that. That is, if you're there to view the buildings, the paintings and walk the tiny garden next to it. The temple shops selling the fortune telling and paintings are open early as well, so if you want to buy temple specific souvenirs while you are there, it can be done at that time too.- Don't forget to check out the ceilings - they have wonderful paintings as well.- the shopping strip in front of the temple opens around 9-10am. They have the best senbei (rice crackers) ever! There are other awesome food stuff to buy there, some being freshly made, like taiyaki (pancake like thing stuffed with red bean), dango and so on.Otherwise, unless you are pressed for time, I wouldn't suggest buying some of the touristy stuff, like the katanas and so on around there. they are a little pricey. - The next street parallel to the temple (or thereabouts) is a local wholesale area for restaurants and so on. They sell many fantastic and cheap (lots of sale stuff too) cups, teapots, bowls as well as chef knives. There are also some souvenirs if you want to purchase from there.

Buddhist temple in the midst of busy Tokyo. Japan is dotted with Buddhist temples and Shinto Shrines. Both are a must see because they give one a perspective into the culture and practices of the Japanese people. There are 2 big places to see in Tokyo, the Sensoji Temple and the Meiji Shrine. This temple is located right in busy Asakusa. The entrance is lined by souvenir shops and Japanese snack shops and sweets in a street leading to the temple called Nakamise St. Great way to try all sorts of Japanese snacks.There is the usual Buddhist temple entrance with the big lantern at the center, and 2 statues to the sides(guarding the temple). The big lantern has some writings on it. As well as the fortune telling part( one chooses one's good or bad fortune based on chance), plus the writing of one's wishes on placards. All in all very much geared to tourists, very crowded, and noisy, but a must see unless one is visiting Nara or Kyoto, then the temples and shrines in Tokyo can be skipped.
impressive temple, but very crowded. This is a very impressive temple. Great picture opportunities! However, the temple is right outside Asakusa Station and when we were there it was very crowded.

A real eye opener. When one considers that there are so many people in Tokyo, plus tourists. The Main Street was really packed. We. Never have any problem seeing over the top of people so were able to see all the stalls as we passed, all vey similar.Our guide showed us all the ceremonial things to do, from smoke washing to water washing. We tried them all and gave respect to those there and their priests. We were fortunate to share in the culture every where we went and the people we kind to us.The temple is amazing and the entry guards are big and bold! The park is lovely and we learnt how there are child Gods which are kept warm with red hats and clothes, caring for children.

Very busy... Meiji a better choice for temple visit. If you want to walk around traditional little shops and don't mind looking over shouders to see things, this the right place. But for a temple, the shops are too close to the temple and the whole place is crowded and busy. We much prefer the space and tranqulity of the Meiji than this place. There were many people at the Meiji as well. But the space and the setting still enable one to enjoy the temple and the surroundings with peace.

A mixture of history and shopping. This is obviously one of the most popular tourist sights in Tokyo, judging by the number of people there. You approach the temple via a long street lined on either side with souvenir shops. We did most of our shopping there and prices were reasonable, if you shopped around. The temple itself was awesome, very ornate and we took a lot of photos. Well worth a visit!

Busy, but worth it. The Sensoji-Ji Temple is easy to get to, beautiful, and busy. Get there the earlier the better, as it gets overwhelming, even during weekdays. Stroll up to the worshiping temple, check out the Coy ponds, and just walk down Nakamise Street, but most of the items are overpriced. From there, you can walk to the Sky Tree or the Sumida River.
Senso-Ji Temple. I liked that we were able to witness a traditional wedding on the weekend.It does get very crowded, lots of tour groups and tourist in general.

Visit early in the morning. Early in the morning is when you see ordinary people starting their day by coming to the temple and offering their prayers. The surrounding shrines and the small garden are also less crowded, and there is a sense of tranquillity. Sensoji is not an old temple like the ones in Kyoto, but it is very definitely a working temple rather than a monument, and that is what interested me most.Later in the day, it gets very crowded, and walking up Nakamise Street is a bit of a circus. There were a few interesting shops there, but most of them were too touristy. There are better shops in some of the nearby side streets. Don't let Nakamise Street put you off the temple, it is possible to get there via other streets.

Swarming with tourists but still worth a visit. If you can't make it to Kyoto, don't miss Sensoji in Tokyo. Although it often seems to be swarmed with visitors, it is a very beautiful temple with a magnificent pagoda. There's a huge outdoor shopping area if you hanker after trinkets and a fairly extensive covered arcade nearby. I'd recommend going early in the day, on a weekday to avoid the crowds.

Sensoji Temple, Asakusa. Buddhist temple located in the Asakusa district. Lots of shops and Japanese food establishments.To experience Japanese sights and food, this is the place to visit. Most of central Tokyo is cosmopolitan in appearance. This district still reflects Japanese atmosphere.

Our Tokyo Tradition. With this trip being our 2nd trip to Tokyo (first in 2008), we knew that visiting the Sensoji Temple in Asakusa was a "must" since we liked it so much the first time. Very easy to find after exiting the Asakusa station - just follow the crowds through the wonderful vendor stalls. One of the favorite stalls sells soft serve ice cream cones in unusual flavors (at least to us) for 300 yen - flavors such as black sesame, rose hip, purple sweet potato, corn, etc. Another favorite vendor here is actually a regular shop in a stand alone building that sells Japanese Wood Block prints and paper products (postcards, cards, bookmarks, etc.) at what we think is a very good value. We stocked up on greeting cards this trip - prices ranging from 150 - 300 yen - very good prices for wonderful paper compared to greeting cards here in the USA. After our journey through the vendors, approached the beautiful temple and admired the awesome pagoda. In my experience, I always find it interesting how crowded the approaches to many of the temples/shrines can be, but once your get to the actual temples/shrines, the crowds thin out and everything calms down.

Shrine & the market in the same area. There are lots of people visiting the shrine and what I like most is the market. You can get many things with cheap price in Asakusa. Not all the stuffs is from Japan, i think some of the also made in China but still worth.
Ancient Tokyo. Very nice area and lovely attraction. Abit of traditional Tokyo. Lots of shops and action around the site...get there early.

Weekdays are the best option. The Senso-ji temple (including the Kaminarimon gate) is one of Tokyo's most famous destinations, and only a few hundred metres from the Asakusa station. Definitely worth seeing, especially at the price. The Kaminarimon gate and the temples can offer very good photo opportunities, and now you can also get the Tokyo Sky Tree tower into the photos.However, it's best to visit during the week. On weekends, the tourists and locals combine to make for big crowds, especially in the shopping street between the gate and the temple, but also in the temple area itself. Do a weekday morning visit, and your visit will involve more temple and less crowding.

Nice Temple. Took the Ginza subway line for Asakusa. Stepped out of the subway and just a few steps away you will see Thunder Gate. Very prominent and will have lots of people taking photos. Step through the gate and you can walk along Nakamise Shopping Street. Just take your time to stroll through the streets with lots selling snacks and foodstuffs and souveniors. At the end of the street you will be brought to Sensoji Temple. Facing the temple on the left, there is a street. You can find a shop called Daikokuya selling tempura. Something quite different from the usual tempura. Asakusa area is famous for its tempura.After food you can walk to the Sumida River on the right of the temple (facing the temple). A good place to take photo of the Tokyo Skytree. While walking to the River you can pass through Shin-Nakamise Shopping Street. Shops selling all sort of stuffs, even a shopping centre nearby.All this in about half a day at a relaxed pace. If only just the temple, shouldn't take you more than 2 hrs.

Must visit this Temple when in Tokyo.. This is a really nice temple in Asakusa. It can be very busy though. Get your O-mikuji fortune told when you are there. They have the old-fashioned shake-the-box-pull-out-a-stick-and-grab-your-fortune-based-on-the-number-you-drew method (at this temple they do have the English version). :-)
A nice piece architecture. Fun walk from hotel, pretty temple surrounded by that beautiful vermillion color! Lots of good souvenir shopping, little restaurants and local fair close by

Great atmosphere. The atmosphere at Sensoji is amazing!! Taking a ride with the rickshaw boys are highly recommended!! its like having your own personal tour for asakusa but with lots of fun too!! Sensoji is definitely a must see attraction if you haven't been.

A MUST see sight in Tokyo. Go twice - once during the day to experience the hustle and bustle, and once at dusk, when the illuminated shrines and park are ethereally beautiful - a photographer's heaven.

Completely Worthwhile: Thunder Gate up to Sensoji Temple. Though the pedestrian walk from Thunder Gate up to Sensoji Temple is lined with tourist oriented stalls - we still loved our half day visiting Thunder Gate, the walk from there to Sensoji Temple, and the temple grounds itself.Start with Thunder Gate (the right subway exit will pop you up "right there") - which is certainly an iconic image you may already associate with Tokyo. Then take a leisurely stroll for the several blocks leading up to the temple itself.The grounds are lovely - and certainly the main temple area is impressive, with some of the minor temples quiet and reflective even with crowds of worshippers and tourists just steps away. Highly recommend including this on your visit to Tokyo.

A good example of a temple close to Tokyo. I visited this temple on my last visit to Tokyo. I have been to Tokyo several times before and had never added it to my list of things to see. This time I was convinced on the flight over by someone as a must see. I enjoyed my afternoon trip to the Sensoji Temple. I would call this a must see if I was only visiting Tokyo as it is a great example of a temple, gates, courtyard and gardens. It is easy to find and I travelled there and back again (from Ueno) and had a look around in less than 2 hours. If you have seen these type of temples before in Kyoto or Nara etc. You can safely skip this one if you are short on time or sick of being a tourist.

Beautiful Temple. The Sensoji temple is typically crowded with locals and tourists but it is beautiful and well worth the visit. The courtyard is well maintained and a walk there gets you away from the crowds. Surrounding the temple is a busy market with plenty of shopping and eating.
Superb. Visit during the daytime to see the temples full of tourists but also worshippers, return in the evening to see them illuminated. It's a MUST see destination.

Big Temple in Tokyo. Around the temple there are a lot of stalls with people selling a fair amount of tat. However, we had a great hour or so wandering around the temple complex. It's not the most amazing temple in Japan, but it's pretty good.
My father particularly liked the massive sandals hanging up on the gate.
Best temple. I love visiting this temple with its beautiful structures and fun shopping & eating areas. Its easy access to main trains and the water buses are also a big plus.

Not Your Typical Shrine. Sensoji is a major tourist destination, not one of the typically quiet shrines that are found throughout Tokyo. I's physically spectacular, with wonderful gates with huge statues, several large buildings, and a huge red paper lantern that weighs 1482 pounds. Lots of people go there particularly in the afternoon. For 100 yen you can shake a box to pick a random numbered stick and get your fortune from a corresponding numbered drawer. The streets leading up to Sensoji are lined with shops selling cakes, candies, snacks, and all sorts of souvenirs. There are also lots of nearby restaurants and beer joints. This is tourist heaven. For spiritual experience go elsewhere.

Prayed for my family's health. So many people visit this temple. I washed my hands and threw in money and clapped my hands right along many Japanese worshippers. Of course, I did souvenir shopping in the street leading up to the temple. Many people from abroad love to visit this temple.
Amazing sight seeing place. Great place to visit. It's located near the busiest areas of Tokyo and a good place to visit to get away from the stress of work.

A One Stop Culture Venue. Yes there are crowds and it can feel a bit touristy but it covers many aspects of Japanese culture in one spot. Temple ritual in its many facets, temple layout and architecture on a grand scale and a chance to do some gift shopping also. Try the local treat: red bean 'cakes' fresh from the bakers hand.

Interesting temple to visit. When you enter the temple precincts, there is a cauldron with incense burning and people crowding around to get the smoke into their hair and on their heads. Many interesting things to see, and a whole street of souvenir shops, many of which are quite tempting.A good place for people-watching.
Nice. Very interesting. Special the street with traditional souvenir shops! It is an old japanese temple. You can see people praying and washing their hands in traditional way.

Beautiful Temple and interesting surrounds. A very busy site in Tokyo but very interesting to see. Open all day so plan your visit whenever you like! The streets surrounding the temple are busy and full of a lot of local, but fairly touristy shops, but interesting nonetheless. The gardens, temple and pagoda are all worth seeing and you can easily see why the temple is popular. A fantastic way to spend half a day in the Asakusa area of Tokyo. It is also within reasonable walking distance to Tokyo SkyTree, or just jump on the subway, whichever you prefer. The walk will take you past the Asahl building and over the river, a nice walk, taking about 20 mins.

A very popular area and beautiful shrine. The Taito area is older and less 'hectic' than its Shinjuku or Shibuya counterparts. In the area surrounding the shrine, you can find rickshaw rides, tons of shops for food and souveniers, and good people watching. There is also a Travelex currency exchange in the office building across the street from the temple entrance.Once you enter through the detailed and decorated Torii gate, you are greeted with a long walkway filled with shops. As you get to the temple itself, you will see a beautiful park and five story pagoda. The temple is usually very busy, but feel free to wander around and take it all in! There are giant lanterns, a huge incense burning pot, and a huge golden buddha in the shrine. We originally were not going to visit this shrine, but passed it while walking to the Skytree. We decided to stop in and were glad we did! The area is vibrant and the shrine is beautiful.

Vibrant area of Tokyo - Worth the Visit. It is Golden Week in Tokyo so the Sensoji Temple area was very crowded -- though very much worth the trip. The Temple is stunning to see. There is so much more here than the Temple. Tons of shopping with lots of Japanese souvenirs, many restaurants, rickshaw rides ... just a great area to spend half a day at. I arrived by Metro train, then found an off-and-on bus stop so hopped on this for a tour around the city. Go to the Visitor's Center for maps and also go up to their 8th floor lookout deck for am amazing view down towards the temple and through the Kaminarimon Gate area.

Very popular. We visited the Senso-ji Temple known as the Asakusa Kannon Temple named after the Buddhist goddess. A very nice garden with a beautiful 5 story Pagoda, giant lanterns in the main hall, incense burners, cleansing fountains, and very diversified and rich variety of stores along the Nakamise-dori street.
loved the temple and the streets!. loved the temple and the adjoining streets ..... can not believe its in the heart of a modern city like tokyo!we bought a kimono there!

A Japanese famous landmark. This temple is in Asakusa district, an old town area. I love walking around that place. I got into the temple, sat down and talked to the monk. A peaceful place. Surrounding the temple, there are many good local food stores and handmade products. I bought a lot of cake for my wife from this area.

Giant Lanterns. My favorite time to visit this site is during cherry blossom seasons (mid-March to mid-April) and the winter months (less crowd).Accessibility: The site is wheelchair accessible. The majority of the path is paved in concrete and there is an elevator to the main temple (hidden on the left side of the building).Cherry Blossom: When you finish viewing the temple ground, I highly recommend you walk along the pedestrian path near the river (about 6 blocks east). From here, you can see Sky Tree, Asahi Beer building, and many sakura trees.

Gem of Asakusa: Sensoji Temple. I go back here again and again, passing through the Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate) with its giant lanterns. Follow the shopping street, Nakamise, and enjoy shopping for typical Japanese souvenirs and traditional local snacks along the way to the temple's inner gate, the Hozomon. Wander around the complex and take in the sights of Tokyo's oldest and most iconic temple. This place is always crowded. If you want a picture of your group, just ask any Japanese to take it for you. No one has ever refused me, and I get a great picture every time. If you have GPS, walk out the back way and stop for a meal on your way back to the subway station.

Best out of Kyoto. A great place to visit if you're not heading to Kyoto. The markets around Sensoji and Asakusa are really nice too. You can buy incense and other offerings in prayer too. This is Tokyo's oldest Buddhist Temple.Get off at Asakusa on the Ginza Metro line (last stop).

Very serene and large temple area. Go there early in the morning to beat the crowds. Sensoji is one of the most popular temples in Tokyo. The areas around the temple are packed with markets and restaurants.
There are so many attractions in the temple grounds. Nothing to dislike. There are many dance and music performances on weekends. We saw a performance involving a monkey.

As advertised.. The walkway to the temple was as crowded with tourists and vendors as we expected, but also had beautiful architecture and design throughout. The temple and pagoda were truly massive and impressive and make an impression on you. I rate it average overall because while it was worth stopping by while we were in the area, it only sustained our interest for about 40 minutes and didn't have a lot of depth. The streets and alleys around it are great though and there are many good finds to be had. We stumbled upon the Jakotsuyu Onsen and had a serene and replenishing experience there, for example.

Senso Ji - The heart of Asakusa. This attraction is best approach through the main alley way with a picturesque gate named thunder gate is, throngs of visitors gather under these gate daily for photo taking including Japanese themselves. It is almost packed daily spin order to escape the crowd, arrive early. But the late noon, early evening would be the best time to visit. Walk through the gate you will find 2 aisle of arcade selling mostly souvenirs and foods, and roughly another 100 meters you'll see the temple. The temple is free for admission but the pagoda on the left needs admission fee. I'll suggest you to skip this pagoda if you are heading to other cities as those in Nara and kyoto are the most beautiful.

Great Budhist Temple. Sensoji-Ji is a very famous temple in Tokyo, it is often also known as Asakusa, which is the area of Tokyo containing the temple.There is a great row of souvenir shops (Nakamise Dori) lining the main approach to the temple, including a fantastic place to buy kimonos and yukata at much lower prices than the airport. The temple itself has large gates on each of the four sides. It has an incense burner the idea is that you waft the incense over a part of your body that needs healing. There is also a spectacular centre to the temple, but we're not really sure what it was about.The traditional way to approach Asakusa was to take a river boat trip from Hama Rikyu gardens. It is not the prettiest ride in the world, but makes a change from the Metro.There is also a Shinto shrine on the west hand side and we were lucky enough to witness a traditional Japanese wedding there.

Oldest temple in Tokyo. You walk up to this shrine on a crowded pedestrian walkway with shops closing in on you from both sides. Each shop has a fake spray of cherry blossoms above your head to create the illusion of blooming cherry trees. The temple itself has a huge incense burner where devotees waft the incense toward themselves before they pray. The inner part of the shrine boasts a beautiful altar. There is an elevator on the side for handicapped access.

Best Temple in Tokyo. Lovely Temple and Pagoda very crowded but this is a working temple, amazing smell of incense. A night visit is not to be missed as it looks even more special.Nakimisa shopping street leading up to the shrine is amazing always very busy.

One of the best temples in Tokyo. Sensoji was easily one of my favourite temples in Tokyo. There is a long street full of market stalls & little shops leading up the temple that sell souvenirs & food & are great to look around. Within the temple, there is a large pagoda & central incense burner, where people are wafting the smoke over themselves to keep healthy. There is also a lovely little garden & beautiful cherry blossom trees around the grounds.
Lovely place. Very nice even though there are many tourists. It is even better if you go with a local who can guide and instruct you as to what to and not to do.

beautiful with cherry blossoms. The whole area is full of picture opportunities, from the statues in little gardens, to ladies fanning incense over their heads, to ladies in kimonos, and people snacking on local treats. The cherry blossoms frame the shrine beautifully. Lots of souvenir shops nearby.
Nice place. Cool temple, pretty darn busy though. The shops lining the approach to the temple make it rather neat as they're lined with all sorts of things.

Beautiful Temple in the heart of Tokyo. This temple is gorgeous and the impressive crowds show you the ongoing relevance of religion in the life of many Japanese. We enjoyed the many photo opportunities here, as well as the opportunity to partake in the rituals: burning incense and praying, getting fortunes of luck and tying away the bad ones. And then of course, wandering through the outlying stalls and snacking on red bean donuts and other treats.

Our favorite temple in Tokyo. This temple is really easy to get to - there is an exit from the Asakusa metro station more or less just outside the temple (Asakusa is 3 stops from Ueno mainline JR station).There is an impressive gateway at the entry to the temple area - followed by a long walkway lined with vendors selling food, souveniers, shoes, clothing and all manner of goods. There is another large gateway followed by the main area of the temple and a 5 tiered pagoda tower. The temple and grounds are large and there are a lot of locals who use it for their daily religious needs who make the experience of visiting far more interesting. Lots of charm selling and fortune telling type things going on so one does get a real local feel to the place which is great.The temple does get a lot of tourists, but at 8am or 8pm you almost get the place to yourself and the temple is very photogenic in the evening.Certainly worth a visit.

Nice temple. The Senjoji Temple is actually nice, and because we visited on the cherry blossom season, it was even better. The market leading to the temple is also interesting, with food vendors and nice snacks...But i actually reccomend walking around the side streets of the temple and the little alleys, there you will find great stuff and really yummy local restaurants!

Love this temple. Visited a number of temples in Tokyo and this is my favourite. I love searching through all the little traditional shops which lead to the temple and then the feeling of sacredness in the temple grounds. Yes, it is crowded but it also shows it's popularity for locals and tourists.

What an experience!!. Coincidentally the day we were there, the locals were celebrating the Golden Dragon Dance Festival!! After our tour, during our free time, I managed to watch the whole procession. It's interesting, exciting and very crowded!! Hahahaha!! Oh well, from what my friend said, normally during these processions, only the locals get to carry those wagons. =)

Not at the top of my list. Didn't like:Touristy and busy. Liked: The Buddhist customs that you can participate in there.Like: Cheap souveniers for kids to take home to their friendsRecommend going to Meiji Shrine instead.

Nice Temple, But Don't Go Out Of Your Way. Sensoji is a pretty standard temple, so don't go out of your way to visit it. However, if you're in the area (say, for shopping Nakamise Street), you might as well pause for a moment. At least for the people watching.

Kimono Rental At Nakamise. Does anyone know where I can rent kimono for adults & children age 9 & 11 in Nakamise near Sensoji Temple? Wanted to wear them & take pictures at Sensoji Temple. I had browse through google and found most either too expensive, too far from Sensoji or without children kimono. Please help. I going there in early June with my family.

Terrific temple, fun shopping. The Sensoji Temple in Asakusa and the surrounding area is a lot of fun and a must do on any Tokyo tourist itinerary. Lots of touristy shops (prices can vary from stall to stall so keep looking!) from the main torii gate to the temple, where you can find all of those souvenirs for your loved ones back home. Be sure to offer your 100 yen and collect your Shinto fortune - but don't forget to tie it to the nearby stands to enhance the good luck fortune you receive or ward off the bad luck if you happen to get one of those.

Nice visit to Sensoji Temple. This is located close to the Asakusa Station, so it was very convenient to get to. Overall, it was a great experience going here. On the way to the temples, you pass so many vendors selling everything from food to souvenirs, it was great. It was real busy when I went, but it was worth coming here to see all the history and culture of this area.

Fascinating area and experience. After the hussle and bustle of downtown modern city life in Tokyo, it was great to head out to Sesoji Temple and experience some of the older temples. Very buzzy with people, stalls and eateries We enjoyed a fabulous bowl of noodles and sake in a side street, small cafe. No English was spoken so it was point and select, but great fun, and lovely people/service.

Something for everyone.... This is a great attraction with something for everyone. Those who are interested in history and culture will find the buddhist temple grounds fascinating - with beautiful architecture, traditional prayer elements and it is great to watch the locals ring the prayer bells, draw prayer sticks from a wall of wooden drawers filled with prayer lots, burn incense and do the whole washing routine before offering prayers. Those who are more into shopping and food, will be able to lose themselves in the pedestrian mall leading to the temple (Nakamise street). Many stalls line both sides of the street, selling traditional Japanese items and souvenirs as well as Japanese snacks. It's such a treat weaving in and out of the different stalls. Great place to buy souvenirs as well. Surrounding the temple grounds are also restaurants and shops - good places to stop for lunch and do more shopping. Many locals go the temple dressed in their kimono best, so it's also a good place for people watching. A great all rounder. Give yourself at least a couple hours to wander around.

A great temple to see within an amazing area.. If you research temples in Tokyo, this one will always pop up and for a reason. Firstly, before you get to the temple, the areas around it are filled with shops and other interesting things to see/do. I went a little overboard on buying souvenirs for friends there, but when you see what they have and the prices, you'll understand. The temple itself is the biggest I saw on my trip. It has amazing detail and the buildings around it are just as spectacular. As always, there are the large gates and its protectors at the front. The temple itself is very tall, with amazing, detailed art on the walls and roof. People give thanks and give offerings here like any temple, but in larger numbers.Next to the temple is a wonderful little garden area with great autumn trees and good side views of the temple.If you aren't big on temples, just go to Sensoji Temple, the Asakusa area is amazing anyway and this temple will make you want to see others!

Great Buddhist temple. I was in Tokyo in March 2013 and wanted to visit a Buddhist temple there. I went to the Sensoji temple and thoroughly enjoyed the visit. The temples is easy to get to on Tokyo's vast train system. I had something that I was particularly thankful for and wanted to offer up thanks at the temple. So, what one does is to go to one of the spots at the temple. There is a rectangular box here with a small hole on top. You shake the box in such a way that a long thin piece of wood that looks like a chopstick comes out through the hole. The stick has a number written on it in Japanese kanji. There is a bank of small drawers with coresponding numbers next to the can. Find the drawer with the number that matches the number on your stick. Open the drawer and take out a piece of paper from the drawer. On the piece of paper is what you need to consider or think about. There are many tourist momentos nearby as well as plentiful food stalls. Don't miss it in Tokyo.

Nice atmosphere. Nice Sunday afternoon stroll.The area has a very relaxed atmosphere.The road to the temple is very busy and full of souvenir stalls, but it all felt very friendly.Best of all, the souvenir stall holders did not pressure you to buy anything - you could just browse at your leisure without hassle.Note for smokers: Couldn't find a smoking area there - if you're a hard core smoker you may need to research where the closest one is.If you have a JR Pass the best way to get there is to get the Rapid Chuo line (Orange) to Kanda.When you get to the station, turn left, then follow the road down the side of the station until you get to the Subway station.Pay for a subway ticket at the machine (think it's about 180 yen - just get one way).At the station, turn right, then you will see the approach to the temple.

a shrine throunging with japanese. take the metro to Asakusa, one of the older districts of central tokyo and walk the crowded avenue lined with stalls selling every sweetmeat and trinket you could imagine, and a few more besides,, through the Thunder Gate with its massive red paper lantern hanging down, to the Senso_ji shrine itself, gilded and red and ornate, Japanese paying their devotions and bowing and praying. A taste of real Japan. The area is surrounded by narrow dense alleys and streets, quite a few touristy shops, but nearly all the tourists were Japanese. A lively bustling area.
Worth visiting. Beautiful and can spend hours exploring the local area. Very busy with all the fellow tourists but lovely experience
Being renovated when I was there. The outside I did not get to see much of as they were renovating but alas the inside was quite pretty. Must visit this place.
Beautiful. Fantastic building. All the different stalls along the road is an experience.Gets very busy with tourist.

Beautiful building. Part of the Asakusa Shrine (I believe, or they are right next to one another and I could not tell the difference).Be warned that people will be throwing money into a mental container and it's super loud.

This is a place worth visiting. The temple is good, loads of souvenir shops enroute. Post the temple on the left side there are a lot of road side eateries, they are clean and present a wide variety of food- Banana in Chocolate Sauce!, Sea Food, Corn on the Cob, Hot Bakes Potato! The price is reasonable!

Beautiful!. We went many times over our time in Tokyo as we stayed just near the grounds of the Temple. See it at different times of the day, if you can. In the mornings it's so serene and at night it's like a completely different place. Fantastic!

Worth it. I like it very much The temple is impressive and beautiful, and nakamise-dori (the street which leads to the temple) is really bustling and the little shops are fun.
It is very crowded in the afternoon but I think if you go early it shouldn't be so bad.

Very crowded. A beautiful temple in it's own right and worth a visit if Tokyo is your only stop but it's extremely crowded. Don't bother if Kyoto is also on your intinerary - the temples are way more impressive there.

The bustling heart of Tokyo's East End. Sensoji Temple is the grand, gaudy heart of Tokyo's traditional Asakusa area. The gate alone is famous in itself - go past it, then past the almost endless row of stalls selling food and souvenirs, to get to the temple itself. It's less about the temple's history and architecture (impressive as they are) than about getting a taste of boistrous, old-style Tokyo street life.

So busy in the day, So peaceful at night. Many people visit Sensoji in the day because it is the "norm" / "done thing" and also because of the shopping along the way. But, it is worth making a trip back to the temple at night, after the crowd had left to experience something entirely different. The temple is beautifully lit up at night. I was there at 11.00pm. It was totally deserted and I got lots of nice shots.
One of my Favourite Temples. Every trip I make to Tokyo I come to this Temple. It gives me a feeling of "really" being in Japan. Sounds abit strange, but hopefully you will experience it for yourself

Great Place to go.. I went here today for the first time. It was beautiful. There are very many deep rooted traditions here that were joyful to watch.The shops were a great addition and make this location a place I could spend hours exploring.
Great place to visit !. Try the freshly baked Japanese rice crackers here ! The temple is simply beautiful and you can conveniently visit the New Tokyo Tower from here as well.

Magic at night.... Kaminarimon...Nakamise Dori...so many people! so many gorgeous shops! so wonderful restaurants in the small streets around there! amazing! And then? You see it! Big and "red", but golden at night. We were there and learn how to pray properly. Magic experience!

most tourist attraction in tokyo. Once we have a short vacation in japan we always spend a time to come in this beautiful attraction. temples, amusement park nearby, souvenir items and etc. Everytime we visited her there's always so many tourists..everything here and so many items you can buy for omiyage to your friends and relatives..

Best Shrine I visited in Tokyo. Absolutely the best shrine I had the chance to visit in Tokyo. Luckily we were staying near by at the Palace Japan Hotel in Taito and we revisited the shrine a number of times by bike, walking and metro (before we realised how close it is).The shrine is beautiful and very large. We took our chance to hide under the Pagodas from the hot August rain and observed local custom by covering our bodies in the smoke at the shrine (meant to heal you).Well worth a visit and of course, completely free to do!

Great Buddha Temple. walked along the Nakamise dori, this Buddha temple was not to be missed. There was a big red lantern in front of this temple. The 5 storey Pagoda made a beautiful picture of this temple, also the Tokyo Sky tree can be viewed from this temple too.

Colourful and bustling with activity. Since I was staying at the Khaosan Kabuki Tokyo hostel just 5 minutes away by foot, it was only natural to check Sensoji Temple out. It was rather fortunate that my visit coincided with the New Year holidays and when walking to the hostel with my bags, I thought half of Japan must be going there for New Year Prayers. We managed to visit at night and the temple looked quite grand with all the lights on! There was also a temple market (not sure if this is just a new year's thing) selling loads and loads of yummy food. We ate some sausage, yaki soba, and mini Hello Kitty and Doraemon shaped castuera (castella) cakes. It was interesting too, to wander around with the crowd and soak in the New Year's atmosphere since it was 1 January after all. I don't know what it is like at other points in time during the year but if you happen to be there on New Year's day, do drop in. It did seem very popular throughout our trip, as there were always hordes of people going in whenever we walked past, so yes, a must-see in Tokyo!

A number one Japan experience. If this is your first time coming to Japan, then Sensoji Temple should be your first visit. The Asakusa street leading to the temple is filled with lots of cutesy japanese souvenirs and must-try snacks. It's so yummy and cheap too! Once u get to the temple, its a unique experience seeing how japanese claps their hands twice and bow to pray, and to tie their 'fortune papers' on strings. I visited this place during New years and it was the best Japanese experience.

Beautiful. Tried everything and it enhanced the experience. The fortunes are also translated in english so that makes it a fun thing to try. The shops on the way there are really nice and have wonderful things to buy.

Huge. very beautiful and fun experience. Tried all the wells that had smoke and the water cleansing as well as the coin toss and wishing (etiquette when visiting a shrine) and tried my fortune which is thankfully written in english as well.

Must See Temple in Tokyo. Sensoji (Asakusa Kannon Temple) is located at the center of Tokyo's old "low city" (shitamachi) near the Sumida River in Taito-ku. It is one of Tokyo's famous temples and is the 2nd "must see" cultural location after Meiji Jingu for the first time traveller to Tokyo (the companious Asakusa Shirne, while less famous, allows the tourist to compare Japanese Buddhist and Shinto traditions). There is a large "shotengai" (local shopping area) on the main approach to the temple that makes the temple the best location for a "one in all" short tourist trip for the businessperson visiting Japan (you can pick up Japanese craft type gifts as well as see a major temple and shrine). A budget of 3-4 hours (half a day) is sufficient to enjoy a unique cultural experience in Japan that is much more rewarding that going to the Ginza or Akihabara. Please be respectful of the Japanese visiting the temple as the temple is in active use for spitirtual purposes by the local community and is very much venerated by all Japanese visitors.

Must see. If you are staying in Tokyo, especially in Asakusa, it would be a real shame if you didn't visit the Sensoji Temple. After you pass through the first gate you will enter into a large bazaar. Not all of the shops have the best prices, but there are a lot of cool things to see. After the bazaar you will get to the gate that leads to the temple complex. There are many shrines and monuments in the complex. It's hard to really describe the beauty of the temple itself, so you should go see it for yourself!

An atmospheric slice of Historical Japan and a must-see attraction in Tokyo. Senso-ji temple is located in Asakusa Tokyo and can easily be accessed from the Asakusa metro exit. Leading up to the Temple is a lovely arcade of Japanese vendors selling all types of traditional foods, products as well as great souvenirs. The arcade or mall is very pretty with the upper part of the stalls decorated with fake flowers and other garlands. Prior to reaching the temple you can sample hand made rice crackers of all different flavors, shapes and sizes and see them being made, red bean paste waffles, sake served in an almond milk like hot liquid- (perfect on a cold winters day), chestnut ball skewers etc etc. Whilst very touristy, it is very pretty and atmospheric. Make sure you take time to peer down the back alleys as we were lucky enough to see two women in traditional dress standing outstanding a traditional restaurant- a perfect photo opportunity! The temple itself is very impressive with its huge imposing gates and enormous red lanterns. There is also a lovely pagoda and gardens and statues to wander around and admire. Take the time to walk down through the temple garden and head out to the left and you will stumble across other lovely roads lined with traditional shops- this really feels like a walk back in time- a very different and historical part of Tokyo that should not be missed. There are also strappingly fit rickshaw drivers who will cart you around the area for a price! In my view, this temple is one of the highlights of Tokyo and you could easily spend several hours here including having lunch at one of the many restaurants in the alleyways. We ate a great soba noodle place for about $10-$12.

The main attration of Asakusa. The place is where the famous big lanterns are. You can't missed it. There are a lot of tourists going to the place. Just follow the crowd. Although we don't speak Japanese, we were able to manage on our own in touring the many attractions of Tokyo. The key is preparation and the tool is the internet.

Not just a temple, an entire complex!. The oldest temple in the city, Sensoji is one of the highlights of visiting Tokyo. But it is probably more accurate to refer to this as the Sensoji complex as there is more to see and do here than just visit the main temple (which is pretty impressive on its own). If you enter from the south side you get to walk through the massive Thunder gate and then you walk along the very clean but busy shops of Nakamise that sell both high end collectibles and low end souvenirs. There are also numerous food shops along the way, but they prohibit walking and eating here so if you buy a snack, they will tell you that you have eat it there before continuing on your way. Sensoji temple is massive, stunning and the huge number of rice barrels on either side indicate the temple’s wealth. When you are done, make sure you exit to the right and cross the walk way to a smaller temple with very colorful designs. Then continue north towards the very clean public restrooms. Across from them in the landscaping are several stone statues, including one of Ultraman! Yes, Japanese pop culture is honored along with the traditional culture at Sensoji. Head back south from the rest rooms and take a quick left so that you are heading east to the Hikan Inari Shrine where you will see the fox gods that protect crops. Its small but unique. When you are done, head back west so that Sensoji temple is on your left. Go past it and then make a left so that you are working your way back south. This way you will see the Zenizuka Jizoson and some other smaller shrines. When you get back to the main pedestrian through fare, turn left and you will see the Nakamise shops up ahead. As you approach Nakamise, on your left will be the Chingodo Shrine, dedicated to the Japanese raccoon god Tanuki. Definitely worth 15 minutes. Cross Nakamise and keep heading east. You will see a handful of life size samurai statues on the buildings and a big Tanuki on your left. In a few blocks the pedestrian mall ends at a traffic street. If you make a right, you will be heading back to the Askausa metro stop.

A great place to visit/stay.... I stayed in this area and visited/shopped/ ate and used the nearby station to connect with the rest of the city. The temple and surrounding area was packed full of int'l and local tourists and is a must see if visiting Tokyo

A land mark in Tokyo. If you visit Tokyo, you MUST go there. Shopping booths are the best place to buy your gifts for friends and loved ones. Check your luck at the temple and if you are 'Un lucky' you still have the chance to wrap the 'bad luck' paper of the 'bad luck' stand, and your Luck might get better! i don't believe in that, but it is fun to do it :)

Great Temple in the Heart of a Big City. If you are looking for traditional Japan, this area and the temple will provide that for you. Tokyo is your typical big city, but Sensoji Temple and the surrounding Asakusa area will provide the ambiance many travelers are seeking when they are in Japan.
Nice temple in Tokyo. Very nice temple in Tokyo, lot of people in day time but in the night time it's better because not much people and good weather!

Giant temple. This place was rebuilt over the remains of the old temple. It's surrounded by little stores, some of which are have been there for donkey's years. I went at night and it was packed. Great little restaurants and street food vendors. I would check prices on things before I bought anything to take home though.

Impressive visually, but not old. This complex of buildings is authentic: a real, live temple and shrine. Built in the Edo style, they do not, however, date from that period. They were built less than a hundred years ago. If, therefore, you are interested in observing a live, religious site, then this is for you. If you are interested in photographing traditional-style religious buildings, then this is for you. If you do not mind having your approach to the site polluted by some 300 metres of stalls selling tourist tat and food, then this is definitely for you. The stalls are divided about 50:50 between the usual rubbish (dolls, sandals, toys, memorabilia) and food, mainly sweet-meats, mostly deep-fried. A few monks ply their trade in the area, so do NOT accept the proffered bit of gold coloured plastic and do not engage in conversation unless you wish to donate.
