The site is well placed some 10 minutes stroll from the river and the district (Taito-ku) is vibrant. A pleasant outing if you have plenty of time in Tokyo, but NOT a priority.

Rickshaw Tour. A great must-see for Tokyo, but for the first timer you really should try the Rickshaw tour. We had a great guide named "Yoshi". He is fluent in English (lived in Cali) and has a wealth of knowledge...as well as insane cardio!

Great experience and must see for first visit to Tokyo. The path leading to shrine has lot of souvenir and sweet shops to get a taste of Japan culture in Tokyo . Although Kyoto is the place to be and i will be visiting. Kaminarimon Gate, lantern form a grand entrance.It takes about an hour to see the temple complex which has asakusa shrine statues of LORD BUDDHA.

Spiritual and Souvenir Center of Tokyo. A Buddhist temple dedicated to the bodhisattva of mercy, Kannon, Sensoji is a tourist hot spot as well as a popular destination for pilgrims seeking good fortune, from success in exams to medical recovery (you kind find the latter covering themselves with incense smoke closer to the main temple). A lane crowded with souvenir and food shops called "Nakamise-dori" leads from the Kaminari-mon (Thunder Gate with its imposing demon guard statues) to the main temple, and one can find almost any gift here. Oddly enough, Nakamise-dori is also traditionally known for cheap but quality "no brand" shoes, though the sizes may be too small for many Western travelers.

Beautiful temple but beware of tourist trap. This temple is definitely worth visiting, but even in November it was exceptionally busy. Do not expect some quiet reflection - the temple itself and the surrounding area is a highly commercial tourist trap. Good to visit - quickly. Take you pictures and then leave - there are other better places in Tokyo to enjoy.

Old Temple full with history. The outlook of the temple is easily to be recognise with a big lantern in front of the temple, while entering the temple, there is a street selling lots of souvenir and typical local foods along the way to the temple. Do go there as early as you can, as it will become crowded when it come to noon.

A must see for a first timer to Tokyo. We very much enjoyed our visit to the whole temple complex. Arriving at the front entrance, the huge Kaminarimon Gate, with it's over sized stone temple guardians and immense red lantern is sure to impress. The Nakamise shopping arcade, which extends to the inner temple gate is sure to be packed with both Japanese and international visitors. It's a little like running a gauntlet of shoppers intent on picking up their 'must have' souvenirs, whether it's a porcelain 'happy cat', a brightly coloured yukata or fan, or a set of finely laquered chopsticks. It seemed very crowded to us, but our guide said that this was actually a reasonably low crowd day!Inside the main temple complex is a lovely 5 story pagoda that can be seen for quite some distance, several small shrines, and the main building, the Senso-ji Temple. We were told that it is the oldest and largest of the Buddhist temples in Tokyo, and the site of many festivals each year. Off to the right of the temple (looking from the inner gate) is the smaller but very lovely Asakusa Shinto Shrine, sitting behind a concrete torii gate. This temple complex is much more than a tourist attraction. It is visited daily by large numbers of the devout who come to pray. Unless you've become jaded by too many visits to temples and shrines already during your visit to Japan, you owe it to yourselves to see this impressive site.
not just another temple. probably the nicest temple to visit in the city if you are staying just a couple of days, huge place (to be able to have so many visitors

number one temple in tokyo. if you want to see a icon of japan temple, i think it must be sensoji temple.it might not the oldest but sensoji is well packed for tourism.reachable from public transport.you walk through nakamise dori , a street which sell many japanese souvenir.there are a lot of restaurant.you must spend half day in here.

OLDEST SHINTO SHRINE IN JAPAN. Asakusa is the old historical district of Tokyo which is why is has Sensoji Temple, the oldest Shinto Shrine in Japan as its centerpiece and it is a restful space in the middle of all of the hustle and bustle of Asakusa. The five story pagoda can be seen from all over the area -- I even had a view of it from my room in nearby Ryokan Shigetsu (a fabulous traditional Japanese Inn. It is behind the large market on Nakamise Avenue and you can enter by the beautiful Kaminarimon Gate. I bought a print of the pagoda at the market and it is now framed in my house so I can still see it every day. The whole area is very safe -- I wandered it on my own or with a couple of friends after dark and never felt uncomfortable. This was one of the keynote sights from my tour that was put together by Samurai Tours out of Colorado and their guides were very knowledgeable and spoke wonderful English.

MY VISIT TO SENSO JI TEMPLE TOKYO. The temple is very colourful and is a very big tourist attraction.When we visited on a Mid september morning,it was full of international tourists It is located in ASAKUSA and literally a stones throw away from asakusa metro station in GINZA subway line.The main gate called THUNDER GATE OR KAMINARIMON IN Japanese is really very impressive which incidentally has become the symbol of Tokyo.The road leading to the equally colourful second gate is dotted with about 100 nsmall shops selling Japanese artikrafts,sweets and worshiping items which, it seems, has has not changed with time this was typically similar to roads in front of all big temples in INDIA also. It is the oldest , biggest and the most important temple in Japan.Before going to Jpan, whichever tourist attraction site Iconsulted, Sensoji temple was one of most important attraction in TOKYO.I travelled as a backpacker with my wife and stayed in an apartment in UENO wherefrom Sensoji temple was only two stations away .So we kept it on the first day of our Tokyo tour along with TOKYO SKYTREE which is also nquite nearby the temple complex is quite big The temple consists of a big hall nand a five storeyed pagoda.It takes about nan hour to see the temple complex which also has asakusa shrine and many beautiffull statues of LORD BUDDHA The temple is open 365 days from sunrise to sunset and entry is free.

Great place to people watch, take in some culture, and get your Tourist on.. I didn't have a lot of time in Tokyo and was glad I chose to go here. One - because I saw a nice cultural heritage site, but also because it proved to be an efficient way to do some shopping for kids etc. A little chaotic working your way from the Metro stop to the temple, but I loved seeing more locals and the hustle and bustle of the area.

A cultural, atmospheric and bustling experience. This delightful Buddhist temple complex within the heart of concrete-and-glass Tokyo is a real must on your To Do list. I have been to a good number of temples in many parts of the world, and so I arrived at this place with some pre-conceived ideas about what I would see. The temples and courtyards themselves were as I would have expected, but what I really got out of this place was the crowds, the atmosphere, and the smells coming from the incense and food stalls that line the complex. This is a real temple where real people come to worship, and that's what I liked best about the place.

Nice and Tranquil. It's a little bit far from the center of the city, but every mile is worth the visit.The outside of the temple has lots of good stuff to buy and to eat, and the inside is just pure beautiful. My personal favorite is to wander around in the alleys surrounding the temple.

One of the highlights of Tokyo. The Sensoji Temple is one of the must visit places in Tokyo, and easily the first temple you should visit.The temple and the accompanying gardens are always a hive of activity. This isn't so much the silent and reserved complex you'd expect from a Buddhist temple but rather an alive and thriving place for common reflection. The nearby Asakusa markets are also worth a visit.

If you have time just to see one temple in Tokyo, this is it!. This temple is located in the Asakusa district of Tokyo. You will pass by a variety of souvenir shops in Nakamise-dori before you reach the main entrance of the temple. The temple is said to be one of the oldest in Tokyo and is considered a landmark so if you have time just to see one temple in Tokyo, this is it!

A beautiful part of Tokyo. We are so glad we took the time to journey to the Asakusa section of Tokyo, visiting this beautiful temple and the Asakusa Shrine. The old-style local shops sell mainly souvenirs but it was a really pleasant place to visit.
Askusa temple. temples, Hystory, culture, people, crowd, shoping, proximity to downtown, accesibility, food, shoping

Beautiful for a relaxing afternoon. Beautiful Temple. There was a sunflower exhibition/competition when I visited, they were hand cultivated by people all over Japan, so its pretty spectacular.There is also a long line of street shops just outside by the entrance of the Temple, be sure to try out their famous 'pineapple bread' that has been in business there for 80 years. 1 weird thing encountered is that the shop owner will stop you from buying food from them and walking off to eat, they will insist that you eat outside their shop front, wonder why.

Crazy In a Good Way. We went on a day there was a festival, though I don't remember the name. There was a parade and many many people. It was a bit crazy but also so much fun at the same time. It was a great atmosphere. We had fun grabbing some stall food as well as some souvenirs for our family back home. We were very tempted to buy some kimono but decided not yet. Very fun but also very crowded. I would probably be worried about trying to maneuver the crowd with children of an age that they might wander off.

A not to miss spot in Tokyo. Not only skyscrapers, Japan is also an old and traditional country. Go to Asakusa and discover it. The temple is at the end of a long street with plenty of souvenir shops on the sides.Do not miss also the side covered streets with plenty of shops. Food? Try Osenbei, the fried rice crackers, also very popular as a gift. "Sarada no aji" (salad taste) is my favourite. respect the people praying at the temple.

Beautiful-crowded. The temple itself is beautiful and iconic symbol of Tokyo. The street and area was very crowded, as clearly most people visit here. Did some good shopping in the streets outside of the temple, great place to pick up souveniers for people back home.

Packed with people on a perfect day!!!. Decided to take the subway from Shinjuku to Asakusa to see this famous temple and do a little souvenir shopping. Once we left the station the site was just down the street. "HOLY COW" It was like a neighborhood block party. Many shops selling everything under the sun and pilgrims coming to offer prayers. It contained an eclectic mix of nationalities and was wonderful to see. The temple itself was absolutely beautiful with its intricate carvings and statues as well as the structure. Off in the distance you can see the Tokyo Skytree which provided such a contract from the old and the new. Serene????? Forget about it!!! It is definitely a must see. Many food options around the temple in fact we ate Greek Gyro Sandwiches while we were there, so the options are endless.

A Place to be when you are in Tokyo!. This well-known Big Red Lamp of Sensoji Temple is famous and was photographed all the time.It locates in Asakusa Area, if you come by Subway, You will need to make a stop at Asakusa Station and you will see the sign in subway station, telling you which direction / exist you should take to come to the temple.If you are happen to be in Tokyo, you should visit this temple. The shopping street in front of the temple is crowded with lots of Japanese and Tourist who come to visit the temple. Lots of Small Shops selling Food, Drinks, Souvenir along the way.You will notice that many people gather at the Huge Incense Pot in front of the Temple as it's believed that the smoke of incense will help the unhealthy person become strong and healthy again.

Beautiful and well maintained but .......... Still an awesome place to visit, the be spellbound by the giant lantern on the Onari Mon Gate and the fun shopping arcade. However, some of the temple facilities like the wooden railings are replaced by steel which lose its old charms and authenticity. Overall it is still worth a visit.

Must-see when in Tokyo!!. Loved it! Very close to Asakusa station. The street that leads to the temple is called Nakamise. It's full of stalls and little shop where you can buy souvenirs, gifts, food. It's really crowded but you should expect that looking at it's rank on tripadvisor!:) Beautiful buildings and surroundings.

Definite must see in Tokyo. It will be probably be very busy whenever you go but for me it is a definite must see in Tokyo. The architecture of the temples themselves is beautiful and you can lose a couple of hours looking at some of the market stalls and looking down the winding alley ways that surround the shrine.
Worth a visit to Asakusa. Be prepared for crowds and lots of markets (which surround the temple), but it is still worth a visit. Just don't expect it to be very serene!

good afternoon out in Tokyo. Loved this temple complex. Beautiful buildings and great photograph opportunities and easy to access from the Asakusa station. The surrounding area has a wonderful selection of stalls and shops for tourists and Japanese alike in a series of covered and uncovered arcades. Good place to buy little gifts to take home. I've included photographs rather than repeat previous reviews.On the day we went there were a group of school children from Fuji asking questions in English as part of a school project. They were delightful and gave us a card of Mt Fuji to thank us for spending time with them.We stopped in one of the malls and tried octupus dumplings. Some older local women watched us eat and giggled. We liked being part of their day's entertainment!However, we were very aware of the pressing crowds in some of the malls and of the potential for pickpockets.

Gorgeous temple with a great atmosphere. Not my favorite temple in Japan but if you're just in Tokyo you can't beat the convenience. The shopping street leading up to the main building is fun, with lots of souvenirs and snacks to buy, and the fact that you can get some great views of the new Sky Tree from the area is pretty cool too. Beautiful architecture and I love the pagoda!

Sensational Sensoji Temple and Area. Here is the low-down: visit this temple not just for the temple itself, but the entire surrounding area. If you are looking for spiritual pondering, history, fortune telling, architecture, souvenirs, handmade items, and cheap restaurants this is the place for you.
nice temple. Nice small temple, the fortune cards are fun and have English translations. There is heaps of good restaurants/cheap eats around the area, worth visiting for them alone.

Despite being very popular, still worth it. This is a fairly touristy site I would say. But it was worth putting up with it to see. The sights were amazing with the new Sky Tree in the background.Just watch out for the tour guides on the streets, they really try to sell you on a tour, but a few did help us find things, probably hoping we would buy their tour.

Thousands there worshipping - plus there's shopping. Senso-ji is a huge temple with the photogenic Kantarimon ?) Gate. You walk up a street of souvenir shops to the temple itself. Watch the devotees buy prayers and so on. Waft some holy incense smoke in your hair, then walk up the stairs with everyone else to the altar where they pray. I prayed, too, for a very sick friend. I'm sure the Shinto god didn't mind an outsider.

Great temple, too many people. Just like other reviewers, the art is great but I could not seem to find the peacefulness that makes a temple, a temple. There are too many tour groups and people coming from all over and the stuffs that were being sold along the lane are overpriced tourist goods. You can purchase all that at a greatly cheaper price somewhere else. Despite the flaws, the art and the temple itself stunned me with its charm. A truly must see, but don't mind the people and don't buy from the shops.

The Oldest Temple. This temple was built in 628 and is the oldest temple in Japan and is very much alive with daily prayer and worship. The Grand Kaminarimon Gate with a large lantern is really awsome to see.

Loved everything about it !. We really enjoyed visiting this temple. To get here you have to walk through a street lined with market stalls. Some people may not like this or find it too busy or intrusive, however for me this just added to the atmosphere of getting of the temple. Once in the main complex, despite it being busy, there is a feeling of calm and tranquility around. There are obviously many people who have come here for religious reasons and to watch people wafting the incense smoke over them, or washing their hands and faces is fascinating. There are numerous different buildings in the complex. Many people, we noticed, just headed to the main temple and then left, which was a shame as there is so much more to see. The Denbo-in garden was lovely to walk around as was the Niten-mon gate, so make sure you take some time to explore all the area!(n.b. if travelling from Asakusa station, first follow the exit signs to kaminarimon gate, then they change to senso-ji temple nearer the exit) once out of the station turn right at the top of the stairs, then left at the top of the road. The entrance to the market and then the temple is about 50m on the right).

Beautiful temple and a good experience. It's a great temple to visit, if you don't mind walking through a crowded lane (~1 km) filled with touristy shops selling almost anything. The temple in itself is very nice, and the huge bells with Japanese font on it looks cool. You can pay 50JPY to light a candle and 100JPY allows you to pick a numbered stick that tells you your fortune. Surrounding are is very commercial and has tall buildings around, which kind of disrupts the view of the temple in photos. Please make sure you do visit other temples and not just this one.

A Truly Zen Experience. Spent 30mins at Sensoji Temple in Asakusa on the way to Narita airport from Tokyo. Very glad that I made the effort although I had my Japanese host drive me. Wonderful & colourful lane way leading to the temple with shops selling trinkets, food, japanese dolls, fans, rice crackers and just about every souvenir. Loved how I had to follow the etiquette on washing my hands before inhaling the incense to purify myself before walking up the step to the temple. Was not very crowded on a Fri early afternoon. I did have my fortune read, using a box with sticks, and numbers corresponding to little pigeon holes with the fortune in Japanese. The temple is dedicated to Kuan Yin, who I connect with. If I had more time I would have spent some time inside to meditate. Well worth a visit..

Boring and touristy - don't waste your time. We changed our return flight home so we had an extra half day to spend in Tokyo. We used the time to visit Sensoji and regret it. It was raining on and off when we visited but still somewhat crowded inside the temple. Having grown up in Asia we have visited many temples - this one was underwhelming. We walked around the area for about an hour. The designated shopping streets are very commercial, with cheap touristy stuff for sale. I don't understand why this place gets such a high rating on tripadvisor.By comparison, we enjoyed our visit to Meiji Jingu a great deal. We were impressed by the simple elegance of the temple and shrine as well as the people watching. Perhaps if we had ventured out further to Kappabashi-dori we may have enjoyed the shopping there. As far as Sensoji and the immediately adjacent sites go, there was nothing memorable.

Breathtaking. This temple is definitely worth a visit and the most beautiful temple we visited in Tokyo. The temple is spectacular and just a short walk from the nearest train station. It is surrounded by small shops and restaurants.

ABSOLUTELY IMPRSSIVE!. After spending my first full day visiting Mt. Fuji and Lake Ashi, I had one day to see and experience AS MUCH of Tokyo as possible. So, I went on a whirlwind tour that included this MUST-SEE attraction...WOW! This shrine is MASSIVE! There have been some SERIOUS renovations to the various temples and buildings, which I felt detracted from the experience; but I'm still glad I visited. Aside from just seeing the shrine, the whole area has shops and restaurants to make for a GREAT trip. I would have loved to have spent more time than I did exploring the area, but the little bit of time that I did have to see the shrine was WELL SPENT!

Very nice, very touristy.. Conveniently close to the subway and surrounded by small shops and restaurants is always very very crowded.If you have time just for one temple, fine, come here. Otherwise Tokyo is full of other beautiful places were you can stop for a sec and really enjoy what you see without beeng pushed away from the next in line. Also Kamakura is just 1 hour away. There you can see different kind of temples and various styles of buildings and gardens.My advice is to go if you will also visit other temples.

Awesome time awesome people. Beyond the fact that it was blisteringly hot outside, it is gorgeous area. All the shops and the people make it awesome. The temple was amazing with its gold all over the place. Multiple temples and shrines around the area make it spectacular. Wife got tons of pictures with the old of the temple and the new of the sky tree in the near distance. We got interviewed by school kids and an endless conversation with an elderly gentlemen. Awesome place to visit, second time I have visited. Well worth the trip.

Great temple. Beautiful and large temple. Many traditional shops and things to see nearby. There is also a good and large selection of restaurants near the temple, Most of them with very reasonable prices.

If you can only visit one temple.... Every time I go, it's always crowded. But I suppose that is what gives this place atmosphere. It's a beautiful temple as are the grounds they reside on. I've been during spring and enjoyed their gardens in full bloom. A lot of little shops and restaurants around the area, as well as souvenir shopping. Probably one of my favorite temples I've been to in Japan thus far. Absolutely beautiful. If you could only visit one temple, I'd high recommend this place.
Must visit!. This temple is interesting. Full of souvenirs, local food and crowded of ppl everyday! If you lucky enough, you will able to see some sort of performance.

Senso-ji Shrine, Asakusa, Tokyo.. Wow. I absoloutly fell in love with this country. My first stop on my tour of Japan was Tokyo. Whilst here I was fortunate enough to visit the Senso-ji Shrine at Asakusa. It is Tokyos' oldest shrine and has so much histroy behind it. Leading up to the shrine there is the Nakamise-dori shopping street where you can buy tradtional Japanese items to take home with you. If you are interested in the traditional side of this country I would say it is a must if you are visiting Tokyo but do not have the time to visit Kyoto.

Old and New Tokyo. Senso-Jim Temple has existed in this location since 628. Destroyed and rebuilt multiple times through the centuries by earthquake, fire, and war, it is the oldest temple in Tokyo.You approach the grounds through numerous shopping booths, selling traditional items as well as tourist trinkets. It is crowded, yet if you look carefully you can find pockets of peacefulness in the small gardens.Worth a visit in Tokyo.

Must see tourist attraction of Tokyo. Has lots and lots of shops selling local trinkets and nick-nacks, neatly organized. Plus ofcourse there is the shrine itself that is excellent Japanese architecture to take photos or just to hang out. Local delicacies are also sold there and nearby you can find western chains too. Walking distance from the new Tokyo TV tower.

Old and new. Beautiful gardens, ornate temples, pagodas, waterfalls. Shops selling Japanese items line the streets. Oldest temple in Tokyo, surrounded by modern buildings, and within sight of the Tokyo Sky Tree. A must see when in Tokyo.

Definitely Visit This Temple. Sensoji Temple offers several types of experiences. As you arrive, there are rows upon rows of shopping booths. The temple itself is gorgeous and awe-inspiring, and it's humbling to watch visitors as they worship. The large incense burner is popular with visitors, too. Put this on your itinerary while you're in Tokyo.

Great Heritage. A trip to Tokyo can not be completed without a visit to one of its many shrines.The Asakusa Shrine has a lot of great history and you tend to run into different ancient shrine ground in the surrounding area as well. So even if you go outside to walk around the shrines, you are very likely to run into a part of the shrine that is outside the main grounds.We were there during the Sakura season and made for some great festivities. So many people around the area with great food selections. We gave and offering and said a prayer. We even got our fortunes. This is a great way to experience the Japanese culture first hand.

Must visit when in Tokyo. Sensoji Temple and the surrounding area in Asakusa are a great experience. It has a sort of theme-park feel to it, but that didn't lessen the experience. Around the temple there are all sorts of shops making sweets and selling trinkets. Also, keep your eye out for Tanuki statues in the open and (pseudo) hidden!

Great Place To See.. This temple has a special place in my heart. Not only is it beautiful and the first temple I visited it is also where I was told to go find my fortune and make a wish. That was in 2005 and my wish was to find my soulmate. I was very specific in what I was looking for and even though it took a little over two years, that soulmate did walk into my life just as I wished. I can't say for sure that the wish made here was responsible for our meeting but I often wonder. Married nearly three years now I am looking forward to visiting again and this time making a wish together. I also really enjoyed the kindness of the locals and the shops and the food surrounding the temple. Lots of fun and lots to see I highly recommend a visit here.

A fun experience. The shops leading up to the temple were all part of the experience. We wafted in the incense and got some great pictures at the temple. The tempura/noodle meal in this area is a must do, it was wonderful!

Must visit. A hive of activity, the Akasuka Temple is a must visit. Around the temple, there were statues and beautiful flowers. Outside the temple, there was a long street with many small stalls selling food stuffs and souvenirs. We were particularly fascinated to watch the baking of the Japanese biscuits and cakes. Nearby we had Japanese bento lunch which was absolutely delicious.

Colorful Culutural Highlight. This temple is unique to Tokyo and Japan. Definatly worth a visit. We had limited time in the city and this was the area we spent our day in. The grounds are quite large, with the main temple, surrounded by smaller temples and various buddhas scattered around. There is also a garden attached. The whole complex butts right up to a colorful Japanese market where you can shop for just about anything you like. Overall, a tastful cultural experience and a nice place to visit while in Tokyo.

Beautiful Temple and surrounding area. My husband and I visited this temple during a weekday. It was not too busy compared to other sites and I highly recommend taking the time to visit this beautiful temple and surrounding attractions which include beautiful shops and food stalls.The gardens and grounds are lovely and would be attractive at any time of the year although we were fortunate to be there during cherry blossom season. We met a lovely man who was kind enough to point us in the direction of 'kitchen area' which is a huge street of shops selling everything in homeware. My husband is the cook of our family and was delighted to purchase Japanese knives and other utensils not readily available in Australia.

Colourful and impressive, but crowded. Being the oldest temple in town, this place is a hit among tourists. However, the crowd makes it looks rather "commercialised". I love the old architecture and the attractions within it and the very interesting Nakamise street beside it which offer lots of local food stuffs and souveniors to choose from.

One of Tokyo's Most Popular Temples. This is a very nice temple to visit, but very crowded. There were people everywhere, alot of them school children. The walkway up to the shrine is lined with food and souvenir shops. It is a great way to try some of the street food. This is Tokyo's most popular temple. If you are going to see any temples in Tokyo I would include this one.
Great temple complex with lots of touristy shops. Beautiful temple gardens, good for people watching and souvenir buying.

My Favorite part of Tokyo. Until I got to Asakusa, Tokyo had just felt like a huge city to me, in the vein of New York or Philadelphia, but this district was truly unique and comfortable and helped me to discover the essence of Tokyo. There is a fantastic shopping district leading up to a massive gate and temple/shrine complex. Well worth visiting, a fun place and a sample of Japanese culture in the midst of a huge and somewhat uninviting city.

A not to be missed... Asakusa Sensoji Temple is a landmark in Tokyo. Having a picture of you with the Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate) marks your footsteps in the land of Japan; so you really don’t want to miss this. In the temple, you may draw an Omikuji, a prediction which tells your fortune either good or bad. The Japanese likes it a lot. Here you’ll find also Nakamise, a shopping street of over 200 meters leading to the temple. This is the best place to get souvenirs as there is no where else in Japan you can find as many choices at competitive prices.Something good for your consideration If visiting the Asakusa Sensoji temple is part of your itinerary:You can follow a route that I plan out for my day tour in Tokyo, It works perfectly to cover a few main must-sees around town. Start of the day with Tsukiji Fish Market, have sushi for breakfast then walk over to Dentsu Obsevatory at Shiodome, take a stroll at Hama Rikyu Teien and catch a river cruise to reach Asakusa Sensoji temple.

main temple assakusa. tranquillity-well it wouldve been but was golden weekend a holiday which falls over 2 weekends none the less very interesting and approach to temple has alot of interesting small shops - gardens really lovely round the back of the temple and big incense burner before you go up the steps to view the shrine -worth going there at night as well perfectly safe even if alnoe
Brilliant photo opportunities. Such a beautiful temple and makes for great pics, but it's packed in like sardines during the day.

Beautiful and traditional place. If you do not mind crowded place and you search for a nice temple go visit Sensoji in Asakusa. It offers beautiful complex of buildings in the traditional Japanese architecture, plus there are many shops and restaurants nearby.

Simply inspiring, great tourist place to hit!. The visit to Asakusa really made my stay in Japan. It was so vibrant and happy and full of culture. We walked down the walkway lined with little shops to buy food and souvenirs, was definately part of the experience. We saw the big entrance gates, the temple, the tower. It was all beautiful and grand in its own way. If you are visiting Japan to see ladnmarks, this is a must! Also, if you walk outsdie of that main strip there are tons of stores and delicious restaurants, we hit an awesome little ramen place.

A walk of joy. A must-go for Tokyo sightseers, Sensoji Temple is invariably packed with enjoyment and activities no matter when you paid it a visit. Conveniently located next to Asakusa metro station, the Buddhist shrine welcomes guests with an iconic great red lantern before myriad souvenir shops and sweetie stores excite your inward steps. Once passing through a Sakura line, you will find yourselves streamlining into the main holy hall or tower wherein statues of Bodhisattva and Buddha are either placed in small wooden sanctuaries or spotted in decent bonsai gardens of Zen style. Surprisingly, from such breathtaking gardens, you are able to enjoy an amazing landscape of Tokyo downtown while Tokyo Sky Tree can be easily viewed and photographed. Additionally, you may wish to “foresee” your luck at a sortilege post for a 100 yen English explanatory note. As sakura blooms for now, a walk to the temple seems to boast a more impressive and unforgettable experience.
Good representation of a temple. well kept ,clean , people come there to worship , not only a touristic site

Fabulous (but touristy). I was lucky enough to visit while the cherry blossoms were blooming, it was so beautiful. I visited several times at different times of day (since my hotel was nearby), it's nicest in the early evening, when the buildings are lit up and there aren't too many other people around; but do also visit during the day when the main building is open - it has great paintings on the ceiling.The streets surrounding the temple are full of tourist shops and food stalls, the main shopping area is between the metro station and the temple's south gate, but the better shops are through one of the other gates (west I think, but I have a terrible sense of direction) - look for the one where the shop keeper works on his wood-block printing right in front of you (and sells the prints for just 500yen!).

A great walk which allowed the kids some running freedom!. A lovely walk through the grounds, very interesting look into Japanese history and if your lucky the great & good of Tokyo might be having their wedding there as it is a apparently an expensive option & the place to be seen. Also if you have kids its a great place to let them run off some energy.
My favourite temple in Tokyo. The temple is magnificient! and the grounds are THE BEST place to buy your souvieniers!!

The temple fortune teller machine is accurate. visited the temple with friends and really enjoyed the area. the monkey show at the side is entertaining. the food and the stall is a good intro to a tourist to japan. I explore the side of the temple and found very interesting kimono shops and the fabric shops. bought 4 pcs which cost me a small fortune but couldnt resist the silk materials!! The temple has a wishing jug that spill out bamboo numbers after you shake it while saying your prayer or wishes, after you collect your small paper, read your result and tie to the rack in the temple. I won't go into details but a few of us had a go at it and predictions were very accurate, either coincidence or not , but good luck and bad luck could be part of the result.do expect to spend 2-3 hours easily at the area,

Asakuha Senso-ji Temple. Visit Tokyo's oldest temple, the Senso-ji with it's two gates, the outer Kaminarimon gate and the inner Hozomon gate. Shop for traditional Japanese souvenir items and snacks at the Nakamise shopping street to bring back home

Too many tourists but well worth the stop. Too many tourists but well worth the stop. Beautiful shrine that was destroyed by fire in WWII but rebuilt in 1978. Tons of Japanese sweets are being made in front of your eyes on your walk up to the shrine. So, stop for a snack and a cool look at a beautiful temple.

Good starting place for visiting the area. The Temple was the first place I started 5 days of sightseeing in Tokyo. Despite the rain, I enjoyed the temple which has some unique features compared to temples I have visited across Asia.
The shopping stalls in the area in front of the temple have a good mix of souvenirs and snacks.

A Wonderful experience.. The Sensoji Temple in Asakusa, Tokyo, Japan is really something. I thought the main attraction was the street leading to the temple - Nakamise Street with all it's little shops and stalls. You can shop till you drop. Little souvenirs are best found here. All in the one street. Reasonably priced too. Don't forget to try the large rice crackers (freshly made) and dipped in soy sauce, the little food stalls and even wasabi flavoured ice-cream.Good idea to do most of your money transactions in cash. I would not try using a credit card here. It is a must-see place in Tokyo. Easy to get to by Japan Rail as well. Enjoy the experience.

A bustling energetic environment, before coming into - the temple.. I was with my mom , and being Asians, we thought we would have 'seen it all' with temples. But this is interesting temple to visit. Sure, the street leading to it is smack full 'tourists catered' but it still offers us visitors a glimpse of interesting Japanese ware, food and beverages. Coming into the temple compound, one can sense an aura of genuine respect accorded to it. We took our time to stroll through the temple compound, with it's handful of interest arras, before stepping into the main complex. Nice . Now be sure to keep your eyes peels for lovely and genial Japanese young ladies in kimonos . They are such a lovely sight. ... :)

A fulfilling do-it-yourself temple experience. I visited Sensoji Temple through a Hatobus tour on a Saturday. The temple and its pagodas were beautiful and vibrant in red color, smells of incense, sounds, and activity. Although most people milling about were tourists, there were some locals who had come to pray. We tried our luck at the fortune telling boxes (where you deposit a donation of 100 yen to have your fortune told). Budget enough time - about 1 hour - for visiting the street full of souveniers and unique Japanese paraphernalia, which is directly adjacent to the temple.

Best Experience in Japan!. Visiting this temple was one of the most amazing experiences I've had in my life thus far. The hustle and bustle of all the people, the incredible buildings, and the whole feel of the area is nearly overwhelming. The buildings are beautifully constructed, and seeing the inside of the temple was a very moving experience for me. I would highly recommend this temple to anyone visiting Tokyo! Put it at the top of your list! Make sure you walk down Nakamise Street!

Colourful, old and beautiful. Going to Sensoji is a great experience - the streets leading up to the temple are FULL of souvenir shops ... making it all the more difficult to focus and reach the temple!The temple itself is grand - big, beautiful and crowded!! :) Go with prenty of time at hand, visit the entire complex and definitely see the cherry (and plum) blossoms if you are there in the right season.

What a Great temple attraction~!!!. The temple was great~! There is many food stalls, souvenir shops around, taste good, reasonable prices~!You can spend a days explore the area around the temple and you might find something interests~!

The pagoda is beautifully lit up at night. I went here a couple of times during my holiday in 2011/12, New Years Eve and New Years Day. New Years Eve was just a huge party, dozens and dozens of market stalls to buy your niffy little gifts, plus as many food stalls as the eye can see. New Years Day was a more subtle affair, with huge lines of people lining up to pray at the alter.The surrounding grounds and temples are colorful, and beautifully constructed, when you see the 5 story Pagoda lit up at night for the first time your draw will drop, it is magnificent. Well sculptured gardens, ponds with huge Koi as well. A sight most definitely worth seeing if your in Tokyo.Unlike the majority of the temples in Tokyo, there is no admission charge to enter.

Approach via Nakamise shopping street for an interesting contrast. Also known as Asakusa Temple, this is a large Buddhist temple in Tokyo dedicated to the bodhisattva, Kannon. Approaching from the Thunder Gate is a good way to visit because you will first walk down the Nakamise shopping street. Here you will find all manner of souvenirs and assorted kitsch as well as some food vendors. It's a flurry of consumerism and a very interesting place to observe people as it is quite a popular destination for both locals and tourists. I had a minor feast on some of the street food, which was quite good. I even got takoyaki, which is more of an Osaka-type treat than a Tokyo-type thing.And then, once at the temple, the tone is a bit more dignified. Visitors may "bathe" in holy smoke to purify or cure their ailments. And then they may pray to Kannon, who is associated with kindness. I'm told Kannon understands what is in your heart so there is no need to worry if you do not speak the language.This was a positive experience and the contrast between the holy place and the street leading up to it was quite interesting to observe. I'll say I did not feel quite as "purified" as I did when I visited Meiji Jingu Shrine. But that's probably because the setting at Sensoji Temple is much more urban. But it was a very neat place to visit and I recommend going there.
Colourful and Unique. Got the underground train there (asy to use) and spent a good fews hours exploring, taking pictures and soaking in the mix of busy market and quiet shrine - well worth a visit.
Nice traditional tokyo. Shopping for souvenirs is excellent here and good value.

Bustling area with lots of interesting souvenir and food stalls. The temple with the big Red Lantern is well worth a visit. It is the oldest temple in Tokyo. The area itself is bustling with souvenir stalls and food stalls. As Westeners we were fascinated by the food stalls, which appeared to be cooking baby octopus kebabs. Getting there was an experience. We took the JR railway to Ueno station. When we got to the station we were directed to the Metro Ginza line, platform 2 which you can access directly from Ueno station. We got off the underground at Asakura from memory stop 19? When you come out of the underground station turn left and walk a few hundred meters and you are there.

Beautiful, but maybe a little over-rated. Sensoji Temple and the Asakusa area is a definite must-see for any tourist in Tokyo. Part of the reason why is because its actually so touristy. When you come out of the station, they've built a marketplace that sells all the tourist goods you could want. It was also the first and only place in Japan that I had people soliciting me for donations and rickshaw rides. Even in Kyoto, people would wait for me to approach them. Just walk past and know that this is one of the only places in Japan like this.Down this market-street you can see Sensoji waiting for you. The huge red-lanterns that are icons of this temple are wonderful and the Pagoda is beautiful. The park is definitely worth a walk through as well.I would say Senso-ji isn't as expansive or impressive as some of the Kyoto temples (or even as impressive as nearby Shinsho-ji in Narita), but its the best one we found in Tokyo and the marketplace is an attraction in itself.

Temple after sunsets. The Sensoji Temple in Asakusa is a very interesting place. Lots to see and eat and shop. Last year, I was there in the afternoon. This year I went in the early evening till after the sun sets. The feel of the place was changed dramatically. The lighted temple looks even more beautiful. I highly recommends that you should come see it before the sunsets and stay till it illuminates the whole place. This place offers a lot of street food and they are all so delicious. It's almost like a night market - I mean Nakamise street (just before the temple grounds & after the big red lantern entrance. )

Landmark for Asakusa- the big red lantern & it's admission free. never missed a pic in front of tis landmark, the temple often hav regular edo style performance during the wkend so do lookout for it, walk along the street to the temples for souvenirs as well

Impressive building with many devotees. The area surrounding the temple is bustling and filled with shops. The temple was crowded with tourists and worshippers alike. There is a smaller shrine next to it, and further along, the Bell of Time and NIsonbutsu, two large Buddha statues. There is also the imposing pagoda. Even in the busy atmosphere, people were able to call upon their inner calm when praying.

Our first Japanese temple. The entrance to this temple is through the Kaminarimon gate which is impressive in colour and size. Once through the gates you will be amazed by the number of shops selling all things from prints done by the Toyko Museum to the usual tourist junk. The store keepers aren't out to get you to buy things like most other countries. After walking past all the shops you come to the temple directly infront of you which isn't to bad. To the left of the temple is the 5 storied pergoda which is very impressive

amazing street food.. i actually went in august of '09 with my best friend. Senso-ji Temple was only about a 20 minute walk from our hotel and we went just about every other day. There is a street full of shops and vendors between the first gate, Kaminarimon, and the temple itself. Many of the shops are filled with kitsch souvenirs, but still many of the shops are full of awesome little treasures and it's hard not to get caught up in the bustle and period setting. The temple itself is absolutely beautiful and serene, despite the chaos of the crowd located in the shops. And the FOOD. The food found throughout is absolutely amazing, I don't believe there was anything I tried that I didn't love, the fried manju being the best! I don't know the name of the vendor but it was on the left hand side towards the temple and they have 4 flavors: plain, green tea, sesame & plum, for a mere ¥80 a piece! I dream about those manju lol. I can't wait to go back!

Nice day trip combined with Tsujiki Market. This is a good stop in the afternoon after visiting Tsujiki Market in the morning. It is however, very crowded. There are alot of small souvenir shops and food stalls. Temple itself is not particularly spectacular when compared to temples in Kyoto. We paid $3000 yen for a 15 minute ride in the man carriage.
I am glad I took the time to visit. I am glad I took the time to visit the place. I was on a business trip and the short break and culture infusion was very welcome. It is very relaxing and pleasant

Interesting and cultural. This was an interesting Temple to visit and easy to get to from the subway line. We walked down the pedestrian street lined with peddlers which was interesting but also touristy. Be sure to hold your bags or purses in front of you and zippedand to carry your wallet in your front pocket (for men) to protect against pick-pocketing.

Great place and many other things to offer nearby. A visit to this temple makes a great program for 2-4 hours. The temple is in the middle of the city, beautiful and its small garden well-maintained. The place is clearly very popular and revered by the Japanese. Even on a late Monday afternoon very crowded. The street towards the temple is packed with small souvenir and snack stalls, quite touristy but not too much. The best thing though, after your visit to the temple, is to wander the side streets, especially on the west side and in the smaller streets. Many small and informal shops and street bars and restaurants. Also some very trendy shops. Likely that you finally run into something that is worth buying.

My favourite temple in Tokyo. We took the boat up the Sumida river to Asakusa after a visit to the Tsukiji fish market. The Sensoji temple is one of the more popular and beautiful temples in Tokyo. If you have time to visit only one temple - this is the one to see. It is a very picturesque buddhist temple, Comprising of the Kaminarimon (Thunder gate), main gate Hōzōmon and Kannondō (Kannon Hall). Between Kaminarimon and Hōzōmon is Nakamise dori shopping arcade. There is a beautiful Pagoda, Gojūnoto. I took lots of photos. I recommend that you spend some time visiting this temple and the Asakusa area.

Great temple and area to visit.. Sensoji is a buddist temple in the heart of Asakusa which is also a really nice are to explore.There are various buildings to explore in the grounds and also a long, busy street of shops that sells food and souveniers. Definitely recommended as something to see for a more traditional side of Tokyo.

Place where you can go back to the good old days of Japan. Asakusa is one of the few places in Tokyo where atmosphere of Japan in early as 50's remains. This is quite rare in Tokyo, as most part of the city is now replanished and old streets are mostly gone. And Sensoji Temple is the most famous symbol of Asakusa. Good place to visit all year long but especailly in the new years day, Sensoji Temple and Asakusa reveals it's true fascination. In NewYears day, Asakusa becomes filled with people who makes their first visit to Temple. Many stalls are out along the main street leading to Sensoji Temple and brings out the energy like the summer festivals of Japan. One of the place I continuously visit.

Best place for tacky souvenirs in Tokyo. The huge gates of this temple are well worth seeing, but if you are visiting temples in Kyoto as part of the typical "golden triangle" tour of Japan then this one won't blow you away. If you are looking for a dumbfounding selection of souvenirs though then the road leading to the temple is the place to be.

If you only have time to visit one shrine, visit this one. A beautiful shrine complex near the Ueno park. Perfect place to fins souvenirs as on the way in/out the avenue is walled with tiny kiosks. You cannot go in the main shrine unless for religious practice but you can see everything from the outside. If you go in the evening (around 6pm), you can see and hear the bells and even get to ring them (for a donation). Try the cooked corn for a snack.

Cool...for a temple in Tokyo. After visiting the Tsukiji Market in the morning, I headed over to the Sensoji Temple in Asakusa. It was still pretty early in the morning so things were quiet around the temple and there were not that many people around. Since it was late November I was there right at the tail end of fall and around the temple the leaves were a beautiful bright yellow, which added to the calm morning atmosphere. The temple itself is nothing all that special, but it was the nicest one that I visited in Tokyo. I stayed in Asakusa, so it was convenient for me to visit this temple and the area around the temple is a really great area of Tokyo…the type of place that you can just walk around for long periods of time and keep seeing interesting things.

Go in May for a Whole New Experience. I've gone to Asakusa 3 years in a row during the 3rd week in May. During this time, there is one of the biggest (if not the biggest) festivals in Tokyo. All of the streets are jammed with people. Not just tourists, but temple staff, locals, and even some Japanese mafia. Its worth seeing because you are emmersed in Japanese culture, and you can experience Japanese festival food. Its crazy and hectic and so much fun. If you're closterphobic, stay away. Its a definite must do in Tokyo!

My Favourite place in all of Tokyo!!. I always stay in Asakusa when I visit Japan. This small town is by far my favourite location in all of Tokyo!This is in part due to the Sensoji temple. Morning, afternoon and evening. Whatever time you visit you are guarnteed to have a whole new experience when you visit.In the morning all the shops on the Nakamise shopping street (Leading up to the shrine at the end of the street) are opening for business. You will see school kids out in force in their sailor uniforms, buying crackers and red bean paste sweets (I recommend the green tea ones!). You can also spot men and women in their suits stopping to pay their respects, bowing, ringing the bell, clapping their hands, throwing in contributions and then rushing off to the subway.This is easily the best place to shop for souvenirs. If you take a turn at any of the side streets that lead of the main street you are greeted with even more shops all small, packed together, with numerous restaurants in between. I always end up back tracking, as its easy to get lost in among all the twists and turns. One of my favourite kaiten sushi restaurants is off one of the streets to the right.I would also recommend visiting at night when it is less busy and the lanterns leading up to the shrine are all lit up. My favourite time to visit and take numerous pictures!A must see!

Nakamise shopping area. The Kaminarimon (Thunder Gate) and Shinto shrines are nice, but one of the most interesting things I found was the Nakamise shopping street with various traditional Japanese souvenirs and local snacks, Although some of the shop ladies can be a little overly pushy at times..there were many interesting souvenirs that couldn't be found at other places

Must see !. A must see for tourists heading to Tokyo. Although there are temples aplenty there, this is one of the more famous ones. The place looks serene even when loaded with tourists. A long stretch of shops on both sides of the walkway leads up to the temple. Loads of souvenirs and food to buy / feast on. Found a shop selling a bowl of ramen for only JPY 200. Delicious and cheap.

A Tourist Trap Worth Taking In. To be honest, I did not know much about the Senso-ji Temple prior to visiting it and my Japanese host and friend felt the temple and the surrounding shopping/eating area would be worth the trip. Once you are in the neighborhood, it is easy to find - just follow the tourists with their city maps, Japanese-English dictionary and cameras to probably the most famous temples in the whole of Japan. It is not far from the Asakusa metro stop. Between the outer and inner gates is a strip of shops and eatery stands that, from what my host said, has been around for centuries. The main temple opens up before you along with a very tall pagoda and the ensence burning pot where worshippers bring the smoke to their face. It was an interesting looking practice and since I'm a firm believer in the old axiom - "When in Rome..." - I gave it go myself, hoping I was not offending anyone. The temple itself is so gaudy, it is impressive. As much as I could with the throngs around me, I tried to lose myself in this old place and groove on what Buddhists get from it. The shops that line the way between the outer and inner gate are typical tourist shops - traditional Japanese snacks, fans with various Japanese symbols on it and local restaurants. I can't remember the name of the small hole in the wall on the back alley way that sold sushi and noodles. I normally chastise the "typical" tourist traps but this is one tourist traps that should be visited while in Tokyo.

fun evening, great Indian food. After a tiring day of touring Tokyo (starting early with Tsukiji) we took the Toei Asakusa line to Asakusa station. The Sensoji temple was easy to find and the tourist information center located nearby was very helpful. The shopping area around the temple provided a lot of diversion. We found a great Indian/Bangladeshi restaurant named Shagorika. The restaurant has great naan bread and chicken curry. The restaurant is at 1-12-10 Asakusa Taito-ku. Pictures of the dishes can be found at [---]. We eat a lot of Indian food and this place is great. My family of four ate a great meal for just under $40 and left absolutely stuffed.

Worth seeing several times.. Since my inn was just a 10 minute walk from the Sensoji Temple, it was my favorite place to start the day, or rest after a day of sight seeing. If possible, see the temple in the early morning. An amazingly peaceful place in the morning mist as the sun rises. No stalls full of venders, no loud crowds. Just the statues, the running water, the clink of coins as the occasional dark-suited businessman on a bicycle stops by to pray on his way to work. After an hour or so about 50 or 60 school children will come though on a field trip, all in their matching uniforms. Since there are so many schools in Tokyo, apparently you can expect a group about every day. Not that it is a bad thing. Personally I prefer their cuteness and excitement over the packed crowds during the afternoons and evenings. Oh ok, indulge the tourist in you and see all the stalls full of T-shirts, key chains, and folding fans. One midday walkthrough was enough for me. Night is another great time to visit, after the venders have closed shop. You will have it almost all to yourself again. Except if you happen across a model photo shoot like I did. The only time the crowds are enjoyable is during the huge Sanja Matsuri; a festival held every May. It is a must see if you are in Tokyo at that time. All of Asakusa is alive with chanting and drums as golden shrines are marched though the streets.

Embrace the Tourist in You!. i typically don't like touristy places, but here is one i enjoyed (though i guess it helps that i was there with great company). yes, it is a temple in a public market. the temple is interesting, though i found the market to be especially fun because of all the snacks and little trinkets along the way. shown in the pics are some delicious treats we bought made fresh on the street. i guess if you're in a foreign place, you'll know to adventurous, so def do so! your tummy will thank you. as for trinkets, i got this neat astroboy keychain which if you pull back he zooms forward. when you make it to the temple, you'll find ppl wafting incense and smoke over themselves. good luck or something. hey, when in tokyo. anyways, i spent about half of a day here before making my way to the imperial palace by train. not sure i'd recommend doing that since i ended up walking quite a bit that day, but i was with someone who wouldnt let me not try to cram in as much of tokyo as possible! :)
Absolutely fabolous. The best temple I had everseen. It was surrounded by public market which is ver cool.
